DOC.HEAD: Visiting Moscow Police Officer Helps Fool Drug Suspect
DOC.TEXT: A visiting Moscow police official helped with a local drug bust by tricking the suspects into opening their hotel door so officers outside could make the arrest, police said Wednesday. Moscow Police Col. V.T. Bobryashov and his Deland police interpreter ``posed as Russians attempting to gain access to the wrong room,'' said DeLand Sgt. Steve Dovi. Bobryashov spoke Russian while jiggling the suspects' doorknob and the DeLand Hilton room occupants called hotel security, who came up to the room, police said. The occupants then opened the door to see what was going on, and Bobryashov pushed the door open further to allow police officers in. Officers said they asked the visiting dignitary to help them bluff their way into the room because that would be safer than identifying themselves and risking attack. Police said they seized crack cocaine and other suspected drugs during the bust late Monday. They arrested Vikki Hankins Henry, 21, and a 17-year-old juvenile. Bobryashov was the top-ranked of 13 visiting Soviet police officers.

DOC.HEAD: ``Twin Peaks'' Season Finale a Convoluted Cliffhanger
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with plot of season's final episode. Pick up 11th graf pvs, `Other characters...
DOC.TEXT: ``Twin Peaks,'' the surreal ABC series that became TV's most talked-about low-rated show, ended its current run Wednesday without solving Laura Palmer's now-maybe murder and with its FBI agent shot three times. The shooting of FBI agent Dale Cooper in his hotel room _ only the gunman's gloved hand was seen _ came at the end of the show and undoubtedly shocked many fans who have followed David Lynch's quirky series from the beginning. It was left uncertain whether Cooper was killed. The surprise shooting was only one of many closing-episode twists that will have ``Twin Peaks'' fans speculating until fall, when the series picks up somes unresolved questions in a two-hour premiere. Among the twists: _ Jock, a fat barkeep shot during his arrest as a suspect in Palmer's death, was smothered to death in his hospital bed by her increasingly deranged father. _ Leo Johnson, a drug-dealing trucker also suspected of killing Palmer, was shot and possibly killed by another Twin Peaks low-life while trying to murder Bobby, Palmer's two-timing boyfriend, with an ax. _ A mysterious assailant's beating of the mad psychiatrist Dr. Jacoby, causing the latter to have a heart attack. Or did the heart attack hit moments earlier when the doctor, hiding at night near a gazebo, saw a woman he thought was Laura. _ The playing of a tape that Palmer, the town's high school homecoming queen, supposedly made before her death. In it, she spoke of a mystery man who she said twice tried to kill her, ``but boy, I sure got off on it.'' The every-which-way-but-loose finale left the series as it began _ shrouded in mystery _ despite earlier statements by ABC that it would tie up some loose ends. Created by Lynch _ whose eccentric films includes ``Dune'' and ``Blue Velvet'' _ and Mark Frost, the series is set in a Pacific Northwest logging town full of sex, lies, drugs, doughnuts, pie and strange events. The last includes last week's slaying of a mynah bird taken into police custody after suggestions it saw the murder of Palmer. In the show's April 8 premiere, the discovery of Palmer's body, wrapped in plastic, touched off a crying jag by a deputy sheriff. That it turned out he always cried at murder scenes proved an early indication that seemingly normal Twin Peaks was in fact Weird City. Subsequent episodes featured FBI agent Cooper's dream of a midget speaking gibberish; Laura's leather-jacketed, two-timing boyfriend, Bobby, howling like a wolf, and her mother, who has psychic visions. Other characters: the Log Lady toting a log that imparts clues about the murder; a shoe salesman who lacks a left arm and carries a suitcase full of right-foot shoes, and singing and dancing Icelanders considering a land deal. A brooding, beautifully filmed series, it is to some is both a whodunnit and a Gothic put-on of soap operas, one with so many Byzantine twists that its ardent fans argue for hours about the meaning of a plot turn or apparent clue. Some viewers complain that if one episode is missed, all is lost. The show's premiere, preceded by considerable publicity and word of mouth, had top ratings of 21.7. But its Nielsens started sliding immediately, and last week hit a low of 10.6. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. ABC renewed ``Twin Peaks'' for another season, and will air it on Saturdays with ``China Beach'' next fall.

DOC.HEAD: The Other `Born on the Fourth of July' ^Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: After 5{ years of work and 50 hours of footage, filmmaker Loretta Smith has almost finished the movie she wanted to _ but now can't _ call ``Born on the Fourth of July.'' That was the film's title for four years, but it had to be scrapped when Oliver Stone used it for his Academy Award-winning feature on the life of paraplegic Vietnam veteran Ron Kovic. ``Born on the Fourth of July'' earned Stone an Oscar as best director, and also won an Oscar for editing. Tom Cruise starred as Kovic in the Universal Studios production that reportedly cost $15 million. ``What do you do when someone steals your title?'' Smith said in a recent interview. She laughed, however, and acknowledged Stone's help with her own film. The title is actually Kovic's, taken from the lyrics of a George M. Cohan song. He used the phrase as the title of his 1976 autobiography. But Smith had lived with it as a shooting title for so long that she almost felt it belonged to her. ``I see them as complementing one another,'' said Kovic in a telephone interview from his home in Redondo Beach, Calif. ``They're two very different films about the same person. I think both the feature and the documentary are important statements.'' Kovic, 44, was a much-decorated Marine in his second tour in Vietnam near the Cua Viet River when a sniper's bullet smashed his spine in January 1968. His resulting paralysis and his experiences in Veterans Administration hospitals turned him into an anti-war activist. In Smith's documentary, Kovic appears as himself _ sometimes naked, with catheters hanging from his body. The movie was filmed with a staff of about 11 people on a budget of $250,000, raised from small grants and public donations. ``The biggest individual donation came from Bruce Springsteen at a fundraiser in Venice, Calif., in 1987,'' Smith said. ``He gave us $10,000 and the use of four of his songs for the soundtrack. ``As a documentary maker, I don't have a very high profile. It's almost like being a nonperson.'' The 42-year-old Smith, who once supported her film work by driving a taxi, came to filmmaking by a roundabout route. A Chicago native who grew up in Sterling, Ill. (``Ronald Reagan grew up 10 miles away _ how more all-American can you get?''), she was working as a textbook editor in 1974 when her then-boyfriend, journalist Richard Boyle, convinced her to trot the world with him. The romance didn't last, but it introduced Smith to Boyle's friend, Kovic, who was then completing his autobiography. It proved to be an eventful friendship. Kovic traveled with Smith and Boyle to Cambodia in 1975, when that nation was falling to the Khmer Rouge. When Kovic was arrested at a Chicago demonstration in 1979, Smith _ by then a film student _ was thrown in the same paddy wagon. When Kovic saw Smith's first documentary, an award-winning effort titled ``Where Did You Get That Woman?'' in 1983, he began pressuring her to film his story as a documentary. He had become embittered with the Hollywood approach after the collapse of a 1978 attempt to film his book on a script by Stone. It would have starred Al Pacino. When she began filming Kovic in 1985, Smith thought it would take her a year to complete. She hadn't counted, though, on the complexity of her subject, or on America's growing conservatism. As the film cans piled up, so did the bills. ``I was turned down for every grant I applied for,'' she recalled. ``Government-sponsored agencies simply didn't want to deal with war and veterans.'' Smith kept on shooting, though. She gathered harrowing footage of Kovic's daily routine as a paraplegic, shots of him addressing veterans' rallies and documentation of a visit to his home town of Massapequa, N.Y. In that sequence, Kovic rolls his wheelchair to a basketball court where he used to play. He talks to some youths shooting baskets and finds out that they plan to enlist in the military. Kovic tells them about his own experiences, but cannot dissuade them. Smith also wove in older material. She obtained home movies from Kovic's family, showing his Long Island childhood, as well as combat footage of the war from television archives. It grew from a cinematic portrait of a friend into an admitted obsession. ``I really am trying to make a statement,'' she said. ``The Vietnam war was the central fact for my generation of Americans. The war touched everyone, whether they went to Vietnam or not, and it changed us _ we'll never be the same people again.'' The project often languished, though, for lack of funding. At times, Smith had to spend more time raising money than working on the film. Her utility bills went unpaid and her telephone was frequently disconnected. In addition, Kovic's treatment at another VA hospital in 1986 left him depressed and sometimes uncooperative. When Stone had a hit with the Oscar-winning ``Platoon,'' and decided to film Kovic's book himself, Smith became worried. Kovic's advisory work with Stone often made him unavailable to her, and the problem of the title had to solved. Smith, though, made a deal with Universal whereby the studio got the title, but she got Universal's aid in the distribution of her film. Stone, a Vietnam veteran himself, helped raise money. ``I'm editing the footage down to feature length right now, and I want to show it at the New York Film Festival in September, so I'll have to raise more funding for post-production,'' Smith said. ``As for a title, I'm open to suggestions. Maybe I'll just call it `A Good American.'''

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Attempt To Enter Israeli Consulate Turns Violent
DOC.TEXT: Palestinian protesters fought police at the door of the Israeli consulate Tuesday during a demonstration against Israel's suppression of the Palestinian uprising. Nine police officers and eight demonstrators suffered mostly minor injuries in the emotional melee, according to police and hospital officials. Nine demonstrators were arrested, said Sgt. Ed Burns, a police spokesman. ``Free Palestine from murder!'' and ``Stop Killing Palestinian Children!'' yelled some of the demonstrators. ``It was like what is happening in the intefadeh, you can't block the Palestinians with coffee and cake, force has to be used,'' said Yuval Rotem, a spokesman for the Israeli consulate. Intefadeh is an Arabic word to describe the uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. Rotem said about a dozen employees were inside the building during the demonstration, including Consul General Uri Savir. He estimated the number of demonstrators at more than 300. At least 100 police officers on foot and on horses surrounded the building, he said. Police refused to say how many officers were sent. Most of the demonstrators stayed within barricades set up by police, but about 50 charged the door to the building housing the consulate, according to Said Elatab, a freelance photographer accompanying the demontrators. Seven demonstrators were charged with assault on a police officer, one with robbery and one with obstruction, Burns said, refusing to elaborate.

DOC.HEAD: Taiwan Burns Confiscated Ivory, Lion Skins
DOC.TEXT: Taiwanese officials burned more than a ton of confiscated ivory and 11 lion skins as part of a policy aimed at protecting wildlife. ``The government is determined to implement its policy to protect wildlife and reverse the nation's unfavorable image,'' Lin Shiang-nung, vice chairman of the Agriculture Council, said Tuesday. He was speaking at a crematory in this northern port city where officials burned 1,540 pounds of ivory and 11 lion skins worth an estimated $3.7 million. Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands, former chairman of the World Wildlife Foundation, urged other Asian countries to take similar action. In June, Taiwan passed a law imposing a maximum three-year prison term for the import or sale of ivory and wild animals. The island has a tradition of importing wildlife for food and ivory for art and jewelry.

DOC.HEAD: Tested As Never Before, Flood Control Projects Spared Urban Areas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: A year's worth of rain in four months washed out crops, damaged homes and caused some $300 million in damage in four states, but experts say dams and levees built since 1950 prevented a far worse catastrophe. Downtown Dallas, for example, probably would have been swamped by Trinity River had five dams not held back 390 billion gallons of water _ enough to cover Rhode Island under nearly 2 feet of water. ``This would have been the new flood of record,'' said Ron Ruffennach of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. ``Our economists . .. think $2 billion in damage was prevented in the Dallas area because of these water projects.'' Instead, water was held back or channeled away from populated areas, and flooding in Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and Louisiana was confined mostly to rural, low-lying flood plains. In those areas, development is sparse, and agriculture and recreation are the only industries. In all, damage from the water draining south toward the Gulf of Mexico is estimated at $300 million or more _ most of it related to agriculture. Exact counts are unavailable because many areas are still under water, and may remain flooded most of the summer. So far, 76 counties in Texas, Oklahoma and Arkansas have been declared eligible for federal disaster assistance. But as water recedes in most areas, officials say it seems clear that given the record volume of water, flooding could have been far worse. ``A lot of the area that was flooded was agriculture area and much less populated than other places. And particularly downstream, it's safe to say a lot of people received an early warning,'' said Laureen Chernow, a spokeswoman for the Texas Office of Emergency Management. ``There's no doubt it could have been a lot worse. The system worked as it was supposed to,'' added Carol Weathers of the Trinity River Authority. In Louisiana, the Corps of Engineers, which operates flood-control dams, warned that 700,000 acres of land could be flooded. With cleanup operations under way, authorities count fewer than 110,000 flooded acres because levees held. About 110 homes sustained damage in five counties, and counts from six others affected by flooding haven't been made, said Janet Merritt, chief of disaster services in Louisiana. Only two counties in Louisiana apparently will qualify for a federal disaster declaration, she said. Agricultural losses are estimated at $7 million. Elsewhere: _ In Oklahoma, President Bush declared 13 counties eligible for disaster aid. One child was killed during storms, about 500 homes were damaged and highways and bridges sustained about $8 million worth of damage, officials said. No crop or livestock losses were reported. _ In Arkansas, 22 counties have been included in the disaster declaration, no deaths were reported, about 500 houses were damaged and agriculture losses were estimated at $4.8 million. _ In Kansas City, 208 houses were destroyed, 302 sustained major damage and 224 minor damage after flooding, which has also covered 800,000 acres of corn. Damage is estimated at least $5 million. _ In Mississippi, 345 houses have been damaged by flooding, and cleanup efforts are well under way. _ And in Texas, 12 people died last month because of the floods, which began April 15. One died last week, authorities said. So far, 41 counties have been made eligible for federal disaster aid, and the Federal Emergency Management Agency has received applications for aid from 3,473 Texas families. Last year, 22 people died in flooding that made 89 Texas counties eligible for federal disaster assistance. FEMA paid out $35 million in aid last year. ``It's impossible to compare with last year at this time,'' said FEMA spokesman George Burgess. ``We won't know for some time.'' What officials do know is that flood control techniques, tested as never before because of the record volume of water, helped to lessen the impact of the torrents. The flood problem began in January and February when heavy rains drenched the ground, National Weather Service hydrologist Ernie Cathey said. ``There was no place for the water to go,'' he said. Record rains continued through April and into early May. Dallas, for example, averages 29.46 inches of rain a year. So far this year, the city has had 29.15 inches. The city experienced its worst flooding ever in 1908, when 184,000 cubic feet of water per second raced down the Trinity at Dallas. The second highest recorded reading was during floods of 1942 _ 110,000 cubic feet per second. But this year the peak was 82,000, and hydrologists estimate that if not for the dams holding back the 390 billion gallons, the flow rate would have topped 260,000 cubic feet per second. Still, the work of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers has come under attack in Arkansas where Gov. Bill Clinton has questioned decisions to release large amounts of Red River water upstream in Oklahoma. That water washed out fields in Arkansas and threatened to crumble a levee at Texarkana. The corps is ``taking a second look'' at decisions made in Oklahoma and Arkansas after Clinton's complaints, Ruffennach said.

DOC.HEAD: Bart Simpson: Cultural Icon _ Or Rebel Without a Clue?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Bart Simpson, the goggle-eyed cartoon kid with a corrugated hairdo, is catching flak from educators who say his smart-alecky attitude on ``The Simpsons'' gives children the wrong message. Bart, with his overbite and backtalk (``Don't have a cow, man!''), is fast becoming an icon of American pop culture, helped along by a multimillion-dollar merchandising blitz from Fox Broadcasting Co. The scene-stealer on the runaway hit TV show also stars in Butterfinger candy bar commercials and there are plans for a starring role in a Nintendo video game. Mattel Inc. promises Bart dolls and action figures among more than 200 Simpsons products entering stores. This summer, Burger King launches a Simpsons-based ad campaign. Bart's influence has reached Stanford University and UCLA, where he won votes in student elections. He was disqualified in both races on the technicality that he was not enrolled, prompting student protests. In a telegram from Fox to Stanford students, Bart told voters to be patient: ``I must tell you I have set my sights on higher goals. Bart Simpson for U.S. president in '92, man!'' Bart is fast becoming the fictional youth American children identify with most. Not bad for a 10-year-old kid with only eight fingers, eh? But his attitude bothers some critical school officials. Last month, Principal Bill Krumnow of Lutz Elementary School in Ballville Township, Ohio, banned Bart's ``Underachiever: And Proud of It, Man,'' T-shirt. ``To be proud of being an incompetent is a contradiction of what we stand for,'' Krumnow said. ``We strive for excellence and to instill good values in kids.'' The show, he said, ``teaches the wrong thing to students.'' The shirt also was banned at Cambridge Elementary School in Orange, Calif., and last week in Kentucky, Principal Lonnie Watts of Taylor Mill Elementary School declared the Bart shirt a dress-code violation. ``We feel like the Bart Simpson show does a lot of things that do not help student self-esteem, such as saying it's OK to be stupid,'' Watts said. ``Simpsons'' creator Matt Groening and Fox officials prefer to let Bart defend himself with statements like: ``I have no comment. My folks taught me to respect elementary school principals, even the ones who have nothing better to do than tell kids what to wear.'' The show's co-executive producer Sam Simon said: ``I don't think it's the job of elementary school principals to pick the role models for their kids.'' The uproar caused J.C. Penney Co. Inc., which created Simpsons boutiques in its stores, to remove the offending ``underachiever'' shirt and another that reads: ``I'm Bart Simpson. Who the hell are you?'' Even drug czar William J. Bennett took a swipe at Bart. On a May 16 tour of a Pittsburgh drug-treatment center, Bennett saw a poster of Bart and told recovering addicts they shouldn't follow Bart's lead as an underachiever. ``You guys aren't watching `The Simpsons,' are you? That's not going to help you any,'' said Bennett, director of the national drug policy office. That wasn't lost on Fox. ``We have great respect for Mr. Bennett's task and responsibility,'' said Fox spokesman Brad Turell. ``But I am not aware of any one TV program that will help teen-agers kick the drug habit.'' Simon said the heat was the inevitable result of the show's success. ``In a matter of a few months it went from being a cult favorite to a critical hit to popular acclaim,'' Simon said. ``I knew that the next step _ because it always is the next step _ is somebody stepping in and saying it's dangerous.'' Some authorities disagree with Bart's critics. ``I think the Simpson family is one of the few thoughtful cartoons on commercial broadcasting,'' said Peggy Charren, president of Action for Children's Television, a lobby and watchdog group based in Cambridge, Mass. ``How can you teach the Constitution if you ban T-shirts?'' she asked. And Fox executives stress they're serious about Bart's image. ``We're sensitive to it, but you can't do your show for three (school) principals,'' said ``Simpsons'' co-producer James L. Brooks, a creator of ``Taxi,'' ``The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' and writer-director of ``Terms of Endearment.'' Brooks said he frequently discusses the show with parents, educators and child psychologists. ``I know from my own childhood that I was messed up most by the portrayal of perfect families,'' Brooks said. ``When you couldn't live up to them then you started to think something was wrong with yours.''

DOC.HEAD: In Muddled War, 20-Year-Old Veteran May Face Another Battle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: At 20, Pvt. Francisco Kisanga is already a veteran of Angola's civil war, decorated for bravery in what the government calls its two most decisive victories, at Cuito Cuanavale and Mavinga. Kisanga, a 5-foot-5-inch warrior whose nom-de-guerre is Jiboia _ ``Portuguese for a large snake that seizes, bites and kills,'' he says _ joined the Peoples' Armed Forces for the Liberation of Angola when he was 15. Now, despite renewed peace efforts between the Marxist government and UNITA rebels, the war for privates like Kasinga continues as the two ``victories'' are debated. He took part in a four-month campaign _ codenamed Operation Zebra _ that the government said wrestled the town of Mavinga from rebel hands Feb. 2 before army forces pulled back to their southern base in Cuito Cuanavale. Guiding foreign reporters in an armored car along tracks in the heavily mined battlefield of Cuito Cuanavale, Kisanga grinned as he recalled the 1988 battle here and the recent fighting in Mavinga. ``Cuito was a real hard battle _ heavy artillery, tanks, bombs,'' Kisanga said. ``Mavinga was just routine shelling and mines _ there was no hand-to-hand combat, the kwachas just run away.'' ``Kwacha'' _ or ``Wake up!'' in the native Bantu dialect of Umbundu _ is the battlecry of Jonas Savimbi's UNITA _ National Union for the Total Independence of Angola. It has fought Angola's Soviet-backed government first with South African and now with U.S. aid, since shortly after Angolan independence from Portugal in 1975. Kisanga's dismissive summary of the Mavinga battle contrasts with the heroic picture drawn by Angolan officials and reflects the controversy surrounding the battles there and at Cuito Cuanavale. According to Lt. Col. Francisco Furtado, chief of staff of Operation Zebra, the attack on Mavinga involved heavy clashes between 7,500 rebel troops and a similar number of government soldiers. It was launched from Cuito on Dec. 21. On Jan. 29, government forces finally crossed the river Lomba, 12{ miles north of Mavinga and the key to strategic control of the area, Furtado said. He said 4,748 rebels died, eight were captured and 10 surrendered before government troops withdrew from the town. Savimbi, speaking May 15 on the rebels' Voice of the the Black Cockerel Radio, claimed the rebels routed government troops and re-occupied Mavinga after heavy fighting. Furtado said two tactical groups were still pulling back to Cuito, where government and Cuban troops halted South Africa's military push into Angola in March 1988. South Africa also claimed victory at Cuito Cuanavale, which became known as southern Africa's Stalingrad because of heavy ground and air clashes between South African and Cuban forces. Western diplomats in Lisbon said intelligence reports indicated no major fighting around Mavinga since February. Recent rebel actions have been smaller hit-and-run attacks, bombings and ambushes in Angola's central highlands and northern provinces bordering Zaire. Zaire serves as a conduit for much of the $50 million in U.S. aid that UNITA receives yearly. ``We have decided to shift units to other parts of the country, to teach UNITA the lesson they didn't learn at Mavinga,`` Furtado said. Pvt. Kisanga, the 20-year-old veteran, knows what the new government orders could mean _ another tour of duty before he can go on leave.

DOC.HEAD: Walesa to Make Pilgrimage to Lourdes
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity leader Lech Walesa plans a summer pilgrimage to the healing springs at Lourdes, a Roman Catholic official said. The visit by Walesa and his wife, Danuta, on Aug. 4-6 will mark a twin-city agreement between Lourdes and Czestochowa, the site of Poland's most famous shrine, said Mgr. Stanislaw Jez, head of Poland's Catholic mission in France. According to legend, the ``Black Madonna'' of Czestochowa was painted by St. Luke on a plank of wood from Christ's table. About 4 million people descend on the southern French city of Lourdes each year to take the reputedly healing waters from its springs and visit sites where 19th-century teen-ager Bernadette Soubirous reportedly saw visions of the Virgin Mary.

DOC.HEAD: Police Rescue Beached Dolphin By Thames
DOC.TEXT: A dolphin beached on the banks of the Thames River in central London was rescued in an elaborate operation involving the police, the fire service and an animal rights group. The dolphin was spotted on the river banks near the Metropolitan police building Tuesday afternoon, and police and fire service workers rushed to its rescue. A spokeswoman for the Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals said she had no idea where the dolphin came from or why it was beached. It was believed the dolphin was ill and could not escape to the open sea when the tide on the Thames went out. The dolphin was placed in a body bag to keep it moist while it waited for an expert from the London Zoo and an ambulance to arrive. It was then driven to an animal hospital and later to a safari park.

DOC.HEAD: More Country Kids Risk School Failure Than City or Suburban Youth
DOC.TEXT: The countryside offers no escape from the social and economic pressures that lead kids to do poorly in school, a study suggests. A study that surveyed school officials in 312 rural, urban and suburban districts last year cast doubt on the popular image of rural children leading wholesome, trouble-free lives compared with youngsters in crowded communities. The study asked officials to estimate the percentage of their students who fit into one or more of a dozen risk categories, including involvement in crime, sexual activity, drug or alcohol abuse, depression, child abuse, poverty or parents who are substance abusers. Rural children fared worse than non-rural children in 34 out of 39 statistical comparisons, according to the survey by the National Rural Development Institute based at Western Washington University. The report thus suggests that the social and economic strains facing rural schoolchildren are every bit as bad, and perhaps worse, as those facing city youngsters. Isolation and rural customs are partly to blame, said Doris Helge, executive director of the institute based at Western Washington University, in Bellingham, Wash. ``A lot of it is attitude,'' Helge said in a telephone interview. ``Sexual activity and dropping out of school is not that unusual in rural settings. There's an acceptance of low self-esteem. A kid has to be really deviant to get any attention.'' A draft of the study, which also compared the state of students with mental and physical handicaps to that of non-handicapped children, was made available to The Associated Press. There are brighter spots on the rural landscape, notably in Minnesota, North Dakota and Iowa, where residents have long put high value on education and completing school. But Helge, an authority on rural education problems, said rural children with handicaps or psychological problems may fare worse than others because isolated communities often lack social services to address their needs. Among the survey's findings: _17.7 percent of non-handicapped rural high school students were estimated to be substance abusers, compared with 10.1 percent in non-rural districts. _12.3 percent of non-handicapped rural elementary school children were found to be suffering depression, compared with 10 percent of urban and 8.5 perecent of suburban youngsters. Among mildly handicapped youngsters, depression was a problem among an estimated 16.9 percent of rural grade-schoolers but only 9.5 percent of urban and 12.4 percent of suburban pupils. _25.7 percent of non-handicapped rural high school students were considered sexually active, compared with 22.5 percent of urban and 20.9 percent suburban students. Among mildly handicapped rural high schoolers, 26.7 percent were sexually active, compared with only 15.3 percent of urban and 18.2 percent of suburban children. _6.7 percent of non-handicapped rural middle school youngsters were said to be involved in crime, compared with an estimated 5.6 percent in urban and suburban schools. _12.7 percent of preschool-age rural youngsters without handicaps were considered victims of child abuse, compared with 11.9 percent in urban and 9.6 percent in suburban districts. Social and family strains have worsened in rural communities in recent years along with downturns in rurally-based industries like farming, petroleum and timber, experts say. ``We shouldn't be surprised that rural children face the same, if not more difficult circumstances as urban children,'' said Denise Alston, senior education associate of the Children's Defense Fund in Washington. ``Services from prenatal care to recreation are limited, and unfortunately, poverty is the common denominator for both groups.'' Helge said the key to helping troubled rural youngsters lies in educating parents, teachers and other adults to communicate more effectively with children and become more attuned to their problems before they become crises.

DOC.HEAD: Massachusetts House Would Ban Gov't Funding of Offensive Art
DOC.TEXT: In a move that echoes national disputes over controversial art, the Massachusetts House approved a measure Tuesday that would prevent state funding of institutions that display works deemed offensive. The measure would bar the Massachusetts Cultural Council from giving any of its $14 million in grants to any institution exhibiting art that depicts sexual exploitation of children or displays religious objects in a disparaging manner. The measure, an amendment to the state budget, passed on a voice vote without debate. It is a long way from becoming law. The House version of the budget must be reconciled with the Senate version, and Gov. Michael Dukakis, who can veto individual sections of the budget, said he believed the measure would be unconstitutional. Rep. Thomas Finneran, who sponsored the amendment, didn't specifically define what he meant by offensive, but mentioned recent disputes over the display of photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe and Andres Serrano. ``It would prohibit the granting of financial support for any individual or group that displays anything that is offensive,'' Finneran said of the measure. Federal lawmakers have subjected funding for art to increasing scrutiny. Last year, Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., pressured the Corcoran Gallery in Washington D.C. to cancel a scheduled exhibition of photographs by Mapplethorpe, whose photos include homosexual themes and nude children. Helms and conservative groups criticized the National Endowment for the Arts' partial funding of the Mapplethorpe show, as well as a grant to Serrano, who aroused Helms' ire with his photograph of a crucifix submerged in urine. ``To me in all honesty it's ridiculous to talk about the expenditure of taxpayer dollars on something that is absolutely horribly offensive,'' Finneran said.

DOC.HEAD: Residents Worry Indian Lease Will Jeopardize City's Future
DOC.TEXT: After nearly a century in which most residents paid a few dollars a year, the only U.S. city on land leased from an Indian reservation has agreed to a fourteenfold increase in rent to the Seneca Indians. The agreement, reached Monday nine months before a 99-year lease expires, also calls for a $60 million payment from the federal and state governments to compensate for what both sides said were unfairly low rents under the old pact. But city officials and residents Tuesday worried about how the community would raise its annual payments to the Indians from $57,000 to at least $800,000. ``If the economy of Salamanca is really impacted by this lease, it can't survive as a city,'' said Patrick Callaghan, chief city negotiator. ``The package we worked out is about the best package we can get from the Senecas. Whether we can get through this, I don't know.'' Salamanca was settled in the mid-1840s on land set aside 50 years earlier for an Indian reservation. In 1892, Congress imposed a lease on the Senecas, over the tribe's objections, that called for most city residents to pay $5 or less a year. The city as a whole paid $57,000 last year. The lease expires in February, and the uncertainty over what form the new lease might take had prompted residents to put off home improvements and businesses to delay expansions. Many banks refused to make loans on property within the Seneca reservation. Some residents appeared stunned and shaken as they left City Hall after learning the details. ``The thing of it is, there are so many people in this town working for minimum wage,'' said Carl Auge, whose lease fee went from $10 to $174. ``I don't know how they're going to make it.'' Frank Dragotta said the $891 a year he will have to pay on his bicycle store could put it out of business. ``I work more or less full time to keep the business afloat. It's not strong enough to keep going on its own,'' he said. ``I don't know where I'm going to be.'' About 90 percent of the property in Salamanca, a city of 6,600, lies on Seneca land. It is part of the 22,640-acre Allegany Reservation on the Pennsylvania line. Under the new agreement, a residential lease will be assessed at 8 percent of the market value of the land and a non-residential lease will be 10 percent of the land value. The new lease will run for 40 years, with an option to renew for another 40 years. Residents will pay the Indians a total of $630,000 annually. The city government will pay the remaining $170,000. Several residents said they didn't begrudge paying the tribe something extra. ``Five bucks wasn't enough,'' said Jack Frost, whose rent will be $161 a year. But they said the federal and state governments should help make the payments. Officials in Washington and New York have said there is no guarantee that government money will be available even for the one-time $60 million payment. ``They were very instrumental in imposing this on the Indians and now they're walking away from it,'' said Joe Giblin, whose payments will rise from $51 to $243. In the meantime, Salamanca could wither and die, some residents said. ``The city's not going to grow,'' said Jean Barrett, who will pay $255 instead of $6. ``How many people build a new house in Salamanca? How many businesses are in Salamanca? We're just stifled.''

DOC.HEAD: Robber Cuts Off Woman's Finger to Steal Wedding Band
DOC.TEXT: A robber cut off a woman's finger to get her gold wedding band during a break-in at her home, police said. A man armed with a gun entered the home of Mary McGowan, 68, Monday night through a back door that probably was unlocked, said Police officer J.T. Robinson. Mrs. McGowan told police the intruder took several credit cards and about $5 in cash from her purse, then grabbed her hand and tried to pull off the gold band. When he couldn't get the ring off, he got a knife from the kitchen, held it to Mrs. McGowan's throat, then used it to cut off her finger, Robinson said. Officers searched the house and found the knife used in the assault, but were unable to locate the severed finger so that doctors might try to reattach it. Mrs. McGowan was listed in fair condition Tuesday at Candler General Hospital. The robber remained at large.

DOC.HEAD: `Twin Peaks' Makes for Quirky TV
With PM-Twin Peaks-Lipton
DOC.TEXT: The only thing undeniable about ``Twin Peaks'' is that the series opened with homecoming queen Laura Palmer's body washing ashore, meticulously wrapped in white plastic tarp. OK, maybe even that's not true. Laura's lookalike cousin also arrived, very much alive, leading at least one TV critic to theorize that Laura Palmer killed Laura Palmer. Or rather, Laura Palmer killed her cousin and now is impersonating her. It's a whodunit gone amok. In ``Twin Peaks,'' we don't even know who's been done. And if you understand the bizarre, quirky, weird, offbeat episodic series brought to television by filmdom's offbeat, weird, quirky and bizarre director David Lynch, please fill the rest of us in. We're hopelessly confused. Tonight's season finale promises to resolve the Palmer murder in a small Northwest lumber town whose occupants are alternately obsessed with doughnuts, coffee, pie, logs, psychic visions, Laura's murder, tape recorders, birds, wife-beating, cocaine, draperies that glide silently and dancing dwarfs who talk backwards. Newsweek was so confused, it ran a chart titled ``The Story So Far (As Near As Anyone Can Figure).'' Los Angeles Times television columnist Howard Rosenberg said he was watching every episode and ``loving it. I think.'' Here's the basic plot, or a reasonable facsimile: Seventeen-year-old Laura Palmer turns up dead. Pie-loving FBI agent Dale Cooper comes to town to help doughnut-loving Sheriff Harry S. Truman solve the murder. Laura may or may not have been a drug dealer, but she most definitely was homecoming queen. Her mother has psychic visions. There is a woman who carries around a log. A one-armed man is ominously referred to. Cooper walks around talking into a tape recorder. Nadine wears an eye patch, lives for noiseless drapes and is married to ``Big Ed'' Hurley, who runs the town gas station. Josie Packard owns the local mill and has the hots for Truman. Everybody is sleeping with everybody else's husband, wife, boyfriend, girlfriend ... well, you get the picture. If you don't, take heart. ``Twin Peaks'' will be back in the fall, ABC announced this week. Oh, goody. That gives us all enough time to get over the motion sickness from trying to figure out this season.

DOC.HEAD: Fired Editor Sues Wall Street Journal for Libel, Seeks $12.64 Million
DOC.TEXT: A former editor for The Wall Street Journal sued the newspaper Tuesday for $12.64 million, claiming he was fired and his reputation smeared by a false charge of plagiarism. Jonathan Kandell, the Journal's assistant foreign editor prior to his dismissal May 2, also demanded the return of notes and other documents that he contended the paper's editors had kept, knowing they would support his position. The Journal fired Kandell, 43, after accusing him of lifting uncredited material from another writer's book for a page 1 article about three private entrepreneurs in eastern Europe. Roger May, a spokesman for Dow Jones & Co. Inc., owners of the Journal, said, ``Dow Jones believes the suit is utterly without merit and the company intends to defend itself vigorously.'' Kandell quoted Paul Steiger, deputy managing editor of the Journal, as having said his alleged offense was ``the most serious transgression to take place at the Journal since the Foster Winans case.'' R. Foster Winans was convicted in 1985 of using his position as a Wall Street Journal columnist to profit from insider stock trading information. He was sentenced to 18 months in prison, a $5,000 fine and five years' probation. In his lawsuit, filed Tuesday in U.S. District court in Manhattan, Kandell contends he was libeled and his professional reputation destroyed by the Journal. He demanded $10 million in punitive damages and $2.64 million in compensation for ``willful, wanton and reckless disregard of the truth'' and ``actual malice'' on the paper's part. He said the libel was contained in a letter of apology that the newspaper sent to the author of a book dealing with the same subject and in a subsequent article in the weekly newspaper Village Voice about Kandell's case. The Voice was not named as a defendant in the suit. Kandell's article, in the March 30 edition of the Journal, profiled a Soviet machine tool maker, a Czechoslovak inventor and a Hungarian banker as examples of individuals succeeding in the private sector. Kandell said he based the story on interviews with the three individuals in their countries after hearing them speak at a meeting in New York last November, sponsored by the Council on Foreign Relations. He said that at the same meeting, he also learned of a book, ``Communist Entrepreneurs,'' and met the author, John W. Kiser III. He said he later ``read the book once and put it aside.''

DOC.HEAD: Preacher Given Probation in PTL Scandal
DOC.TEXT: The last of six defendants in the PTL scandal was placed on three years' probation for lying to a federal grand jury in denying he took Jessica Hahn to a hotel to have sex with TV evangelist Jim Bakker. U.S. District Judge Robert Potter on Tuesday also ordered John Wesley Fletcher to observe eight months of curfew from 8 p.m. to 5:30 a.m. The 50-year-old former preacher from Durham pleaded guilty earlier this month to perjury. Under federal guidelines, he faced 6 to 12 months in prison. ``I feel fortunate not to have to go to prison,'' he said as he left the courthouse. ``I was scared. I was petrified.'' Four other defendants _ Bakker, top PTL deputy Richard Dortch, Bakker aide David Taggart and his brother and PTL decorator James Taggart _ are in prison. Bakker is serving a 45-year term for fraud and conspiracy. He was convicted last year of fleecing his followers of millions in donations to his evangelical empire, which collapsed after his sexual encounter with Ms. Hahn became known. Perjury charges against a fifth defendant, former PTL pastor Sam Johnson, were dropped. Once a favored guest on Bakker's TV show, Fletcher appeared twice before a grand jury. The first time, in 1987, he denied that he took Ms. Hahn, a church secretary, to a Clearwater Beach, Fla., hotel in 1980 to have sex with Bakker. A year later, Fletcher testified that Bakker had asked him to ``get me a woman'' and that he brought Ms. Hahn there to have sex with Bakker. On Tuesday, Fletcher, who now does roofing work, cried as he stood before the judge. He said only, ``I'm sorry.'' Defense attorney George Laughrun said Fletcher was on an anti-depressant when he first appeared before the grand jury and twice attempted suicide. ``He has seen rock bottom and is working his way back up,'' Laughrun told the judge. ``Give him credit for coming in and pleading guilty.''

DOC.HEAD: Probation for Man Who Introduced Bakker to Hahn
DOC.TEXT: Evangelist John Wesley Fletcher was sentenced to three years' probation Tuesday after pleading guilty to charges of lying to a grand jury about the reasons he introduced PTL founder Jim Bakker to Jessica Hahn. Fletcher is the last of six defendants to get his day in court after the 1987 PTL scandal. Bakker resigned from the television ministry following reports of his sexual encounter Ms. Hahn she was paid to keep quiet about the encounter. Fletcher, who now does roofing work, cried as he stood before U.S. District Judge Robert Potter. ``I feel fortunate not to have to go to prison,'' Fletcher, 50, said as he left the courthouse. ``I was scared. I was petrified.'' Four other defendants _ Bakker, top PTL deputy Richard Dortch, Bakker's personal aide David Taggart and his brother and PTL interior decorator James Taggart _ are in prison. Perjury charges against the fifth defendant, former PTL pastor Sam Johnson, were dropped. Fletcher was accused of lying to the special grand jury that investigated the ministry's operations under Bakker's leadership. Perjury is punishable by five years in prison, but under federal sentencing guidelines, Fletcher faced from 6 months to 12 months in prison. Potter told the former preacher to observe an eight-month curfew, remaining in his home in Durham from 8 p.m. until 5:30 a.m. In keeping with a plea bargain struck earlier this month, prosecutors supported his request for a light sentence. Fletcher was a regular guest on Bakker's television show and had met Ms. Hahn when he conducted revival services on Long Island, N.Y., where she was a church secretary. Fletcher told the grand jury during one appearance that he didn't introduce Bakker and Ms. Hahn with the idea that they would have sex. But during another appearance before the grand jury, Fletcher said that sex was the motive behind the introduction and that Bakker had told him to ``Get me a woman.'''

DOC.HEAD: 10 Coast Guardsmen Targeted in Drug-Smuggling Investigation
DOC.TEXT: A Coast Guardsman assigned to a ship near President Bush's summer retreat in Maine is among 10 current or former servicemen targeted in a federal drug-smuggling investigation, according to Coast Guard officials. Commandant Paul Yost told a news conference Tuesday that one of the servicemen was relieved of duties Friday when Yost learned that a two-year-old Justice Department investigation was still active. Yost said at a news conference that those being investigated included four current and six former guardsmen. Yost did not specify which active-duty guardsman had been relieved of duty. He said he would discuss with the U.S. attorney's office how to handle the three other active servicemen. The admiral declined to identify any of those involved in the investigation or to give details of possible crimes committed. Yost said he did not learn of the inquiry until after NBC News interviewed him on Friday. The network reported that indictments were pending. The serviceman on the ship off Maine was not involved in the president's security detail, Yost said. ``He was assigned to a vessel that could've been used as a backup to that security detail from time to time,'' he said. ``The vessel had not been so used that I know of, but it could've been.'' Coast Guard spokesman Jack O'Dell said the case stems from the conviction of four guardsmen in 1988 for selling drugs and passing information to smugglers. Investigators have been interviewing those convicted, O'Dell said. All of those involved in the continuing inquiry were stationed in Islamorada, Fla., at the time of the earlier charges, O'Dell said. The commandant said he was telling the truth when he told NBC he was not aware of any inquiry or any pending indictments against members of the Coast Guard. Since then, he said, he learned of ``Operation Tempest,'' an ongoing investigation by the Justice Department's Organized Crime Drug Enforcement Task Force. ``I am disappointed that any Coast Guard personnel are involved,'' Yost said. ``We will ensure they are prosecuted and punished.'' He said nearly all of the 38,000 men and women in the service, which is part of the Transportation Department, are serving honorably.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Sylvester Stallone says this summer's ``Rocky V'' will be the last in the series because there is nothing more to say about the not-so-talkative palooka. ``I have no more to say about the character, which is my alter ego, I can't deny that,'' Stallone said Tuesday. So what's ahead for Stallone? ``Right now,'' he said, ``we're doing something ecological, which is the theme of the 1990s. Then I'd like to do a comedy.'' The movie's premiere is tentatively set for Nov. 15.

Marlon Brando spoke of his family's ``acute misery'' after a judge refused to set bail for his son, who is charged with murdering his half-sister's boyfriend. ``There's no way to describe it to you unless you've gone through it in your life. We must just be strong, and the family, with love and supporting each other, will prevail,'' the reclusive actor told reporters. The white-haired Brando sat in the front row of the packed courtroom Tuesday and stared straight ahead as his son, Christian, was brought in. William Kunstler, the civil rights attorney summoned by the elder Brando to defend his son, said the shooting of Dag Drollet, 26, at the Brando estate last week was an accident and that Christian Brando was drunk at the time. But Municipal Judge Rosemary Shumsky denied bail. Christian Brando, 32, is a welder and tree-trimmer. Drollet was the boyfriend of Cheyenne Brando, 20. ``To those people who do not know the nature of this acute misery that both our families suffer, no explanation is possible,'' Marlon Brando said.

Kathleen Turner will transfer her smoldering performance as Maggie in the stage version of ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' to the small screen. ABC said Tuesday that no date has been set for the start of production. The play will air next season. Turner, nominated for a Tony for her role in the Broadway revival of Tennessee Williams' play, has starred in such films as ``Body Heat,'' ``Peggy Sue Got Married'' and ``The Accidental Tourist.'' The production was among 11 new TV movie projects announced by ABC. One will pair Vanessa Redgrave and her sister, Lynn, in a TV version of ``What Ever Happened to Baby Jane,'' a dark comedy whose 1962 film version starred Bette Davis and Joan Crawford as feuding sisters.

The Rev. Robert H. Schuller says he will pull the plug on his ``Hour of Power'' worldwide TV ministry if viewers don't send in $3.2 million to cover its debts. ``What I said is not an exaggeration. We are that close to terminating the television ministries. ... There's no money in the bank,'' Schuller said Monday. The minister will warn viewers of the possible cancellation and launch a five-week fund-raising drive on Sunday's ``Hour of Power,'' seen in 179 markets in the United States and in 21 European nations. Schuller blamed his financial problems on the rising costs of airtime. It costs $14 million annually to broadcast his weekly ``Hour of Power,'' he said.

Melba Moore will sing out in different languages during a commencement address at her alma mater, Montclair State College. She plans to sing ``Lift Every Voice and Sing'' in English and several nations' anthems in each country's language Friday. Moore also will be awarded an honorary doctorate. She is on tour promoting her latest album, ``Soul Exposed.''

Leonard Bernstein has canceled his appearance at the opening of the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. because of pneumonia. ``I am in the process of recovering from a brush with pneumonia and a complete week's rest has been imposed upon me,'' the conductor said in a statement from New York. Bernstein, 71, was to have conducted Beethoven's Symphony No. 7 in a Friday concert. The opening gala instead will feature mezzo-soprano Tatiana Troyanos, 18-year-old violinist Midori and conductor Julius Rudel. The annual festival is dedicated this year to the city's comeback from Hurricane Hugo.

Dan Rather returns to Texas this week to anchor the news from a station where he spent his early reporting years. Rather will anchor the ``CBS Evening News'' from the KHOU-TV studios on Wednesday and Thursday, the station said.

Michael ``Supe'' Granda of the Ozark Mountain Daredevils has withdrawn from a race against a state legislator who wants labels on records containing objectionable lyrics. Granda said Tuesday he doesn't have time to campaign against Rep. Jean Dixon in the August primary because of a busy concert schedule. ``I'm an artist, not a politician,'' said Granda, bass guitarist and vocalist for the Daredevils, who are best known for their 1970s hits ``If You Want To Get To Heaven'' and ``Jackie Blue.'' Mrs. Dixon, a first-term Republican, is seeking warning labels on albums, tapes and compact discs containing explicit lyrics. Granda, 39, said he still considers record labeling censorship. He said he supports Connie Wible, one of two remaining opponents of Mrs. Dixon in the Republican race.

DOC.HEAD: Cuomo Will Seek Re-election, Aides Say; GOP Still Without a Candidate
DOC.TEXT: With Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo reported to be on the verge of announcing for re-election, New York Republicans are still looking for a well-known challenger. Cuomo, widely viewed as a potential contender in the 1992 presidential election, has decided to seek a third four-year term, aides said Tuesday. They said the announcement could come within the next few days. The Republicans find themselves without a standardbearer at a time when Cuomo is considered vulnerable because of rising taxes and continuing budget deficits. The state GOP convention is next week; Democrats meet to nominate their slate the following week. State Republican Chairman J. Patrick Barrett called together his top-level candidate search team Tuesday night. But after a four-hour session, Barrett aide Elizabeth DelTorto said, ``There's nothing new to report.'' ``There are some new people Pat will be talking to tomorrow,'' DelTorto said. She refused to say who they were. On Saturday, Assembly Minority Leader Clarence Rappleyea turned down the GOP recruiters, and on Tuesday, former state GOP Chairman Richard Rosenbaum all but ruled himself out of the race. So far, the only announced candidate for the GOP nomination is little-known insurance broker Herbert Holland from Rockland County, outside New York City. He has never run for office and has little support among the GOP leadership. Under consideration by Republican leaders, largely because of strong support within the state's tiny Conservative Party, is New York University professor Herbert London. He briefly sought the GOP nomination for mayor of New York City last year. London hasn't announced for governor. Nonetheless, DelTorto said London was ``certainly still among the top finalists.'' The governor, at a New York City appearance Tuesday, would not comment on his intentions. But Cuomo, who already has more than $7 million in his campaign warchest, has said in recent months he expects to seek re-election. He has said there's no other job he'd rather be doing now. He also has said that with the state's fiscal problems, it's no time to be quitting. Cuomo and the Legislature, in the face of a third straight year of budget deficits, just adopted a budget that raises taxes a record $1.8 billion. While not confirming what the other advisers said about the governor's intentions, Andrew Cuomo, the governor's son and chief political adviser, called it ``a pretty safe story.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Asks Israelis To Show Restraint
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is asking Israeli security forces to restrain themselves in confronting Palestinians mounting angry protests over a weekend massacre. Bush emphasized his concern on Tuesday by extending personal sympathy to the families of all Palestinians killed in the spiraling violence. His condolences were pointedly expressed to both the families of the 13 Palestinians killed by Israeli security forces since the violence began as well as to the families of the seven Palestinian workers slain by an allegedly deranged Israeli gunman on Sunday. Bush's gesture comes amid rising discontent inside the Bush administration over the course of events in Israel. The discontent centers not only on the loss of life suffered during the Israeli crackdown on rioting Palestinians this week but also on Israel's seeming reluctance to enter a dialogue with Palestinian representatives. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said that while Bush was anguished at the murders of the seven Palestinian workers, he is also ``deeply troubled by the violent aftermath to these deaths.'' ``Besides expressing condolences to the families of all those who have lost their lives amidst the subsequent violence, the president calls upon the Israeli security forces as well as others to act with maximum restraint,'' Fitzwater said. ``Additional bloodshed and loss of life will only compound the tragedy.'' But Fitzwater said Bush believes that simply deploring what happened and calling for restraint is not enough. ``It is essential to address the political issues that lie at the core of the region's strife,'' Fitzwater said and added: ``Based on experience, we believe that violence in the Middle East will continue and possibly grow so long as there is an absence of a promising peace process that nourishes hope amongst Israelis and Palestinians alike.'' The administration continues to believe, Fitzwater said, that the initiative of Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, which the administration has been trying to implement for months, offers the best path to a negotiating process productive for both Israelis and Palestinians alike. Shamir repeatedly refused to endorse U.S. suggestions for an Israeli-Palestinian meeting in Cairo to start implementing the initiative. His government collapsed over the issue. Both Shamir, leader of the Likud coalition, and Labor Party leader Shimon Peres have been unable so far to form a new government. ``We look forward to the quick emergence of an Israeli government that is capable of making decisions on issues of peace and is committed, just as we are, to moving ahead on the peace process,'' Fitzwater said.

DOC.HEAD: Burned Boy Bouncing Back, Could Head Home Soon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Pretrial hearing for alleged attacker set for 10 a.m. EDT; may be led
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY4
DOC.TEXT: Twelve-year-old David Opont, given only a 50-50 shot at survival 3{ months ago after a neighborhood bully allegedly set him on fire, could walk out of the hospital before the end of the month. ``He's come a long way. We expect him to be released shortly _ possibly within the next week,'' said Myrna Manners, a spokeswoman for the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. The Brooklyn boy has been in the hospital, undergoing four skin grafts and therapy, since he was torched on March 7. Doctors said then if his recovery went perfectly, he would be out in four months. But his release from the burn unit will send David into another world that relatives say is just as scary to the boy: the legal system. David may have to testify against the 13-year-old who allegedly torched him in an abandoned building. A pretrial hearing for that boy was set for today. David's lawyers also will need his help in preparing a multimillion-dollar lawsuit to be filed on his behalf. And eventually, he'll be back on the streets where he was trapped, bound and burned. The future makes David nervous, said Guito Lavoile, 35, David's cousin and a family spokesman. ``It's not a problem of him, it's a problem of time. It's still too close to it all. The scars will not go away easy,'' said Lavoile. ``If you ever happened to be a victim of a crime, you'd think twice about going over it again. He was 50 percent dead. ... There's no doubt that's how he feels.'' David's parents, who brought their son here from Haiti in 1988, speak little English. They have kept a daily vigil at the hospital, as has their teen-age daughter Naomi. The boy was on his way to school when a bully forced him into a building, tied him to a railing and set him afire, police said. David, who allegedly was robbed by the same boy a day earlier, suffered burns over 55 percent of his body. David initially told relatives he was torched because he refused to smoke crack. But police filed no drug charges against the suspect and now believe his only motive was being a bully. The alleged assailant was arrested hours after the attack and has been jailed at a juvenile center. David was in critical condition for most of his hospitalization. Doctors put his chances of survival at 50-50, fearing any complication could kill him. He is now in stable condition, Manners said, but faces years of treatment. He is badly scarred by the burns, does not have full use of one arm and will go from the burn unit to a rehabilitation center. But he already is taking short walks around the hospital and may speak with reporters next week, Lavoile said. ``I think it's going to be amazing, to see him back as a normal person, to see him back on the streets,'' his cousin said. David's plight touched hearts throughout the city and nation. More than $280,000 poured into a fund established to cover his medical expenses. He was visited by Ronald and Nancy Reagan, Bill Cosby, Vice President Dan Quayle and the Rev. Jesse Jackson. David marked his 12th birthday one day after the attack, and the hospital was flooded with hundreds of cards, gifts and flowers. Mayor David Dinkins, another visitor, used the boy as a metaphor for the city in his May 11 call for racial harmony in New York. ``Like the city in which he lives, young David is suffering. He's scarred and he struggles to overcome the damage that anger has inflicted on him,'' the mayor said. Yet Dinkins saw a bright future for the boy. ``When I see him, I see life in his eyes,'' he said. ``Despite all he's seen, David's eyes are wide open, looking not behind him in fright but ahead in the fond hope that he will heal and move on.''

DOC.HEAD: Form of Vitamin A Turns Cancer Cells into Normal Ones
DOC.TEXT: In a unique assault on leukemia, doctors have found that a form of vitamin A will turn cancer cells into normal ones. Medicine's usual way of combating cancer is to kill it. Doctors administer powerful toxic drugs in the hopes that they will destroy more cancerous cells than healthy ones. The new approach instead tries to reform cancer cells. It changes the cells' genetic program, bypassing the genetic mix up that makes them kill. In this way, the treatment induces the cancer cells to live, to grow and eventually to die by the same rules that govern the rest of the body. The drug, a synthetic form of vitamin A called all-trans retinoic acid, was developed in China and tested in France. Though it has drawbacks and works in just one rare form of leukemia, doctors hope it will provide clues for short-circuiting the basic errors that underlie all cancers. ``The dogma has been to try to kill cancer cells,'' said Dr. Laurent Degos. ``Is it possible to change a cell, and not kill it, so it becomes normal?'' Degos, a researcher at Hopital Saint-Louis in Paris, presented evidence that this indeed is possible in a report Tuesday at the annual meeting of the American Society of Clinical Oncology. He tested the drug on victims of acute promyelocytic leukemia, a rare blood cancer that strikes a few hundred people in the United States each year. All of them had failed earlier standard therapy. He achieved complete, though often temporary, elimination of all signs of the disease in 16 of 17 patients who had relapsed for the first time. There was complete remission in one of four patients who had relapsed a second time. ``There was no killing of cells, but they change,'' said Degos. ``We see more mature cells.'' This form of leukemia is caused by a specific genetic defect, the mislocation of a piece of one string of genes, or chromosome, onto another chromosome. As a result, the cells get stuck in their juvenile stage. They fail to mature normally and eventually die. Treatment with all-trans retinoic acid appears to bump the cells past this roadblock in their development so they grow old. ``This is a smashing development,'' commented Dr. Charles Schiffer of the University of Maryland. ``It has impressed even the most cynical. This is a different approach to anything we have done in this disease in the past.'' Dr. Bruce Chesen of the National Cancer Institute said the institute plans soon to sponsor four small safety studies of the drug. Once those are done, it will begin a larger review of its effectiveness. Though the synthetic vitamin wiped out obvious signs of the leukemia, the disease frequently came back, apparently because some cancer cells were resistant to the drug. Degas said it may be necessary to combine the treatment with standard chemotherapy to try to obliterate the few remaining cancer cells. The drug was developed in China by Wang Zeng Yi, dean of Shanghai University II, a French-speaking medical school. It is now being produced by Hoffman LaRoche, the pharmaceutical firm. In an earlier report, doctors said they found that the acne medicine Accutane, another synthetic form of vitamin A, prevents new tumors from developing in people treated for smoking-related throat cancer. Among other research presented at the meeting: _Dr. Steven A. Rosenberg of the National Cancer Institute outlined the first results of his pioneering attempt to insert foreign genes into cancer patients. The initial effort, carried out on seven melanoma patients, was intended to show that gene therapy is possible. Doctors removed cancer-fighting blood cells from the patients' tumors, inserted a bacteria gene into them and then put them back into the patients' bodies. The manipulated cells zeroed in on their tumors. The doctors hope soon to repeat the experiment, this time inserting a gene that produces a cancer-killing chemical called tumer necrosis factor. _A survey of American and Caribbean blacks in central Brooklyn showed that a surprising 4 percent were infected with cancer-causing human T-cell leukemia virus Type 1, or HTLV-I. Dr. Harvey Dosik of Interfaith Medical Center in Brooklyn said the infection rate is 200 times higher than that seen nationwide in blood donors. _Dr. Lode J. Swinnen of Loyola University in Chicago said he had found evidence that OKT3, an antibody treatment widely given to recipients of organ transplants, significantly increases their risk of non-Hodgkins lymphoma, a blood cancer. He reviewed 154 heart transplant patients and found that 11 percent of those getting OKT3 since 1986 had developed the disease.

DOC.HEAD: Senator Threatens To Hold Up Nomination
DOC.TEXT: The ranking Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee is threatening a delay in the confirmation of a top Pentagon nominee until a dispute over civilian oversight of intelligence activities is resolved. Sen. John Warner of Virginia expressed concern Tuesday over a classified memorandum in which the head of Special Operations Command proposed sole Defense Department oversight of military intelligence actions. ``Prior approval process of these activities now involve agencies other than the Defense Department, as it should,'' Warner said. ``But reportedly under the proposal only the secretary of defense, on behalf of the National Command Authority, would have to approve such activities.'' The memo was written by Gen. James Lindsay, commander of the Special Operations Command. Warner told Lt. Gen. Carl Stiner, President Bush's choice to replace Lindsay, that the issue of civilian oversight could hold up his confirmation to the Defense Department post. ``It may well be that this senator feels that that issue is going to have to be resolved prior to such time as this committee completes the work on your nomination,'' Warner told Stiner. The nominee said he was not familiar with the memo but promised an immediate review and recommendation to Powell after his confirmation. The controversy centers on the Defense Department's Special Operations, a combatant command of specially trained Defense Department forces who operate in peace or war. The units can either support conventional forces or act in their place. Warner expressed concerns that the defining of activities as intelligence gathering would be done without oversight from agencies other than the Defense Department. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Armed Services Committee, said he shared Warner's concerns and the ranking members of the Senate's Intelligence Committee harbor similar misgivings. ``We want to make sure that our special operations forces have the right kind of intelligence,'' Nunn said. ``We want to make sure that the CIA does its job. We want to make sure that intelligence areas of the Defense Department do their job but we also absolutely insist that the civilian oversight of those intelligence activities not be lost. ``That's the bottom line,'' Nunn said.

DOC.HEAD: FDIC Lost Money in 1989, Following Larger Loss in 1988
DOC.TEXT: For only the second time in its history, the federal fund that insures deposits at the nation's banks lost money in 1989. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. reported that its insurance fund lost $851 million in 1989 following an even bigger loss of $4.24 billion in 1988. The back-to-back losses were blamed on a post-Depression record number of bank failures. In 1988, 221 banks failed or required government assistance to remain open. That number declined only slightly to 207 in 1989. FDIC Chairman L. William Seidman estimated Tuesday that 150 to 175 banks probably would fail this year but that the fund still should be able to return to profitability if none of the failures involves a large institution. However, he conceded that his estimate was highly dependent on the health of the overall economy. ``Much depends on future interest rates and future real estate markets,'' he told reporters. A big part of the 1989 loss was blamed on the failure of the 20-bank MCorp. based in Dallas, which it is estimated will cost the government $2 billion, making it the second biggest bank failure in history. Last year's loss to the FDIC fund came because the agency was forced to pay out more to take over the failed banks than it received in insurance premiums paid by healthy banks. For 1989, the FDIC had liquidation expenses of $4.13 billion. That compared to $7.36 billion it spent on failed banks in 1988. ``Although the bank fund declined in 1989, the drop was considerably less severe than the previous year,'' Seidman said. A financial institution becomes insolvent when the value of its assets, primarily in the form of loans it makes, drops below the level of its liabilities, represented by its customers' deposits. The amount of money left in the bank insurance fund at the end of 1989 was $13.21 billion. That represented 0.7 percent of insured deposits, far below the 1.25 percent level set as a goal by Congress. By comparison, in 1987 the FDIC fund stood at $18.3 billion, representing 1.10 percent of insured deposits, during a year when 193 banks failed or required government assistance. Despite the losses in 1988 and 1989, analysts said they believed the FDIC would be able to escape the sort of trouble that beset the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corp., the sister fund set up to insure deposits at savings and loan institutions. A record number of S&L failures pushed the FSLIC into insolvency, forcing Congress to step in with the costliest bailout in U.S. history. Robert Litan of the Brookings Institution said he believed Congress had learned some painful lessons from the S&L crisis and would act quickly to prevent a similar occurrence in the banking fund. ``In order for this situation to be like the thrifts, you would have to have both a recession and a congressional refusal to recognize reality,'' he said. He said Congress and the administration were slow to respond to the S&L crisis, forcing regulators to keep sick S&Ls open while their losses mounted, making the ultimate bailout costs even more expensive. ``The key lesson we learned is don't delay,'' he said. ``The thrift crisis got out of hand because Congress and the regulators did not act.''

DOC.HEAD: No. 1 Rating Goes to `America's Funniest Home Videos'
With PM-Nielsens-List
DOC.TEXT: TV viewers can't get enough of ``America's Funniest Home Videos.'' The deep desire to watch ourselves being ourselves _ as recorded by ourselves _ lifted the ABC show into the No. 1 spot in the ratings last week, according to figures released Tuesday by the A.C. Nielsen Co. On Monday, as part of its preview of the fall season, the network announced it had finally come up with a companion for its top-rated show _ ``America's Funniest ... Part II.'' The shows will run back-to-back, proving that imitation is the sincerest form of cashing in on hit programming. During the Sunday night show, $100,000 was awarded to the best video submitted during the season. The grand prize went to a clip of a man who snagged and lost his pants on a fence as he tried to catch a baseball. As the May ``sweeps'' period comes to a close, NBC recaptured first place from CBS, which landed the No. 1 spot for the first time in two years for the week ended May 13. Ratings during the sweeps period are used to set ad rates. For the week ended May 20, CBS was back in its usual last place with an 11.2 average. ABC was second with 11.5 and NBC led with 11.7. Each ratings point represents 921,000 households. Repeats of NBC's ``Cheers'' and ABC's ``Roseanne'' came in second and third, respectively. And reruns of ``The Cosby Show'' and its spinoff, ``A Different World,'' both on NBC, ranked fourth and fifth. CBS had three shows in the top 10 _ ``Murphy Brown,'' ``Designing Women'' and ``60 Minutes.'' The season finale of NBC's ``L.A. Law,'' which saw the yuppie law firm hold on to heartthrob actor Harry Hamlin after teasing viewers with his apparent departure, rose to ninth place. Friday's two-hour movie ``Return to Green Acres,'' reuniting Arnold the Pig, Eddie Albert and Eva Gabor, won its time slot on CBS with an 11.8 average. The murky, much-hyped soap opera ``Twin Peaks,'' tied for 40th place. No matter. ABC announced ``Twin Peaks'' will be back in the fall, bad ratings or no. Here are the top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC, 25.2; ``Cheers,'' NBC, 18.9; ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 17.7; ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC, 17.4; ``A Different World,'' NBC, 17.1; ``Murphy Brown,'' CBS, 16.8; ``Designing Women,'' CBS, 16.7; ``NBC Sunday Night Movie Perry Mason: The Case of the Silenced Singer,'' NBC, 16.5; ``L.A. Law,'' NBC, 16; and ``60 Minutes,'' CBS, 15.8. ``Elvis'' on ABC is really dead and so are its ratings. The network canceled the show and with apparent good reason. It tied for last place at No. 83 with ``Booker'' on Fox. In the news battle, ABC and Peter Jennings were No. 1, with a 9.6 average. Dan Rather and CBS were No. 2 with 8.5, followed by NBC and Tom Brokaw with 8.3.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Agreeing On Need To Limit Independent Campaign Spending
DOC.TEXT: Key senators working on campaign finance reform are finding common ground in a desire to curb how much money special interest groups can spend independently on behalf of a candidate. Leading Republican and Democratic lawmakers also agreed behind closed doors Tuesday to cut the rates broadcasters charge for political ads and to jointly tackle millionaire candidates' use of their fortunes to finance their races. ``There are some areas we have a good chance of agreeing on,'' Sen. Mitch McConnell, R-Ky., head of the five-member GOP team, said Tuesday after the first of what are expected to be dozens of closed meetings over the next several weeks. ``We tried not to harp on the areas of disagreement.'' McConnell and Oklahoma Sen. David Boren, head of the Democratic negotiating team, said members of both parties have been victims of 11th-hour TV ads on behalf of a candidate by so-called independent political action committees. ``In very general terms, neither side is very happy with independent expenditures,'' McConnell said. As an example, he cited the hundreds of thousands of dollars an imported car dealers' PAC poured into key House and Senate races in 1988 on the basis of how candidates had voted on trade issues. The negotiations taking place in an office just off the Senate floor are aimed at preventing campaign finance reform efforts from degenerating into a Democrat vs. Republican fight like it did two years ago. Boren said they will be patterned along the two months of private meetings earlier this year that produced a compromise clean air bill passed by the Senate last month and being debated this week in the House. ``We've not set a particular time frame,'' Boren said. ``But we're going to operate under a rule that no decision is final until everything is final. Obviously some decisions on individual items will depend on what the overall framework of an agreement is.'' Democrats have insisted that any reform proposal must contain fixed state-by-state ceilings on how much candidates can spend. A majority of Republicans reject campaign ceilings and are demanding measures to curb Democrats' historic reliance on unions for their get-out-the-vote efforts. Both bills contain provisions that would prohibit TV and radio stations from charging candidates campaign ad rates often two to three times higher than what commercial advertisers pay. To prevent millionaire candidates from using their fortunes to overwhelm opponents in a spending race, Senate Democrats would impose a $20,000 ceiling on the amount an office seeker can personally spend on his or her campaign. Republicans approach the issue from the other direction, requiring a wealthy candidate to say well before an election how much of his own money he plans to spend on the race. If it is more than $250,000, the Republican measure would allow an opponent to tap wealthy contributors up to $5,000 each instead of the current $1,000 ceiling on individual contributions. If a candidate spends more than $1 million of his or her own money, there would be no limit on how much a wealthy benefactor could contribute to an opponent.

DOC.HEAD: Report Recommends Cutting Conventional Forces While Boosting NATO
DOC.TEXT: The United States can respond to the lessening Soviet threat by significantly reducing its conventional forces but must strengthen its European alliances, says a congressional study. The report recommended that the Bush administration consider ``parallel paths'' of continued reliance on NATO and attempts to make arrangements, such as the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, stronger. ``Along one path, the United States could seek to revise NATO's policies, doctrines and forces to take into account the new political and military situation in Europe,'' said the report by the Congressional Research Service.
