The report suggested that strengthening of the CSCE could be done by a legal treaty foundation and institutionalizing conventional arms control negotiations. ``Both goals could be adopted at a CSCE summit later in 1990,'' said the report released on Tuesday. In light of the push toward democracy in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, the United States will be able to reduce its military forces in Europe from more than 300,000 to less than 100,000 by the middle of the decade, the report said. U.S. influence in Europe would depend more on its political and economic roles rather than military strength. Stanley R. Sloan, senior specialist in International Security Policy at the Congressional Research Service, prepared the report at the request of Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee. Nunn said the study ``offers a thoughtful and well-reasoned set of policy prescriptions for U.S. and allied decision-makers to ponder as they prepare for the July NATO summit in London.''

DOC.HEAD: Brides, Vision Obscured By Veils, Marry Wrong Men
DOC.TEXT: Two Hindu brides, their vision obstructed by long veils, married the wrong men _ giving new meaning to the expression ``Love is blind.'' The Times of India said today that two marriage parties arrived at the same time Tuesday in Patan village in the central Indian state of Madhya Pradesh. The ceremonies were rushed, and the long veils obscured the brides' vision, preventing them from picking out their true fiances, the report said. Following Hindu tradition, one bride circled a fire with a bridegroom seven times, sealing the marriage. The other bride then completed ``the seven steps'' with the second bridegroom, the paper said. When they lifted their veils, the brides discovered they had married the wrong men. But village elders said that ``the seven perambulations around the sacred fire'' were final and there could be no exchange of spouses, the paper said. Most marriages in rural India are arranged, especially among Hindus who comprise 82 percent of India's 880 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Higher
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed Wednesday at 32,176.51, up 238.21 points, or 0.75 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: EPA Reviewing Report On Link Between Cancer And Electrical Power Lines
DOC.TEXT: An Environmental Protection Agency study still under scientific review suggests that there is increasing evidence of a link between heavy electrical currents and some types of cancer. The study, an EPA official said Tuesday, shows that research over the last decade has established at least a tentative connection between leukemia and some other cancers, and the slowly varying magnetic fields created by powerful alternating electric currents. Richard Guimond, director of EPA's Office of Radiation, said the report has no original research, but rather is a review of a variety of scientific studies of the human body effects of long-term exposure to magnetic fields created by power lines. At one time, he said, studies showed no link between electrical current and human cancer. The new report, however, said Guimond, ``suggests that there is in fact stronger and stronger evidence being developed as more and more of these studies are done.'' After the report is reviewed by a group of scientists, it will be available for public review sometime this summer, probably in July, he said. Until then, he said, ``We can't say that it is final and what the final conclusions are going to be.''
DOC.HEAD: Senator Criticizes Romania Government's Election Behavior
DOC.TEXT: Romania's newly formed government tolerated violence and voter intimidation before last Sunday's national elections, says the co-leader of an international observer team. Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn., just back from Bucharest after monitoring Romania's first free elections in 53 years, said Tuesday the United States should supply humanitarian aid immediately. But he said further aid should be conditioned on the new government's ability to move toward democracy. ``There was a lot of unfairness in the pre-election process,'' Lieberman told reporters. ``Some of it was intentional by the government party and some of it was unintentional.'' A problem facing the opposition parties, he said, was a lack of time to organize a campaign against the governing party, which dominated media outlets. ``What happened on Sunday was a significant step forward toward democracy but there is a lot more to be done,'' Lieberman said. ``They've come a long way; they deserve some help. But they also need some pressure to continue to move toward more human rights, more political freedom, and greater recognition of the rights of minorities, particularly Hungarians.''
DOC.HEAD: Minorities Underrepresented in Peace Corps, Congress Told
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 30 years after the Peace Corps was founded by President John F. Kennedy, the General Accounting Office says the agency is still perceived as a white middle-class institution. Only about 7 percent of the agency's roughly 6,300 volunteers are minorities, a congressional investigative agency found. And through 1988, no minorities held any of the top 20 management jobs at the agency. ``Efforts to improve the Peace Corps' minority profile in the past have been short-lived and costly,'' the GAO said Tuesday. It called for a long-term strategy to correct the problem. The underrepresentation of minorities in the Peace Corps has made it difficult for the agency to teach foreign peoples about the racially diverse American culture, the study said. Congressional researchers acknowledged, however, that the Peace Corps ``has historically experienced great difficulty attracting sufficient number of minorities to serve as volunteers.'' Part of the problem stems from the lower economic status of blacks and other minorities, the study said, who ``believe that they cannot afford to volunteer two years of their lives to Peace Corps service.'' But it said minorities also ``tend to see the Peace Corps as a white middle-class organization.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Agrees to Visit Mapplethorpe Exhibit
DOC.TEXT: A judge says he will visit an exhibit of Robert Mapplethorpe photographs before considering a request to dismiss obscenity charges against the art gallery showing the pictures. Municipal Judge David Albanese also set a hearing for Thursday to consider a request for changes that would make the indictment against the Contemporary Arts Center conform to U.S. Supreme Court obscenity standards. The judge said Tuesday he will view the photos before the six-week exhibit closes Saturday. H. Louis Sirkin, a lawyer for the Arts Center, applauded the decision. Defense lawyers argue that the 175-photo exhibit doesn't violate obscenity standards when viewed as a whole. Seven pictures were cited by prosecutors. The lawyer said he will oppose attempts by prosecutors to alter the indictment against the museum and its director, Dennis Barrie. Sirkin said any changes must come from a grand jury, not a judge. Barrie and the gallery are charged with pandering obscenity and using children in material involving nudity. If convicted they face $6,000 in fines, and Barrie also faces six months in jail. More than 67,000 people have seen the exhibit. A showing of Mapplethorpe's photos in Washington stirred national debate last year over government support of the arts. At the urging of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., Congress barred funding for certain sexually explicit works. The museum and its director argue that the judge should dismiss the charges because the photographs are art. Senior Assistant City Prosecutor Frank H. Prouty Jr. said the city wants the indictment to specify that two pictures of nude children in the exhibit include ``a lewd, graphic exhibition of the genitals.'' The indictment issued April 7 says the exhibit includes ``a photograph of a minor male child ... with his genitals exposed, and a photograph of a minor female child ... with her genitals exposed.'' Prouty also asked to add a phrase alleging that five pictures of sex acts in the exhibit are obscene under the three-part test established by the Supreme Court in a 1973 decision. That decision said that to be ruled obscene, material must violate local community standards, depict clearly offensive sexual conduct and lack artistic value. The judge also agreed to accept a brief filed by the Cincinnati chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union in favor of dismissing the charges.

DOC.HEAD: Steel Beams Fall, Kill 3 Workers
DOC.TEXT: Investigators ruled out a design flaw in the collapse of five 50-foot steel beams that killed three workers at Ohio State University. But officials said it may take weeks to determine the cause of Tuesday morning's accident, which also injured a worker. The workers were erecting a four-story glass and granite building that will house a state computer center.They were on the roof bolting on a 10-foot cantilever, a section of beam that extends outward without the support of a vertical column, said Richard T. Lombardi, vice president of Turner Construction. The cantilever fell, causing five beams to drop, Lombardi said. He estimated 75 to 100 workers were in the area at the time. The worker who was injured was listed in fair condition. An official of the Ohio Department of Industrial Relations said the deaths were caused by human error or structural failure. ``It's real hard to tell how it happened,'' said Elmer Waltz, chief of the factory and building division. ``But design had nothing to do with the accident.'' Waltz said the accident could have been caused by a worker misdirecting the crane moving the steel or by a bolt shearing away from one of the beams.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls, Stocks Move Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended sharply lower against the yen Wednesday, while the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange closed moderately higher. The dollar closed at 151.35 yen, down 1.05 yen from Tuesday's 152.40-yen finish. The currency opened at 151.65 yen and ranged between 150.60 yen and 152.00 yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average gained 238.21 points, or 0.75 percent, ending the day at 32,176.51. The price of the benchmark No.119 10-year Japanese government bond rose to 87.74 from Tuesday's close of 87.45. That dropped the yield to 7.015 percent from 7.075 percent. ``Trading was very rough,'' said Minori Takeuchi, a currency dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. She said the dollar, which started lower in Tokyo following its overnight decline in New York, fell further as market players bought the yen against the West German mark, as well as the dollar, for technical adjustments. ``But the market has not determined the dollar's direction, and it is unlikely to fall below the 150-yen line, where investors tend to pick up the U.S. currency.'' Ms. Takeuchi said. Stock traders attributed the Nikkei's gain to index-linked buying in early trading as well as to the yen's recovery against the dollar. They said participants bought issues in the spot market to take profits from price gaps between the spot and the futures market.

DOC.HEAD: Front Success Rooted In Communist Past, Not Election Fraud
AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Few here were surprised by the landslide victory of Interim President Ion Iliescu. Although the opposition claimed vote fraud, Iliescu's success appears more a result of the nation's Communist past and its desire for stability. Iliescu and his National Salvation Front, who have dominated the government since the December revolution that ousted dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, will be the first ex-Communists to triumph in Eastern Europe's current series of multiparty elections. With nearly all ballots counted Tuesday night, Iliescu had captured 86 percent of the vote and the National Salvation Front had more than two-thirds of the seats in the two-chamber Parliament. Iliescu's challengers _ the National Liberal Party's Radu Campeanu and the National Peasant Party's Ion Ratiu _ claimed the campaign was undemocratic, and that the voting process was manipulated by the Front in a manner reminiscent of falsified elections under the former regime. But while many of the 500-odd foreign observers agreed that the election had some flaws, most appear to believe the results should be accepted. Gov. Garrey E. Carruthers of New Mexico, the official U.S. government observer, called the poll ``a good election'' and ``a very giant step toward toward democracy.'' Harry McCubbin, a British Labor Party parliamentarian, noted that ``the size of the results we're getting would indicate that any errors at the poll would not have made any difference in the result whatsoever.'' More than 85 percent of the 16 million eligible voters cast ballots in Sunday's election, the first in which people had a choice in decades. The victorious Front portrays itself as a modern social-democratic party, but critics say it is merely a renamed version of the Romanian Communist Party. Because of its close identification with December's uprising, the Front won a legitimacy lacked by other reformed communists. Most Romanians view Iliescu primarily as the kindly but authoritative figure who announced the arrest of Ceausescu while bullets flew outside the revolutionary headquarters at the TV studio Dec. 22 _ risking his life to bring the country its first breath of freedom in decades. Iliescu, who was a Communist minister under Ceausescu in the early 1970s, now argues vehemently that communism is dead in Romania. When intellectuals accuse the Front of ``neo-communism,'' they are referring less to discredited economic theories than to the suffocating, bureaucratic mentality they associate with the old regime. Indeed, while the Communist Party as an institution is gone and many of the more visible leaders have been dismissed or punished, the old bureaucracy is still firmly in place. Iliescu's inner circle is itself divided between older members with links to the Ceausescu regime and younger types, with a more Western orientation, who press for more radical change. This generation gap appears to be widespread. In many cases younger people voted for the Liberals or Peasant Party, while their parents, wary of a real upheaval which might threaten their jobs, opted for the Front. The long years of oppression worked to the Front's advantage as well. Bowing to authorities is firmly ingrained in many Romanians. Some, especially in rural and outlying areas, found it difficult to conceive of voting for anyone but the party in power. Romania's media are still controlled by the state, and the opposition parties have accused the Front of manipulating TV coverage to its advantage and of causing the paper and ink shortages and distribution problems that have plagued their newspapers. While the Front denies this, Iliescu has prevented the establishment of independent TV stations and alternatives to the state-run publishing house. The opposition was hurt by organizational problems as well, one of the reasons why it originally sought to delay elections. Iliescu benefited from the opposition's inability to unite behind one candidate. Campeanu and Ratiu are elderly former exiles vulnerable to charges that they did not understand the needs of today's Romania. Ratiu, who spent the past 50 years in England, alienated some voters by emphasizing his ties to the West and his constant references to ``my friend Maggie Thatcher.'' The Front's ideologue, Silviu Brucan, said his party benefited by ``giving the workers what Ceausescu didn't ... a 40-hour work week ... here was a government that for the first time cared for their basic needs.'' The undecided voters, he said, saw the Front as ``the only party they felt could ensure their desire for tranquility ... Romanians had reached a point of saturation with violence and tension.''

DOC.HEAD: Most Ex-Smokers are Quitting By Themselves, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: People who try to quit smoking on their own succeed twice as often as those who enroll in programs, researchers reported today. The reason may be that the help-seekers are largely hard-core smokers, they said. A 1986 nationwide telephone survey of more than 13,000 adult smokers showed that of those who tried to kick the habit within the previous 10 years, 47.5 percent who tried solo succeeded up for a year or more, the researchers said. Only 23.6 percent of those in kick-the-habit programs made it for that long, the scientists said in the Journal of the American Medical Association. Thus smokers who try to quit on their own are more likely to succeed, but programs serve a ``limited but important public health role,'' researchers said. Such programs are treating ``the most addicted, most hard-core,'' said Dr. Michael C. Fiore, head of the study. ``And these hard-core smokers are most at risk for the terrible health consequences of smoking,'' Fiore, a professor of medicine at the University of Wisconsin, said in a telephone interview. Forty million Americans have stopped smoking, but more than 71 million are still puffing, up to a third of whom try to quit annually, the researchers reported. Less than 10 percent succeed each year, the researchers said. Overall, people who succeeded tended to be older and more educated but were equally likely to be heavy smokers _ 25 or more cigarettes a day _ as those who failed. More than 70 percent who tried to quit had been urged to do so by a doctor. The American Cancer Society offers self-help material for smokers trying to quit, including supporting the annual Great American Smokeout. It also has its FreshStart kick-the-habit program. That program recorded a 14 percent success rate in a recent study, led by Dr. Harry A. Lando of the University of Minnesota, who agreed with Fiore's assessment that such programs tend to draw the most addicted smokers. But ``the best group programs get 40 percent success _ that is for intense kind of treatment,'' Lando said. Smoking is blamed for 390,000 U.S. deaths a year. About 1.3 million smokers quit every year, but their ranks are being replenished by 1 million people annually _ mostly young people _ who start smoking, Fiore said. Another report in today's JAMA said tobacco companies and federal and state governments reap more than $500 million a year from sales of tobacco products to minors, accounting for 3.3 percent of the domestic market. The estimate was based largely on federal surveys of smoking patterns among youngsters, on tobacco company sales and profits and on tax rates, said authors Dr. Joseph R. DiFranza of the University of Massachusetts Medical School at Fitchburg and Joe B. Tye of Baystate Medical Center in Springfield. Thomas Lauria, spokesman for the Tobacco Institute, an industry trade group, called the report a ``preposterous economic analysis.'' He said the authors ``start off with the erroneous assumption that the industry targets kids, and extrapolate from there.'' He added, ``So they not only build sand castles in the air, they fly flags up the sand castles.''

DOC.HEAD: Moonwalker, Watergate Figure Taking Care of Business in Moscow
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: When they first met 21 years ago on the deck of the aircraft carrier USS Hornet, Edwin ``Buzz'' Aldrin and H.R. ``Bob'' Haldeman were at the pinnacles of their professions. Astronaut Aldrin had returned from the Apollo 11 lunar landing with Neil Armstrong and Michael Collins. Haldeman, the chief of staff to President Richard Nixon who had taken office six months earlier, accompanied his boss to meet the returning heroes. The two men fell hard in the years after that July 24, 1969 meeting, one disgraced by scandal and the other suffering painful personal trials. Now they've resurfaced together in the 1990s, pitching a hotel and business complex in post-Cold War Moscow. Haldeman and Aldrin participated Tuesday in a signing ceremony during a meeting of the U.S.-U.S.S.R. Trade and Economic Council. They represent Americom International Corp., an office technology concern in Irvine, Calif., which will operate the facility along with Radisson Hotels International of Minneapolis. The companies signed an agreement with the Soviet travel organization Intourist to operate the 430-room, 165-office building on the Moscow River. In addition to being the first U.S.-managed hotel in the Soviet Union, it will also have direct satellite communications links to the West, geared to business travelers. Aldrin, who suffered from depression, alcoholism and two divorces after becoming the second man to walk on the moon, is now an aerospace consultant. He described how he managed to be in the ``right place at the right time'' 27 years ago in being selected for the U.S. space program. ``And I look on this particular venture here _ to open up the opportunities for East-West trade _ again as being an opportunity coming my way, and Bob's, ... to be in the right place at the right time,'' said Aldrin, 60. Haldeman, who was convicted of obstruction of justice and conspiracy in the Watergate scandal, served 18 months in prison. He said he is in business along with several other small entrepreneurs ``in a peculiarly wide range of things'' _ owning a steakhouse franchise in Miami, a high-tech company in Santa Barbara, Calif., called Conductive Rubber Technology, and a real estate syndication business in Los Angeles. When asked if the Soviets he meets ever bring up that other office and residential complex in his life _ Watergate _ Haldeman stares and tersely answers no. ``The reaction I find here and really throughout all the world, other than the United States, is only one of wonderment as to what on earth the country could have been doing to throw that guy out on what any other country regards as a ridiculous farce, rather than anything of any major substance,'' he said. Haldeman also admits to being a fan of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ``I can only say having observed one politician very closely with a remarkable ability for survival and recovery, and watching Gorbachev, I have utmost admiration for his political skills,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney, Rights Activist Slain
DOC.TEXT: A 37-year-old attorney who successfully agitated against police torture in northern Mexico's Sinaloa state was killed by unidentified gunmen, police said. Norma Corona Sapienz was shot Monday night near the Sinaloa Autonomous University where she used to teach law, said Adriana Leyva of the state judicial police. ``The impact of her death has been tremendous here,'' said Leyva, also a spokeswoman for the state bar association. Coronal Sapienz was president of the state bar here. Leyva spoke Tuesday in a telephone interview. A police report said Corona Sapienz's automobile was intercepted by three gunmen in a pickup. It cited witnesses as saying two of the men apparently tried to kidnap her, but she tried to flee on foot. The two then opened fire, jumped back into the pickup truck and fled, the report said. An autopsy indicated she was shot five times. Maj. Lorenzo Goroztiza, state judicial police commander, told reporters 12 people in pickup trucks similar to that used by the gunmen have been detained for questioning. Last week, the state legislature mandated 10 years imprisonment for any police officer convicted of torture. The State Commission for the Defense of Human Rights, which Corona Sapienz headed, had long been pressing for such legislation. Sinaloa and its capital, Culiacan, have been major centers for smuggling drugs to the United States. Murders and human rights abuses are common. For the past two years, Corona Sapienz had been complaining to journalists about receiving anonymous death threats. Corona Sapienz defended a fellow Sinaloa lawyer and three Venezuelans charged with drug trafficking who were kidnapped and killed under mysterious circumstances in February. State and federal judicial authorities claimed the lawyer, Jesus Guemes Castro, and Venezuelans Victor Suate, Jose Vladimir Arzonaly and Jose Glaciano Planchart were killed by drug traffickers in retaliation for the murder of a drug baron's wife and daughter. The killings brought protests from the Venezuelan government. Corona Sapienz publicly accused the federal attorney general's office at the time of dragging its feet in investigating the multiple murders.

DOC.HEAD: Dumped Salmon Creates Fishy Situation
DOC.TEXT: Wildlife officials went fishing for answers when anglers started hauling in salmon from a trout pond. It turned out that two workers taking the salmon from a state hatchery to protected waters in a reservoir had decided to ``liberate'' some of them, said Carl Prescott, deputy director of the Division of Fisheries and Wildlife. The 850 fish, their fins clipped for identification, were dumped May 9 in Snow's Pond near the small town of Ware. Wildlife officials heard about the salmon bonanza in Ware two days later, Prescott said Tuesday. ``Somebody stopped by and saw all these kids having a whale of a time of it and identified these fish as salmon and reported them to us,'' Prescott said. The fish are landlocked salmon, which are about 6 to 9 inches long, smaller than their better-known cousins, the Atlantic salmon. ``I suppose that the fish were probably a little scrappier to catch but there were so many at that site that the ease of catching them and the numbers being caught would have made some good fishing,'' Prescott said. The two workers involved in the dumping face a hearing on the matter. The men said that the fish were ``under stress,'' so they released them, Prescott.

DOC.HEAD: Hearst-Izvestia to Publish Joint Weekly Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet newspaper Izvestia and the Hearst Corp. plan to test market a weekly paper in both superpower countries starting on the Fourth of July. American and Soviet journalists will work together on the newspaper to be jointly edited at Hearst's Washington news bureau, Hearst announced Tuesday. Some 25,000 copies of the newspaper, which will be called WE-Miy, are slated to be distributed to government, business and education leaders in Moscow, Leningrad, Kiev, Washington and other U.S. cities. Miy, pronounced ``mwee,'' is Russian for ``we.'' In the newspaper's logo, it will be a Cyrillic character. ``Glasnost has opened tremendous opportunities and new opportunities demand new journalism,'' Vladimir Nadeine, Washington correspondent for Izvestia said in a statement. ``With this issue of WE-Miy, we have started to push glasnost further and further _ to the plain and simple press freedom we need.'' Hearst said the paper will cover political, economic, social issues and in both countries and will include fashion, sports, arts and entertainment news. ``The Soviet-American interchange has a vitality and tension derived from the clash of values, power drives, cultural differences and national interest,'' said WE-Miy editor Jerrold L. Schecter. ``We intend to explore these differences and similarities in depth.'' Izvestia, with a daily circulation of 11 million, is the newspaper of the Soviet government and the Congress of People's Deputies. Hearst publishes 14 consumer magazines, 12 daily and three non-daily newspapers and numerous business publications. It also operates seven radio and six TV stations.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Debates Abortion Bill
DOC.TEXT: Canada's Parliament has begun debating an abortion bill that would allow abortion if a doctor believes the physical, mental or psychological health of a pregnant woman is threatened. The bill has split Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's governing party and is opposed by both pro- and anti-abortion lobbies. Parliamentarians from all parties have proposed two dozen amendments, most designed to tighten the restrictions. The pro-choice lobby is fighting the law because it says there have been no restrictions for the past two years and none are needed now. Anti-abortion forces say the bill doesn't go far enough. The bill, on which debate began Tuesday, is aimed at filling the void left when the Supreme Court struck down a previous law restricting abortions in January 1988. The court said the old measure was arbitrary and violated women's rights. About 60,000 abortions were performed in Canada last year. Mulroney supports the bill but has given his Conservative Party lawmakers freedom to vote their consciences. The future of the bill seems to rest on how many of his legislators switch sides and vote against the government. The final vote is scheduled May 29. Under the old law, abortions were allowed if they were approved by a hospital's therapeutic abortion committee, which had to have at least three doctors. The life and health of the woman were the only criteria. It was a cumbersome, often agonizingly slow procedure. There was no single standard, and acceptable reasons for abortion varied across the country. Under the government's proposal, the judgment of a single doctor would be sufficient to determine that the physical, mental or psychological health of a pregnant woman is threatened. Requiring medical opinion on the need for abortion appears to be a gesture toward the anti-abortion forces. At the same time, the Justice Department says the wording of the proposed law is broad enough to permit abortion on social or economic grounds. ``It pretends to be a pro-life bill,'' said Margaret Purcell, national vice-president for the anti-abortion Campaign Life Coalition organization. ``But under the bill, a woman would only have to walk through her doctor's door and she has established that she is psychologically unwell,'' she said. The pro-choice Canadian Abortion Rights Action League opposes the bill for different reasons. ``This law will make some abortions criminal,'' said Jane Holmes, executive coordinator for the lobbying group. ``This is insulting legislation. This is a primary women's issue.'' Pro-choice advocates complain the legislation does nothing to ensure access in provinces like Prince Edward Island, where no abortions have been performed for eight years because no doctors are willing to do them. The group's president, Kit Holmwood, said she believes anti-abortion forces will press for charges against any woman who has an abortion. ``They have done it in the (United) States. They are going to take this law and use it any way they can to stop abortion,'' she said. The measure calls for up to two years in prison for a doctor who defies the law or a woman who lies about her health. It says all abortions are criminal unless ``induced by or under the direction of a medical practitioner who is of the opinion that, if the abortion were not induced, the health or life of the female person would be likely to be threatened.'' The Canadian Medical Association also opposes the measure, saying the government should keep abortion out of the criminal code. The association fears anti-abortion forces will harass doctors by filing criminal charges.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinistas Demonstrate Against New Laws
DOC.TEXT: Sandinista union demonstrators sang nostalgic revolutionary songs outside the Supreme Court to protest newly passed laws that would limit strikes and allow the government to fire civil servants. ``We won't let them destroy the gains of the Sandinista revolution,'' Jose Angel Bermudez, head of the National Employee's Union, told the Tuesday night gathering of about 1,200. Also Tuesday, a United Nations observer group said 194 anti-Sandinista guerrillas were demobilized and a shipment of U.S. emergency medical aid arrived by air. President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, who took office April 25, had originally enacted the laws by decree but retreated when a strike virtually shut down the government last week. But the laws were then passed by the National Assembly, which Mrs. Chamorro's coalition party controls. The leftist Sandinistas, replaced by Mrs. Chamorro after controlling the government for nearly 11 years, call the new laws unconstitutional and plan to appeal to the Supreme Court, which their judges still dominate. ``The people voted for Dona Violeta because she promised to improve the economy, not to have their rights violated,'' said Gonzalo Araico, a telephone company worker. Mrs. Chamorro's coalition says the government is virtually bankrupt and the national payroll must be slashed. The demonstrators, led by former President Daniel Ortega's common-law wife Rosario Murillo, joined in revolutionary songs like ``The Wall,'' ``It's Not Enough to Pray'' and ``The People United Can Never Be Defeated.'' Murillo, former director of Nicaragua's Institute of Culture, said musicians and singers were reliving their days of opposition before the Sandinistas took power in 1979. ``Artists didn't play in the street (under the Sandinista government) because the rules made it too hard,'' Murillo acknowledged. ``You had to talk to 50 bureaucrats to get permission to do one performance.'' The $300,000 in U.S. medical aid, including supplies of antibiotics and antimalaria pills, arrived in a chartered jet Tuesday morning. The government, embarrassed by the U.S. Congress's delay in appropriating aid for Nicaragua, trumpeted the arrival as an expression of U.S. support and said it expected another shipment next month. Fernando Castanon, spokesman for the U.N. observers, said 98 Yatama Indian fighters were demobilized Tuesday. Yatama is an independent Indian organization that fought alongside the Contra rebels on the Atlantic Coast. The Contra leadership, now based in El Almendro, 110 miles southeast of Managua, has said it will not order Contra fighters to disarm because it cannot guarantee their personal security. Individual Contras have continued disarming, but at a very slow pace. The Contras claimed 15,000 men under arms as of Sunday, while the United Nations estimate was about 11,000. The 96 regular Contras demobilized Tuesday brought the total since May 8 to 1,404. At 96 a day, there would still be 9,000 to 13,000 Contra guerrillas under arms when the June 10 deadline for full demobilization arrives.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``These are the trademarks of assassins.'' _ Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., discussing semiautomatic rifles and a proposed Senate ban on nine models of the assault weapon.

``I can only say having observed one politician very closely with a remarkable ability for survival and recovery, and watching Gorbachev, I have utmost admiration for his political skills.'' _ H.R. ``Bob'' Haldeman, former chief of staff to President Nixon, on Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

``Anyone wishing to see in this mad murder an expression of Israeli government policy and intentions is maliciously and viciously distorting the picture.'' _ Prime Yitzhak Shamir of Israel on the massacre of seven unarmed Arabs by an Israeli civilian.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Release Transplant Patient
DOC.TEXT: Stormie Jones, the world's longest surviving heart-liver transplant patient, is out of the hospital, and doctors hope higher doses of an experimental anti-rejection drug will allow the 12-year-old to stay out. Stormie was discharged from Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh on Tuesday after doctors controlled a mild episode of rejection of her second donor liver. She could return to her home in White Settlement, Texas, within a few days, perhaps in time for her 13th birthday on May 31, said her mother, Lois ``Suzie'' Purcell. They were staying with friends Tuesday, she said. Stormie returned to Children's Hospital on Sunday after tests showed high liver enzyme levels _ a possible sign of organ rejection. Doctors raised her dosage of FK-506 to control the rejection episode. The Japanese drug has been approved by the Food and Drug Administration for use only at Children's and Presbyterian-University hospitals. Stormie received a historic heart-liver transplant at Children's in 1984 to control a congenital condition that left her cholesterol level 10 times higher than normal. She received another liver in February after hepatitis damaged her first donor liver. Until November, Stormie had been taking cyclosporine, an anti-rejection drug that lowers the body's ability to fight infection. Researchers say FK-506 is more powerful and causes fewer side effects. Modifications in dosages also will be made for many of the 400 transplant patients currently taking FK-506, said Dr. Robert Gordon, a surgeon at Children's.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council To Meet In Geneva So Arafat Can Speak
DOC.TEXT: UNITED NATIONS _ The U.N. Security Council has decided to meet in Geneva Friday to hear PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat in what was seen as a compromise to avert a dispute over a U.S. visa for the Palestinian leader. The announcement Tuesday night came after the United States failed to grant Arafat a visa to address a session in New York. The 15-member Security Council, the highest U.N. body, held several hours of closed consultations on an Arab request for an immediate meeting addressed by Arafat. The meeting is to discuss the escalating violence in Israel's occupied territories and the need to protect Palestinians. Two years ago, the United States rejected Arafat's request for a visa to address the General Assembly and the session was moved to Geneva. This time, however, the United States did not reject or accept the request. Rather, U.S. officials said Arafat did not personally make the request. Arabs seek to win U.S. support in condemning violence against Palestinians and thus wanted to avert a confrontation over the visa. Israel and influential U.S. lawmakers oppose giving Arafat a visa. The United States, a member of the Security Council, did not oppose a move to Geneva. In December 1988, Arafat renounced terrorism and implicitly recognized Israel's right to exist, prompting the United States to open a dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization. U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering declined comment when reporters asked him what the United States had decided on granting a visa to Arafat. On Monday, the 22-nation Arab League requested the urgent meeting, prompted by the killing of seven Arabs by an apparently deranged Israeli gunman on Sunday and the subsequent shooting deaths of 10 Arabs by Israeli soldiers in the occupied lands. Arafat last visited the United States in 1974 when he addressed the General Assembly on Palestine. The Security Council has met outside New York only twice: in January 1972 in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, to discuss African matters, and March 1973 in Panama City to discuss the Panama Canal.

DOC.HEAD: Duck Lands in Co-Pilot Seat; Pilot Lands Plane Safely
DOC.TEXT: The co-pilot was a dead duck, but the pilot and passenger lived to tell the story. The 3-pound duck landed in the co-pilot's seat after crashing through the windshield of the single-engine plane. ``It happened real fast. I saw a shadow closing in on my windshield, and then felt a rush of air coming through,'' pilot Oddvar Sand of L.A.B. Flying Service said Tuesday. ``I had feathers in my mouth.'' The duck is in a freezer, he said. ``I'm going to have it stuffed for the memory.'' The accident occurred Saturday while Sand was taking a passenger on the 40-mile flight from Hoonah to Juneau. Sand said he was climbing to cruising altitude when he ran into a flock of ducks at about 2,000 feet. ``I didn't have a chance to duck,'' he said. One bird crashed through the quarter-inch plastic windshield, bounced off the dash, hit Sand in the chest, and then fell into the co-pilot's seat, said Lynn Bennett, chief pilot for L.A.B. Sand suffered a gash on his head that took six stitches to close. His passenger was in the back seat of the Piper Cherokee and was not hurt. Sand said the duck ``fluttered his wings a little bit and just died right there.'' It took him about 10 minutes to reach the airport after the accident, the wind blowing in his face through the broken windshield, he said. ``I just slowed down the airplane and flew into Juneau,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Foe Wins GOP Gubernatorial Nomination; Andrus Seeks Fourth Term
DOC.TEXT: Republicans nominated a former state lawmaker and abortion opponent to challenge Democratic Gov. Cecil Andrus, who vetoed what would have been the nation's most restrictive state abortion law. With 92 percent of the votes counted in the GOP primary, former Senate majority leader Roger Fairchild had 34,446 votes, or 38 percent, to 29,163, or 32 percent, for state Sen. Rachel Gilbert, another abortion opponent. Stockbroker Milton Erhart, who hoped to capitalize on his support of legalized abortion, finished third with 26,344 votes, or 29 percent. Andrus, seeking an unprecedented fourth term, had no primary opposition. In other races, a GOP congressman seeking to succeed retiring Republican Sen. James McClure won his party's primary. Democrats picked a Boise businessman to oppose him. With 84 percent of the vote in, Rep. Larry Craig had 51,312 votes, or 57 percent, to 38,909, or 43 percent, for Attorney General Jim Jones in the GOP Senate primary. Craig, 44, campaigned on his conservative record over 10 years in the House, underscored by his drive to pass a constitutional amendment for a balanced federal budget. In the Democratic Senate race, businessman Ron Twilegar had 22,963 votes, or 63 percent, to 13,641, or 37 percent, for political newcomer David Steed with 85 percent of the vote in. Andrus was governor from 1971 to 1977, then served as President Carter's interior secretary for four years. He regained the governorship in 1986. A longtime opponent of abortion, Andrus angered anti-abortion forces when he vetoed what would have been the nation's most restrictive state abortion law a half-hour after the Republican-dominated Legislature adjourned on March 30. The legislation called for outlawing abortion except in cases of rape reported within seven days, incest if the victim is under 18, severe fetal deformity or a threat to the life or physical health of the woman. Fairchild, 37, said during the campaign that he would have signed the legislation ``in a baby's heartbeat.'' Abortion-rights advocates targeted lawmakers who backed the bill. The Right to Life Committee took aim at legislators who backed legalized abortion. The effort created 20 primary races on Tuesday's legislative ballot that pitted candidates with opposing abortion stands, but only nine involved incumbents.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Castro Cuban Leaders to Host Soviet Officials
DOC.TEXT: In an event that would have been almost unthinkable a year ago, Miami's militantly anti-communist Cuban leaders are playing host for a weekend of meetings, seminars and parties with visiting Soviet officials. Soviet political advisers, including five members of the Supreme Soviet, will stop here Saturday and Sunday to talk with community leaders before attending next week's Bush-Gorbachev summit meeting in Washington. ``The Cold War is really over. It's a new era,'' said Soviet delegate Andrei Kortunov. In the past, Miami has been the site of a militant, sometimes violent brand of anti-communism. A Polish vessel was hit with a homemade bazooka in 1968, the city tried to ban Miss Yugoslavia from an international beauty pageant here, and as recently as last year, Miami's Calle Ocho street festival barred anyone who had ever performed in Cuba. Businesses and museums that do business with Cuba have been bombed. But Cuban community leaders, including Mayor Xavier Suarez and Jorge Mas Canosa, the head of the anti-Castro Cuban American National Foundation, agree that the world has changed. ``The time has come to take risks,'' Mas said. ``We have a great opportunity to convey to the Soviet people that we Cuban-Americans are not the enemy. The event, called the Moscow in Miami Pre-Summit, gets under way officially on Saturday. It includes seminars on regional conflicts and superpower relations, sessions on glasnost and tips on how to do business in the Soviet Union. There is also a lighter side, including a party in cowboy hats at Regine's nightclub and sightseeing for the Soviets. Cuban-American leaders here, heartened by the strained relations between Mikhail Gorbachev and Fidel Castro, hope to take advantage of the Soviets' presence to persuade them to stop subsidizing Cuban communism. The Soviets in turn are seeking landing rights for the national airline Aeroflot in this gateway to Latin America. Kortunov said moves toward greater freedom in the Soviet Union have changed the way people in his country see Miami. ``The basic vision of Miami was as a city of racial tension, a city of Cuban criminals and a place where American millionaires can come to enjoy life at the beach,'' he said. ``Now the image of Miami is changing. We understand that Miami is the unofficial capital of the Caribbean. We also should change our attitudes about Cuban immigrants here.''

DOC.HEAD: Teens Indicted in Sexual Assault on Retarded Girl
DOC.TEXT: Four former high school football players were indicted on charges they sexually assaulted a retarded girl while nine other young men participated or watched. Defense lawyers generally acknowledge what happened in 1989 in the basement of a house in Glen Ridge, an affluent New York City suburb of 8,000 people, but say the girl consented. But the victim has an IQ of 49 to 64 and cannot consent to sexual activity, Essex County Prosecutor Herbert H. Tate Jr. said in announcing Tuesday's indictments. Indicted were twins Kevin and Kyle Scherzer, former co-captains of the Glen Ridge High School football squad, and former teammates Richard Corcoran Jr., and Peter Quigley. All four are 19 years old. They were accused of assaulting the girl with a broomstick and a miniature baseball bat while some of the nine other teen-agers present cheered. The girl was ``physically helpless, mentally defective or mentally incapacitated,'' the indictment said. The four were charged with aggravated sexual assault, conspiracy and aggravated sexual contact. Each faces up to 20 years in prison. Lawyers for Quigley and Corcoran denied their clients participated. Two friends of the players also were indicted Tuesday. Mari Carmen Ferraez, 19, was accused of contacting the victim and tape-recording her in an attempt to get her to change her story. She was indicted on witness-tampering and obstruction charges. John Maher was charged with conspiracy for allegedly asking the victim to return to the scene of the incident the next day. Maher faces 10 years in prison if convicted, Ms. Ferraez five. Tate said three juveniles arrested in the case and a fourth, who has not been charged, are named as unindicted co-conspirators in the indictment. Prosecutors have asked that the three juveniles charged be tried as adults. A judge has not ruled on the request.

DOC.HEAD: School Board Bans e.e. cummings Poem
DOC.TEXT: An e.e. cummings poem that uses sexual imagery in telling of a man's reaction to a new car was too explicit for some school board members. They voted to ban the textbook in which it is found. ``The poem was open to numerous interpretations, one of which was explicitly sexual,'' Susan Zimmerman of the Grand Rapids Board of Education said at Monday's meeting. The board split 4-4 on whether to ban the book, ``Literature _ An Introduction to Reading and Writing.'' The tie means the textbook, used in a pilot program last year at City High School, will not be used permanently. Diane Wakoski, writer in residence at Michigan State University in East Lansing, said the board should appreciate the poem for expressing passion without being blatantly vulgar. ``There are sexual puns in almost every e.e. cummings poem,'' Wakoski said. ``He's a great love poet and everyone's loves usually include sex.'' Written in cummings' unconventional style, the poem begins: ``she being Brand -new; and you know consequently a little stiff i was careful of her and (having thoroughly oiled the universal joint tested my gas felt of her radiator made sure her springs were O.K.) i went right to it flooded-the-carburetor cranked her up, slipped the clutch ...'' Wakoski was dismayed with the board's action. ``I thought we had reached the stage in our culture where we could talk rationally, realistically and sensibly about sex in our classrooms,'' she said. ``e.e. cummings' use of language is discreet and practically genteel.''

DOC.HEAD: Funeral Procession For Student Who Died During Protest
DOC.TEXT: Radical students shouting anti-government, anti-U.S. slogans marched in this southern city today behind the coffin of a dead student activist heralded as a martyr and patriot. ``Drive out Yankees,'' students shouted, ``Crush (President) Roh Tae-woo!'' Riot police armed with clubs and shields were deployed around government offices and along major downtown streets to deter violence. Traffic on streets came to a stop as the procession passed. About 3,000 radical students, many wearing traditional white Korean mourning clothes, chanted and hummed funeral dirges as they followed a hearse bearing the body of student activist Shin Jan-ho, 21. Some waved long colorful funeral streamers printed with anti-government slogans. Shin was one of 20,000 students from around the country who came to Kwangju to participate in protests over the weekend. He died of massive head injuries Saturday after jumping off a speeding train to avoid police checkpoints at the train station. Radicals claim police are responsible for the death and vowed to retaliate. Violent protests have been staged for a week in Kwangju to mark the anniversary of a 1980 civil uprising, the bloodiest in modern Korean history. At least 84 police and 400 students and citizens have been injured in five-days of protests. During today's funeral, six students wearing white clothes and black headbands carried a giant Korean national flag at the head of the procession. Others carried a large photograph of the dead student rimmed in black. Hundreds of citizens watched from the sidewalks as the procession wound along city streets to Chosun and Chonnam Universities where two funeral rites were held. A traditional fortune teller performed a dance for repose of the soul at Chonnam University. Students frequently interrupted services with dissident songs and shouted slogans. ``The U.S. _ real culprint of the Kwangju massacre _ get out!'' students chanted. The student was to be buried as a martyr at a cemetery outside Kwangju where victims of the 1980 uprising are buried. Police officials feared the funeral would spark more violence and about 7,500 riot police were on alert. Thousands of students rioted in the city over the weekend, burning tires on the streets and attacking police with firebombs, rocks and clubs. Radicals claim the United States condoned the suppression of the 1980 uprising against a martial law government and anti-American sentiment is strong in Kwangju. U.S. flags are painted on campus roadways and banners and posters showing shredded American flags are common. By official count, about 200 people were killed and more than 1,700 others wounded 10 years ago in the 10-day, pro-democracy revolt in Kwangju, 150 miles south of Seoul. Kwangju citizens claim the death toll was much higher. Also today, a protester shouting anti-Japanese slogans attempted suicide in front of the Japanese Embassy by stabbing himself in the abdomen to demand Japan make a clear-cut apology for its colonial rule over Korea. About a dozen riot police guarding the embassy rushed toward him and snatched the knife, the witnesses said. A police patrol car the man to a nearby hospital, but the man's condition was not immediately known.

DOC.HEAD: Alleged Hit Man Cleared of Firebomb Murders
DOC.TEXT: An alleged hit man for a drug dealer was cleared of murder in the firebombing deaths of six people. A jury, brought in from St. Louis because of publicity surrounding the case, deliberated four hours Tuesday before acquitting 33-year-old James A. Skinner in the 1989 blaze at a Kansas City home. Members of four generations of a family, including three children and an invalid, were killed in the fire. Seven other family members, including the drug dealer's target, escaped. The dealer, Aaron O. Frazier, testified he paid $150 to Skinner and two other men to firebomb the house in a feud with a member of the family. Three of Frazier's friends also testified he hired Skinner to burn the house. Assistant Prosecutor Joseph P. Bednar Jr. said jurors told him after the trial there were too many inconsistencies in the witnesses' stories to believe them. Frazier and the others differed over whether the bomb was thrown from Skinner's car and whether the arsonists had walked to the house. Frazier testified as part of a plea bargain to avoid the death penalty. Skinner told police he was home in bed on the night of the fire. He did not testify.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Along Coastlines; Fog in South
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell along the East and West coasts early today, and fog covered parts of the South. The wet weather in California was a welcome change as the region is in the fourth year of drought, and the summer fire season still lies ahead. Rain also fell in the Northwest and parts of the Midwest. Scattered thunderstorms were expected in northern Florida, and showers and cool temperatures were expected in much of the Northeast. Temperatures in Arizona were expected to soar into the 100s. Snow was expected in the mountains of northern New England. Fog was over a swath of the South, from Arkansas to Virginia. Tornadoes touched down Tuesday west of Port O'Connor, Texas, and at Hickman Crossroads, N.C. Also Tuesday, unseasonably high temperatures of up to 95 degrees were across much of Florida. Heavy rainfall on Tuesday included 3 inches at Alexandria, Minn., and Wilmington, N.C. The nation's high for Tuesday was 104 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: FBI Agents Search Northrop Plants in California
DOC.TEXT: Federal agents searched three Northrop Corp. plants, reportedly looking for defective parts and for records of alleged overcharging on contracts for the FA-18 fighter jet. About 50 FBI agents raided the plants in El Segundo, Hawthorne and Carson on Tuesday, authorities said. ``We are working with them in their search, and that is all that I can comment upon,'' said Northrop spokesman Ron Owens. FBI agent Fred Reagan would not comment on the raids. The Los Angeles Times quoted an unidentified federal law enforcement official as saying the agents were looking for defective FA-18 parts and records on alleged overcharges. Northrop assembles FA-18 fuselage sections in El Segundo. The Hawthorne plant makes parts for the aircraft, and the Carson plant is a records storage center. The search warrant was issued based on a sealed affidavit with information developed by the Naval Investigative Service. NIS is part of a multi-agency task force that is investigating the company. The raids follow a series of legal run-ins Northrop has had with federal agencies. In February, Northrop pleaded guilty to falsifying tests on parts for nuclear-armed cruise missiles and agreed to a $17 million fine. Also in February, federal agents raided Northrop's B-2 stealth bomber plant in Pico Rivera and confiscated records. In April, the Justice Department sued Northrop, accusing the company of padding FA-18 bills submitted to the Navy. The lawsuit seeks at least $25 million.

DOC.HEAD: University Sells its Tobacco Stocks
DOC.TEXT: Harvard University has sold the stock it owned in companies that manufacture tobacco products because of the dangers of smoking. The university decided to sell the stocks last September and completed the sales in March, according to Harvard President Derek Bok. He revealed the sale May 18 in a letter to three Harvard School of Public Health students, who had been demanding the university sell its investments in companies manufacturing cigarettes. ``In reaching its decision, the corporation was motivated by a desire not to be associated as a shareholder with companies engaged in significant sales of products that create a substantial and unjustified risk of harm to other human beings,'' Bok wrote. Dr. Allan Blum, a Houston physician and chairman of Doctors Ought To Care, a national anti-smoking group that pushes for divestment of tobacco stocks, called Harvard's decision a ``breakthrough morally and financially.'' ``This is a historic event that can't help but send a message that there's something rotten about holding tobacco stocks,'' Blum said. Sara Ridgway, vice president of public affairs for the Lorillard Tobacco Co., said the decision may deprive Harvard of profitable stock investments. ``I think it would behoove them to look at the best investments, and our stock has done very well,'' she said. Bok said the decision was based on an Advisory Committee on Shareholder Responsibility review. He also said tobacco companies did not adequately answer questions about ethical issues in selling tobacco and their adherence to World Health Organization guidelines for marketing tobacco products in the Third World.

DOC.HEAD: Peres Says Israel Does Not Intend to Attack Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Associated Press Writer= CAIRO, Egypt (AP) _ Israeli Labor Party leader Shimon Peres said today his country does not intend to attack Iraq or any other Arab country, but remains worried about Iraqi policy. Peres, who arrived Monday for a meeting of the Socialist International Council, told a news conference he spoke for all of Israel. But he warned that it would be ``a tragedy'' if an Arab summit conference set to meet next Monday in Baghdad, Iraq's capital, adopted a belligerent attitude toward Israel. Peres was asked about Arab fears of an Israeli attack on Iraq. ``I think I can speak for the whole of Israel,'' he replied. ``Israel does not have any intention of attacking Iraq or any other country.'' Peres served as finance minister in the government of right-wing Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir before breaking up the governing coalition in March in a disagreement over U.S. Middle East peace proposals. Shamir is now trying to form a government. Peres suggested that Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak will be a moderating influence at the Arab summit. ``President Mubarak is of help to the Middle East, (taking) a middle road,'' Peres said. ``He remains totally committed to peace.'' On Tuesday, Mubarak reiterated to reporters that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has no intention of attacking Israel. Mubarak added, however, that Saddam continues to be haunted by memories of Israel's 1981 air attack that destroyed an Iraqi nuclear reactor, and fears a new atack. Saddam last month threatened to destroy half of Israel with binary chemical weapons from his arsenal if Israel mounts a nuclear attack on Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Stranded Soviet Circus Runs Afoul of Feds, Creditors
DOC.TEXT: Uncooperative creditors and trouble with federal wildlife authorities dashed plans by a bankrupt Soviet circus to stage a series of tour-saving shows. The Great Circus Bim Bom ran out of money and had to halt its U.S. tour on May 9. Now U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service officials in New York are threatening to seize 54 circus animals allegedly in the country illegally. Costumes and equipment needed for the Atlanta shows, which had been tentatively scheduled for next month, will not be released by a transportation company that is owed money, circus spokesman John Stallion said Tuesday. The combination of dilemmas effectively killed plans to stage the Atlanta shows, he said. Problems brewing over the animals stranded in Newburgh, N.Y., were caused by a lack of paperwork, circus managing director Andrew Trueman said. ``I can't believe Fish and Wildlife is going to ship our animals back just because we don't have a $25 report,'' he said. ``The animals are here illegally,'' said Sam Librandi, a wildlife official in New York City. ``We think they should be sent back until the problems are solved.'' The 54 animals, which include bears, lions, horses and chimpanzees, have been under federal scrutiny since last week, when a Humane Society official reported they were being kept in cramped cages meant only for transportation. Circus officials in Marietta with the troupe's 125 performers are trying to find money to resume the tour and said they working to correct problems surrounding the animals. But Librandi said his agency has gotten no cooperation from the circus. Animals brought into the United States from foreign countries are required to have wildlife declaration documents. Bim Bom's animals did not have the documents when they arrived in the country, and circus officials have not provided them since, he said.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Heckling the President Isn't What It Used to Be
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS final graf to show that the church group Bush won't be speaking to is the Southern Baptists, not just Baptists.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush recently counseled Mikhail S. Gorbachev to shrug off the heckling he got at a May Day parade, suggesting the Soviet leader ``ought to come join some of the parades I go to.'' But actually Bush has had it easy. Signs waved in his face are just as likely to make whimsical comments about broccoli these days as denounce U.S. policy in Central America. And some hecklers have gone so far as to buy tickets to gain legal admission to Republican fund-raisers _ a form of protest that activists of the 1960s and 70s would never have dreamed of doing. As he crisscrosses the country giving speeches and raising funds for Republican candidates, Bush is seldom confronted with the angry crowds that dogged and sometimes drowned out other presidents. It may be a sign of the times, but protesters don't seem very angry these days. Last Sunday, Bush was on his way to a speech in Portland, Ore., when a passenger train drew abreast of his motorcade on tracks that paralleled the highway. Two passengers, a man and a woman, recognized the president and both began making obscene gestures at him from the train window. This went on for several minutes as the train and motorcade kept precise pace. Bush looked at the couple and nodded politely. Finally, the two stopped gesturing and both began waving at the president. ``Hello Mr. President,'' the words formed by the woman said. A crowd of 150 to 200 demonstrators burned flags and newspapers the next day outside the hotel in downtown Portland where Bush was speaking. There were a few arrests of those starting the fires. But for the most part, the crowd broke up peacefully when police moved in. The signs carried by the protesters covered a range of subjects. Some protested Bush's environmental record. Others dealt with AIDS, the homeless, U.S. support for El Salvador. One targeted administration tax policy: ``If his lips are moving, he's lying.'' And that was one of the biggest demonstrations Bush had seen in months. With the mixture of messages, protesters don't seem to be very organized. At an event earlier this week in Los Angeles, where Bush gave a neighborhood speech praising community anti-drug efforts, one heckler within easy earshot of Bush screamed: ``Contras. Cocaine. El Salvador. It's all your fault.'' Bush looked at him quizzically. ``Oliver North. The CIA. The homeless,'' the man shouted, repeating the same words over and over again. Bush shrugged. Others in the crowd told the man to keep quiet. At two fund-raisers this year, hecklers who interrupted Bush's speeches turned out to have purchased tickets to get in _ at several hundred dollars apiece. More often than not, demonstrators at Bush's speeches complain for a few minutes, then sit down and keep quiet. Protesters who show up at Bush events most frequently complain about U.S. support for El Salvador, Bush's anti-abortion stance and his position on feminist issues. There also usually are several signs calling attention to environmental issues or lamenting levels of spending on AIDS research and for the homeless. But there also are more and more broccoli signs. Ever since Bush declared war on broccoli, there have been a myriad of broccoli signs at Bush events, some of them nasty, most of them good-natured. One proclaimed ``Bush Beats Broccoli'' and bore a cartoon of Bush in boxing trunks, standing victoriously over a fallen broccoli stalk. Restaurants sometimes bear signs with variations on this theme: ``We don't serve broccoli, come on in Mr. President.'' Bush's tendency to meet with various interest groups may help mute some of the criticism _ even though it may also spawn it in some unexpected areas. The president's decision to include several gay rights activists at a White House ceremony to sign legislation to crack down on so-called ``hate crimes'' won him plaudits from gay organizations. But partly as a result of those invitations, Southern Baptists withdrew an invitation to Bush to speak at their convention this June in New Orleans.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Tom Raum covers the White House for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Korean Stabs Self in Protest in Front of Japanese Embassy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with arrests of protesters, ADDS background, MOVES UP attack on eve of Roh visit. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A man shouting ``Apologize, Akihito!'' stabbed himself in front of the Japanese Embassy today in a protest demanding that Japan's emperor apologize for Japan's colonial rule over Korea. The attack came on the eve of President Roh Tae-woo's state visit to Japan, which is aimed at increasing economic and other ties between the two countries. The man pulled a knife from his jacket, knelt down on the street about 10 feet from the embassy gate and stabbed himself in the abdomen, police said. About a dozen riot police guarding the embassy rushed toward him and snatched the knife, witnesses said. A police patrol car rushed the man to a nearby hospital. He was identified as Kim Kuk-bin, 33, a videotape dealer from Seoul. He told a news conference later at Hankook Hospital he could not endure what he called Japan's ``lukewarm'' attitude in apologizing for its actions. His exact condition was not known. In Korea and Japan, ritual suicide called harakiri has been a traditional form of protest. Police also detained about 50 other protesters who staged a separate demonstration outside the embassy today. Four busloads of police guarded the embassy after the attack and the arrest of the protesters. It was not known whether the protesters were released. For more than a week, bands of 30 to 40 mostly elderly Koreans have been staging protests at the embassy, demanding Akihito apologize for Japan's colonial rule of Korea. They want the apology to be made during Roh's three-day visit to Japan, which begins Thursday. ``I cannot bear the president's visit to Japan with the legacy of Japan's imperial colonial rule remaining unliquidated here,'' Kim said. He said his father was a guerrilla fighter during Japan's colonial rule. The protesters also demanded Japan compensate for actions during its 1910-1945 colonial rule of Korea, during which hundreds of thousands of Koreans were forced to work as slave laborers. The protesters contend that the Japanese killed thousands of Koreans during the war. Roh has been under public pressure to cancel his trip. Dissidents contend Roh's trip to Japan will deepen South Korea's economic dependence on Japan. Japan and South Korea also have been locked in a diplomatic war over better treatment of about 600,000 ethnic Koreans in Japan. Seoul has asked Tokyo to eliminate discrimination against Koreans in Japan who were forced to live there after being drafted for forced labor.

DOC.HEAD: Fired Editor Sues Wall Street Journal for Libel
DOC.TEXT: A former Wall Street Journal editor is suing the financial daily for $12.6 million, claiming he was wrongly fired and libeled by a false charge of plagiarism. Jonathan Kandell, 43, who was fired as assistant foreign editor of the Journal on May 2, filed the lawsuit Tuesday. The Journal accused Kandell of lifting uncredited material from another writer's book for a page 1 article about three entrepreneurs in Eastern Europe. Roger May, a spokesman for Journal owner Dow Jones & Co., said, ``Dow Jones believes the suit is utterly without merit and the company intends to defend itself vigorously.'' Kandell's article on March 30 profiled a Soviet machine tool maker, a Czechoslovak inventor and a Hungarian banker as individuals succeeding in the private sector. Kandell said he based the story on interviews with the three in their countries after hearing them speak at a November meeting in New York sponsored by the Council on Foreign Relations. He said that at the same meeting he learned of the book ``Communist Entrepreneurs'' and met its author, John W. Kiser III. He said he later ``read the book once and put it aside.'' Kandell's suit said he told his editors that he hadn't credited Kiser's book in his article because he had ``done all his own legwork and the book was not where he had first learned of the subject.'' On May 1, Kandell said, the editors told him they had decided he should have mentioned Kiser's book in the article, ``but emphasized that it was a judgment call.'' Later that same day, Kandell said, he learned he was to be fired. He quoted Paul Steiger, a deputy managing editor, as saying he had a gut feeling that Kandell had not been truthful and that he had shown a ``lack of candor.'' Kandell said he was dismissed the next day after consulting with his lawyer and refusing to sign a letter of resignation that he said would have kept him on the Journal's payroll through June 30. In his lawsuit, filed in U.S. District Court in Manhattan, Kandell contends he was libeled and his professional reputation destroyed by the Journal. He demanded $10 million in punitive damages and $2.64 million in compensation for ``willful, wanton and reckless disregard of the truth'' and ``actual malice'' on the paper's part. He said the libel was contained in a letter of apology that the newspaper sent to the author of a book dealing with the same subject and in a subsequent article in the weekly newspaper The Village Voice about Kandell's case. The Village Voice was not named as a defendant in the suit. Kandell's suit also demanded the return of original notes and other documents that he contended the paper's editors had kept, knowing they would support his position.

DOC.HEAD: `Gonzo' Writer Ordered To Stand Trial on Felony Drug, Explosives Charges
DOC.TEXT: Journalist-author Hunter S. Thompson was ordered to stand trial on four felony drug and explosives charges. The father of so-called ``gonzo'' journalism sprinkled the preliminary hearing Tuesday with low-key outbursts before District Judge Charles Buss ruled there was sufficient evidence to proceed with a trial. The judge dismissed one felony count of drug use because Thompson's primary accuser could not verify a substance she testified the writer sniffed was a narcotic. Thompson, 53, was fidgety during the hearing and at times was heard muttering, ``That's bull'' or ``Ah, come on,'' particularly during the testimony of Gail Palmer-Slater, 35, of Port Huron, Mich. Sexual assault allegations by Ms. Palmer-Slater, a former X-rated film producer, prompted a two-day search of his secluded mountain home in February that led to the drug and explosives charges. Three separate misdemeanor charges stemming from the alleged sexual assault were not considered at Tuesday's hearing. The felony trial was scheduled for June 25. At the noon break Thompson left the courthouse followed by photographers and reporters and at one point stopped to pose. ``Let me do a Nixon,'' he said, stopping to raise his arms and flash a V-for-victory signal with both hands. The columnist and writer of such books as ``Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas,'' has said he never assaulted the woman, who he says was drunk and pressured him to have sex. Defense attorney Hal Haddon argued Pitkin County prosecutors cannot prove that Thompson owned the drugs and explosives found at his home in rural Woody Creek. Thompson has said that the search was so extensive it may have turned up drugs left by party guests years earlier. Found at the house were a small amount of cocaine, more than one ounce of marijuana, tablets of LSD and the tranquilizer diazepam, four sticks of dynamite and three blasting caps, authorities said. Haddon said the explosives were owned by a friend of Thompson's who used them to dislodge beaver dams. Supporters of the writer who inspired the character Duke in the ``Doonesbury'' comic strip demonstrated outside the courthouse, waving signs like, ``When the going gets weird, the weird go to jail,'' and, ``Today the doctor, tomorrow you.'' Thompson's books are written in a style dubbed ``gonzo'' journalism because their seemingly non-fictional narratives of news events often include exaggerated accounts of his antics brought on by drug and alcohol abuse.

DOC.HEAD: Thai Leader Says Cambodian Factions Soon To Sign Truce
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Sihanouk comment, background. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The four warring factions in Cambodia have agreed to sign a cease-fire pact soon, Thailand's prime minister was quoted as saying today. Official Radio Thailand said the Thai leader, Chatichai Choonhavan, a key mediator in the conflict, mentioned a possible truce while speaking about talks on the Cambodian conflict to be held in Tokyo June 4-5. If a pact is signed, it would be the first significant agreement reached in 11 years of conflict. In the past, however, all sides to the conflict have gone back on promises of agreements. ``It is certain that the four Cambodian factions have agreed to sign a cease-fire agreement soon,'' the broadcast paraphrased Chatichai as saying. It said Chatichai briefed reporters after conferring in Bangkok on Tuesday with Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach of Vietnam, which backs the Phnom Penh government in its battle against the three guerrilla groups. Officials have said the talks are likely to focus on questions of how to monitor a cease-fire and conduct free elections, as well as the role of the United Nations in the process. Negotiations thus far have been stymied by quarrels over who should govern Cambodia before the election. Various officials have said a truce should be reached without waiting for resolution of the political disagreements. Communist Prime Minister Hun Sen of Cambodia has said he will attend the Tokyo talks. A Thai Foreign Ministry spokesman quoted Thach as saying he hoped Hun Sen would be flexible at the talks. Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the main non-Communist guerrilla leader, said in a statement issued in Bangkok today that Thailand's army Chief, Gen. Chavalit Yongchaiyudh, the main broker of the proposed truce, persuaded him to attend. Sihanouk referred vaguely to ``the Cambodian peace agreement ... which possibly I would sign in Tokyo.'' But he said the agreement would commit only himself since he recently resigned as head of the guerrilla coalition. Son Sann, leader of one of the guerrilla groups, the non-Communist Khmer People's National Liberation Front, also will be in Tokyo at the time of the talks, his office said. It was not certain if the third guerrilla group, the Communist Khmer Rouge, would participate. Vietnam invaded Cambodia in late 1978, ending nearly four years of bloody Khmer Rouge rule, then installed Hun Sen. Hun Sen, Sihanouk and Son Sann have spoken in favor of a truce, but the Khmer Rouge, which has the largest guerrilla army, previously said it wanted a cease-fire only in the context of an overall political settlement. The Thai Foreign Ministry spokesman, Somphong Faichampa, said hopes for a settlement have risen because Vietnam and China, which arms the guerrillas, soon will hold another round of talks on Cambodia. The United Nations Security Council also will meet soon to discuss its role in the peace process, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Call on Citizens To Identify Protest Organizers
With PM-Romania-Analysis, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Police today called on citizens to identify organizers of a planned demonstration to protest alleged vote fraud in the national elections won by the National Salvation Front. A handful of protesters gave passers-by leaflets in Bucharest's downtown University Square today, urging Romanians to join the protest march Thursday. Police said they questioned several of those handing out leaflets but none were arrested. Police said they suspected the leaflets were trying to incite the public but that those distributing the handbills had not committed a crime. A police statement in the pro-government daily Adevarul urged citizens to identify ``ill-meaning elements'' giving out the leaflets. It did not elaborate. The leaflets claimed results from Romania's first democratic election in 50 years were rigged by the Front, a loose grouping of former Communists and technocrats that has dominated politics since a revolution in December toppled hard-line Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Interim President Ion Iliescu and the Front are likely to become the first ex-Communists in Eastern Europe to triumph in multiparty elections. ``The votes were manipulated'' and even those who died in the revolution ``were registered and `voted,''' said Elena Vasile, 30, who was among those handing out leaflets. Foreign election observers said there were many irregularities in the balloting, but not enough to affect the outcome. Officials said 16 million Romanians were eligible to vote and that at least 85 percent of them participated. With 14 million votes counted, Iliescu captured 85.30 percent of the three-way presidential race. His main contender, Radu Campeanu of the National Liberal Party, had 10.6 percent, and Ion Ratiu of the National Peasant Party had 4.1 percent. The Front took about two-thirds of the vote for the Senate and Chamber of Deputies. Iliescu, 60, a former Communist party secretary who says he wants to turn Romania into a Swedish-style social democracy, went on record as saying he would seek a coalition with the opposition. But his two opponents, who said they will seek to nullify the election on grounds of fraud, indicated it was unlikely they would join.

DOC.HEAD: New York Mayor Calls For Racial Unity
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts 2nd graf to CORRECT location of cathedral in reference to Harlem.
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins asked a city torn by racial strife to come together to fight the common foes of crime, poverty and prejudice. The city's first black mayor made his plea Tuesday before 6,000 New Yorkers at a city-sponsored rally on the edge of Harlem. ``When a few shout out words of hate, we can drown them out with acts of hope,'' Dinkins said. ``And when the instigators seek to turn us against each other, we can respond by turning to each other _ and coming together to fight our common foes: crack and crime, poverty, prejudice and pollution.'' The most recent irritant to race relations was a pair of verdicts in the Bensonhurst case, the slaying of a black teen-ager by a mob of whites in the mostly white section of Brooklyn in August. One white teen-ager was convicted of murder; a co-defendant was acquitted of murder but convicted of lesser charges. A black boycott of a Korean-American grocery store and a speech by a City University professor who espouses white supremacy also have heightened tensions. Dinkins, in announcing the city-sponsored Unity Rally on Monday, said ``a silent majority'' needed to be heard above the voices of some activists who have been fueling instead of soothing tensions. Dinkins was joined Tuesday night at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine by Gov. Mario Cuomo and Cardinal John O'Connor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese. ``For God's sakes, why are we fighting among ourselves?''
