Cuomo asked the crowd. ``We must save our strength for the real battles _ for fighting the closed-minded, the skinheads, the anti-Semites, the racists and gay haters.'' The speeches, interrupted by standing ovations and cheers, were broadcast live on local television. About a dozen blacks picketed the cathedral, holding signs that read: ``Let's take our peace, justice and unity rally to Bensonhurst.'' The rally was followed by a candle-lighting ceremony and singing, led by the mayor. ``We are witnessing the children of the immigrants and the oppressed fighting each other as never before,'' he told the crowd. ``The powerless are trying to prove their power by hurting those who are just as powerless. It must stop _ and it must stop now.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Kill Five, Wound Nine in Attack
DOC.TEXT: Communist rebels firing from a van ambushed a high-ranking security official on one of Manila's busiest streets today, killing him and four other people and injuring nine. Later today, about 50 members and supporters of the Communist urban guerrilla unit blamed for the attack _ The Alex Boncayao Brigade _ rallied briefly in the center of the capital to mark the group's sixth anniversary. Police believe the brigade, the Manila wing of the Communist New People's Army, is responsible for killing about 60 soldiers, police and civilians in the capital this year. President Corazon Aquino called the killing ``brutal and senseless'' and ordered ``swift justice'' for the killers. Also today, the Cabinet decided to ask Congress to extend the president's emergency powers by six months. The additional powers were granted after December's bloody coup attempt. Five people, including Col. Reynaldo Dino, were killed in the ambush on Epifanio de los Santos Avenue, one of the city's busiest thoroughfares. Police said the six assailants, led by a woman, pulled alongside a car carrying Dino and fired at about 7:30 a.m. Dino's car careened into a bus. Then the woman and two male companions jumped from their van and continued firing, police said. Witnesses said the woman spat in contempt after she stopped firing. Dino, a deputy personnel chief of the Philippine Constabulary, died later in a hospital. Also slain were Dino's 23-year-old daughter, Lolita Halili, two bodyguards and a female bystander. Most of the nine injured were on the bus, which was hit with stray bullets. The assailants escaped. Police Col. Victor Tiangco, operations chief of the Capital Command, blamed the killing on Communist rebels. Tiangco said Dino had received death threats from the insurgents and one suspected guerrilla was arrested last month near his home. The ambush was the latest sign of deteriorating security in this turbulent capital. On Tuesday, police defused powerful bombs outside two banks. Officials said the explosives, timed to explode during the morning rush hour, could have destroyed both buildings. Following the Dec. 1-9 coup attempt, Congress granted Mrs. Aquino emergency powers under a decree that expires June 8. Presidential legal adviser Adolfo Azcuna told reporters the Cabinet decided to ask Congress for a six-month extension of some of the powers. He said they include tougher controls on firearms, the authority to take over public utilities and the right to regulate distribution and use of fuel and electricity.

DOC.HEAD: Curfews, General Strike In Territories; Mourning In Jordan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with violence at Temple Mount, Foreign Ministry accusing world leaders of encouraging unrest. Pickup 5th graf, `Five people ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY7, NY10
DOC.TEXT: Israeli troops today enforced curfews in the occupied lands, confining 1.5 million people to their homes, and Palestinians observed a general strike to protest the killing of seven Arabs by an Israeli civilian. Hundreds of police reinforcements poured into Jerusalem to prevent unrest as Israel marked the 23rd anniversary of the capture of the Old City and surrounding Arab east Jerusalem from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war. Two Jewish extremists came under a hail of stones while attempting to pray at the disputed Temple Mount, as thousands marched through Arab east Jerusalem demonstrating Israel's claim to the area. They were not injured. Two Palestinians were wounded in stone-throwing incidents, Arab reports said today. Also today, the Israeli government sharply rejected U.S. and European criticism that the violence resulted because Middle East peace talks have been stalled. The Foreign Ministry even implied that world leaders were encouraging Arab violence by connecting the unrest to political developments. ``Linking the violence to the peace process is liable to be seen by certain groups as a reason to continue the violence in hope of attaining their ends,'' ministry spokesman Yossi Amihud said in a prepared statement. On Tuesday, Palestinians in the occupied territories and in neighboring Jordan took to the streets in escalating protests over Sunday's massacre of the seven Arab laborers. Five people, two in Israel and three in Jordan, were reported killed and at least 47 injured on Tuesday, the third straight day of violence following Sunday's shootings. The third death in Jordan _ a Palestinian accidentally shot by another _ was reported by hospital officials, but government officials have not confirmed it. In Moslem areas of Lebanon today, a general strike to protest the slayings brought commercial life to a standstill. Palestinians also observed the third day of a general strike in the occupied territories. In Jordan, relatives quietly buried a 14-year-old Palestinian boy shot by police Tuesday during a protest in the Irbid refugee camp near Amman. All shops, businesses and schools ended a general strike in Jordan and Israel, but a week of mourning continued over this week's deaths. ``Black flags were flown on every corner in the streets of the camp,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. A similar scene was reported at the seven other major refugee camps in Jordan. In the occupied West Bank and Gaza, soldiers enforced widespread curfews for a fourth day in an effort to curb the violence set off by Sunday's massacre. In clashes Tuesday, Israeli troops killed two Palestinians and wounded 22, raising the toll since Sunday's shootings to 13 Palestinians slain and more than 800 injured. The deaths brought to 708 the number of Palestinians killed by Israelis in the Palestinian uprising. At least 216 other Palestinians have been slain by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel. Forty-three Israelis have been slain in the revolt. In Jordan, at least two people were killed and 25 wounded Tuesday as police fired to disperse demonstrations in two cities and the Baqaa refugee camp near Amman, the capital, the official Petra news agency said. Prime Minister Mudar Badran pledged to take ``all necessary measures to guarantee safety and order.'' Nearly half of Jordan's 3.1 million people are Palestinians who fled Israel in the 1948 or 1967 Middle East wars. Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir defended his government against criticism by Arabs and the U.S. State Department _ both over Sunday's slayings and the heavy use of gunfire by Israeli troops during protests. ``Anyone wishing to see in this mad murder an expression of Israeli government policy and intentions is maliciously and viciously distorting the picture,'' Shamir told legislators from his right-wing Likud bloc. Palestinians charge that Israel's harsh tactics in handling the 29-month-old Palestinian uprising and the government's failure to begin peace talks have increased anti-Arab sentiment. ``There is no doubt that the Israeli government led by Shamir ... leads to such catastrophe,'' said pro-PLO leader Faisal Husseini. ``The atmosphere created by such a government is responsible.'' Israeli authorities say the man charged in Sunday's seven killings in a Tel Aviv suburb, 21-year-old Ami Popper, was deranged and also upset by an unhappy love affair. A judge ordered psychiatric evaluation for him on Monday. Foreign Minister Moshe Arens said today Popper ``had nothing to do with who is the prime minister, the composition of the government or the policies of Israel's government of Israel.'' ``The man simply went berserk,'' said Arens, a member of Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc. President Bush extended personal condolences to the families of the seven slain Palestinians and those killed later by security forces. He urged Israel ``to act with maximum restraint.'' In Washington, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher complained about the number of casualties caused by the Israeli army, and spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said the United States believes ``that absence of a peace process contributes to violence in the Middle East.'' Shamir has headed a caretaker government since its coalition with the center-left Labor Party collapsed March 15 over Labor's insistence on negotiating with the Palestinans. At the United Nations on Tuesday, the U.N. Security Council said it will meet Friday in Geneva to hear PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat discuss violence in Israel because the U.S. government has not granted him a visa to speak in New York. The U.S. government has neither accepted nor rejected Arafat's visa request, saying it was not made by Arafat personally.

DOC.HEAD: Official Indicates Japan Won't Allow Entry of Democracy Ship
DOC.TEXT: Japan will block the Goddess of Democracy radio ship from entering its ports if the vessel will be used to make unauthorized broadcasts to China from international waters, the chief Cabinet secretary said today. It was the latest setback for project organizers, who hope to beam pro-democracy messages to China before the June 4 anniversary of the Chinese crackdown on protesters in Beijing. They want to load a transmitter in Japan. ``If we give tacit approval to such behavior, we would be inviting international criticism,'' Misoji Sakamoto told Japanese reporters, according to an official of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's office who spoke on condition of anonymity. Officials said the Japanese government has not yet received an entry request from the crew of the 1,200-ton ship, sponsored by the French magazine Actuel and other publishing organizations. Sakamoto said the unauthorized broadcasts would be illegal. If the crew asks to enter Japanese ports, the government will handle the matter ``strictly according to Japanese regulations,'' he said. Japan is a signatory of the International Telecommunications Union, an agreement that prohibits the establishment or use of broadcast stations on objects on the sea or in the air, even outside a nation's territorial waters. The ship left France on March 17 and last week reached Keelung in northern Taiwan to take on supplies, including a radio transmitter sent from France. But customs officials refused to release the equipment on grounds that the unauthorized radio broadcasts violate international agreements. Earlier, Hong Kong, which reverts to Chinese sovereignty in 1997, denied entry to the ship. China reportedly has pressured Taiwan not to extend any assistance to the vessel and asked Japan not to allow the ship to land. The ship was reported preparing to leave Keelung tonight for Japan. Kyodo News Service reported that Nichiei Marine Service Co., a Japanese shipping agent, received a telex today from Paris saying the ship would enter Tokyo, Kobe, Nagasaki or Naha in Japan to obtain equipment and replace crew members. Officials of Nichiei Marine could not be reached immediately for comment. The ship's organizers have said they hoped to begin broadcasting to China before the June 4 anniversary of China's crackdown last year on the pro-democracy movement in which hundreds and perhaps thousand died. The ship is named after a statue built by students in Beijing's Tiananmen Square that was destroyed by Chinese tanks during the repression.

DOC.HEAD: Noted Nuclear Weapons Scientist Switching Jobs After Protest
DOC.TEXT: A scientist who resigned from a high-ranking position in nuclear weapons design to protest the government's ``Star Wars'' research has taken a new job at the Los Alamos weapons lab in New Mexico. Roy D. Woodruff had been in charge of the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory's nuclear weapons design work and had stepped down to take a lower-ranking job at the research center. The 49-year-old scientist announced Tuesday that he will join Livermore's counterpart in Los Alamos, the birthplace of the atom bomb, after a three-month vacation. John Nuckolls, director of the Livermore lab, issued a statement saying he was ``pleased that Roy has been able to work out a suitable arrangement with Los Alamos.'' In 1985, Woodruff was involved in a dispute with Dr. Edward Teller, the designer of the hydrogen bomb, and a Teller protege, Lowell Wood, over research into the Star Wars system, known officially as the Strategic Defense Initiative. He accused the two of making ``wildly optimistic assessments'' of a controversial anti-missile X-ray laser weapon. Woodruff found support for his position among many scientists, including Dr. Sidney Drell of Stanford University and a Nobel Prize-winning physicist, Dr. Hans Bethe of Cornell University. But Woodruff complained that former Livermore director Roger Batzel wouldn't allow him to give his own assessment of the X-ray laser to high Reagan administration officials, including the late CIA director William Casey, as Teller and Wood had done. He resigned his weapons post in protest. After being given a much lower position, Woodruff filed a grievance with the University of California, which manages the lab for the U.S. Department of Energy. UC agreed to his demand for a more responsible position and appointed him assistant associate director for treaty verification. Meanwhile, Congress began an investigation into his allegations about the X-ray laser and what role, if any, UC and the lab played in muzzling Woodruff. Woodruff received the 1988 Hugh M. Hefner First Amendment Award for his ``willingness to jeopardize his career in order to go public with a realistic assessment of the state of the Strategic Defense Initiative program.'' Colleagues said Woodruff has been unhappy over his treatment by the lab and UC, which he felt should have taken a stronger stand in his defense.

DOC.HEAD: Six Mutilated Bodies Found in Monrovia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with more killings, reax, background. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The mutilated bodies of six soldiers, one of them decapitated, were dumped today in the Liberian capital. A diplomat said the killings were tribal slayings related to a rebel onslaught. A day earlier, four decapitated bodies were found in Monrovia, causing panic among residents who fear a rebel attack, the ELWA Christian missionary radio station reported. The identities of the men were not immediately known. ``There are rumors of a lot more such killings going on and fears that this is just the beginning,'' a diplomat said from Monrovia on condition of anonymity. The bodies found today were dumped around the city. One had been decapitated and the other victims had been ``hacked to death,'' he said. All were soldiers from the Gio and Mano tribes, to which many rebels belong, the diplomat said. International human rights organizations have accused the troops of Liberia's president, Samuel Doe, of massacring hundreds of Gio and Mano civilians in its battle against insurgents. The rebels, led by Charles Taylor, have been accused of killing civilians of the Mandingo and Krahn tribes, to which Doe and many of his officers belong. The rebel National Patriotic Front invaded Liberia from neighboring Ivory Coast on Dec. 24 in a bid to overthrow the government. Doe's troops have been unable to halt the advance, and the rebels attacked the south Atlantic port of Buchanan on Sunday. The diplomat said there might be ``a few pockets of soldiers still resisting in Buchanan. But there is no doubt the city is in rebel hands.'' It was considered a major victory for the rebels. Buchanan is 50 miles from Liberia's main international airport and 90 miles from the capital. It is the country's main port and exit point for iron ore, which earned more than 70 percent of the country's foreign currency. The mine itself, in northern Nimba County, was captured by rebels last week. Taylor has said he is fighting to overthrow Doe and the corrupt government that has ruined this West African nation, founded by freed American slaves in 1847. Doe seized power in a bloody 1980 coup that ousted descendants of slaves who discriminated against indigenous groups.

DOC.HEAD: Police Raid Black Township at Night
DOC.TEXT: A thousand policemen conducted house-to-house searches before dawn today in the black township of Thabong, then drove a convoy through a neighboring white town to reassure its residents. Twelve people have died this week in clashes with police and in mob attacks in Thabong in the Orange Free State province. Police said they arrested 39 people and confiscated knives, homemade weapons, marijuana and stolen property in their raid at 2 a.m. After 9 a.m., police said, a convoy of armored cars and police vans drove through the white areas of nearby Welkom to allay white fears and demonstrate the presence of security forces. Welkom and Thabong have been the scene of several weeks of racial tensions. Blacks in Thabong started a boycott of white businesses to protest harassment by white vigilante patrols. White vigilantes threatened to blockade the township and cut off all supplies. Last week, two white men were killed in a clash between black mineworkers and security officials. On Sunday, police fired on crowds of blacks trying to march from Thabong into white Welkom, killing 11 people, according to police. A former black mayor was stoned, stabbed and burned to death by a mob in the township on Monday night, and his business and home were burned. Albert Phakathi was the local leader of Inkatha, a Zulu-based political organization that rivals the African National Congress. More than 90 people have been injured by police and by crowds of youths enforcing the boycott or attacking black officials they consider to be government collaborators. Homes, businesses and vehicles in the township have been burned. But the streets were cleaned by youth organizations Tuesday. And a community group canceled its boycott of white businesses today, saying, ``It has created loss and sadness to many people.'' Col. Hennie Heymans, the police commissioner for Welkom, said the raid on Thabong homes was a crime prevention exercise and had been a ``total success.'' He declared the township was now ``cleaned up and stable.'' He said no complaints were received from the inhabitants, and pamphlets were distributed urging them not to be intimidated by radicals. But local news organizations quoted residents as saying police banged on their doors, shouted at them and threatened them as they slept. ANC-affiliated activists under the umbrella name, Mass Democratic Movement, issued a statement condemning the raid and urging police to stop ``indiscriminate shooting, beating, tear-gassing and killing of our people. ``We also condemn the general harassment of our people under the guise of crime prevention,'' the group said. It also condemned ``the looting and burning of private and business properties (which) do not advance our struggle.'' Police said in their daily unrest report that four blacks had been killed in the 24 hours ending this morning. Three were burned to death by groups of black men in townships in Natal province, where more than 5,000 people have died in five years of fighting between Inkatha and ANC supporters. The fourth death was caused by a policeman defending himself from a group of black men who fired several shots at him, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Pioneer Aviator and Speed Record Setter Reported Dead at 94
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with son confirming death, inserting day of death and new quote, only survivor. Pickup 5th graf, `Later in...'. Subs penultimate graf to conform. Adds byline.
DOC.TEXT: Mary Victor Bruce, a pioneer race car driver, speed boat pilot and aviator once arrested for flying circles around the Empire State Building, has died, her son said today. She was 94. She died Monday ``of old age,'' said her son and only survivor, Anthony Bruce. She was born Mildred Mary Petre on Nov. 10, 1895, to English nobleman Lawrence Petre, the squire of Coptfold Hall, and his wife, a Broadway actress. Her great-grandmother was a California gold miner. Within months of taking up flying, Mrs. Bruce went around the world solo in her airplane, ``Bluebird.'' The 1930 trip included a crash on takeoff in Baltimore and Mrs. Bruce's arrest in New York for her stunt flying. ``She was flying such tight circles around the building that the typists inside said they could see the color of her eyes (blue),'' her son told The Associated Press. He said she was quickly released after the arrest and celebrated by New Yorkers for her daredevilry. Later in the same decade, Mrs. Bruce performed dives from 2,000 feet to 50 feet for a flying circus. She founded and owned an air ferry service that flew British newspapers and executives across the English Channel to Paris in time for breakfast. The airline was the first to use stewardesses, substituting young women for the traditionally male stewards. In race car driving, Mrs. Bruce won the 1927 Ladies Cup at Monte Carlo and set 117 world records for motoring, including traveling the farthest north into Lapland by motor car. Mrs. Bruce, who never wore slacks but frequently pearls, also set records on water. She once set the speed record for crossing the English Channel from Dover to Calais by speed boat and the 24-hour record for distance covered at sea _ 674 miles _ set in 1929. She married Victor Austin Bruce in 1929. They were divorced in 1941. At the age of 81, she made a comeback after 37 years out of the air and flew a loop the loop on a two-seater plane.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Loses Effort To Block Report of Her Divorce
DOC.TEXT: A judge ruled against a woman who sued a newspaper in an effort to prohibit it from printing news of her divorce. ``The state of Rhode Island ... has expressly made that information a matter of public record,'' Superior Court Judge Richard J. Israel wrote in the decision. The lawsuit was filed on behalf of a woman using the name Jane Doe. She was delaying her final divorce decree in hopes it would not be printed in The Newport Daily News. The newspaper reported the judge's decision Tuesday. A second woman, calling herself Allison Roe, was allowed to join the suit earlier this month. The woman claimed that she received obscene phone calls the day her divorce notice appeared in the paper. Thomas W. Kelly, the attorney for the two women, argued that printing divorce records of private persons violated the state Privacy Act. But Joseph V. Cavanagh Jr., the paper's lawyer, argued that divorces are considered public information. He said the U.S. Supreme Court had ruled in favor of newspapers that printed court information. Cavanagh also argued any ban would violate the First Amendment to the Constitution. Israel did not rule on the constitutional issue but rejected Kelly's privacy argument. ``It was a mistake for Jane Doe or any other person to seek a court order telling The Daily News not to publish the news about divorces or other matters in court,'' said David B. Offer, editor of the paper.

DOC.HEAD: Antonin Kapek, Former Politburo Member, Dies in Apparent Suicide
DOC.TEXT: Antonin Kapek, a former Politburo member and Communist Party boss of Prague, was found hanged at his daughter's cottage and apparently committed suicide, the state news agency said today. He was 68. Kapek had tried to commit suicide in January, and was hospitalized after being found shot in the head near an isolated country house in Bohemia. Kapek supported the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia that crushed the ``Prague Spring'' reforms in 1968. The Warsaw Pact nations that participated in the invasion have now officially declared it a mistake. On Tuesday, Kapek was found hanged in his daughter's country cottage in west Bohemia, according to the CTK news agency. ``No other person's responsibility was found,'' the agency said. Viliam Salgovic, a former member of the Slovak Politburo, also committed suicide earlier this year, following the peaceful revolution that ousted the Communists from power. Miroslav Stepan, Kapek's successor as Prague Communist Party chief, is currently in custody. He will stand trial on charges of abuse of power and faces a jail term of up to 10 years.

DOC.HEAD: State Loses Bid To Force Airport Open to Malathion Helicopters
DOC.TEXT: The state's anti-Medfly air force is homeless. Forced from its base in suburban El Monte by noise complaints, agricultural officials wanted to move the squadron of pesticide-spraying helicopters to Fullerton Municipal Airport. City officials went to court to block the move. Orange County Superior Court Commissioner Julian Cimbaluk on Tuesday denied the state's request for a temporary restraining order that would have forced Fullerton city officials to open the airport to the helicopters. Agriculture officials pledged to find someplace else to base the choppers before tonight's scheduled malathion spraying of Garden Grove and Panorama City. The state's Medfly Project lost its base at the El Monte Airport last week after neighbors complained about noise from the nighttime missions, which began last summer. Cimbaluk ruled the state failed to prove an emergency existed to warrant an injunction. The commissioner scheduled a full hearing on the issue for June 8. Meanwhile, two lawsuits filed by the city of Los Angeles and the Natural Resources Defense Council and aimed at halting aerial malathion spraying of urban areas are headed for court July 26, state Assemblyman Richard Katz said. ``These lawsuits are designed to end the aerial spraying and force the state to put health factors above economic considerations,'' Katz said Tuesday. Agriculture officials contend the spraying and massive releases of sterile flies are the best ways to protect California's multibillion-dollar agriculture industry from the Mediterranean fruit flies. They also maintain that the amount of malathion being sprayed is not harmful to humans or animals. Opponents claim more study of malathion's health effects is needed.

DOC.HEAD: Commission: Don't Rely on Standardized Tests
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Recasts lede to CORRECT that commission not calling for ban on elementary school testing. Picks up 2nd graf pvs, The National Commission.
DOC.TEXT: Overuse of standardized test scores is cutting off education and job opportunities for countless children and adults who are not being evaluated fairly, a commission said today. The National Commission on Testing and Public Policy released a highly critical study of standardized, multiple-choice tests and said educational and employment testing should be changed so that the talents of all Americans are promoted. ``We recognize that in the past some tests have been a positive force for numerous individuals and institutions,'' the report said. ``However, the growing over-reliance on testing over the past several decades deprives the nation of much of the talent it needs and sometimes conflicts with the nation's ideals of fairness and equal opportunity,'' it said. Commission Director George Madaus said the main message is to ``move away from a single test score to select people, the way we've been using them, to open doors, to identify talent and to help nurture talent.'' The commission report, ``From Gatekeeper to Gateway: Transforming Testing in America,'' is based on a three-year study of more than 75 reports by scholars as well as hearings across the country. From 1972-85, the number of state standardized testing programs grew from one to 34. This year, every state in the nation has a mandated testing program. The study said standardized test scores often are the single barrier keeping promising students out of schools and competent employees from obtaining jobs or promotions. Madaus said today that more is at stake than simple justice for minority groups who tend to perform relatively poorly on standardized tests. ``As a practical matter, the demographics are such that these groups are going to be more and more represented in our society,'' he said. ``We can't afford any longer to exclude them from education and employment opportunities at which they would succeed, on the basis of a single test score.'' Madaus said no other industrialized Western nation has a comparable system of standardized testing. Some use rigorous examinations at the high school or college levels, he said, ``but there's nothing equivalent to the elementary and secondary school testing that we have here.'' According to the study, tests may mislead as indicators of performance and scores can be affected by numerous outside factors, such as anxiety, noise level of the testing environment and test-taking habits. All tests are to some extent culturally dependent and almost always reflect the dominant or national culture in both form and content, it said. Differences between average scores of black and white Americans are fairly substantial, the report said, and in employment tests only 16 percent of black Americans score above the median scores of white Americans. Black Americans have scored on average 100 points below white Americans on Scholastic Aptitude Tests. In 1988, women averaged 56 points lower than men on the SAT, the study said. Hispanics, Native Americans, native Pacific Islanders, some Asian Americans and other minorities tend to score significantly lower on many tests, the study showed. There is too much educational testing, the study said, noting that mandatory testing consumes some 20 million school days and the equivalent of $700 million to $900 million in direct and indirect expenditures annually. Each year elementary and secondary students take 127 million separate tests mandated by states and districts. Achievement testing is required for first graders in nine states; for second graders in nine states; and for third graders in 27 states. The commission recommended banning standardized testing for all elementary students, especially those in preschool and first grade. ``Four and five-year-olds are simply too young to be subjected to standardized testing as a measure of achievement,'' said the report. ``(The commission) hopes as a result of the study, many governors will rely on the findings of this report to back away from prior calls for more testing at younger levels.'' In other recommendations, the commission called for: _Re-evaluating the judging of the quality of tests, the names given to them, the way results are reported, and the ways they are used. No testing program should be tolerated that classifies people as unable to learn, it said. _Instead of merely multiple-choice tests, candidates should supply answers, perform acts, demonstrate skills, create products and supply portfolios. _Evaluating critically the fairness and accuracy of all test-based classifications in terms of the opportunities being allocated. _Test scores should not be used by themselves to determine kindergarten entry, grade promotion, graduation, or employment opportunities. _Assessment of the effectiveness of institutions and programs should differ from assessment of individuals. The commission, formed by the Ford Foundation in 1987 and administered through Boston College, is a group of education, government, labor and business leaders.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Candidates Appeal for International Help in Drug War
DOC.TEXT: A leading presidential candidate accused the United States and other nations of failing to do enough to help fight drug barons, and a second candidate promised to seek United Nations mediation in the drug war. ``The nations of the world have an obligation to help us,'' Alvaro Gomez said in statements published in Bogota's El Espectador newspaper today. Gomez, a center-right candidate for the National Salvation Movement, said he would ask a special U.N. drug council to analyze earlier peace proposals by Colombia's powerful drug lords as a way to stop terrorism. His opinions were echoed by front-runner Cesar Gaviria of the governing Liberal Party. Gaviria said the rest of the world has left Colombia alone in its violent drug war. He said industrialized countries such as the United States continue to consume huge quantities of cocaine but are not doing enough to help Colombia fight the drug barons. Authorities blame cocaine traffickers for killing 259 Colombians since August, when President Virgilio Barco began his most sweeping anti-drug crackdown. In the past 10 days, five car bombs have exploded in three Colombian cities, killing 28 people and injuring about 300. Government officials said the new wave of terror is an attempt by drug lords to scare people away from the polls in Sunday's presidential elections. The army and police said they are mobilizing 230,000 troops to ensure peaceful elections, in which 13.8 million Colombians are eligible to vote. Military checkpoints have been placed on major streets and highways, and armored personnel carriers and jeeps mounted with machine guns are seen patrolling the principal cities. Three of the four major candidates have hinted at some sort of accomodation with the drug lords to end the violence. But Gaviria, favored to win the elections, has said he will continue the current government's hard line against the traffickers.

DOC.HEAD: Memorial Day's Birthplace Dedicated to Holiday's Original Meaning
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `Waterloo adopted...' to CORRECT to Decoration sted Declaration.
DOC.TEXT: Memorial Day for many means picnics, beach outings and the Indianapolis 500. And that bothers people in this village that claims to be the holiday's birthplace. People in Waterloo take Memorial Day seriously. ``The meaning of the day's been lost,'' said Joseph C. Donahue, a retired postmaster and World War II veteran. He is co-chairman of the Waterloo Memorial Day Committee planning next year's 125th anniversary observance. ``Nowadays, Memorial Day is thought of as a reason for a three-day weekend. A day for boat races, fishing derbies, marathon races or fireworks. There's lot of activities, but nothing that really has to do with Memorial Day.'' It's difficult to say exactly where Memorial Day was first observed. Southern communities like Columbus, Ga., and Columbus, Miss., began paying tribute to their war dead by decorating graves as the Civil War wound down, said Ruth Semtner, curator of Waterloo's Memorial Day Museum. Carbondale, Ill., held a community observance for its Civil War victims on April 29, 1866. Six days later, all businesses in Waterloo closed for the day while local citizens honored the war dead. Women prepared wreaths, crosses and bouquets for each veteran's grave, said Semtner. The community was decorated with flags at half staff, and veterans and townspeople marched to martial music to the three village cemeteries. Waterloo adopted May 30 as the observance date in 1868 when the commander of the Grand Army of the Republic, Gen. John A. Logan, established that day for the national observance of Decoration Day. The American Legion and the Veterans of Foreign Wars say Congress' decision in 1971 to shift Memorial Day from May 30 to the last Monday in May _ so workers can enjoy a long weekend _ diminished the holiday. While the two groups have lobbied to change the holiday back, the people of Waterloo never changed the observance date from May 30. ``It's not intended to be a day of celebration. The Fourth of July is a day of celebration,'' Donahue said. This Memorial Day, in keeping with tradition, the town will hold a parade to the three cemeteries, with prayers at each site. The central New York community made its bid as the birthplace of Memorial Day in 1965, and Congress and President Lyndon B. Johnson issued proclamations in 1966 upholding the claim. ``Many communities held Memorial Day-type observances,'' said John Genung, a Waterloo mortician. ``But they all fell short in one way or the other. They weren't formal, they weren't community-wide or they were one-shot affairs.'' While there is disagreement over the origin of Memorial Day, there is a widespread accord among veterans' groups that the nation should take the holiday more seriously. ``We're disturbed that it's become a nice spring holiday to go fishing. As we get further away from the most recent war, people tend to forget why the day is set aside as a national holiday,'' said Vern Pall from the Kansas City headquarters of the VFW. The holiday honors the more than 1 million American soldiers killed since the American Revolution, he said. ``It's a special day. The lives we lost were special and the causes they died for were more meaningful than a day off from work,'' Pall said.

DOC.HEAD: House Votes to Restrict Salvador Aid, Then Kills Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tops with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Foley comment, freeing of $4 billion money bill; picks up 9th graf, `House and ... .
DOC.TEXT: The House voiced strong disagreement with current U.S. military aid for El Salvador in a largely symbolic vote that Speaker Thomas Foley today called a ``watershed'' in policy toward the Central American country. Foley, D-Wash., said Tuesday's 250-163 vote to cut military aid was a sign of new thinking on U.S. policy, and an indication that ``in some form, military aid will be curtailed in the future.'' Propelled by Bush administration lobbyists and moderate Democrats led by Rep. Dave McCurdy, D-Okla., the House reversed course moments after that vote and killed the bill to which the aid curbs had been attached. But despite the murkiness of the situation, it was apparent that a solid majority in the chamber believes continued human rights violations by the Salvadoran military dictate an end to what some have called a ``blank check'' policy. ``The American people and the American Congress have been played for fools'' by the military and by extremists on both the left and right in El Salvador, said Rep. Joe Moakley, D-Mass., a sponsor of the aid restrictions. ``This must end and it must end now.'' Church and labor groups which had supported the aid restrictions hailed Tuesday's vote as a significant victory, the widest margin in favor of curbs on Salvador aid in six years. The Bush administration sought to dilute the victory by lobbying hard against final passage of the underlying bill, which would have provided authorization to send new aid to new democratic governments in Panama and Nicaragua. Fanning the normal skepticism of lawmakers toward foreign aid spending, the administration succeeded and the bill was killed, 244 to 171. Foley said today that having achieved a victory on the Salvador issue, majority Democrats would move to a vote Thursday on a separate $4 billion supplemental spending bill that includes $720 million in aid to Panama and Nicaragua. The bill, which President Bush has urgently sought, had been held up by Democrats to gain leverage on the Salvador issue. That meant the aid money _ along with more than $3 billion in add-ons for domestic programs wanted by the administration and individual lawmakers _ probably would win final approval before Congress leaves Friday for a 12-day Memorial Day recess. House and Senate negotiators completed work on the $4 billion measure on Tuesday after agreeing to about $2 billion in cuts from this year's Pentagon budget to pay for some of the new spending. The bill includes $300 million for Nicaragua's struggling new democratic government and $420 million for Panama. It also includes $110 million to help the Census Bureau complete its lagging 1990 head count, $435 million for veterans' medical and pension benefits, and $166 million for the Head Start program. Various powerful lawmakers also won approval of favored projects for their home states. Among the largest was a $185 million automated FBI fingerprint facility for West Virginia, home of Senate Appropriations Chairman Robert Byrd, D-W.Va. His House counterpart, Rep. Jamie Whitten, D-Miss., and other Southerners won inclusion of millions in disaster relief money for their region. During debate on the aid restrictions Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., noted that El Salvador's decade-long civil war has cost 70,000 lives, uprooted one-fourth of the country's population and left its economy in ruins, while the tiny country has swallowed $4 billion in U.S. aid. ``I don't see how anyone could be satisfied with that record,'' he said. ``It is time for a new approach.'' The amendment adopted by the House, sponsored by Moakley and Rep. John Murtha, D-Pa., would have withheld of 50 percent of El Salvador's $85 million in annual military aid this year and in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. Under the legislation's terms, if the government failed to pursue peace talks with leftist rebels, the rest of the aid could be cut. If the rebels balked in peace efforts, the aid could be restored. But Bush's congressional supporters argued that curbing military aid would amount to a reward to the rebels of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, who they branded terrorists. ``This makes the (democratically elected) government morally equivalent to the guerrillas, who have never participated in any electoral process,'' complained Rep. Gerald Solomon, R-N.Y. Opinion on Capitol Hill has turned increasingly against the Salvadoran military since the murders last Nov. 16 of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter. Nine soldiers have been charged in the murders, but there is widespread skepticism about whether the killers will ever be brought to justice.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Team Mapping Out Plans for Gorbachev Visit
DOC.TEXT: Aides to Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev have turned down an offer for him to speak from the steps of the Minnesota capitol, but he probably will appear in public during a visit here next month. Tentative plans for Gorbachev's June 3 visit were worked out Tuesday by a Soviet advance team and a State Department protocol group. The groups met with Gov. Rudy Perpich and scouted sites Gorbachev may visit during his six-hour stop in Minnesota after his summit meeting with President Bush in Washington. Similar planning is under way in California, where Gorbachev will travel after Minnesota. Although his itinerary is not yet set, officials in San Francisco said it will include a visit with former President Reagan and meetings with scholars at Stanford University. In Minnesota, Gorbachev probably will have lunch with Perpich, then tour the Twin Cities and meet with business leaders at the Radisson Plaza Hotel in Minneapolis, according to the tentative plans. ``Nothing is set in concrete,'' said William Black, assistant chief of protocol for the State Department. He said the decision by Gorbachev not to speak from the Capitol steps was ``their call,'' referring to the Soviets. Perpich had said he would like the Soviet leader to deliver a speech there. Soviet officials declined to discuss why Gorbachev won't speak at the Capitol. The planners, however, are expected to schedule some type of appearance where Gorbachev will at least be able to wave to a crowd. Some details of Gorbachev's visit were to be disclosed at a news conference later today. However, tentative plans call for possible stops at the Walker Art center and the Sculpture Garden in Minneapolis. Another possible stop is the Control Data Corp. headquarters in Bloomington. The only confirmed agenda item is a meeting in Minneapolis with a small group of business and agricultural leaders. Gorbachev is scheduled to arrive at Minneapolis-St. Paul Airport at 1 p.m. and leave for California at 7 p.m. There, tentative plans confirmed by officials Tuesday include: _Meeting for breakfast June 4 with former President Reagan and former Secretary of State George P. Shultz. _Speaking to the Stanford community during a visit to the campus from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. and meeting with scholars from the Hoover Institution and the School of Business. _Speaking at a luncheon sponsored by the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce with executives from 150 West Coast businesses, Mayor Art Agnos and Gov. George Deukmejian. During his June 3 stayover in San Francisco, Gorbachev will sleep at the Pacific Heights residence of the Soviet consul general, the San Francisco Chronicle reported today.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Reported Killed in Explosion of World War II Mines
DOC.TEXT: Eight workers involved in the dismantling of World War II mines in eastern Libya have been killed by an explosion, the official Libyan news agency JANA reported Wednesday. JANA said the victims were a West German explosives expert, two Libyans, three Mauritanians, a Ghanian and a Thai who were working for a West German company. The dispatch, monitored in Rome, said the explosion occurred Monday 60 miles southwest of Tobruk, a coastal city near the border with Egypt. Northeastern Libya, a former Italian colony, was the scene of some fierce World War II fighting involving German, British and Australian forces, and reports of discoveries of undetonated mines are reported occasionally. According to the Libyan agency, the fatal explosion Monday involved 400 British anti-vehicle mines.

DOC.HEAD: Student Activist Buried as Martyr
DOC.TEXT: A student activist who fell to his death while trying to avoid police was buried as a martyr and patriot Wednesday after a funeral procession attended by thousands of students shouting anti-government slogans. Riot police carrying clubs and shields remained on alert as the procession passed through downtown Kwangju. In addition to denouncing the government of President Roh Tae-woo, radicals shouted ``Drive out Yankees!'' reflecting anti-U.S. sentiment that runs deep in this southern city. About 3,000 students, many wearing white Korean mourning clothes, chanted and hummed funeral dirges as they followed the hearse carrying the body of Shin Jan-ho, 21. Mourners waved long colorful streamers printed with slogans. Shin was one of 20,000 students who came to Kwangju from around the country to take part in protests Saturday. He suffered fatal head injuries after jumping off a speeding train to avoid police checkpoints. Violent protests have been staged for five days in Kwangju to mark the 10th anniversary of a May 1980 civil uprising, the bloodiest in modern Korean history. At least 84 police and 400 protesters have been injured. During the funeral, six students wearing white clothes and black headbands carried a giant Korean national flag at the head of the procession. Others carried a large photograph of the dead student. Hundreds of citizens watched from the sidewalks as the procession wound along city streets to two university campuses where funeral rites were held. A traditional fortune teller performed a dance for repose of the soul at Chonnam University. Students frequently interrupted services with dissident songs and slogans. ``The U.S. _ real culprit of the Kwangju massacre _ get out!'' they chanted. The students dispersed peacefully after the procession moved to a cemetery outside Kwangju, where victims of the 1980 uprising are buried. Radicals claim the United States condoned the military suppression of the 1980 uprising, in which officials say 200 people died. Kwangju citizens say the death toll was much higher. Anti-American sentiment is strong in Kwangju. U.S. flags are painted on campus roadways for people to walk on, and banners and posters showing shredded American flags are common. The United States denied playing a part in the suppression of the 1980 uprising.

DOC.HEAD: Private Guards Pose Risk To Military Security, Parliamentarians Say
DOC.TEXT: Some private security guards hired to protect British military bases have criminal records, are afraid of the dark or fall asleep on the job because of overwork, according to a parliamentary committee report. Some guards have even smashed windows at the bases they were hired to protect, the House of Commons committee said. The report, issued late Tuesday, was based on an inquiry into security at the bases following a series of terrorist attacks, including the bombing of the Royal Marine Music School in September. The bombing, claimed by the Irish Republican Army, killed 11 people. There was a public outcry at the time when it was disclosed that private guards had partial responsibility for security at the school. Nearby residents said security had been lax. The report by the parliamentary select committee on defense found the standards applied to private security guards hired by the Ministry of Defense were far lower than those applied to the military. One committee member, Bruce George of the opposition Labor Party, called their training ``abysmally inadequate.'' As a result, the firms offer ``a consistently unsatisfactory and potentially dangerous'' level of service, the report said. Allan Rogers, Labor's spokesman on defense, said the report ``is a fairly savage indictment of the government and of the whole process of security.'' He called for government regulation of the private security industry. Of the 2,000 or so military facilities in Britain, 56 use private security companies. A spokesman for the defense ministry said security guards are used for low-level tasks to free trained military personnel for more important work. Rogers said the firms are hired because it is cheaper to use private guards than soldiers or military police. ``Some guards had proved to be hopeless _ physically incapable of lifting a barrier or afraid of the dark,'' the report said. ``A significant proportion of those presented by security companies failed (defense ministry) vetting.'' The report also said: ``It is evident that there is a very serious problem with the caliber of people employed by private security firms, arising in part from the employment of guards with criminal records or propensities.'' The report cited: _Low wages, high staff turnover and poor screening of applicants. _Guards falling asleep as a result of working two straight shifts. _A ``significant proportion'' of guards who failed military screening. _Cases of vandalism, including smashing of windows. The committee recommended the defense ministry not enter into any more contracts with private security firms until the industry is regulated by the government. It said it should consider replacing private firms with soldiers and police. The parliamentary inquiry also was prompted by bombings at Inglis Barracks at Mill Hill in north London in August 1988 and at Clive Barracks at Tern Hill in Shropshire in February. One soldier died and nine were injured in the Mill Hill bombing, and one soldier was injured at Tern Hill. After the inquiry began, there were attacks at military centers in Leicester and Halifax in February and two bombings last week in London. The overwhelmingly Roman Catholic IRA is fighting to get British forces out of Northern Ireland and unite the Protestant-dominated province with the Irish Republic.

DOC.HEAD: Declining Orders for Durable Goods Signal Slump in Manufacturing
DOC.TEXT: Orders for ``big ticket'' durable goods reversed direction in April after two months of increases and fell 4.1 percent, the government said Wednesday. ``It kind of a coincides with the industrial production report we saw earlier,'' which showed a 0.4 percent decline in April, said economist Thomas Runiewicz of the WEFA Group in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. ``It shows the manufacturing side is still sluggish and planners are still insecure about the future.'' The Commerce Department said durable goods orders to U.S. factories totaled a seasonally adjusted $123.3 billion for the month. The decline erased nearly half of the 8.9 percent gain during the previous two months after a record 10.5 percent drop in January. But excluding the transportation sector, orders for durable goods _ items expected to last at least three years _ were off just 0.1 percent in April. ``The volatility in orders the last four months is attributable to the transportation equipment industry,'' the department said. ``Excluding transportation, orders have been relatively flat.'' Declines in both aircraft and automobile orders in April caused a 14.3 percent drop in the transportation sector to $31.6 billion. The drop followed gains of 23.4 percent in March and 10.1 percent in February. Transportation orders had plunged 29.4 percent in January. Both Runiewicz and Kris Bledowski, an economist with Cahners Economics in Newton, Mass., said they expect the manufacturing economy to pick up later this year. ``Investment spending will rebound after a year and a half of depressed spending that was caused by lower profits,'' Bledowski said. ``And I would see a tremendous pull from Europe that is going to grow this year much, much more robustly than the United States ... that would stimulate demand for U.S. exports.'' Runiewicz also said he expects consumer spending in the United States to pick up in the second half. Non-defense capital goods orders, often a barometer of business investment plans, were down 9.7 percent to $36.9 billion after rising 13.3 percent in March. Shipments of durable goods fell 2.3 percent to $122.1 billion, but unfilled orders inched up 0.2 percent to $497.8 billion. ``The one positive note is that unfilled orders are still on the plus side,'' Runiewicz said. ``It means there's still a backlog there.'' A backlog of orders means there less chance of production cutbacks and loss of jobs. The electrical machinery sector posted the only gain, up 4.5 percent to $20.4 billion. Most of the increase represented defense communications equipment. The sector had slipped 2.1 percent the previous month after a 2.8 percent advance in February. Non-electrical machinery orders fell 2.5 percent to $21.8 billion after being unchanged in March. They had edged down 0.6 percent the previous month. Orders for primary metals also dropped, down 1.5 percent to $11.6 billion after rising 7.9 percent in March and falling 4.2 percent in February. Excluding defense, durable goods orders decreased 4.5 percent. Defense orders were up 2.3 percent to $7.9 billion on top of gains of 0.6 percent and 18.3 percent in March and February.

DOC.HEAD: Commuter Train Writes Late Notes For Tardy Workers
DOC.TEXT: Late for work and need an excuse? A commuter rail service is happy to provide a note _ but only if the tardy employee rode a delayed train. ``In the railroad industry business tardiness is not tolerated,'' said Sharon Austin, a division manager for Metra, a commuter rail service. ``So we can sympathize with people who are worried because they arrive late to their jobs at a bank or office. A note might read: ``To whom it may concern: This is to advise that Metra-Electric trains were unavoidably delayed due to difficulties encountered in suburban service on this date.'' Ms. Austin said she once copied a note 200 times for sailors. ``They were only 17 and 18 years old and scared out of their wits that they'd be considered AWOL,'' Ms. Austin said.

DOC.HEAD: Three Killed, 10 Injured in Courthouse Battle
DOC.TEXT: A soldier whose brother was facing drug charges opened fire outside a courthouse during an escape attempt, and the two men and a policeman were killed in the shootout that followed, a newspaper said Wednesday. Ten others were injured in the violent getaway attempt Tuesday in the southern town of Songkhla, the Bangkok Post reported. About 100 police took part in the hourlong shootout, in which the brothers threw hand grenades and fired a hundreds of rounds from M-16 and AK-47 assault rifles, the Post said. The escape attempt began when a policeman was escorting Suphon Phetchara from the courtroom after the defendant had met with his lawyer, the newspaper said. Suphon's brother, Sunthorn, pointed a pistol at the officer and ordered the release of Suphon, who was charged with narcotics and weapons trafficking. Sunthorn fired three shots, which missed the policeman. The newspaper said he and Suphon ran to a pickup truck and fled, chased by police on motorcycles. About a half-mile from the courthouse, the truck crashed into another truck, injuring the driver of the second vehicle and three passengers. About 100 policemen then surrounded the getaway truck, and a fierce shootout began. The brothers were killed, along with a policeman, the newspaper said. Interior Minister Banharn Silpa Archa, who visited the city 590 miles south of Bangkok, was quoted as saying security at courts would have to be strengthened.

DOC.HEAD: Strikers Return to Work At Cincinnati Bell
A version moved on business wires.
DOC.TEXT: Striking union members returned to work at Cincinnati Bell Telephone Co. today and began voting by mail on a new contract for installers, linemen and directory assistance operators. ``We're back out there giving service,'' said Chuck Givin, spokesman for the Communications Workers of America. Members of CWA Locals 4400 and 4401 held a combined meeting Tuesday and were briefed on the tentative three-year agreement reached by negotiators Monday. Union employees began returning to work at midnight, ending a nine-day strike. Mail ballots are to be counted by June 19, Givin said. Union employees walked off the job nine days ago when Bell negotiators demanded that they agree to pay part of their health insurance cost and that some lower-paid workers take pay cuts. The company dropped those demands during negotiations. The contract affects about 2,900 installers, linemen and information operators. It provides a 7 percent wage increase over three years; a profit-sharing plan that could add 9 percent in compensation over three years; and improvements in dental and vision insurance, a savings plan and pension plan, according to Cincinnati Bell spokeswoman Cyndy Cantoni. Cincinnati Bell serves about 580,000 customers in the Cincinnati area and neighboring parts of northern Kentucky and southeastern Indiana.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Says ``No Danger'' of Accidental Explosion of Nuclear Shells
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 23rd graf pvs, `I can ...' to UPDATE with confirmation of congressional call for independent inquiry; note this restores insert made in a0583, but then dropped in latest lead a0605. ^By SUSANNE M. SCHAFER
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today there were problems with U.S. nuclear artillery shells in Europe, but he said they have been fixed and there was never any danger of an accidental nuclear explosion. A published report said some experts feared a possible accidental nuclear explosion if the problems were not solved. ``It is important here not to over-dramatize the nature of the problem,'' Cheney said. ``I will simply say that ... there was no danger but that the shells in question did not meet the very high standards that we have. I don't believe there was any cause for concern.'' He declined to go into details of what was done to correct the problems, saying such matters were classified. Cheney, speaking at a news conference after wrapping up a two-day session with NATO defense ministers, was responding to a story in today's editions of The Washington Post. It said the United States was repairing artillery shells and examining the design of two kinds of missiles because of the possibility of an accidental nuclear explosion. Cheney said he was not certain at what point the German government had been informed of potential problems with the artillery shells. Maj. Gen. Dieter Wellershoff, West German chief of staff who briefed West German reporters in Brussels, said the U.S. had told Bonn of ``technical changes'' on the nuclear warheads. Spokesman Klaus Naumann said the West German military was informed before and after these technical changes were completed. Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg said he saw no reason to demand immediate withdrawal of the nuclear artillery. But he said the government hoped that ``a situation would come soon whereby the nuclear artillery could be scrapped.'' In the Netherlands, where some U.S. nuclear weapons are based, Defense Ministry spokesman Martijn Verbrugge said, ``We are always informed when the Americans are planning maintenance'' on warheads stored there. He refused to say whether or when Dutch officials were told about the problems reported by the Post today. U.S. troops in Europe were warned not to move the shells until they are fixed, the paper said. The problem with the W-79 shell, designed for eight-inch howitzers, was one of three found recently by Energy Department experts, the newspaper said. A special committee will be appointed to review the W-88 warhead atop the new D-5 missile being deployed on Trident submarines this year, the Post said. And it said special flight restrictions have been instituted pending review of the W-69 warhead on the short-range SRAM-A missile carried by some bomber aircraft. The W-88 and W-69 warheads use the same volatile fuel that experts feared could explode in certain accidents and set off the conventional explosives that trigger the nuclear explosives. Those conventional explosives surround a mass of plutonium and compress it from all sides to the point where the nuclear chain reaction begins and proceeds to cause a nuclear explosion in a split second. The artillery shell problem was discovered by special computer studies using new, more powerful computers in 1988, the Post said. Those studies raised the possibility that a bullet striking the conventional explosive could set off part of it, dispersing the highly toxic plutonium, though not necessarily causing a chain reaction. At least a dozen such accidents are known to have occurred in the nuclear age. But if the bullet hit while the shell were in the artillery piece, the barrel of the weapon might reflect even neutrons back into the plutonium to cause a nuclear explosion, according to the experts' thinking as described by the Post. The W-88 was feared to be vulnerable to an accidental nuclear explosion, but the W-69 threat was dispersal of plutonium, the newspaper said. An unidentified senior military official was quoted as saying, ``For a while, we were worried that these things might go off if they fell of the back of a truck and landed in a certain way.'' Special teams early in 1989 installed ``safing mechanisms,'' and the shells are being modified, the Post said. Energy Secretary James D. Watkins, though declining to discuss specifics or confirm all details, was quoted as saying in an interview, ``Without any question, safety has been preserved'' for the artillery shell. ``I can confirm that the admiral was concerned about nuclear weapons safety,'' said M.J. Jameson, the energy secretary's spokeswoman. As to details, ``I'm not at liberty to talk about that.'' Rep. John M. Spratt Jr., D-S.C., chairman of the House Armed Services subcommittee on defense nuclear facilities, confirmed that the subcommittee had called for an inquiry by a panel of non-governmental physicists into the safety and security of U.S. nuclear forces. Spratt's office released a letter sent to Watkins on May 3 advising him of the planned inquiry, along with Watkins' reply agreeing to cooperate. Spratt said in the letter that the subcommittee knew the department was already taking action but believed that ``an independent assessment will be as valuable to the department as it will be to Congress.'' When Watkins arrived at DOE last year, he learned of several ``highly visible'' safety problems. He started investigating and at some point he recommended the creation of a subcommittee of the nuclear weapons council, a joint DoE-DoD body, which was done, she said. ``He felt that the secretary of energy should place a greater emphasis on nuclear weapons safety,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Radio Says Three Killed by Rockets in Kabul
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of rockets rained down on the Afghan capital Wednesday, killing three people and injuring 12, Afghanistan's state-run radio reported. Radio Kabul, monitored in Islamabad, said 26 U.S-made rockets slammed into Kabul's residential districts, destroying several homes and landing next to a mosque. No one accepted responsibility for the barrage. The radio blamed ``Pakistan-backed extremists,'' an apparent reference to Moslem guerrillas financed by the United States and headquartered in Pakistan. For the past 12 years, the insurgents have been fighting to topple Kabul's Communist-style government. The guerrillas deny targeting civilian areas but admit they occasionally misfire.

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers in the United States and abroad. May 21 Argus Leader, Sioux Falls, S.D., on President Gorbachev's tour: Mikhail Gorbachev's decision to visit Minnesota has the potential to focus the eyes of the word on this nation's heartland. The Soviet president will visit Minneapolis on June 3, where he is expected to meet with business and agriculture leaders. If there is one place where this man, who offers himself as a visionary for a better world, can learn about the American way, it is in the Midwest. Just as Soviet Premier Nikita Kruschev did during his 1959 trip to an Iowa farm, Gorbachev will come in touch with the values and work ethic of people who make a major contribution to the strength of the free world. Despite political differences, there is an intrigue with the style of this Soviet leader that makes him more likeable than those who have preceded him. There is still need for progress. The summit with President Bush offers one opportunity to further advance those relations. The trip to the heartland offers Gorbachev the opportunity to shake hands with the kind of people who have made a difference. It will be worth his time.

May 21 The Times, London, on disarmament: Stressing the toughness of talks so as to claim noble achievements is an old tactic, and President Gorbachev and the American Secretary of State James Baker made full use of it last week in Moscow. With one exception _ the U.S.-Soviet agreement on chemical weapons _ Washington's references to dramatic breakthroughs should be read as expectations deliberately lowered. On almost every point on the agenda for the Washington summit on May 31, including agreement on a Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty (Start), serious obstacles remain. ... There is little doubt that negotiations came close to breakdown. ... First, the shadow of Lithuania loomed larger over the Moscow talks than either side admitted at the time. ... Second was the failure to make any real progress through the current stalemate on reducing conventional forces in Europe. This failure was a sure indication of the tension that has now entered Soviet-American relations.

May 17 The Marion (Ohio) Star on Bush-Lithuania: President Bush, defending his cautious approach to the Lithuanian crisis, could have called on Emerson, the 19th-century yankee sage who once observed that there is action in inaction. Instead, the president quoted a more recent Yankee thinker. ``I don't want to make the wrong mistake,'' baseball Hall of Famer Yogi Berra is supposed to have said. Neither does the president. His remarks recently were not as flippant as the Yogi allusion suggests. In fact, they were refreshingly candid and absolutely correct. ... The president said he wanted to avoid any action ``that would set back the cause of freedom around the world.'' Lithuanian officials reacted bitterly. Those same officials need to realize that their right to be free and independent is not the question. The question has to do with such practical considerations as timing and process and political reality. Those considerations dictate moderation and compromise. President Bush, like Yogi Berra, understands that.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: understands that.
DOC.TEXT: May 15 Concord (N.H.) Monitor on Sununu and Bush: (Chief of Staff John Sununu) is an outspoken bully given to belittling his opponents. But Sununu is also a decoy. As chief of staff, he is doing a terrific job deflecting anger at administration policies away from President Bush. ... When it comes to domestic policy, Sununu is the accomplice who bumps into you on the street to divert your attention. It is Bush who steals your wallet _ if, that is, you are part of America's middle class, the people financing the nation's obscene deficit.

May 17 The Westerly (R.I.) Sun on the population growth: Right now, there are 5.3 billion human types walking this planet Earth. That number, says the United Nations Population Fund, could approximate 15 billion in 100 years, a scant five generations into the future. During this present decade ... it is projected that another billion people will be added to humankind's total, that's at a rate of 100 million a year, roughly 275,000 a day. Big numbers. And they translate into big problems. At the present population level, we are unable to feed ourselves, whether the problem be one of production, distribution or economics. The horror stories of hunger and starvation throughout the world are brought to our attention daily. If the demand for food cannot be met now, what lies ahead? If the unacceptable pressures brought to bear on our environment by five billion people are trebled, what lies ahead? The United Nations report says decisive action is needed to slow population growth. The United Nations is right. And because the United Nations is an organization that transcends national boarders, it must play the leading role in determining what lies ahead. As the UN says, the alternative to action is to leave our children a ``poisoned inheritance.''

May 18 Grants Pass (Ore.) Daily Courier on drugs: Two psychologists at the University of California, Berkeley, say experimenting with drugs can be a sign of normal adolescent development. And they question the ``just say no'' approach to completely abstain from drugs. Jonathan Shedler and Jack Block concluded that adolescents who experiment with drugs tend to be better adjusted than abstainers or abusers. They say self-control may be more critical than abstinence. ... The study found drug abuse is a symptom of psychological problems originating in childhood and made worse by parents. While some may misinterpret the study as approving of some drug use, it did not do so. It found, for example, that at age 18, those who used marijuana once a week or more were alienated, lacking in ability to control their impulses and distressed, compared with experimenters. But it also found those who abstained were anxious, emotionally constricted and lacking in social skills, compared with experimenters. The study defined experimenters as those who used marijuana or another illegal drug no more than once a month. Shedler said the study's conclusions ``absolutely do not mean drug experimentation is something that is beneficial. But it does mean that some limited drug experimentation may not be catastrophic. It could be a sign of trouble to come or simply a sign of normal adolescent exploration.'' Shedler says more effective anti-drug efforts would identify ``at risk'' children who would tend to have drug problems later in life, and counsel them.

DOC.HEAD: Red Cross Assistance Centers Open, Flood Areas Expand
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with waters leveling off at dam and expected to crest at Liberty today. Picks up 12th graf, `In Arkansas...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LR1
DOC.TEXT: Floodwaters began leveling off at Lake Livingston Dam and were expected to crest today downstream in southeastern Texas, where the rain-swollen Trinity River surged over a milelong levee in Liberty. ``If I had to pick a cutoff day _ a day when this would start turning around _ it would be today,'' said Jim Mitchum, Liberty County Emergency Management coordinator. ``I think we're getting the worst of it now.'' The Trinity River Authority dropped the release of waters through the dam to 82,500 cubic feet per second early today. After four days of record-setting 100,800 cfs releases, the authority began dropping the rate Monday to 96,000 cfs and to 93,600 cfs on Tuesday. One cubic foot of water equals 7.5 gallons. The lake level, considered full at 131 feet, peaked at 132.88 feet Friday and dropped at 131.82 feet today. Elsewhere, floodwaters receded in Arkansas and wheat farmers in Lousiana harvested their crops early. Indiana Gov. Evan Bayh declared southern Indiana eligible for state disaster assistance. Heavy flooding since April 15 has been blamed for 13 deaths in Texas and one in Oklahoma. Flooding and storms elsewhere have killed two people in Illinois and one in Missouri. The floods have caused an estimated $300 million in damage in Texas, Arkansas, Oklahoma and Louisiana. So far, 79 counties in Texas, Oklahoma and Arkansas have been declared eligible for federal disaster assistance. Five Red Cross centers serving seven flood-ravaged counties in southeastern Texas began interviews Tuesday to arrange food deliveries, clothing, temporary housing, household furnishings and medical aid. ``I've got five kids and couldn't get anybody to rent to me because of that,'' said Melba Scott, 24, who's been out of her South Liberty home for two weeks. The Red Cross has estimated more than 4,600 homes have been affected by flooding in the seven counties. The agency has sheltered more than 500 people and provided meals to some 9,000 since the river was forced from its banks by torrential rains more than two weeks ago some 200 miles to the north. Workers in Liberty have been hauling truckloads of dirt and sandbags to a levee to protect high-priced lakefront homes and a drainage ditch leading into town. The levee has been raised about 2 feet in an effort to stay ahead of the floodwater. ``Our crews are working their hearts out,'' city secretary Beth Staton said. ``But as soon as we get one low spot fixed, the waters seems to come over someplace else,'' she said. In Arkansas, floodwaters receded in Garland County, where victims met Tuesday with Gov. Bill Clinton at a disaster relief center in Hot Springs. A 24-hour deluge of 13 inches of rain over the weekend caused flash flooding. ``We're trying to find a place to sleep and a way to clean our clothes,'' said Brownie Mitchell, one of 150 residents who applied for aid. ``We don't have immediate money to draw from for our families to have a place to sleep.'' In Lousiana, wheat farmers in Brouillette, where the Red and Black rivers converge, are harvesting their crops in a race against time. Runoff from heavy rain to the north is pushing downstream and is expected to flood parts of Catahoula and Avoyelles parishes next month. Brouillette farmers who erected a makeshift levee against the rising Red River are afraid it won't hold back the water. The 12-mile levee is protecting about 20,000 acres of wheat and recently planted corn and dozens of homes. Avoyelles Parish Civil Defense Director Cindy Dupuy said Brouillette farmers will lose money by harvesting their wheat so early but have no choice. ``We want to get it out,'' Miss Dupuy said.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: counsels them.
DOC.TEXT: May 17 The Record, Hackensack, N.J., on Sammy Davis Jr. and Jim Henson: They were among the most familiar entertainers of their time _ the high-spirited song-and-dance man whose smile was as bright as his copious gold jewelry; the gentle puppeteer with long hair and a bushy beard who turned a felt frog into a soft-voiced friend, philosopher and secret romantic. The deaths of Sammy Davis Jr. and Jim Henson take something away from all of us, but especially from children. Davis, who succumbed to throat cancer in Los Angeles at age 64, symbolized the triumph of talent and tenacity over racism. Henson, the creator of Kermit the Frog, the Cookie Monster, and dozens of other Muppet characters, died suddenly in New York Hospital at age 53. Davis' recordings have long been classics; Henson's films and cartoons are staples of practically any video store. The ebullience and sparkle these men brought us in life is gone, but their creative gifts will long endure to entertain us and our children.

May 18 The Press-Enterprise, Riverside County, Calif., on video games and reality: Nintendo, the Japanese computer gamester, has announced it will donate $3 million over five years to the pioneering Media Laboratory at Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The idea is to help children learn while they're having fun. Certainly these two parties are equipped to do that. But the sight of them shaking hands produces a vague sense of uneasiness. ... Commercially, Nintendo's instincts have been impeccable. Their game machines now are in one of five American homes. But charges of monopolistic practices swirl around Nintendo. American rival Atari has filed an antitrust suit and the Justice Department has been asked to investigate it. Much of this stems from Nintendo's practice of tying its software designers up with exclusive contracts that prevent them from adapting successful games to anyone else's hardware systems. To these charges Nintendo's president Hiroshi Yamauchi replies: ``If our terms are so strict they make people unhappy, they're always free not to accept them.'' Yes, they are: Free to walk away from an association with the outfit which controls 80 percent of the market. But then these decisions always cost something. As do the decisions on what proprietary interest Nintendo may claim in any research breakthroughs this union with MIT may produce. Perhaps it's that aspect of things, that pitting of ethics versus instinct, that gives rise to the sense of uneasiness. One side seems to have a head start.

May 19 Green Bay (Wis.) Press-Gazette on college athletics: There are too many incidents of recruiting violations, players who spend little time in classes and just plain bad behavior in college athletics. A better system than the one now in place is obviously needed to control such abuses. Two attempts at imposing controls surfaced in recent days. One is a good idea. The other isn't. If the good idea is not acted on, the bad idea may be imposed. The good idea was embodied in a Washington meeting that brought together men and women coaches and college presidents. Basketball topics ranged from shoe contracts to graduation rates to tenure to recruiting violations. Notre Dame's Digger Phelps suggested that a sport czar replace the National Collegiate Athletic Association as rulemaker and disciplinarian. Indiana's Bobby Knight touched on tenure. ``When a coach loses his job and we know he's a good coach, we know he's an honest guy, we wonder, `What do I have to do to keep my job?''' Knight said. Knight also said that a school's athletic scholarships ought to be based on its graduation rate. Louisiana State's Dale Brown and North Carolina's Dean Smith pointed to potential problems with the contracts coaches sign with manufacturers of athletic shoes. The good idea is that coaches and university presidents see the need for new action to rid college athletics of abuses. The bad idea was on display in Springfield, Ill., where a bill was introduced in the state legislature to make the NCAA's list of recruiting violations part of the criminal code. That's a poor idea for two reasons: _ First, such a proposal would add another complex duty to law enforcement's list of chores.
