Abuses in college athletics are serious, but not nearly as serious as other problems police and prosecutors are asked to solve. _ Second, while the Illinois proposal may die in the legislature, it is a sign that people are unhappy with athletics in state-supported schools. In effect, introduction of the proposal says that if schools don't police themselves, others will take on the job. Those in college athletics _ presidents and coaches in particular _ must do more of what they were doing in Washington. If they don't, they will eventually see what was proposed in Springfield enacted into law.
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
Study Finds Differences in How Fat and Lean People Store Extra Calories
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For Release at 6 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: A study helps explain one of nature's injustices _ why some people can eat with abandon and stay slim while others put on weight with the slightest dining no-no. The answer is individual differences in what the body does with unneeded calories. Some folks tend to store them as fat, others lay them down as muscle. Since building lean tissue uses up much more energy than storing fat, fat makers grow fat, while muscle makers stay trim. Many people seem to fall somewhere between these two extremes. The findings come from a unique experiment. Doctors put 12 pairs of identical twins on diets in which they ate 1,000 more calories each day than their bodies needed, and they got almost no exercise. When it started, all were slim men in their early 20s with no family history of obesity. After 84 days, they had all eaten 84,000 excess calories, but some had grown fat, while others stayed relatively trim. The man who gained the most weight put on 29 pounds and stored up every extra calorie somewhere on his body. The man who gained the least added 9 pounds and stored only 40 percent of the extra calories. ``It demonstrates for the first time that for a given amount of calories, you have differences in the body's response to the surplus of energy,'' said Dr. Claude Bouchard, who directed the study. ``The individual differences are amazing. They are huge.'' The study suggests that individual differences determine to what degree people resist, or succumb, to the excess calories they take in when they eat an ice cream cone or an extra hamburger. ``Almost 40 percent of the weight gain is explained by the propensity to store in the form of lean or fat tissue,'' said Bouchard. ``This is the single most important variable that has been presented in the literature to account for differences in weight gain.'' Bouchard's study, performed at Laval University in Ste. Foy, Quebec, in 1988 and 1989 was published in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine. In the same issue was another twin study conducted at the University of Pennsylvania and an editorial by Dr. Ethan A.H. Sims of the University of Vermont. Sims wrote that Bouchard's work ``will become a classic study.'' Because Bouchard's experiment was conducted on genetically identical twins, he was able to provide more evidence to support the widely held idea that obesity is at least partly an inherited disorder. When one man put on a lot of weight in the study, his twin tended to do the same. The study found that there was three times more variation in weight gain between pairs than within pairs. The study also found close links between twins regarding whether they tended to grow pot bellies or big bottoms. In the study, the doctors first determined how much each volunteer needed to eat to stay the same weight and then added 1,000 extra calories to each's diet. They lived under around-the-clock supervision in college dormitories and were allowed to take a half-hour walk each day. But otherwise they did nothing more strenuous than play cards or watch television. Experts believe that other factors also contribute to how people handle calories. These include their metabolic rates _ the amount of calories their bodies need to keep going while resting _ and how much they fidget. All the extra blubber did not stick long to the Quebec men. They lost the weight within six months. In the Pennsylvania study, researchers examined 673 pairs of identical and fraternal twins in Sweden. About half of the pairs were raised together, while the rest had been separated at birth. They found genes could explain most of the difference in people's weights, although there was a slight sex difference. Genetic influences accounted for 70 percent of the differences in fatness among men and 66 percent in women. Their childhood home environments had no effect at all on whether they grew up to be heavy or slim. Four years ago, the same group found that twins who had been put up for adoption grew to have the body builds of their biological parents, not the people who raised them. In his editorial, Sims said the two latest reports show that ``destiny, in the form of our genetic makeup, has a great deal to do with the shape of our middles.''

DOC.HEAD: Boesky Calm, Professorial in Testimony on Wall Street Dealings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT 2 grafs after 5th graf pvs, `Later, U.S....,' to UPDATE with testimony delayed this morning because of sick juror. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `Boesky pleaded.... A version moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: Ivan Boesky brought his command of Wall Street to federal court, calmly admitting to insider trading and giving a jury a lesson in risk arbitrage, leveraged buyouts _ and deliveries of briefcases full of cash. Appearing relaxed on the stand in the trial of former associate John A. Mulheren Jr., Boesky delivered his first public testimony Tuesday since his 1986 plea bargain, centerpiece of the nation's biggest insider trading scandal. Boesky spoke in a deep strong voice, occasionally adjusting the microphone when it failed to pick up his words. When a juror complained she couldn't hear his answers, he suggested he and the prosecutor go over the testimony again. That command is usually reserved for the judge, who put a finger over her lips in a hushing gesture to Boesky. Later, U.S. District Judge Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum had to admonish him for answering questions before they were asked. Resumption of Boesky's testimony was delayed this morning because of a sick juror. Mulheren, a diagnosed manic depressive, told reporters outside the court that he's trying not to let the trial bother him. ``When you face the kinds of things I face every morning, you don't get upset about things like this,'' Mulheren said. ``Try being a manic depressive for a while.'' Boesky pleaded guilty to one felony count in 1986 and paid $100 million in penalties. He served two years in prison and gave the government incriminating information about a number of associates, including Mulheren. Boesky is the government's main witness in Mulheren's securities fraud trial. The biggest drama could come later; Mulheren's lawyer, Thomas Puccio, is expected to grill Boesky about his own credibility and criminal past. Dressed in a charcoal suit and dark blue tie, testified that he received inside information about proposed takeovers from former investment bankers Dennis Levine and Martin Siegel, and that he had agreed to pay them up to 5 percent of his firm's profits for their help. He said he never gave Levine any money. Siegel, however, received $800,000 in three cash deliveries, Boesky said. ``It was assembled by a colleague out of my personal accounts, put into a briefcase and handed by an intermediary to Mr. Siegel,'' Boesky said. A fourth cash delivery was canceled when he received word of a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into Levine's dealings, he said. ``Did you understand you were committing a crime when you traded on inside information from Dennis Levine?,'' asked Assistant U.S. Attorney Scott Gilbert. ``Yes,'' Boesky said. Boesky, who credited Mulheren with saving his business from collapse in 1982, said Mulheren was one of the few friends with whom he shared the information he received from Levine and Siegel, although he never revealed its source. Mulheren, 40, is accused of manipulating a stock price and concealing ownership of other stocks to help Boesky cheat on his taxes and evade securities laws. He faces up to five years in prison and $250,000 fine on each of 41 counts. Boesky avoided looking at Mulheren, who once was trustee of Boesky's children's trust funds but later allegedly plotted to assassinate Boesky when he learned the speculator had fingered him. Weapons charges were later dropped. ``He wouldn't look at me,'' said the eccentric Mulheren as he left the courtroom in a red leather bomber jacket with 1940s air speed records stitched on the back. Under questioning, Boesky recounted his days as the son of a Detroit restaurant owner and his rise to head of his own Wall Street firm. He stopped now and then to explain a term to the jury. He left the stand to explain risk arbitrage, using a chart prepared by the prosecution. Siegel and Levine, the former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. banker who first implicated Boesky in wrongdoing, have pleaded guilty. Levine agreed to cooperate with prosecutors. Siegel is awaiting sentencing.

DOC.HEAD: Commission Criticizes Reliance on Standardized Testing
DOC.TEXT: Simple justice and workplace realities demand that American schools and employers stop relying on flawed standardized tests to decide who gets ahead, a private commission said Wednesday. Low test scores should ``never stigmatize an individual as a failure or permanently restrict the individual's life choices,'' the Ford Foundation's National Commission on Testing and Public Policy said in a report. But the panel of education, government, business and labor leaders said standardized test scores are often the single barrier keeping promising students out of schools or competent employees from advancing. The group recommended a series of steps designed to improve the accuracy as well as reduce the influence of the tests that many Americans must take to qualify for everything from kindergarten to office promotions. Among the panel's conclusions: Tests should promote human talents rather than inhibit them; multiple-choice tests should be replaced with better methods of evaluation, and test results alone should not be used to make any major judgments about a person. The report noted that minority groups and women _ vital to the workforce of the future _ score lower than white males on many aptitude and achievement tests. ``We can't afford any longer to exclude them from education and employment opportunities in which they would succeed, on the basis of a single test score,'' said commission director George Madaus. ``This report doesn't constitute a special plea for minorities,'' said commission chairman Bernard Gifford. ``What the report constitutes is a call to common sense. It argues that tests should be used where appropriate to the task at hand.'' The commission opposes standardized testing of preschool and elementary children but did not recommend a ban in its report. Instead, noting that such tests are mandated or widely used in most states, the panel said test results should not by themselves determine kindergarten entry, grade promotion or, later in life, graduation or job opportunities. The report said standardized testing has become pervasive across the country. One state had a mandated testing program in 1972 while all 50 had them in 1989, it said. Elementary and secondary students take 127 million mandated tests a year, using 20 million school days and costing up to $915 million in direct and indirect expenditures, the report said. For all the money and time and effort, the report said, the tests can be highly misleading. They almost always reflect the dominant national culture, accounting for the score gap suffered by minorities, and scores can be affected by any number of factors ranging from anxiety to noise level. Students and job-seekers would be evaluated more fairly if they had to supply answers and portfolios, perform acts, demonstrate skills and create products rather than simply fill out multiple-choice exams, the commission said. Madaus said no other industrialized Western nation has a comparable system of standardized testing. Some use rigorous examinations at the high school or college levels, he said, ``but there's nothing equivalent to the elementary and secondary school testing that we have here.'' The commission was formed in 1987 by the Ford Foundation and is administered through Boston College. Its report, ``From Gatekeeper to Gateway: Transforming Testing in America,'' is based on a study of more than 100 research papers by scholars and hearings conducted in San Antonio, Honolulu, Washington and Albuquerque.

DOC.HEAD: Officer Injured in Shooting in Northern Ireland
DOC.TEXT: Masked men opened fire with machine guns on two officers standing guard outside Londonderry police headquarters, and one of them was critically wounded, authorities said Wednesday. The second officer escaped injury, but two women walking nearby were treated for shock after narrowly avoiding the gunfire, said a spokesman for the Royal Ulster Constabulary. The Constabulary said five or six masked men ambushed the officers late Tuesday while they were on guard at a security checkpoint outside the headquarters building. Police said the wounded officer's partner returned the fire, but the attackers got away. A number of people were arrested in connection with the shooting, said a Constabulary spokesman, who was not named in keeping with British custom. No one claimed responsibility for the shooting, but suspicion fell on the Irish Republican Army. The spokesman noted that the IRA has carried out similar attacks in the past. The IRA is fighting British rule in Northern Ireland. It wants to unite the predominantly Protestant province with the mainly Catholic Republic of Ireland under socialist rule.

DOC.HEAD: Repair Work on Columbia Completed
DOC.TEXT: NASA said Wednesday it has completed repair work on space shuttle Columbia, clearing the way for a liftoff next week. ``We don't have any significant problems going into the flight readiness review'' on Thursday, said agency spokewoman Lisa Malone. Mission managers planned to set an official launch date at the meeting. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has been working toward a Wednesday liftoff. Columbia's flight with seven astronauts and the $100 million Astro observatory was delayed two weeks because of a bad cooling valve that had to be replaced in the shuttle's payload bay. Technicians began removing a makeshift platform and other work items Wednesday after performing a final check of the cooling system. It will be the first Spacelab mission since 1985 and the 36th shuttle flight.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Says Bush Spoke to Mubarak by Phone
DOC.TEXT: President Bush spoke by telephone to Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak but did not offer to increase further the number of Soviet Jews permitted to enter the United States, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said today. The Arabs are concerned about the heavy influx of Jews into Israel _ many from the Soviet Union _ especially those settling on the West Bank, in Gaza and in Easter Jerusalem. Baker's comments were in response to an Israeli radio report. It quoted an Egyptian presidential spokesman as saying Bush had told Mubarak steps were being taken to enlarge the number of Soviet Jews allowed to come to the United States. Baker, at a White House news conference, said Bush had spoken by phone today with Mubarak. However, Baker added, ``It is my understanding that the president did not offer to take in more Soviet Jews.'' Baker said, however, that as many as 70,000 Soviet emigres already are expected to come into the United States this year _ up from 50,000 in 1989 and 14,000 in 1988. ``So we are increasing the number of Soviet emigres that we receive in the United States,'' Baker said. The secretary of state added that it was his understanding that Bush did not give Mubarak a commitment to further increase those levels.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer Acquitted in Ashland Oil Scheme
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer was cleared today of charges stemming from a scheme with former Ashland Oil Co. Chairman Orin Atkins to sell confidential Ashland documents to the Iranian National Oil Co. Atkins, who pleaded guilty last year to conspiracy and wire fraud, had been a key witness against the attorney, Charles Barnett of Palm Beach, Fla. A jury in U.S. District Court in Manhattan acquitted Barnett, 39, of conspiracy and six counts of wire fraud after a four-week trial. The government had alleged that Barnett participated in a plan to sell the documents to the Iranians for use in a lawsuit against Ashland, which had not paid $283 million for seven tanker loads of oil. One of the jurors, Jack Perlstein, said the jurors followed instructions from U.S. District Judge John E. Sprizzo that they acquit Barnett if they found Ashland had defrauded the Iranians. ``We felt the defendant may have been guilty, but we went by the judge's charge,'' Perlstein said. Atkins had testified that after he resigned in 1981 as Ashland chairman but remained at the Kentucky oil concern as a consultant, he improperly obtained 259 corporate documents and tried to sell them to the Iranians for millions of dollars. Prosecutors alleged that Barnett became involved through his late father, Barney Barnett, who was a close friend of Atkins. Assistant U.S. Attorney Herve Gouraige said during the trial that the younger Barnett was instrumental in getting the Iranians to agree to the alleged scheme, although no money ever changed hands. The Iranian company eventually sued, and the case was resolved last summer when Ashland agreed to pay $325 million to settle the claim. Barnett testified his efforts were legitimate legal work to help the Iranians collect money from Ashland. ``During this time I was simply accommodating a client of the firm and an old friend of the family,'' Barnett said. ``My feeling was that (Iranian oil company) had been defrauded and that they deserved to get the money which they were due.'' At the trial, prosecutors presented a videotape of a secretly recorded meeting between Atkins and another conspirator, Roy Furmark, who had agreed to cooperate with investigators. The videotape showed Atkins urging Furmark to close the deal with the Iranians because he needed money.

DOC.HEAD: Dolphin Dies After Rescue from Thames
DOC.TEXT: A young dolphin that became stranded on the shore of the Thames River died five hours after an elaborate rescue operation, a veterinarian said Wednesday. ``It was critically ill when it got here and was suffering from pneumonia and a lot of skin damage through having been too long in fresh water,'' John Taylor said at Windsor Safari Park. A second dolphin has been spotted swimming with the one that was retrieved Tuesday. Taylor went to the river Wednesday to determine whether it could be saved. ``It will surely die like the other if it is left there,'' he said. ``These animals are tired and sick after swimming about 40 miles from the sea to the center of London.'' After the first dolphin was rescued, a veterinarian swam with it an isolation pool filled with mildly salty water in an effort to keep it alive. The police, fire service and Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals participated in an elaborate rescue operation after the dolphin, which they named Phoenix, was spotted beached on a gravel bank of the Thames near Vauxhall Bridge. Taylor said the dolphins may have come up the river from the North Sea in pursuit of salmon, which have returned to the cleaned-up Thames after a 145-year absence. Porpoises were also seen in the Thames last week.

DOC.HEAD: Bush To Push Gorbachev for Troop Reductions In Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs pvs graf 9, Baker said, with further quote. Adds last two grafs.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will press Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at their summit meeting to revive negotiations to remove tens of thousands of troops and tanks from Europe, Secretary of State James A. Baker said today. Baker, outlining Bush's agenda for the May 31-June 3 summit, also said the president will try to keep the talks from being impeded by unrest in the breakaway republic of Lithuania. Baker said it is important that a treaty be signed this year to cut U.S. and Soviet non-nuclear forces in Europe. Baker failed to make headway on the issue last week in his own talks in Moscow. U.S. officials said the Soviets were reluctant to conclude the accord until they were assured there would be reductions in German forces, as well. But Baker said the administration hoped ``president-to-president level of discussions can give some new impetus'' to the negotiations. On Tuesday, a senior U.S. official said it would be difficult to complete the treaty this year because of the German issue and also because of Soviet concerns about the steadfastness of the East European allies. At a White House news conference today, Baker said the treaty being negotiated by NATO and the Warsaw Pact in Vienna would ``change the map of Europe.'' Baker said it was up to Germans to decide ``the internal aspects'' of the unification of East Germany with West Germany. On troop levels, Baker said outsiders could get involved in the discussions, but here, too, the Germans were in charge of their future. Apart from Soviet concerns about Germany and the Warsaw Pact, the treaty also is lagging over differences about some of the weapons to be reduced and about anti-cheating provisions. Baker said the main sticking point is a dispute over which aircraft to limit. He also stressed the importance of verification. ``At stake is the destruction of tens of thousands of pieces of Soviet military equipment,'' he said. On Lithuania, where the Soviets have imposed a partial economic boycott to deter an independence drive, Baker said a long-term improvement in superpower relations depends on ``widening democratic values throughout Soviet society.'' Baker said Soviet policies in Lithuania ``may disturb us deeply, offending our fundamental values.'' But, he said, ``there is too much at stake ... to dismiss cavalierly the potential for progress.'' Also, Baker said the slowdown in conventional arms negotiations would not deter the Bush administration from completing another treaty to cut long-range nuclear missiles on both sides. ``It is a very good thing for the United States of America,'' he said, ``so why link it?''

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Say Bush, Gorbachev Should Discuss Angola
DOC.TEXT: President Bush should urge Mikhail Gorbachev to stop arming the Angolan government so peace talks can begin in an effort to end the 15-year civil war, a spokesman for the U.S.-armed rebels said Wednesday. The rebels want the issue discussed at the Bush-Gorbachev summit that starts here next week, said Jardo Muekalia, the U.S. representative of the Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or UNITA. Muekalia said attempts to start peace talks were at a crucial juncture and the Soviet position could determine their success. He called the Soviet attitude ambivalent, with diplomats supporting peace talks but the army providing the Angolan government with weapons. The Soviet Union's leading African Affairs official, Yuri Yukalov, was in Lisbon on Tuesday for talks with Portuguese government officials on the Angolan peace process. Yukalov said the Soviets would not halt their supply of arms to Luanda while fighting continued, and might even increase it if the United States boosts aid to UNITA, Portugal's Lusa news agency reported. The United States provides UNITA with an estimated $40 million to $50 million of weapons every year, although the program is secret and exact figures are not available. U.S. supporters of the aid argue that the Soviets give Angola's government as much as $600 million or $800 million annually. Muekalia said UNITA would require more American weapons because it had almost exhausted the supply provided in an emergency U.S. airlift in January. Officials of UNITA and of the Luanda government held talks in Evora, Portugal, last month and will meet again soon, he said. Muekalia described the talks as exploratory but said there was good will on both sides. He said UNITA agreed at the talks to recognize the legitimacy of the state and its president but refused to recognize the government as legitimate, saying only free elections could pick a legal government. However, UNITA appears to have dropped a key demand of establishing a transitional government composed of representatives from both sides to arrange elections. UNITA now appears willing to let the government of Jose Eduardo dos Santos rule until elections occur. The government appears to have dropped its demand that UNITA leader Jonas Savimbi step down, Muekalia said. That demand was one of the main reasons for the failure of a cease-fire in June.

DOC.HEAD: Far-Right Leader Pays Token Damages For Belittling Holocaust
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to CORRECT that Le Pen to pay 11, not 16 groups, token damages; Le Pen paying legal fees, not fine; UPDATE with 15 suspects released.
DOC.TEXT: Jean-Marie Le Pen, leader of the far-right National Front, was ordered today to pay symbolic damages to 11 groups that protested his description of Nazi death camps as ``a detail'' of history. A court in Nanterre ordered Le Pen to pay the equivalent of 18 cents to each organization, as well as $720 to each group to cover legal fees. A hearing on the case took place March 28. Le Pen did not attend the hearing. But he said afterward the decision was another move in the ``general offensive against the FN,'' or his National Front. Le Pen, 61, caused a scandal during a 1987 radio interview by calling the Nazi gas chambers a ``detail of World War II history.'' He has denied this and other controversial remarks were evidence of anti-Semitism. The National Front currently holds only one seat in the National Assembly, but has received about 15 percent support in recent opinion polls. Its central theme is ``France for the French'' and it advocates deportation of immigrants. Bernard Jouanneau, a lawyer for the groups that lodged the complaint, hailed the judgment as an important message ``to all of France and in particular to those who listen to Jean-Marie Le Pen's messages of hate.'' Numerous French political and civic leaders have accused Le Pen of creating an atmosphere of racial intolerance that indirectly led to the desecration of a Jewish cemetery at Carpentras two weeks ago. A corpse was mutilated at the cemetery and 34 tombs were vandalized. Today, about 15 people in the southern region of Albi were taken into police custody for questioning but released later in the day, reliable sources said, speaking on condition they not be named. Several newspapers in southern France published a letter today claiming responsibility for the desecration in the name of an unknown Moslem organization. The letter purported to corroborate similar claims made earlier by telephone. Police have said the claims are under investigation but there is no indication that are legitimate.

DOC.HEAD: McCain Pushes Case for Relatives of Soviet Defectors
DOC.TEXT: Four Soviet defectors want their relatives to visit the West but Moscow has stonewalled the request, Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., said Wednesday. McCain said he has asked President Bush to raise the issue with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at their May 31-June 3 summit meeting. ``The refusal to grant exit visas to Soviet citizens violates their human rights and contradicts the principles of human rights which President Gorbachev has enunciated as Soviet policy,'' McCain said. The relatives of the defectors live in Moscow and have applied for exit visas to visit the United States. None of the requests have been granted. The four defectors are: Arkady Shevchenko, a former undersecretary at the United Nations; Stanislav Levchenko and Victor Sheymov, former KGB officials, and Eugeni Novidov, formerly with the staff of the International Development of the Central Committee.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Lithuania Reportedly Offers To Suspend Some Independence Laws
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with report of vote to suspend some independence laws. Pickup 4th pvs, `Landsbergis and...'
DOC.TEXT:
Lithuania's parliament today offered to suspend some of the laws it has passed since declaring independence two months ago, but not the declaration itself, Soviet television reported. The Supreme Council of the Baltic republic passed a resolution that offers to suspend the laws. The brief report on the TV evening newscast ``Vremya'' did not detail which legislation was involved. The laws passed after the March 11 declaration include those governing Lithuanian participation in the Soviet army draft. Earlier today, Lithuania's president today encouraged countrymen suffering under the Kremlin's 5-week-old economic embargo to ``survive as though we were in a surrounded fortress.'' ``We are poor, but we'll not starve to death,'' President Vytautas Landsbergis said in a speech reported by the Lithuanian news agency ELTA. ``Our main weapon is unity and stamina.'' Before today's announcement, the Baltic situation was settling into a stalemate as Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev insisted that Lithuania and its sister republics of Latvia and Estonia retreat from independence.
Landsbergis and other Baltic leaders have said they are willing to compromise but will not surrender their goal of seceding from the Soviet Union, which forcibly annexed all three republics in 1940. Gorbachev responded to Lithuania's declaration of independence by cutting off oil, natural gas and key raw materials. Since energy supplies were cut off April 18, factories have ground to a halt, traffic has thinned out and 19,000 people have been thrown out of work. Soviet authorities have blocked hard currency transfers to all three Baltic republics, but otherwise have not used economic punishments against Latvia and Estonia for their more cautious approach to secession. Non-Estonian workers were striking at 21 enterprises in Tallinn, the capital, to protest the republic's secession drive. The Estonian government responded by trying to block food shipments to the strikers, the Soviet newspaper Izvestia reported. The strikes appeared to have little popular support. In Lithuania, Landsbergis said the Soviet blockade was ``strangling'' the republic, and Radio Vilnius reported that over one-quarter of all industry was idle at some point during the working day because of the shortage of energy or other supplies. The report, monitored in London, cited official figures that 11,000 industrial and 8,000 agricultural workers were unemployed because of the blockade. The sanctions have cost the republic $75 million, the report said. Beginning today, Lithuania said private motorists will no longer be able to buy gasoline. Gas will be reserved for ambulances, police cars, fire trucks, food trucks, armored cars, hearses and agricultural equipment, said Algirdas Brazauskas, head of Lithuania's anti-blockade committee. Landsbergis told a news conference in Vilnius that ``it is unlikely that the U.S.S.R. will lift the blockade,'' ELTA reported. ``The Kremlin's aim is to cause riots in Lithuania and make the republic surrender,'' he said. ``But Lithuania will not capitulate. Our strategic task is to prepare the public so that we could survive as though we were in a surrounded fortress.'' Gorbachev met Tuesday with the presidents of Latvia and Estonia, but did not budge from his hard line against their independence. Gorbachev, who sat down last week with Lithuania's prime minister, met at the Kremlin for 20 minutes with presidents Anatoly Gorbunov of Latvia and Arnold Ruutel of Estonia, the Estonian News Service reported. Gorbachev reportedly told them the same thing he told Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene: the Baltic republics must either suspend or revoke their declarations of independence, which violate the Soviet Constitution.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Says Pentagon Should Release Panama Tapes
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 4th graf pvs, bgng, `The Defense,' with 2 grafs of Pentagon comment; picks up 5th graf pvs, In an
DOC.TEXT: A congressman on Wednesday criticized the Pentagon's refusal to release videotapes shot by the military last December during the U.S. invasion of Panama. ``What is the military secret that has to be protected?'' said Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., who has filed a freedom of information request for release of the tapes. In February, Rangel requested the release of all tapes shot by U.S. forces during the December 20 invasion. But according to the congressman, the Defense Department has released a portion of the tapes while withholding tapes shot from Apache helicopters during the invasion. An Army spokesman said the Pentagon has released ``hundreds of hours of footage,'' but chose not to release the tapes from the Apache gun camera because it portrays classified military operations and weapons. ``It's not just videotape,'' said Col. Bill Mulvey. ``There are gun camera dials, distances to targets.'' In an interview, Rangel said he did not know what the tapes contained but noted published reports of Panamanians complaining that missiles fired from the Apache helicopters caused most of the damage to apartment buildings. ``Aren't the American people entitled to know what they supported?'' said Rangel, the chairman of the House Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control. The United States launched the invasion to remove Panamanian leader Manuel Antonio Noriega, who faces a range of U.S. drug charges, and help install a democratic government. In a statement, Rangel said release of the tapes to answer the ``nagging questions about the conduct of the invasion by actually showing what happened would be more in the interest of the national security than blocking the public's ability to judge for itself.''

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Truckers Block Border Crossings
DOC.TEXT: Canadian truckers upset over competition from U.S. drivers blocked commercial border crossings today, causing miles-long backups of big rigs. One blockade closed commercial lanes on the Ambassador Bridge leading into Detroit from Windsor, Ontario, and trucks backed up five miles into Canada. Parked big rigs blocked commercial traffic in both directions at another important border crossing, the Blue Water Bridge at Port Huron. Car traffic wasn't impeded. A third big crossing, at Sault Ste. Marie, remained clear, said Mel Hendrickson, U.S. Customs supervisor there. The action began Tuesday at crossings between Quebec and New York state, and spread to Ontario today. The Quebec blockades were lifted. The Canadians say American truckers bring in goods from the United States, then slash their rates to grab U.S.-bound Canadian business so they won't have to drive home empty. The Canadian truckers said such practices force them to work 80-hour weeks and cut their own wages. They also are upset over alleged lax enforcement of their country's trucking regulations on U.S. truckers. And they complain that a U.S.-Canada free trade agreement signed last year hurts Canadians because their industries are overwhelmed by competition from their more powerful neighbor. At the Ambassador Bridge, truckers parked their rigs in front of trucking lanes and walked away, stranding those behind them. ``I'm just a truck driver with a family. I'm 42 years old and I've been driving a truck for 20 years now, and I don't know anything else, but we can't compete with American drivers,'' said Wayne Whitney of Windsor, an organizer of the blockade. In Quebec, blockades called by the Quebec Independent Truckers' Association were lifted after provincial Transport Minister Sam Elkas agreed Tuesday to tighten controls on truckers from outside the province. But at least 200 Ontario truckers said they would continue blocking trucks trying to reach the United States. ``We'll stay here for as long as it takes until (Ontario Transportation Minister) Bill Wrye tells us we have a chance to make a decent paycheck,'' Whitney said.

DOC.HEAD: Silver Fetches $1.9 Million After Century in Vault
DOC.TEXT: Four pieces of early 18th-century silver that lay unclaimed in a bank vault for 101 years were sold for nearly $2 million Wednesday, Christie's said. The silver belonged to Thomas Wentworth, 3rd earl of Strafford, a distinguished soldier and diplomat who died in 1739. The maker was David Willaume, a French Huguenot and one of the three top silversmiths in London in his day. The Wentworth silver _ a pair of wine bucket, an ewer, and a basin _ was deposited at Glyn, Mills and Co.'s bank on London's Lombard Street in 1859 by a descendant who died soon afterward, as did his executor. ``The bank tried to trace other descendants but found none, and the silver remained in the vault until 1960 when a family descendant claimed it and sold some pieces in 1963,'' said auctioneer Stephen Clarke. ``The four pieces now sold were sent by a descendant of that claimant,'' he said. He said an unidentified telephone bidder paid $1.3 million for the wine buckets. The London dealers Armitage paid $632,000 for the other pieces. ``The silver had gone black when it came out of the vault in 1960, but we have kept an eye on it since then and it is in splendid condition,'' Clarke said. The record price for any piece of silver is $1.98 million paid at Christie's in New York last month for a 17th-century Sicilian table fountain.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Upholds Ban On Assault Weapons
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th graf to UPDATE with Senate vote against reconsideration.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate voted 52-48 today to restrict the import and manufacture of semiautomatic assault weapons, handing a surprising defeat to the National Rifle Association. ``These are combat weapons,'' Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., said shortly before the vote to bar imports of five foreign-made assault weapons and ban domestic manufacture of four others. The vote came as lawmakers worked on a larger anti-crime bill that also includes provisions to restore capital punishment for 30 federal crimes, including presidential assassination. Opponents of the restrictions immediately called for reconsideration of the decision. But the Senate voted 50-49 not to reconsider. The first vote on semiautomatic weapons came on a move by Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, to strip from the legislation the restrictions on nine different types of weapons. The outcome represented a stunning setback for the National Rifle Association, which had lobbied hard to kill the curbs. Supporters of the ban had said over the weekend they held little hope of winning. They said they expected to face opposition on the campaign trail this fall because of the legislation. Senate critics called for tougher criminal penalties in place of curbs on guns. ``Let's try 'em and fry 'em,'' Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo., told the Senate Tuesday night. ``That will start a lot of action in the United States and we won't have to worry about this stuff.'' DeConcini, the chief sponsor of the restrictions, scoffed at claims that they would place a burden on the hunters. He pointed to a picture of a Street Sweeper, a sinister-looking, round-drummed semiautomatic shotgun of African origin that he called ``an apartheid control weapon.'' ``Its not going to be used on deer because it would absolutely blow the deer to pieces,'' DeConcini said. But Hatch told the Senate that ``there is nothing in the Constitution that limits the 2nd Amendment to ownership of guns for hunting.'' There is no legislation in the House at present corresponding to the Senate crime bill. The bill would ban the import of five types of semiautomatic assault weapons and outlaw the manufacture of four others in this country. Other provisions would restore capital punishment for 30 federal crimes including presidential assassination. The measure would overhaul the way courts review the constitutionality of criminal trials. It would allow use of evidence gathered with flawed warrants and fine tune the money-laundering laws. It also would allow death row inmates to use statistics to prove claims that their sentences were the result of racial bias. A campaign for curbs on assault weapons began in January 1989 after a deranged gunman with an AK-47 semiautomatic assault rifle opened fire on a Stockton, Calif., school yard at recess time, leaving five children dead and 30 others wounded. The Senate held its first vote on the issue Tuesday, killing 82-17 an attempt by Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, to enlarge the list of banned weapons from nine to 21. Two Republicans joined 15 Democrats in the futile attempt to keep the measure alive. Metzenbaum sought to assure lawmakers that they could weather criticism from the National Rifle Association. ``Let us show some courage here today,'' he said. ``Let us stand up to the National Rifle Association and stand up with the police officers of this country.'' ``I know the political liability, it is no secret that some of the people on my staff are urging me ... not to vote for this,'' Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., said at another point. But he added: ``We're not going to be around here forever and we ought to be thinking about what we can contribute.'' ``We face the choice of siding with the gun lobby or the law enforcement people and, my friends, in that choice I'm going to stick with the law enforcement people,'' Simon added. Police group representatives earlier urged the Senate to approve the ban. ``The NRA ... has almost completely alienated law enforcement. We're not divorced, but we're estranged,'' said Baltimore police Col. L.J. Suspenski. He said he had resigned from the NRA because of its position on the legislation. The bill initially was part of the Bush administration's anti-crime package, but has long since been reshaped by majority Democrats led by Senate Judiciary Chairman Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del. The administration now opposes the measure. The plan would ban the import of these weapons: _Norinco, Mitchell and Poly Technologies Avtomat Kalashikovs. _Action Arms Israeli Military Industries UZI and Galil. _Beratta AR-70 (SC-70). _Fabrique Nationale FN-FAL, FN-LAR and FNC. _Steyr AUG. And it called for a prohibition on domestic manufacture of these: _INTRATEC TEC-9. _Street Sweeper-Striker 12. _Colt AR-15 and CAR-15. _MAC 10 and MAC 11.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Says China's Human Rights Record Not Only Factor in Trade Decision
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 15 grafts new to include Baker comments; picks up 12th graf pvs, If the.
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III said today that China's human rights record ``should not be the only factor'' in a decision to extend trade benefits for that country. Some members of Congress say Bush faces a heated battle if, as expected, the administration announces Thursday a decision to extend the benefits. While stopping short of actually announcing Bush's decision, Baker listed reasons at a White House news conference why the preferential trade status should be extended. ``The real issue is who gets hurt or who gets hit if you terminate it,'' Baker said. He said withdrawing the benefits would have a negative impact among ``reformers in the Chinese government,'' would damage the economy of Hong Kong and would hurt ``very significant and substantial'' U.S. economic interests in China. Baker said China's human rights record in the aftermath of the bloody crackdown June 4, 1989, on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square was ``one of the factors'' but ``it should not be the only factor'' in the decision. Despite the threat of a confrontation with Congress, senior administration officials said Bush would propose a one-year extension of the most-favored-nation preferential tariff treatment for China. Bush solicited comments from Republican leaders Tuesday. He was contacting Democrats by telephone today, said White House deputy press secretary Alixe Glen. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, has opposed giving more trade benefits to China and has urged Bush to overhaul U.S. policy toward China. ``By its actions, the Bush administration is sowing the seeds of disaster with respect to the next generation of leaders in China,'' Mitchell said. ``Like other despots before them, the Chinese government of today will pass from the scene in time. The question and the challenge for the Senate is whether we will continue to support a regime which caused the deaths of many of their own people,'' he said. Mitchell narrowly lost a congressional fight with Bush earlier this year over legislation dealing with Chinese visas. One key House Democrat, Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., criticized Bush for failing to build a consensus on China policy. Solarz is chairman of a House subcommittee on Asia, which canceled a planned hearing today to explore China's trade status with Richard Solomon, an assistant secretary of State. Solarz' office said the administration asked for a postponement of the hearing because it was not ready to testify on the issue. Meanwhile, congressional aides said Bush was expected to make his decision on the matter public Thursday. If the trade issue ``is not handled in an appropriate way, it will set the stage for what will be, I think, a very divisive debate here in the Congress, not on a partisan basis by the way,'' he said. Solarz said he is not opposed to extending most-favored-nation status, but he wants Bush to put attach strings to the extension. Administration officials say ``some conditions'' will be included in Bush's trade extension as a way of expressing displeasure over China's human rights. Most-favored-nation status gives China the same trade benefits, including lowest-possible tariffs, that the United States extends to most of its major trading partners. Cancellation of the benefits would cause tariffs to rise sharply on some $12 billion in annual Chinese exports. Rep. Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., a supporter of China's students in the United States, said she wouldn't vote for most-favored-nation status for China. Her main concern, however, is the $450 million in loans the World Bank is scheduled to consider later this month. Mrs. Pelosi would like the United States to block the loans. Several Republicans, including House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., said they would go along with Bush's apparent attempt to extend trade benefits. But the sentiment was not unanimous. ``I know the president thinks he has good reason _ American business interests,'' said Rep. Mickey Edwards, R-Okla., chairman of the Republican Policy Committee. ``But I'm bothered by the idea of granting special treatment'' to China, he said. Edwards said China has ``cracked down more, not less'' on human rights since Tiananmen Square. Edwards predicted Bush could probably win a congressional fight on China. Congress could block Bush's decision, but only by passing a ``resolution of disapproval.'' That, in turn, could be vetoed. And it takes two-thirds votes in both houses to override a veto. By a single vote in January, the Senate sustained Bush's veto of a bill to extend the visas of Chinese students in the United States. Bush argued that he was offering the Chinese students the same safe haven through administrative actions. On Tuesday, the Independent Federation of Chinese Students and Scholars asked Bush to suspend China's most-favored-nation status to demonstrate U.S. ``commitment to democracy and human rights in China.'' The federation says it represents some 40,000 students at more than 200 universities in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Defense Ministers Call For Swift Agreement On Arms Accord
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 4th, `The ball...' to UPDATE with Baker saying Bush will push same topic at superpower summit. Pickup 5th, `Western officials...' ^By SALLY JACOBSEN
DOC.TEXT: NATO defense ministers today called for a quick East-West accord to slash troops, tanks and other non-nuclear arms in Europe to wipe out the chances of a surprise attack by the Soviet Union. ``We appeal to the Soviet Union to show a constructive attitude,'' said NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner at the end of two days of talks by defense ministers of North Atlantic Treaty Organization members. U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney joined his counterparts in the Western alliance by urging the Kremlin to speed up progress on negotiating a conventional arms agreement this year. ``The ball is in their court. ... We are eager to negotiate such an agreement,'' Cheney said. In Washington, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said today that President Bush will press Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at their summit meeting May 31-June 3 to revive negotiations to remove tens of thousands of troops and tanks from Europe. Baker said it is important that a treaty be signed this year to cut U.S. and Soviet non-nuclear forces in Europe. Western officials have complained in recent weeks of Soviet foot-dragging at the Vienna talks between negotiators of the 16 NATO nations and the seven of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. The NATO defense chiefs said in a final statement that an accord, along with other security measures, ``will virtually eliminate the possibility of a surprise attack on NATO as a whole by vastly superior conventional forces.'' ``As a result, the minimum warning time for any large-scale offensive operation will substantially increase,'' the statement said. The officials said they also decided to ``lower the readiness and availability'' of some of their forces. Cheney said that with the collapse of the Warsaw Pact, ``it's not unreasonable for us to think ... that we would not have to maintain the same high state of readiness that we have in the past.'' The ministers noted they have already reduced the number of military exercises for their soldiers and planned to make ``further substantial reductions'' in the training programs. Many of these exercises are conducted in West Germany, and residents have grown increasingly tired of having their lands overrun by tanks and being subjected to noise from low-level flights. The ministers, as expected, called for a review of their own military strategy in light of the dramatically reduced East-West tensions. They also asked military authorities to look into forming multinational forces, drawing soldiers from the different NATO nations to create joint divisions. No deadline was set for NATO analysts to come up with a report. President Bush has urged that the summit participants launch a ``wide-ranging NATO strategy review for the transformed Europe of the 1990s.'' The ministers confirmed they have scrapped a guideline, in effect since the late 1970s, calling for a 3 percent annual increase in defense spending by each alliance nation. The target, they said, was ``no longer appropriate.'' Many nations have failed in recent years to reach that goal, and even fewer are likely to meet it now. British Defense Secretary Tom King on Tuesday raised the possibility that an East-West deal to cut forces in Europe would not be reached this year, which would be a serious setback to Western hopes for rapid arms control deals. The two sides are still trying to agree on a ceiling for combat aircraft and on measures to verify compliance once a treaty is reached. The United States currently has 305,000 troops in Europe, while the Soviets have an estimated 565,000 soldiers. Moscow and Washington have settled on a plan to trim their forces to 195,000 for each side in Central Europe, with the United States retaining an additional 30,000 in Britain and southern Europe. The NATO alliance is under pressure to respond to the momentous changes in Eastern Europe by emphasizing its role as a political organization rather than a military pact. It is battling some calls in Europe that it and the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact be scrapped and replaced by an umbrella security organization. That organization would be formed from the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, a 35-nation forum for discussions on human rights and other issues.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Blasts Yeltsin As Anti-Socialist
With AM-Soviet-Baltics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev attacked maverick Communist Boris Yeltsin's campaign platform for the Russian presidency on Wednesday, accusing him of working toward ``the breakup of the Soviet Union.'' Gorbachev launched the quick, sharp attack on Yeltsin at the Russian Congress, which he has attended as a silent observer over the past week. His speech exposed the deep concern that led him to sit through hours of tedious procedural debates. Yeltsin's plan for wresting control of the Russian republic from the Kremlin and allowing it to set its own policies amounts to ``an attempt to cut Russia off from socialism,'' Gorbachev said. ``That will contradict the line of perestroika, which we proposed to give a second wind to socialism on the road to democratization,'' he said. ``Can we do without Russia, if she decides to go another route?'' Russia is the largest of the 15 Soviet republics, with just over half the country's population and two-thirds of its territory. In Russia's second-largest city, Leningrad, outspoken reformer Anatoly Sobchak was elected mayor Wednesday, the official Soviet news agency Tass reported. Sobchak is a lawyer and member of the national legislature who has frequently clashed with Soviet authorities. He received 223 votes out of 320 in the Leningrad Council of People's Deputies, the local parliament. He faced two opponents. Gavrill Popov, the mayor of Moscow, the country's largest city, is also an outspoken reformer and member of the same opposition group as Sobchak. The Russian Congress is expected to end discussions on sovereignty on Thursday and turn to nominations for president. The president is chosen by the 1,059-member Congress rather than in general elections. The current president is Vitaly Vorotnikov. Yeltsin, a populist who won the backing of millions with his calls to speed reforms and do away with privileges for the elite, is the only contender for the presidency who has announced his candidacy. He has said he expects to face Alexander Vlasov, the current premier of Russia, and cannot predict whether he will win. Yeltsin's speech Tuesday on Russian sovereignty proposed economic independence for the vast republic and said it should have the final say over whether Soviet laws and decrees were valid on its territory. ``A serious analysis shows what he suggests under the banner of restoration of Russia's sovereignty means a call to the breakup of the Soviet Union,'' Gorbachev charged. Some observers at the Congress suggested Gorbachev's overt intervention in the race for president _ which could be seen as inappropriate because he is not even a member of the Congress _ would backfire and cause more deputies to vote for Yeltsin. Others said his main goal had been to get across to obedient deputies their duty to vote against Yeltsin, and in that he surely succeeded. The Congress was generally raucous, with a major disruption in the morning and loud heckling during Gorbachev's speech. In the morning, deputies shouted ``Shame! Shame!'' and jeered a monarchist colleague who erected a small red-white-and-blue flag, the symbol of czarist Russia, on his desk. He was forced to remove it. When Gorbachev was speaking, hecklers led him to retort: ``You're active, but I've met up with more active people.'' He accused Yeltsin of being ``confrontational,'' and appealed for greater harmony to allow reforms to move forward. Yeltsin was Gorbachev's protege at one point, but in the past two years has become his most vocal public critic. Gorbachev has rarely responded to Yeltsin's criticism with direct counter-attacks, but he has complained several times of radical ``demagogues'' who care more about their own ambitions than the good of the people.

DOC.HEAD: Rain Washes Out Cuban-American Event at White House
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tuesday in 2nd graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Cuban-Americans who came to Washington to celebrate Cuban Independence Day with President Bush went home disappointed after the White House canceled the outdoor ceremony due to the threat of rain. But several hundred others who showed up anyway at the White House gates Tuesday were treated to a tour of the mansion and an East Room rally where Bush made a surprise appearance. The standing-room-only crowd of 350 gave Bush a tumultuous welcome as he strode into the East Room just as Vice President Dan Quayle finished a speech denouncing Cuba's Fidel Castro. Bush called Cuba the only ``holdout against democracy and freedom'' in this hemisphere. ``I am convinced in my own heart that it will not be very long before Cuba is totally democratic and free,'' he told the exiles and their families. ``We are going to keep broadcasting the truth to Cuba,'' Bush said of his TV Marti broadcasts to the island, which Castro has jammed. ``We will keep the pressure on.'' Quayle said he hoped ``next year we will celebrate Cuban independence in Havana.'' David Demarest, who decided to cancel the event, said Wednesday that it probably was the right decision. Demarest, White House communications director, estimated a couple of hundred other Cuban-Americans came from Miami and other distant places and never got into the White House. Although it poured Tuesday morning and was raining as late as 1 p.m., the sun was shining when Bush spoke at 2:25 p.m. Demarest said 1,900 guests were expected on the South Lawn, which was ``soup'' when he decided at 8 a.m. to cancel the event. ``The tickets all say it's canceled in case of inclement weather,'' he said. ``We sent some people to the Miami airport to try to notify people.'' But hundreds still came by plane and by bus from New York, New Jersey and elsewhere. Demarest hastily arranged the East Room rally, where the visitors sang the Cuban national anthen and heard from Cuban-born Rep. Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, R-Fla., Andrew Card, the deputy White House chief of staff, and William Price, a National Security Council Latin expert. Then Bush showed up with John Sununu, his Havana-born chief of staff. Demarest said it was impromptu. Bush has held Rose Garden events in the rain, including greeting the University of Miami Hurricanes football team after they won the national championship. Jacqueline Tillman, executive director of the Cuban American National Foundation, said some members of her organization were disappointed. ``The lesson is if you're going to do it outdors in Washington in May, when it rains a lot, you need to have a backup plan,'' she said. But Demarest said it would cost money to hire Constitution Hall or other alternative sites. ``We don't have a budget for things like that,'' he said. ``We will follow up. We'd like to do a large Cuban-American event probably in Miami at some point in the future,'' Demarest said.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Nuclear Safety, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The three types of U.S. nuclear munitions that reportedly have been modified for safety reasons or are undergoing review are designed to be fired from field artillery, submarines and bombers. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney acknowledged in Brussels, Belgium, on Wednesday that officials found in 1988 that W-79 howitzer shells, currently deployed in Europe, did not meet minimum safety standards. He said the problem was corrected and there was never any risk of an accidental nuclear explosion. Cheney commented on a report in Wednesday's editions of The Washington Post, which also said the W-88 warhead atop the new D-5 missile being deployed on Trident submarines this year would be reviewed by a special committee. The newspaper said flight restrictions had been instituted pending review of the W-69 warhead on the short-range SRAM-A missile carried by some bombing aircraft. The W-79 warhead goes on an 8-inch Army artillery shell and is designed to explode in battle with a nuclear yield of up to 10 kilotons. That is about two-thirds the force of the atomic bomb dropped on Hiroshima in 1945. The Trident missiles are designed to be launched from Navy submarines at sea. Their mission, the Pentagon says, is to deter a nuclear attack by assuring U.S. ability to retaliate. SRAM, or short-range attack, missiles are supersonic, air-to-ground nuclear weapons designed to be slung below the wings of B-52, B-1B or FB-111 bombers or carried in the internal bomb bay, the Post reported. The Pentagon has said such missiles are designed to enable the Air Force to strike defended targets without flying directly over them. The Post said the yield of the W-88 is 475 kilotons and that of the W-69 is 1,100 kilotons.

DOC.HEAD: Doe Acknowledges Loss to Rebels of Major Port City
DOC.TEXT: President Samuel Doe's government acknowledged Wednesday that rebels have captured the country's main port but said it would send forces to retake the city. Acting Information Minister Moses Washington told a news conference soldiers will make ``gradual moves to recapture'' the Atlantic port of Buchanan to minimize casualties. Rebels of the National Patriotic Front led by Charles Taylor, a former Doe aide, invaded Liberia from its northeastern border with Ivory Coast on Dec. 24. Doe's troops have been unable to halt their advance. The capture of Buchanan, 88 miles from the capital, was a major victory for the rebels. It is the country's main port and exit point for iron ore, which earned more than 70 percent of the country's foreign currency. The mine itself, in northern Nimba County, was captured by rebels last week. Doe, meanwhile, ordered the military and police to set up a special team to track down the killers of 10 men found beheaded in the capital Monday and Tuesday. Doe, noting reports the victims were members of tribes that support the rebels, said the government ``will not encourage, condone or resort to sectional killings of peaceful citizens.'' His information minister said the killings were being perpetrated by people ``determined to stir up further trouble by doing strange things to embarrass the government.'' Police said only one of the bodies had been identified, as Sgt. Y.S. Grabia of the Liberian army. Local newspapers quoted Grabia's wife as saying he was arrested at their home Sunday night with some other men. The newspapers did not identify the woman by name or say whether they knew the fate of the others. A diplomatic source in Monrovia, reached by telephone from Abidjan, Ivory Coast, said the killings were tribal murders related to the rebels' attempt to overthrow Doe. ``There are rumors of a lot more of such killings going on, and fears that this is just the beginning,'' said the diplomat on condition of anonymity. The bodies were found ``dumped around the city,'' the diplomat said, adding all those killed were government soldiers from the Gio and Mano tribes to which many rebels belong. International human rights organizations and survivors accuse Doe's troops of massacring hundreds of Gio and Mano civilians in the battle against insurgents. The rebels are accused of killing civilians of the Mandingo and Krahn tribes, to which Doe and many of his officers belong. Taylor has accused Doe's government of corruption and bringing ruin to this West African nation, which was founded by freed American slaves in 1847. He calls himself a capitalist. Doe seized power in a bloody 1980 coup that ousted the descendants of the slaves, who discriminated against indigenous groups.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Wants to Reduce Readiness of Soldiers in Europe
DOC.TEXT: NATO defense chiefs said Wednesday the Soviet military threat has declined so much they can begin reducing the readiness of their soldiers to fight a war in Europe. Defense ministers of the North Atlanic Treaty Organization ended two days of talks by setting in motion a wide-ranging study of the military strategy that guided the Western alliance during the Cold War years. ``Today's meeting signifies an important step toward a new security relationship in Europe,'' NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner said. Among the changes to be studied are less emphasis on troop readiness and cuts in availability, the defense ministers said in a final statement. More emphasis will be placed on reserve forces, they said. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said that with the unraveling of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact, ``we can afford to change the current status of our forces.'' ``These are drastic changes,'' said Gen. Klaus Naumann, security adviser to Defense Minister Gerhard Stoltenberg of West Germany. NATO leaders will meet in London in early July to formally launch the overall review of alliance policy. NATO is under pressure to respond to the momentous changes in Eastern Europe by emphasizing its role as a political organization rather than a military pact. In their statement, the defense ministers also appealed to the Kremlin to speed progress so that agreement can be reached this year on slashing troops, tanks and other non-nuclear arms in Europe. ``The ball is in their court. ... We are eager to negotiate such an agreement,'' said Cheney. Western officials in recent weeks have accused the Soviets of foot-dragging at talks in Vienna between negotiators of the 16 NATO nations and the seven Warsaw Pact countries. Moscow and Washington have settled on a plan to trim their forces to 195,000 for each side in Central Europe, with the United States retaining an additional 30,000 in Britain and southern Europe. The United States currently has 305,000 troops in Europe, while the Soviets have an estimated 565,000. Still unresolved are reductions in combat aircraft and measures to ensure compliance with an eventual accord. In Washington on Wednesday, Secretary of State James A. Baker II said President Bush will press Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to revive the Vienna negotiations when the leaders meet at the May 31-June 3 summit. The ministers' statement said an accord on troop reduction, coupled with other security measures, would ``virtually eliminate the possibility of a surprise attack on NATO as a whole by vastly superior conventional forces.'' ``As a result, the minimum warning time for any large-scale offensive operation will substantially increase,'' the statement said. Cheney said later the warning period has been moved from a few days to ``at least a few months.'' Consequently, U.S. officials said readiness time for some NATO units will be lengthened on July 1. ``A (helicopter) unit, which is now supposed ... to be ready to go within four hours of the gun going off, now has 48 hours,'' said Stephen Hadley, assistant defense secretary for international security policy. Cheney said earlier the United States could now also consider revising its readiness time to send troops to Europe to fend off an attack. Currently, the United States must be prepared to deploy 10 divisions of soldiers within 10 days. In the future, he suggested reserve units might be given a few months to get ready. The ministers also said they would make more cuts in military exercises and training programs, some of which can be replaced with computer simulations. ``This will reduce the impact on the public, will benefit the quality of life and protect the environment,'' the statement said. Many of NATO's war games take place in Germany, where residents are fed up with tanks rolling down their highways and military aircraft flying low over their houses.

DOC.HEAD: AFO-CIO Plans Campaign for National Health Care
DOC.TEXT: The AFL-CIO will launch a $4 million television campaign in an effort to rally support for a national health care program, union president Lane Kirkland said Wednesday. The 14.2 million-member federation also plans to hold summer hearings around the country to explore options for containing health care costs that have been rising by 20 percent a year, Kirkland said. Americans who have health insurance are paying for the 37 million Americans who are uninsured because their employers are ``freeloading on the rest of us,'' Kirkland said. Another 50 million Americans have inadequate insurance, he said. ``The AFL-CIO intends to expose the dimension of the nation's health care crisis for the rest of 1990 and as far into the future as it takes to get a solution through Congress,'' Kirkland said at a news conference. Last year, organized labor enlisted Polish Solidarity leader Lech Walesa for its ``Union Yes'' TV blitz aimed at improving the image of U.S. unions. Kirkland said the new round of TV campaigns, which will run this fall, will be designed to build support among Americans for national health care legislation. Labor wants to ``spread the net of support as wide as we can,'' Kirkland said, including soliciting business' help. ``To those who believe this crisis doesn't affect them, we say you are wrong. ... If you think it's only your neighbor's problem, just wait until tomorrow,'' Kirkland said. In the past, the AFL-CIO has backed legislation to require private employers to provide private health insurance to workers. However, at the federation's executive council meeting in February, labor leaders didn't back a specific proposal and instead said they were committed to finding a solution as long as it was fair, affordable and provided access for all Americans. ``We are in a negotiating mode,'' Kirkland said. On another matter, Kirkland said a special panel studying whether labor should take a stand on abortion expected to have a recommendation by August. The president of Planned Parenthood and a high-ranking official of the Roman Catholic Church will meet with labor leaders in July, Kirkland said. Women union members have been pressing the AFL-CIO _ traditionally led by older men _ to back abortion rights for women. Anti-abortion groups have urged the federation to stay out of the controversy, saying a pro-choice stand would cost the AFL-CIO membership.

DOC.HEAD: Coalition Seeks Alternative To Federal Transportation Policy
DOC.TEXT: Groups critical of the government's new transportation policy laid out their own plan Wednesday, calling for more support for mass transit and pedal power and less reliance on autos and airplanes. Harriet Parcells of the National Association of Railroad Passengers said 27 organizations and several members of Congress support the plan. ``U.S. transportation policy neglects clean, energy-efficient alternatives to driving alone and jeopardizes not only our mobility but the health of our environment, economy and our cities and U.S. energy security,'' Parcells told a news conference on the Capitol lawn. Several speakers from environmental, consumer and labor groups attacked the National Transportation Policy announced by the government in February. The federal policy covers most of the concerns the groups cited but puts more emphasis on state and local funding and decision-making. ``The federal government can't just stand back and referee from the sidelines,'' Parcells said. Announcing the Campaign for New Transportation Priorities, the groups outlined eight goals: preserve the existing infrastructure, reduce congestion, enhance energy security, protect the environment, improve safety, curtail auto and truck subsidies, create liveable communities, and promote new research. Ms. Parcells said the group has no estimate of the overall cost of its proposals but said money would be provided primarily by diverting funding from federal programs that will lead to more pollution and energy waste. Among the coalition's specific proposals are: _Increase funding to repair aging railroad tracks and rail cars. _Fund and encourage high-occupancy vehicle programs, bicycle paths and pedestrian walkways, high-speed rail and peak-hour pricing at airports. _Increase auto fuel economy standards for new cars and trucks. _Boost funding for Amtrak and other alternatives to cars and planes. _Eliminate policies that favor heavy trucks over freight railroads. _Increase the federal gas tax, impose congestion fees on auto commuters, and provide tax benefits for non-auto commuters. _Preserve open spaces in urban areas and keep railroad rights of ways under federal control. _Pass laws to reduce the number of billboards.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Crime Bill, Bjt
Soviet Jewish Group Appeals to Bush
With AM-Summit, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The umbrella organization of Jews in the Soviet Union has asked President Bush to press Mikhail Gorbachev at next week's summit over ``his decision to keep silence on the problem of growing Nazism in his own country.'' A letter to Bush from the Vaad, a confederation of Soviet Jewish communities, accused Gorbachev of ``connivance ... toward this great danger.'' Secretary of State James Baker, describing the summit agenda on Wednesday, said Bush would raise the issue of anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union. The May 20 letter from Vaad, a copy of which was obtained by a reporter Wednesday, said ``We feel the time has come to persuade the Soviet government and President Gorbachev that they cannot join the family of civilized nations ... carrying anti-Semitism in their luggage. It described the revived neo-Nazi ideology of Pamyat, a popular movement which has flourished under Gorbachev's liberalized domestic policies. ``... Soviet Nazis comprise different groups united by xenophobia and the search for a scapegoat'' for the Soviet Union's problems, the letter said. ``All these groups are involved into mass incitement of the hatred towards the Jews, ... preparation for mass physical violence, desecration of Jewish sanctuaries,'' the letter said. A recent State Department report found that anti-Semitism of the type described in the letter has spread over the past few years as barriers on free expression have been lifted. Growing anti-Semitism has resulted in massive Jewish emigration, made possible by a significant easing of previous restrictions on leaving the Soviet Union. But Baker said a debate scheduled next week in the Supreme Soviet on a package of emigration laws had been postponed, raising doubts about the signing of a trade agreement at the Bush-Gorbachev summit. The United States has made passage of the emigration laws a precondition for granting the Soviets trade concessions.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhotos NY44, NY29
DOC.TEXT: Marla Maples, the Other Woman of Donald Trump fame, came out of ``hiding'' Wednesday, showing off her brand new jeans and smiling sweetly for photographers. ``I'm kind of easing my way back in'' to a normal life, the 26-year-old Maples said after a news conference introducing her as the new spokeswoman for No Excuses jeans. Maples, a model and actress, refused to discuss her relationship with Trump, whatever it may be, saying, ``I don't want to comment on that. He's still working on his own personal situation.'' Trump in February separated from his wife, Ivana, of nearly 13 years. Maples found herself in the eye of the Trumpian storm after she was tagged the ``other woman'' in the billionaire's life. Maples said she was on her third callback for a part in a movie when the Trump deluge began. ``It was looking very, very good,'' but because of all the attention ``I just pulled out. That's when I chose to go into hiding because I didn't want to get involved.'' Maples signed a one-year contract with No Excuses for a reported $500,000. Donna Rice, whose alleged affair with Gary Hart forced the senator from Colorado to drop out of the 1988 presidential race, was also a spokeswoman for the jeans.

Wynton Marsalis, Dizzy Gillespie, George Adams and Tania Maria will highlight this summer's Mount Fuji Jazz Festival, one of Japan's most popular jazz events, organizers said Wednesday. The annual outdoor festival, held on the banks of Lake Yamanaka at the foot of Mount Fuji, brings leading jazz musicians from the United States to join a handful of Japanese musicians in three days of concerts. Also playing in this year's festival, Aug. 24-26, will be groups led by Jimmy Smith, Ellis Marsalis, John Scofield, Rachelle Ferrell, Terumasa Hino and others, the organizers said. Another annual Japanese international jazz festival, Select Live Under the Sky, will be held July 28-Aug. 1 at various Tokyo locations, organizers say. Among the participants in that festival will be Pat Metheny, Herbie Hancock, David Sanborn, Wayne Shorter, Al Jarreau and Jack Dejohnette.

Prince is used to getting royal treatment, but one Dutch couple decided to put a stop to the divine rights of rock stars. A Dutch court has ruled in favor of Marcel Soek and Merith Gijtenbeek, who sued the posh Hotel des Indes for allegedly giving their VIP suite reservation to the singer. The court ordered the hotel to pay a $13,369 penalty unless it gives the Imperial Suite to the couple for their June 2 wedding night, the couple and the hotel management said Wednesday. The couple booked the suite in March, but ``the hotel told us after several weeks that the room was going to be given instead to an American pop star along with 10 other royal suites,'' Soek said. ``They didn't tell us who the star was, but the lawyer slipped the other day in court and said it was Prince,'' Soek said. Hotel Des Indes General Manager Bernard Felix said the hotel had not decided whether to appeal the ruling.

Another pair of blue eyes will be hitting the supermarket _ Frank Sinatra has joined Paul Newman in the pasta sauce business. Sinatra unveiled his three varieties of sauce _ Tomato Basil with Parmesan, Milano Style and Marinara with Mushrooms _ during a gathering Monday evening at Melrose Avenue's trendy Mortons restaurant. Grocery stores in Nevada and northern California have been selling the 25-ounce jars for months. The Sinatra sugo da tavola Italian sauce hit Southern California markets this week. ``Our family has always favored simply cooked sauces made with the freshest ingredients,'' Sinatra said. ``It's a kick having our sauce in the market and terrific when people tell us how much they like the taste.'' Asked what he thought about competing with ``Newman's Own'' pasta sauce, Sinatra says he hopes both companies do well. Sinatra said his company shares its profits with charity.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Say Harry Helmsley Unfit to Stand Trial
DOC.TEXT: Doctors have found billionaire developer Harry Helmsley unfit to stand trial on state tax fraud charges, a judge said Wednesday. The 81-year-old Helmsley had also been found unfit to stand trial on federal tax charges after suffering a series of strokes. Helmsley was examined by two court-appointed doctors and both found him to be unfit, said State Supreme Court Justice John Bradley, a trial level judge. Bradley said he will decide whether to hold a hearing on Helmsley's mental and physical condition after he gets the physicians' reports. Assistant Attorney General Alfredo Mendez asked the judge for time to study the report and address ``the apparent inconsistencies, that Mr. Helmsley is not fit to stand trial but is fit to do other things.'' A 188-count state indictment charges Helmsley and his wife, Leona, with tax and business fraud. Most of the counts alleged they renovated, furnished and operated their estate in Greenwich, Conn., while charging the personal expenses to their businesses. On May 16, Bradley dismissed 180 of the 188 counts against Mrs. Helmsley on double jeopardy grounds. Mrs. Helmsley, tried and convicted in federal court, was sentenced to four years in prison and fined $7.1 million. She is appealing that conviction. All the state counts remain against Helmsley because he was never tried in federal court. Mrs. Helmsley, sobbing as she left court Wednesday, said the state was proceeding with the case against her husband, despite his condition, ``because he's Harry Helmsley and they want me.''
