DOC.SECOND: Eagleburger Urges Grants, Not Loans to Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger on Wednesday urged Western allies to provide the emerging Eastern European democracies with economic gifts, rather than loans. ``Loans would just add to the great debt burden that Eastern Europe already has,'' Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger told an international conference on aid to Eastern Europe. Most of the proposals from other countries have been for loans. The United States is committed to $533 million in aid for Poland and Hungary this year, most of it in form of grants or credit guarantees. President Bush has proposed adding $300 million next year to the $205 million in assistance already approved for fiscal years 1991 and 1992. Eagleburger acknowledged the administration has no overall blueprint for helping the region. ``Anyone who had such a blueprint would have had to change it several times recently,'' he said. Despite his opposition to loans, Eagleburger endorsed the newly organized European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which will have $12 billion available for lending to the area. He said it would be useful for large-scale projects which would be too big for any one donor country or small group of countries. The United States, one of 24 countries in Western Europe, America and Asia which set up the new European bank, is expected to provide about 10 percent of the initial funding for the bank.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Sharply Raises Price Estimate on S&L Bailout
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration on Wednesday dramatically boosted its estimate for rescuing the savings and loan industry, saying the government will need to borrow between $90 billion and $130 billion to clean up the S&L mess. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, in an appearance before Congress, blamed the slumping real estate market for bloating what was already the largest government bailout in history. It was the first time the administration has acknowledged what critics have been contending for some time _ that the amount of money included in last year's massive S&L bailout bill would not be enough. During debate on the legislation last year, the administration insisted the problem could be largely handled with the $50 billion in long-term borrowing authority included in the bailout bill. Some Democratic critics contended the new estimate showed that the administration was not moving quickly enough to close sick S&Ls. Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., called the situation an ``unmitigated disaster'' and warned that without greater administration attention ``the crisis will get worse.'' The administration said its more pessimistic projection was based on a belief that the slumping real estate market means more S&Ls are likely to fail and the cost of protecting depositors at the insolvent institutions will be greater. Since most of an savings institution's assets are in the form of loans based on the value of real estate, falling real estate prices put more borderline institutions into trouble. The administration's new cost range assumes that between 722 and 1,032 institutions could fail. During debate on the S&L bailout bill, the number of threatened institutions was put at around 500. The new cost estimate does not include the cost of borrowing the money over the next 30 years. When that price is included, the bailout cost is expected to exceed $300 billion. The General Accounting Office in April put the bailout cost with interest payments included at $325 billion, saying that figure could skyrocket to $500 billion if the economy falters. Brady presented the administration's new estimate in testimony before the Senate Banking Committee. He refused to provide an estimate of the total pricetag with interest costs included, but he did not dispute the GAO assumptions. Brady said about 90 percent of the administration's higher cost estimate stemmed from falling real estate prices, especially for commercial real estate such as office buildings. He said depressed real estate prices were showing up not only in the Southwest but also in the Northeast, Southeast and other sections of the country. ``We are dealing with a moving target, made greatly more expensive by a weakening real estate market and constantly changing economic conditions,'' he said. ``This is a long, hard job and it will take an extended period of time to finish it.'' The administration estimated that for just the 1991 fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1, the cost of the S&L bailout will be $61 billion, more than eight times the $7.3 billion called for in the president's January budget request. White House budget director Richard Darman told lawmakers at a separate hearing that the pricetag of the mushrooming S&L crisis played a major role in driving the administration to seek budget negotiations with Congress. ``It is extraordinary,'' Darman said. ``The magnitudes are just very, very much larger than the budget system is prepared to deal with.'' Darman said the S&L rescue cost would force automatic spending cuts under the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law that could exceed $100 billion. The cuts could reach 45 to 50 percent in many domestic programs, he said. The law will trigger spending cuts in October, the start of fiscal 1991, if the new year's deficit is not reduced to $74 billion. The administration and some members of Congress want to exclude a portion of the S&L costs from the deficit calculations, a step that would make it easier to meet the deficit targets in the Gramm-Rudman balanced budget law. Brady, appearing with Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan and other members of the oversight board supervising the S&L bailout, dodged questions on how the government should raise the extra money needed to complete the S&L rescue effort. He said that issue should be addressed in the budget negotiations the administration was conducting with Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Chimp Virus Closely Related to AIDS Virus, Study Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EDT, time set by source.
DOC.TEXT: A recently isolated chimpanzee virus is more closely related to the human AIDS virus than other AIDS-related monkey viruses are, and may be a ``missing link'' between human and primate versions, scientists say. However, the finding does not resolve the question of whether the AIDS virus originated in humans or in animals, scientists said. Analysis of the chimpanzee virus is presented in Thursday's issue of the British journal Nature by scientists from Gabon and from the Pasteur Institute in Paris. The virus was identified in two wild chimpanzees in the West African nation and isolated from one of them. It is classified as a lentivirus, the same category that includes HIV-1, which causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome in the United States. Other lentiviruses, called simian immunodeficiency viruses or SIVs, have been found in four kinds of monkeys: macaques, sooty mangabeys, African green monkeys and mandrills. Analysis of the new virus showed it was the first non-human lentivirus to contain the same overall genetic structure as HIV-1, the researchers reported. And when the protein products of its genes were studied, they were more like those of HIV-1 than those of the simian viruses tested. Nonetheless, when compared to the range of known genetic variants of HIV-1, the chimp virus lay outside that range, the researchers said. They suggested it might be called chimpanzee immunodeficiency virus. Only two of 83 chimps tested in Gabon carried the virus, indicating it is not widespread there, they reported. And none of more than 250 chimpanzees caught over the last 15 to 20 years in West Africa showed evidence of the virus. The two chimps in which the virus was found were both infants in relatively good health. If the virus had made them ill with anything like AIDS, they probably would not have survived predators in the jungle, researchers said. It is not possible to conclude that the chimp virus was a precursor to HIV-1, and even if it were, analysis indicates that it could not be the immediate precursor, they said. But the virus may be a form of ``missing link'' between the African Old World primate viruses and HIV-1, wrote Ronald Desrosiers of the New England Regional Primate Research Center in Southborough, Mass. He agreed that the discovery does not settle the question of whether HIV-1 originated in humans or came from a non-human ancestor. But further study of the isolate may shed light on it, he said in a Nature editorial.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Says `Got What We Want' in Pre-Summit Soviet Arms Deal
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Wednesday rejected charges that he gave away too much to the Soviets in an nuclear arms deal, asserting ``We've got what we want.'' He also said too much is at stake to allow disputes over Lithuania to block U.S.-Soviet progress. Baker, at a news conference, also revealed a new stumbling block to the signing of an economic agreement leading toward normal trade relations with Moscow. Baker, previewing next week's summit meeting between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, said the Soviet legislature has again delayed adoption of a law allowing the free emigration of Soviet Jews and other dissidents. Bush has made passage of such a law a condition for giving Moscow most-favored-nation trade status. Such a trade declaration would provide the Soviets with the same benefits, including lowest-possible tariffs, that the United States extends to other major economic partners. The Soviets had been expected to pass the law May 31, but Baker said the action ``has been postponed somewhat.'' Since returning Sunday from arms negotiations in Moscow, Baker has been attacked by conservatives who say the United States, dealing from a position of strength, made too many concessions to a weakened Soviet Union. Critics include Richard N. Perle, who served as assistant secretary of defense in the Reagan administration. Baker and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze resolved most of the key differences to a treaty cutting long-range nuclear missiles but did not agree to any limits on modernizing the Soviet SS-18 heavy missile, the most dangerous weapon in Moscow's arsenal. Baker, however, said, ``There is very strong support for this agreement among the military leadership of the United States ... support for it as a good agreement that is very much in the national security interests of the United States. ``And it would appear to me at least that most of the criticism is coming from those who in the past, from time to time, have simply rejected the concept of arms control generally,'' Baker said. Rather than the United States making concessions, Baker said, ``it's been pretty much all the other way around.'' He noted that Moscow will cut its force of SS-18s in half, and the superpowers had cut through longstanding differences on air- and sea-launched cruise missiles. ``And we've got what we want,'' Baker said. The secretary said Bush will press Gorbachev to revive negotiations to cut tens of thousands of troops and tanks in Europe. However, he said there should not be any linkage between a treaty to cut nuclear weapons and the separate agreement on conventional forces in Europe. Baker said the United States still wants to sign a treaty this year to reduce the non-nuclear forces. However, he failed to make progress on the issue in Moscow last week, apparently because the Soviets want assurances about reductions in German forces after unification. Baker said it was up to Germans to decide ``the internal aspects'' of the unification of East Germany with West Germany. On troop levels, Baker said outsiders could get involved in the discussions, but here, too, the Germans were in charge of their future. Baker said the main obstacle to a conventional force agreement concerned which aircraft to limit. On Lithuania, Baker said the Soviet Union's policies ``may disturb us deeply, offending our fundamental values. But as the president has made clear, there is too much at stake in the United States-Soviet relationship to dismiss cavalierly or imprudently the potential for progress.'' ``We must continue the search for points of mutual advantage,'' he said. ``We have been saying for quite some time that we see a little bit of tension in the relationship as a consequence of what's happening in the Baltics, and we'd very much like to see a peaceful dialogue resolve that issue,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets to Hold Referendum Election on Economic Reform
LaserPhotos MOSB1,4
DOC.TEXT: The government will lay its future on the line in the Soviet Union's first national referendum, in which voters will consider a shift to a market economy that could cost tens of millions of jobs, officials said Wednesday. The government believes it must have clear public support before starting the potentially destabilizing five-year reform plan, First Deputy Premier Yuri Maslyukov told a news conference. ``If the program is not approved, it is my opinion the government should resign,'' Maslyukov said, referring to the Council of Ministers led by Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov. It was unclear whether the public would endorse the reforms, which would double food prices Jan. 1, 1991, lead to widespread closures of inefficient factories, and eventually allow private ownership of most businesses. Ryzhkov was to present the plan Thursday to the Supreme Soviet parliament, where some radical reformers were planning to seek his resignation. He survived a similar no-confidence vote last fall. No Soviet government has ever fallen because of either a referendum or a parliamentary vote, although prime ministers have been forced to resign by the Communist Party leader. Even if the government falls, Soviet law guarantees that Mikhail S. Gorbachev would continue the four-year presidential term to which he was elected by the Congress of People's Deputies this year. He is also general secretary of the Communist Party, traditionally the top Kremlin job. But Gorbachev has balked at standing for popular election, and defeat of the referendum would throw the future wide open, Maslyukov said. ``If the public refuses to consent to the price rises, then perhaps we will have to resort to round-table discussions,'' Maslyukov said, referring to talks that led to the fall of the Communist government in Poland last year. Soviet reformers are seeking talks to discuss devolving political and economic decision-making power from central authorities, where it has resided since the Bolshevik Revolution of 1917. The government has been wary of radical reform, however. Officials rejected proposals for a more abrupt, two-year Polish-style ``shock therapy,'' fearing public anger. And Soviet officials have said they do not enjoy the same popularity as Poland's Solidarity leadership. Shock-therapy, which calls for rapid reform to keep the period of dislocation short, could put 40 million Soviets out of work, Maslyukov said. ``We are unable to offer normal living conditions to such a number if they lose their jobs. It would the lead the country to the edge of an economic crash,'' he said. Deputy Premier Leonid Abalkin told a news conference that even under the proposed five-year transition, tens of millions of jobs could be lost. The plan calls for rapid conversion of state-owned enterprises to stock companies, and the gradual sale of their stock to the public. It would permit certain companies and industries to contract directly for their supplies and to sell their products in a free market. Unprofitable firms would go bankrupt. The plan sets target price increases for various sectors of the economy, including an 82 percent rise in energy prices, an average 43 percent rise in retail prices and doubling the price of food, which is now subsidized. Wages and other compensation would rise to match only some of the price increases, Abalkin said. Maslyukov said the Supreme Soviet would set the date for the referendum, which would be the first in Soviet history. The outcome is far from certain, as Soviet people cling to an ideology that brands individual wealth harmful to the collective good. Gorbachev has blamed public opinion for retarding reform. A recent poll found 54 percent of Soviets favor market reforms but 46 percent are opposed, said Stanislav Shatalin, the lone economist on Gorbachev's advisory Presidential Council. The council approved the reform plan Tuesday. Nikolai Petrakov, one of Gorbachev's top economics aides, said Wednesday he was unhappy with the plan. Asked whether announcing price increases seven months before they take effect would cause a rush on shops and hoarding by businesses, Petrakov said: ``This will create a panic, an economic panic.'' The government discussed radical reforms last fall, but backed away. The economy has deteriorated sharply since then. In the first three months of 1990, wages rose 13.4 percent while production declined. Official figures show that industrial output dropped by 1.2 percent. Under the latest proposal, workers are to receive raises, businesses are to recalculate their books based on new prices, and the government will discover how many businesses will need subsidies to continue operating. Petrakov said 220,000 state enterprises, or 70 percent of the total, will be converted to stock-based companies within the next several months, as a first step toward selling the shares to individuals, companies and banks. Maslyukov said prices on 60 percent of the items sold will remain controlled. These include prices for raw materials, energy and products made by the monopoly firms dominating the economy. An additional 25 percent of prices will be regulated and 15 percent will float with the market, Maslyukov told the U.S.-U.S.S.R. Trade and Economic Council.

DOC.HEAD: Military Force Down About 46,000 Since Last Year
DOC.TEXT: The number of men and women in the armed forces is down slightly from last year, according to figures released Wednesday by the Pentagon. The latest total, for April 30, was 2,063,743 full-time military personnel, counting both regulars and reserves on active duty and officer candidates and cadets at the three military academies. This was 46,544 fewer than on the same date in 1989. It was also down 7,347 from the previous month. The figures exclude approximately 74,200 full-time military personnel who are paid from appropriations for reserve components and Corps of Engineer functions, rather than appropraitions for active duty military personnel. This group amount to about 72,000 last year. The Pentagon described the figures as preliminiary. It gave the totals for the Army as 745,763, the Navy 581,525, the Marine Corps 195,384 and the Air Force 541,071.

DOC.HEAD: Far-Right Leader Fined For Belittling Holocaust
DOC.TEXT: A court on Wednesday ordered far-right leader Jean-Marie Le Pen to pay a symbolic fine for referring to the Nazi gas chambers as just a ``detail in World War II history.'' Judge Lefoyer de Costil, presiding in the Nanterre court outside Paris, said Le Pen should pay one franc to each of the 11 religious and human rights groups that filed suit against him following the remark. He also ordered the judgment printed in five national newspapers, five regional papers and six weeklies. In addition, Le Pen must pay $720 to each of the groups to cover their legal fees, the judge ruled. Le Pen ``committed a fault for which he cannot validly exonerate himself by invoking freedom of expression, which has as a limit ... certain essential values and respect for others,'' the judge told the court. He called Le Pen's choice of words ``shocking,'' saying they ``put into question, banalize or, at the very least, make less specifically dramatic the persecutions and sufferings inflicted on deportees and particularly on Jews and Gypsies by the Nazis.'' Le Pen, who did not attend the trial, said the decision was another move in the ``general offensive'' against his National Front. ``All means are good to try to sweep the National Front and the millions of French who, more so each day, put their hope in it,'' Le Pen said in a written statement. He did not say whether he would appeal. Le Pen, 61, who has about 15 percent support in recent opinion polls, has been increasingly ostracized since the desecration two weeks ago of a Jewish cemetery in the southern town of Carpentras. Several towns have refused to allow meetings of his National Front party. Le Pen maintains that France is being overrun by immigrants. Under the motto ``French First,'' he wants to expell immigrants and enact laws to keep them out. Le Pen has repeatedly been accused of racism and anti-Semitism, but denies the allegations. Planning Minister Lionel Stoleru said the decision was both ``a victory and a relief.'' ``To be proud to be French is from now on to be proud to combat Jean-Marie Le Pen,'' the minister said. Le Pen, a deputy in the European Parliament, caused a scandal with his remarks about the gas chambers in a 1987 radio interview. In the past six months, the Justice Ministry has succeeded in having Le Pen's parliamentary immunity lifted to prosecute him on two issues. The first was a play on words he made in 1988 linking a Cabinet minister to the Nazi crematory ovens, and the second, a 1989 interview in which he said ``large internationals, like the Jewish international, play a non-negligible role in the creation of this anti-national spirit.'' Numerous political and civic leaders have accused Le Pen of creating an atmosphere of racial intolerance that led to the desecration at Carpentras, where a corpse was mutilated and 34 tombs were desecrated. On Wednesday, police questioned 15 people around the southern town of Albi. All the suspects were later released. Several newspapers in southern France published a letter Wednesday claiming responsibility for the desecration in the name of a Moslem organization, the Mohammed El Boukhima group. Police sources said the letter was considered to have ``little credibility.'' Shortly after the discovery May 10 of the desecration, an anonymous caller to a local paper claimed responsibility for the crime in the name of the same unknown group.

DOC.HEAD: Mary Victor Bruce, Daredevil Pilot and Auto Racer, Dead at 94
LaserPhoto NY33
DOC.TEXT: Mary Victor Bruce, the daredevil pilot who broke land, air and sea speed records and was once arrested for flying circles around the Empire State Building, has died, her son said Wednesday. She was 94. She died Monday ``of old age,'' said her son and sole survivor, Anthony Bruce. The pioneer race car driver, speed boat captain and pilot, who once said ``going slowly always makes me tired,'' was christened Mildred Mary Petre on Nov. 10, 1895. She was the only daughter of English nobleman Lawrence Petre, the squire of Coptfold Hall. Her mother was an American actress and her great-grandmother was a California gold miner. In 1926 she married Victor Austin Bruce. A year later the two undertook a 6,000-mile tour through Sweden and Finland, penetrating 270 miles north of the Arctic Circle where they planted the Union Jack after ``running out of road,'' she said. In 1929, she broke the 24-hour record by driving alone on the Montlhery track near Paris. She covered more than 2,200 miles at an average of 90 mph, a feat that also broke the world record for the greatest non-stop run by a solo driver. Mrs. Bruce took a fancy to boats, and in 1929 made the roundtrip crossing to France in a record 79 minutes, 24.5 seconds. Months after learning to fly, Mrs. Bruce went around the world alone in her airplane, ``Bluebird.'' The 1930 trip included a crash on takeoff in Baltimore and her arrest in New York for flying around the Empire State Building. ``She was flying such tight circles around the building that the typists said they could see the color of her eyes,'' her son told The Associated Press. He said his blue-eyed, petite mother was quickly released and became the darling of New Yorkers. Her accomplishments, listed in Who's Who, include: the first solo flight from England to Japan in 1930; the longest solo flight in 1930; record solo flight India to French Indochina in 1930; British Air refueling endurance flight in 1933; 24-hour record by motor boat covering 674 nautical miles single-handed 1929. Bruce never wore overalls or slacks, preferring a blouse, skirt and pearl necklace. ``Don't call me a women's libber,'' she snapped at an interviewer later in life. ``I don't really approve. I was a girl among five brothers and I've always tried to remain feminine.'' She founded and owned an air ferry service that flew British newspapers and executives across the English Channel to Paris. The line signed up the first British stewardess, Daphne Vickers. In her spare time, she bought a pony and was first in the open jumping class at the Royal Horse Show at Windsor in 1939. In her mid-70s, she returned to the racetrack to test-drive a new Ford car. At 81, she made a spectacular air comeback after 30 years, flying a loop the loop in a two-seater plane. ``What a lark,'' she was quoted as saying as she left the airfield in her 1938 Phantom III Rolls-Royce. ``It's knocked 50 years off my life.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Naval Construction Rate Highest in Two Decades
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union is building new warships at the highest rate in 20 years to replace old vessels that are being retired, according to Jane's Fighting Ships. The latest edition of the respected defense directory, to be released Thursday, says the Soviet Union will be retiring 17 nuclear submarines, 80 diesel powered submarines, three cruisers and 25 frigates under a program to rid the navy of technology from the 1940s and 1950s. But a balanced view of the Soviet Fleet ``must include the unpalatable fact that at the same time as these obsolete ships are being paid off, the new naval construction rate is, in terms of tonnage, the highest it has been in 20 years for surface warships and the highest in the last decade for submarines,'' Capt. Richard Sharpe wrote in his foreword to Jane's Fighting Ships 1990-1991. No precise figure on the total tonnage was available. Sharpe said he reached his conclusion after studying the figures following a comment by U.S. Rear Adm. Thomas Brooks, director of naval intelligence. Testifying before a committee of the House Armed Services Subcommittee on March 14, 1990, Brooks said: ``In terms of tonnage of submarines accepted by the Soviet Navy, 1989 was the most productive year since 1980.'' Brooks added: ``In terms of tonnage of surface competence (warships) accepted by the Soviet Navy, 1989 was the most productive year in more than 20 years.'' Sharp said Soviet naval officials have been arguing the West has superior naval forces and ``that there has been no positive response to maritime arms control initiatives.'' The arguments have convinced policy makers in Moscow that ``the modernization of the fleet's overall capabilities should continue without check,'' said Sharpe, a former commander of submarines and destroyers for the Royal Navy. He said the emphasis on fixed-wing aircraft carriers and nuclear attack submarines seemed to contradict the Soviets' stated doctrine of defensive sufficiency. Analysts who attempt to portray such vessels as purely assets for strategic defense are being ``depressingly naive,'' he says. Sharpe said improvements in the availablity of information from the Soviet Union made possible the first listing of Soviet warships scrapped or awaiting the breakers.

DOC.HEAD: North Appears Before Federal Judge, Avoids Grand Jury
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs top 3 grafs to update with grand jury adjourning for the day shortly after closed-door session with North
DOC.TEXT: Oliver North appeared in federal court Wednesday, apparently to challenge a subpoena for his appearance before a federal grand jury looking into the Iran-Contra affair. North and his lawyers attended a closed-door session before U.S. District Court Judge Aubrey Robinson while the grand jury met on another floor in the building. Iran-Contra prosecutors also were at the court session. After a hearing that lasted more than half an hour, North and his lawyers emerged from Robinson's courtroom, bypassed the third-floor grand jury room and walked out of the courthouse. The grand jury adjourned for the day an hour and a half later. One of North's lawyers, Brendan Sullivan, refused to comment. Iran-Contra prosecutor Craig Gillen and the office of independent counsel Lawrence Walsh also declined any comment. North's brief appearance suggested he has been subpoenaed to testify before the grand jury but is challenging the subpoena. The newly empaneled grand jury met for the first time last Friday. A court fight over a grand jury subpoena for North's testimony could take months to resolve. North could appeal any order issued by Robinson compelling the former White House aide's testimony. Sources familiar with the 3{-year-old criminal investigation have said Walsh's office wants to use the new grand jury in an attempt to determine the precise roles Ronald Reagan, George Bush and others had in the affair. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said last month that it was likely North would be called before a grand jury and that Iran-Contra prosecutors also were likely to call former National Security Adviser John Poindexter. Robinson held North in contempt of court earlier in Walsh's probe when North refused to comply with a grand jury subpoena. The legal dispute hinged on North's refusal to provide a grand jury with a sample of his handwriting in 1987. North's attorneys filed an appeal and obtained a stay of the judge's order. Walsh eventually obtained samples of the handwriting of North and other Iran-Contra defendants. Iran-Contra prosecutors also tried unsuccessfully to obtain North's notebooks through the use of a grand jury subpoena. North ultimately was forced to turn over the notebooks at his trial last year when he took the witness stand in his own defense. Some 2,600 pages of North's notebooks have been publicly released over the past two weeks in connection with a lawsuit filed against the government by two private groups. North, 46, was convicted on May 4, 1989, by a federal court jury after a two-month trial. He was found guilty of aiding and abetting an obstruction of Congress, altering and destroying National Security Council documents and receiving an illegal gratuity. An appeal of his convictions is pending before the U.S. Court of Appeals. North was placed on two years' probation and ordered to pay a $150,000 fine. He also is performing 1,200 hours of community service work as part of his sentence. Poindexter, convicted last month of five felonies in connection with the Iran-Contra affair, is scheduled to be sentenced June 11. He could face up to 25 years in prison and $1.25 million in fines for his convictions on one count of conspiracy, two counts of obstructing Congress and two counts of making false statements.

DOC.HEAD: Former Lawmaker Wins GOP Primary to Challenge Gov. Andrus
DOC.TEXT: A former legislator who says he would have signed a tough anti-abortion bill ``in a baby's heartbeat'' has won the Republican nomination to oppose Democratic Gov. Cecil Andrus, who vetoed the bill. Former state Senate Majority Leader Roger Fairchild finished first in a three-way GOP primary race Tuesday, defeating state Sen. Rachel Gilbert, also an abortion foe, and Boise stockbroker Milton Erhart, who is pro-choice. In the battle to succeed retiring GOP Sen. James McClure, Rep. Larry Craig won the Republican primary and Boise businessman Ron Twilegar captured the Democratic nomination. Abortion, which dominated Idaho politics through the winter and into the spring, was a point of contention in 20 legislative primaries. All eight pro-choice incumbents who faced anti-abortion primary opponents held on to their seats; the single anti-abortion incumbent to face a challenge also won. Overall, pro-choice candidates claimed 12 of the races and abortion foes won eight. Fairchild had to overcome charges from his ex-wife that he used drugs and beat her and her children. He repeatedly denied the allegations, but pumped $90,000 of his family's money into the primary, partly to overcome moral questions in the minds of conservative voters in eastern Idaho. ``I'm not a silk-stocking politician, I never have been,'' Fairchild said Wednesday. ``I'm accepted in the fields and the factories and the woods.'' Andrus, who had no primary opposition in his bid for an unprecedented fourth term, drew fire from some conservatives for his March 30 veto of what would have been the nation's most restrictive state abortion law. Andrus has maintained his opposition to abortion but said the bill was too strict in cases of rape and incest and too liberal in cases of severe fetal deformity. ``We're going to move on with our campaign as we planned it, showing where we were four years ago, where we are now and where we're going,'' Andrus said Wednesday, referring to the fact the state is in the third year of a strong economic resurgence. Final unofficial returns in the GOP primary gave Fairchild 37,690 votes, or 37 percent, to 33,546 votes, or 33 percent, Gilbert, and 30,524 votes or 30 percent to Erhart. In the GOP Senate race, Craig had 66,249 votes, or 59 percent, to 45,689 votes, or 41 percent, for Attorney General Jim Jones. On the Democratic side Twilegar had 30,197 votes, or 64 percent, to 16,658 votes, or 36 percent, for political newcomer David Steed.

DOC.HEAD: Cape Verde's Ruler Quits Party in Advance of Reforms
DOC.TEXT: President Aristides Pereira of Cape Verde said Wednesday he is quitting the West African nation's ruling party to help prepare for multiparty rule, the news agency Lusa reported. Pereira has ruled this island archipelago as a Marxist-inspired, one-party state since independence from Portugal in 1975. However, the ruling African Party for the Independence of Cape Verde announced plans in April to revise the constitution to allow presidential elections by direct universal suffrage. Pereira said Wednesday he would leave the party at its congress scheduled for July, the Portuguese news agency reported. He now serves as the party's general secretary. ``The president of the republic must have full autonomy in relation to all political forces,'' he said during his speech to the People's National Assembly in the Cape Verdian capital of Praia. Cape Verde, 385 miles off Senegal, is the second of Portugal's five former African colonies to announce plans to break with single-party rule. Sao Tome e Principe announced last year that competition among political parties will be allowed in future elections. Pereira said his departure from the party would help ensure openess in an ``examplary transition'' to multiparty democracy, Lusa reported. A party spokesman said the presidential elections, expected in December, would be on a nonpartisan basis. The party has said multiparty parliamentary elections will follow.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela: ANC Stands by Nationalization Policy
DOC.TEXT: The ANC stands by its policy of nationalizing major private industries, but would be willing to negotiate government participation rather than takeovers, Nelson Mandela said Wednesday. The African National Congress leader spoke to 300 South African businessmen, about 40 ANC delegates and representatives of leading labor organizations. After the conference he told reporters the ANC has not changed its view that banks, mining companies and other major private industries must be nationalized. ``We are not rethinking our nationalization policy,'' he said. But, he said, ``Government participation must be done in cooperation with the corporate sector. There are different forms of government participation and this will be negotiated.'' Murray Hofmeyr, chairman of the Johannesburg Consolidated Investment Co. Ltd. mining house, said the meeting had shown ``there is a lot of disagreement between the business community and the ANC. We have a long way to go. There is also a degree of mistrust ... which will have to be overcome.'' But Hofmeyr also said there were areas of common ground, such as agreement on the need to end racial discrimination, transform the economic, political and social orders, and to retain the confidence of investors. Mandela said the ANC policy on nationalization is designed to bring social change in South Africa. ``If we are genuinely interested in ending the old social order and bringing in a new one, it is quite obvious that the economic power relations represented by the reality of the excessive concentration of power in a few white hands have to change,'' Mandela said in his speech. ``I would, however, like to share a secret with you,'' Mandela said. ``The view that the only words in the economic vocabulary that the ANC knows are nationalization and redistribution is mistaken.'' Mandela suggested considering methods such as the U.S. anti-trust laws or the British Monopolies Commission ``to ensure that there is no unhealthy over-concentration of economic power.'' He also said future governments might place directors on the boards of private companies ``to see whether it is possible to balance pursuit of private gain with the need to promote common good.'' In some areas, Mandela said, it may be necessary to establish or strengthen public corporations to redress the disparity in economic opportunity and share of national wealth after centuries of white domination in South Africa. Mandela said the ANC was firmly opposed to the government's current program of privatizing public services. ``It would seem only reasonable that so important a question as the disposal of public property should be held over until a truly representative government is in place,'' he said. The government led by F.W de Klerk has implemented a series of reforms that included releasing Mandela from jail in February after 27 years. De Klerk and the ANC also met to pave the way for negotiations on black-white power sharing.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Commander: Soviets Have Not Reduced Gulf Presence
DOC.TEXT: The Soviets have kept up the size of their navy in the Persian Gulf despite the end of the Cold War, a U.S. military commander was quoted as saying Wednesday. Rear Adm. William M. Fogarty, commander of the Joint Task Force Middle East, told Kuwaiti newspapers that ``Moscow currently has 10 to 12 ships in the waterway _ the same number it had during the Gulf war.'' Fogarty commands U.S. naval forces that have been gradually reduced from 27 ships at the height of the 8-year Iraq-Iran war to six warships and a command vessel within the Gulf. Another U.S. battlegroup is in the region but outside the Gulf. The Soviets built up their navy inside the Gulf about the same time as the Americans. In his remarks published by the Arabic daily Al-Qabas and the English-language Arab Times, Fogarty also renewed the U.S. commitment to ``defend friendly states in the Gulf and protect their and our interests.'' Fogarty talked to Kuwaiti reporters during a port call by the USS Reid, a guided-missile frigate.

DOC.HEAD: Embassy Rebuts Administration On West Bank
DOC.TEXT: Israel rejected on Wednesday the Bush administration's attempt to link the slaying of seven Palestinian laborers by an apparently deranged Israeli gunman to lack of progress in Mideast negotiations. ``There is no correlation between the act of one crazed individual and the peace process,'' the Israeli embassy said. The statement cautioned the Bush administration that its linking of the violence to the diplomatic stalemate ``is liable to be seen by certain groups as a reason to continue the violence in the hope of attaining their ends.'' Terming the shooting Sunday near Tel Aviv a tragedy, Israel said irresponsible elements led by the Palestine Liberation Organization were cynically exploiting the incident to incite violence on the West Bank and in Gaza. The Israeli army is dealing with the extremely difficult situation with ``maximum restraint,'' the embassy statement said. In a related development Wednesday, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said the Bush administration was willing to discuss at a U.N. Security Council meeting the idea of sending a United Nations observer team to the occupied territories. The council will hold the meeting in Geneva so PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat could attend. Arafat would have required a U.S. visa to be at the meeting if it were held at U.N. headquarters in New York. Arafat had approached the Bush administration through U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, but a showdown was averted when the meeting was shifted. Baker, asked at a White House news conference if he had opposed a visa for Arafat, replied: `There was never any formal application for a visa, so the question is hypothetical.'' On Monday, the State Department said lack of progress in negotiations increases the likelihood of violence and bloody crackdowns, such as the shooting and subsequent violence on the West Bank and in Gaza. ``We see that as another sign that there must be a peace process,'' the department said in a statement read by spokesman Richard Boucher. ``In the absence of a peace process the potential for this kind of senseless violence and spiraling responses afterwards goes up,'' he said. The statement was issued after Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir deplored the shooting and expressed condolences to the victims and their families. The embassy statement Wednesday said Israel and its citizens have condemned the coldblooded murder of seven Palestinians and the wounding of 11 others at Rishon La Zion. ``Restrained and balanced reactions on the part of the international community will contribute to the restoration of calm in the area,'' the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Resolution Passed by Lithuanian Parliament
With AM-Soviet-Baltics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of a resolution passed Wednesday by the Lithuanian parliament aimed at getting the Kremlin to negotiate its independence declaration, as translated by the official Soviet news agency Tass. The Supreme Soviet of the Lithuanian Republic, with a view to solving through talks with the U.S.S.R. a package f matters pertaining to the consolidation of the restored independent Lithuanian state, resolves as follows: 1. The actions and decisions, aimed at implementing the acts of the Lithuanian Supreme Soviet, arising from the act dated March 11, 1990, which affect interests that the two sides determined as the subject of talks, shall be suspended for the period of official interstate talks. 2. This resolution takes effect from the beginning of interstate talks between the Lithuanian Republic and the U.S.S.R. and remains effective for the period of talks determined by the sides.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Leaders Complain of Moslem Domination
DOC.TEXT: A leading Christian cleric urged President Ibrahim Babangida to include more Christian southerners in the ruling military council that is dominated by Moslem northerners, newspapers reported Wednesday. Roman Catholic Archbishop Anthony Olubumi Okogie also appealed to Babangida to spare the lives of soldiers who led a failed coup on April 22. The soldiers said they wanted to end Moslem domination of Nigerian politics. Okogie was speaking at a Tuesday news conference in his capacity as president of the Christian Association of Nigeria, according to newspapers in the capital of Lagos. Okogie said the nation could be ``on the path to a crisis'' if Christians were not given more power in the government. In his address he repeatedly referred to Sudan, where Christians and animists in the south are fighting a guerrilla war against Moslem northerners who dominate the government. It is estimated Moslems account for slightly more than half of Nigeria's 100 million people. But previous attempts at a census in Africa's most populous nation have been foiled by groups that have registered inflated numbers of people for political purposes. Christians were deeply angered by a January reshuffle of the ruling council that removed two leading Christian southerners, Defense Minister Lt. Col. Domkat Bali and Internal Affairs Minister John Shagayi, leaving no Christians or southerners holding important portfolios. On Monday, the military began a court-martial of 10 soldiers accused of organizing the coup attempt. Two hundred other soldiers and an unknown number of civilians have also been detained for questioning in connection with the rebellion. In the first few hours of the coup, the rebels almost killed Babangida during a tank bombardment of his house.

DOC.HEAD: Suit That Questioned Garbo Memoir Settled
DOC.TEXT: A lawsuit that questioned the accuracy of a Greta Garbo biography was settled out of court, both sides sides said Wednesday. ``Greta: Her Story,'' was released last week. Its dust jacket says it is an ``unauthorized memoir of Garbo, based on a long and intimate friendship,'' with ``Garbo's own memories,'' as reported by the author, the late Antoni Gronowicz. The reclusive screen legend died last month at age 84. A settlement of the suit by Garbo's niece and only heir, Grey Reisfield, was signed Monday. In confirming the settlement Wednesday, neither Reisfield's lawyer nor the publisher, Simon & Schuster, would say if any changes would be made in the book or the way it is marketed. Theodore A. Kurz, Reisfield's attorney, said the terms of the settlement required it be kept confidential. But in a statement Wednesday he said he was ``extremely gratified by the outcome and that the estate's concerns had been addressed.'' Simon & Schuster issued a statement calling the settlement ``amicable.'' ``The words that purport to be Garbo's are not _ they are Gronowicz's, impersonating Garbo, and are imaginary,'' the copyright infringement suit said. Attempting to block publication herself, Garbo swore in a 1978 affidavit that, ``To the best of my knowledge I have never even met (Gronowicz) at any time in my life.'' The niece's suit, filed Friday against Simon & Schuster, alleged the publisher was making false marketing statements about the book. It didn't ask for money damages, but sought an injunction against sale of the book. ``This action is brought, not to stop Simon & Schuster from selling this book, but to require that it do so accurately and honestly,'' the suit said. The court papers said publisher Dodd, Mead & Co. rejected the book in 1972 because Gronowicz couldn't prove its authenticity. Simon & Schuster, in a statement read by spokeswoman Barbara Reno, said it would not have published the book, ``had it not believed in the fundamental accuracy of the book.'' Gronowicz's work has been questioned before, most notably in the early 1980s with ``God's Broker,'' which purported to be the life of Pope John Paul II as told in his own words. The Vatican denied Gronowicz had ever spoken to the pope. The publisher withdrew the book in 1984 and sued Gronowicz, calling the book ``fraudulent'' and ``a disaster.''

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania Tries Anew for Moscow Talks by Shelving Some Laws
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with details of Lithuanian offer, Estonian strike ending, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's parliament tried again Wednesday to get the Kremlin to the negotiating table by offering to suspend some of the laws it passed after declaring independence March 11, but not the declaration itself. Lithuanian officials said earlier Wednesday that Soviet energy sanctions imposed on the Baltic republic five weeks ago will force all but emergency vehicles off the road by the weekend. Lithuania's president, Vytautas Landsbergis, encouraged countrymen to ``survive as though we were in a surrounded fortress.'' ``We are poor, but we'll not starve to death,'' Landsbergis said in a speech reported by the Lithuanian news agency ELTA. ``Our main weapon is unity and stamina.'' In a conciliatory gesture, the republic's Supreme Council voted 74-15, with 10 abstentions, for a resolution that offers to suspend the laws if Moscow agrees to talks. The resolution did not spell out which laws could be suspended, but Soviet officials have objected to measures that would create a system of special identification cards for Lithuanian citizens, bar Soviet army draft boards in Lithuania and establish Lithuanian control over its borders. Wednesday's resolution said Lithuania decided ``to temporarily suspend, for the period of official interstate negotiations, those actions and decisions arising from realization of the March 11, 1990, acts of the Supreme Council of the Republic of Lithuania related to interests that could be defined by both parties as objects of negotiations,'' said a text released by the Lithuanian parliament's press office. Before Wednesday's announcement, the Baltic situation was settling into a stalemate as Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev insisted that Lithuania and its sister republics of Latvia and Estonia retreat from independence. Landsbergis and other Baltic leaders have said they are willing to compromise but will not surrender their goal of seceding from the Soviet Union, which forcibly annexed all three republics in 1940. Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia had been independent between World War I and World War II. Gorbachev responded to Lithuania's declaration of independence by cutting off oil, natural gas and key raw materials. Since energy supplies were cut off April 18, factories in Lithuania have ground to a halt, traffic has thinned out and 19,000 people have lost their jobs. Soviet authorities have blocked hard currency transfers to all three Baltic republics, but otherwise have not used the economic punishments against Latvia and Estonia for their more cautious approach to secession. A committee directing a strike by non-Estonian workers for the past three days to protest Estonia's secession drive decided Wednesday night to call off the walkout, Tass reported. The official Soviet news agency said workers were told to return to their jobs Thursday because the strike committee felt the main goal, to publicize its cause, was achieved. The Estonian News Agency said Soviet Vice President Anatoly Lukyanov sent a telegram asking that the strike end ``in view of the complicated political and economic situation in the country.'' The report said the telegram was sent ``on behalf of the Soviet president'' _ Gorbachev. Twenty-one businesses reportedly were struck in Tallinn, the Estonian capital. The Estonian government responded by trying to block food shipments to the strikers, the Soviet national newspaper Izvestia reported. The Baltic independence declarations angered Gorbachev and raised concerns among non-Baltic residents that their rights might be jeopardized. Gorbachev calls the declarations illegal. He met Tuesday with the presidents of Latvia and Estonia, but did not budge from his hard line against their independence. Radio Vilnius said Wednesday that shutting down transport in Lithuania would throw 28,000 more people out of work. Food is plentiful, but the energy crunch has forced authorities to curb electricity to industry for three hours a day, Lithuanian officials said. ``The energy shortage is getting bad,'' Lithuanian parliament spokeswoman Rita Dapkus said. ``By the end of the week, most bus routes will be cut. The only thing left will be emergency services, like ambulances and fire trucks.'' Gasoline sales to private vehicles have all but stopped, and only 3,500 out of 13,000 government and commercial vehicles will be running by the weekend, Radio Vilnius said, quoting the Communications Ministry. By Friday, the oil-burning electrical generation plant at Elektrenai was expected to run out of fuel, further curtailing industrial production, Ms. Dapkus said.

DOC.HEAD: Dalai Lama Says Reforms in China Are 10 Years Away
DOC.TEXT: The Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual leader, said Wednesday that China may eventually accept democratic change and loosen its grip on his Himalayan homeland. However, he said the process, if it occurs, will take up to a decade. Opening a private visit to Italy, last year's Nobel Peace Prize winner said he hoped the changes sweeping Eastern Europe will also occur in China and lead to greater freedom for Tibet. ``I predict, however, that it will be a long process, from five to 10 years _ although that's not meant to be a prophecy,'' he told reporters at Marco Polo Airport. The Dalai Lama fled to exile in India after a Tibetan uprising was crushed by Chinese troops in 1959.

DOC.HEAD: Eagleburger Urges Grants, Not Loans to Eastern Europe
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 4 grafs after 3rd graf pvs, Most of, with World Bank, IMF reactions; picks up 4th graf pvs, The United
DOC.TEXT: Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger on Wednesday urged Western allies to provide the emerging Eastern European democracies with economic gifts, rather than loans. ``Loans would just add to the great debt burden that Eastern Europe already has,'' Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger told an international conference on aid to Eastern Europe. Most of the proposals from other countries have been for loans. International financial leaders doubted if enough grants could be put together. ``I hope Mr. Eagleburger will take the lead,'' said Barber Conable, president of the World Bank. Conable said interest rates for World Bank loans to Eastern Europe could not even be reduced. Michael Camdessus, managing director of the Intertional Monetary Fund, said that although grants would be more desirable, he doubted Western nations had enough money available to send funds to Eastern Europe. The United States is committed to $533 million in aid for Poland and Hungary this year, most of it in form of grants or credit guarantees. President Bush has proposed adding $300 million next year to the $205 million in assistance already approved for fiscal years 1991 and 1992. Eagleburger acknowledged the administration has no overall blueprint for helping the region. ``Anyone who had such a blueprint would have had to change it several times recently,'' he said. Despite his opposition to loans, Eagleburger endorsed the newly organized European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which will have $12 billion available for lending to the area. He said it would be useful for large-scale projects which would be too big for any one donor country or small group of countries. The United States, one of 24 countries in Western Europe, America and Asia which set up the new European bank, is expected to provide about 10 percent of the initial funding for the bank.

DOC.HEAD: Widow Will Get Forgotton Thousands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Edd, two d's, cq in 5th graf.
DOC.TEXT: A 93-year-old widow has $127,000 coming to her from stocks and cash she simply forgot about more than 20 years ago, state officials said Wednesday. Thea Sala will get $127,045, found in an unclaimed safety deposit box said Controller Gray Davis. It was recovered under a state program to return unclaimed property to its owners. A check for $37,891 will be written for the cash portion and the rest, mostly stock, will be turned over within six weeks, Davis said. Ten percent of the money will go to Wayne Eproson of Sacramento, the ``heir-finder'' who found Sala living in a downtown Oakland residential hotel. Sala, who didn't attend the ceremony, asked that reporters leave her alone, said Edd Fong, a spokesman for Davis' office. There have been some news reports that the widow, described by Eproson as ``a little forgetful,'' planned to turn the money over to charity. Fong said the finding was the second biggest returned property coup in California. The largest was the $207,000 given to a 71-year-old homeless man in Los Angeles in 1988. Sala, whose husband died several years ago, has no children. The find was announced at an auction for property from unclaimed bank deposit boxes throughout California. Davis told the 150 people at the auction that his office has more than $500 million in unclaimed property belonging to 1.5 million account holders.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Promises To Promote Exports
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Wednesday announced a new government effort, to be coordinated by Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher, to help promote U.S. exports. Bush said the group, called the ``Trade Promotion Coordinating Committee,'' was a first step toward providing U.S. businesses with a ``one-stop shop'' for trade promotion. ``This committee will, for the first time, harness all the resources of the federal government to serve American exporting businesses,'' Bush said. Speaking at a Rose Garden ceremony honoring World Trade Week, Bush said the unit was charged with helping U.S. companies ``move competitively into foreign markets.'' It is the second panel to promote U.S. competitiveness that Bush has named. Earlier in his presidency, he created a Council on Competitiveness, chaired by Vice President Dan Quayle. White House aides said the new committee would not replace Quayle's council, but work alongside it. Bush said the committee would put particular emphasis on promoting American businesses in new or neglected markets. Also sitting on the committee will be representatives from the Departments of State, Treasury, Agriculture, Defense, Energy, Transportation, the Office of Management and Budget, the U.S. Trade Representative, the Small Business Administration and the Export-Import Bank. ``As the winds of freedom blow down old barriers and liberalize new markets from Managua to Warsaw, we must be prepared to take advantage of this opportunity, historic opportunity, to compete and to win,'' Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: Beirut Strike to Protest Killings by Israeli
With AM-Israel
DOC.TEXT: Almost 10,000 people carrying Palestinian and Lebanese flags marched in Moslem west Beirut on Wednesday to protest an Israeli's killing of seven Palestinians near Tel Aviv this weekend. The protesters marched to a local U.N. office and handed officials a memorandum calling on international humanitarian organizations and the United Nations to take ``swift and categoric action against the colonialist crimes and Israel's aggressiveness.'' The protesters also burned effigies of President Bush and Israel's Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir in front of the five-story U.N. office. Also on Wednesday, Moslems observed a general strike to protest the killings. Government offices, banks, schools, shops, amusement centers and other businesses closed for the day in Moslem west Beirut, south Lebanon, the eastern Bekaa Valley and north Lebanon. Beirut international airport closed for an hour to observe the strike. The strike coincided with a general strike in the Israeli occupied territories to protest the slaying of the seven Arab laborers by an Israeli who police described as deranged. The killings led to violent clashes in the occupied territories and Jordan in which several people have been killed and hundreds wounded. In west Beirut, Palestinians wearing camouflage fatigues and brandishing automatic rifles demonstrated. Children carrying large slingshots led the protesters. ``I'm carrying a big slingshot and a big stone so that my blow can have more effect on the Israelis,'' said a 7-year-old boy. Slingshots are one of the main weapons used by Palestinian youths in their 29-month-old uprising against Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. In the southern port of Sidon, a green BMW rigged with 110 pounds of TNT exploded slightly injuring four civilians, police said. A police spokesman, who cannot be identified in line with standing regulations, said the bomb went off two minutes after Anwar Madi, a local commander of the Palestinian Fatah organization, drove by. ``It could have been an attempt to assassinate him,'' the spokesman said. No group claimed responsibility for the blast. Sidon is a main power base for Fatah, the Palestinian faction led by Palestine Liberation Organization Chairman Yasser Arafat.

DOC.HEAD: Survey: Most Developmentally Disabled Say They Don't Control Lives
DOC.TEXT: Only about one in four developmentally disabled Americans consider themselves independent enough to control their own lives, survey results released Wednesday show. The study, commissioned by the National Association of Developmental Disabilies Councils, found that while 75 percent of the respondents felt it important to be independent, only 26 percent believed they had achieved any level of independence. Independence was defined as ``making choices and exercising control over one's life.'' Only 16 percent of adults were allowed to choose their own places to live, the survey said. Nearly 60 percent _ both adults and children _ live on their own or with families rather than in various types of institutions. The survey also found that: _78 percent felt it important to be productive, but only 38 percent believed they fit the description of being able to ``work or make a contribution through productive activity.'' Only 11 percent said they were completely unable to work. Those who were employed were paid a weekly average of $60 for 24 hours of work, with an average hourly wage of $2.87. Statistics show that people with mental retardation earn nearly two-thirds less than people with other disabilities. _75 percent of respondents felt it important to be integrated, while only 40 percent felt they were. Integration was defined as ``participating in community life and interacting with other members of society.'' Far fewer respondents said they knew their neighbors than those participating in a survey of non-disabled Americans, the study said. ``This is despite the fact that most people in the survey live in their own homes or with relatives.'' The survey was conducted by the Developmental Disabilities Center at Temple University in Philadelphia. It was part of a larger report required by a 1987 law to help Congress determine the needs of the developmentally disabled. The results also will be used to help with implementation of the Americans with Disabilities Act, comprehensive civil rights legislation adopted by the House Tuesday and expected to become law this summer. The combined effort took 2{ years. Some 15,000 people _ one out of every 200 people with a developmental disability _ were interviewed. All states and U.S. territories were included in the survey. The association is the umbrella group for state and territorial councils that work to improve the lives of people with disabilities. The report included a compilation of smaller studies from the state councils on the needs of the disabled. Key recommendations included supporting families ``as needed'' to assure that children grow up in families and using ``funding mechanisms that support individual choice and control, that fund individuals rather than facilities, and that reduce rather than reinforce dependency.'' Developmental disabilities are impairments that are present at birth or occur before a person's 22nd birthday. They include mental retardation, cerebral palsy, chronic mental illness, epilepsy and autism.

DOC.HEAD: Romania's Iliescu Hits Challengers for Not Accepting Defeat
DOC.TEXT: Ion Iliescu, Romania's interim president and now its president-elect, accused his opposition of political immaturity Wednesday for complaining that his lopsided victory in weekend elections was fraudulent. He rejected a proposal that a commission be set up to investigate allegations of electoral fraud, a major demand of the chief U.S. government observer, Gov. Garrey Carruthers, R-N.M. ``None of the foreign observers could point to even one fact that constitutes fraud,'' Iliescu insisted. ``It's all based on claims by the opposition.'' Iliescu reiterated at a news conference Wednesday his claim of a complete break with his Communist past, and said he wanted the new government to include ``competent people, regardless of party affiliation.'' According to a near-final tally of the vote released Wednesday, Iliescu received 85 percent of the votes for president and his National Salvation Front 67 percent of the votes for the two-chamber Parliament. Iliescu said, ``The opposition doesn't want to accept the result because it's not in their favor. ... They misunderstand the political game and are displaying political immaturity. It's very sad when someone doesn't know how to lose.'' Iliescu and the Front have dominated government since the December revolution that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Opposition parties and demonstrators have accused both of being neo-Communist. The president-elect called this charge an ``election slogan.'' ``Romania's break with communism was the most brusque and revolutionary in all East Europe,'' he said. ``There is no way back, and to try such a thing would be political suicide. So it's impossible.'' He said his challengers _ Radu Campeanu of the National Liberal Party and Ion Ratiu of the National Peasant Party _ lost because they ``misunderstood the character of the revolution and slid to the extreme right.'' He said they ``frightened voters away with violent language and incitements to violence.'' He said Ratiu and Campeanu, both elderly, longtime exiles, ``showed that they are detached from the realities of Romania and failed to establish the necessary dialogue with the people.'' But he added that the Front, which can govern alone if it chooses, ``remains open to any possible coalition or parliamentary cooperation.'' ``We need trained, experienced, competent people, regardless of party affiliation.'' He said the priority of the new government would be the creation of a constitution and development of a ``coherent strategy'' for transition to a free-market economy. Iliescu refused to say if Petre Roman would continue as prime minister, saying, ``This is up to the new Parliament.'' Roman said the anti-Front demonstration in downtown University Square, which has blocked the capital's central intersection for 32 days, was ``inadmissible'' now that ``the government had the legitimacy of being elected.'' But Iliescu said no force would be applied to clear the square, ``I hope.'' He pledged Romania will be ``open to all countries of both East and West,'' but added: ``We don't want to be dependent on anyone any more. ... Romanian politics will be made in Romania.'' Iliescu rejected the proposal, made by Carruthers and other foreign observers who monitored the election, that Romania must abolish the state monopoly over electronic media. He said state-run television guarantees access to all political points of view, and that a private channel ``would create a lack of democratic access.'' He insisted ``at the present time the press is under no control or censorship.''

DOC.HEAD: Senegal, Guinea Bissau Agree to Pull Back Troops in Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Senegal and Guinea Bissau agreed Wednesday on a mutual retreat from their common border to settle a maritime dispute that has reportedly left 17 soldiers dead, the Senegalese Embassy announced. The two sides are arguing over who controls waters believed to contain oil deposits. The area is off the land border between the two West African nations. Wednesday's settlement was reached by Foreign Minister Seydina Oumar Sy of Senegal and Finance Minister Col. Manuel Santos of Guinea Bissau during a meeting in Paris, the Senegalese Embassy said. The meeting was held during a visit to Paris by Guinea Bissau's leader, Gen. Joao Bernardo Vieira. However, there was no immediate comment from Guinea Bissau. The Senegalese Embassy statement said the two countries hope to ``find through dialogue peaceful solutions to all questions regarding their relations.'' The statement said the two nations' troops would be pulled back to a ``reasonable distance'' from the border. The dispute over maritime borders dates from colonial times. Since Saturday, clashes on Guinea Bissau's northern land border have left at least 17 soldiers dead, according to news reports. The disputed waters were confirmed as Senegalese territory in 1960 by an exchange of letters between Portugal and France, the colonial powers at the time. However, Guinea Bissau challenged control of the zone when it gained independence from Portugal in 1974. In 1989, Guinea Bissau rejected the verdict of an international court in Geneva, which found in favor of Senegal. It has taken its complaint to the International Court of Justice in The Hague.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil's President: Economic Shock Treatment is Working
DOC.TEXT: President Fernando Collor de Mello said Wednesday his tough anti-inflation plan is working better than expected, despite an outbreak of strikes to protest layoffs and the loss of purchasing power. He said inflation had plunged from a record 84 percent a month to 3.3 percent in April. The government's goal initially had been to reduce inflation to 10 percent a month in 100 days. ``The program has turned out much better than we imagined,'' the president said during his press conference at the Foreign Ministry in this inland capital. Collor said the government had moved up its economic targets for the first 100 days ``because the results have been surprisingly positive.'' The reform plan, which went into effect March 16, froze $115 billion in bank and money-market deposits, fixed prices for a month and created a new currency. In addition, price controls have been lifted on everything except utility rates and basic foods. The president said the exchange rate ``is on the verge of total freedom.'' The bank freeze reduced the amount of money in circulation in Latin America's most populous nation, with 145 million residents. Officials believe an excess of cash was the main cause of Brazil's chronic inflation. ``The success of the plan is palpable,'' Collor said. ``The catastrophic predictions of recession and depression have not materialized.'' However, unions and private economic institutions claim the real inflation rate was as high as 40 percent last month. Buying power is estimated to have fallen by up to 63 percent in March. In recent days, strikes have broken out in cities across the country to protest the loss of buying power and a rise in layoffs. Bus and subway workers walked off their jobs in several state capitals. Labor leaders have talked of organizing a general strike. The austerity measures have led private companies to fire an estimated 400,000 workers and put 700,000 others on paid holiday. The government recently said up to one-fourth of its 1.6 million employees would be laid off. However, Collor said workers would not be jeopardized by the government's decision to eliminate official cost-of-living raises and allow free salary negotiations between managers and employees. He said the government will intervene if employers ``try to impose impossible sacrifices on wage earners,'' but he did not offer details. He also said the labor protests would not shake his determination to carry out the cutbacks. ``My will is firm and the goals will be met,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Alabama Congressman Given First Profile In Courage Award
DOC.TEXT: A man who lost his political career and was left in financial ruin because of his fight to help people of all races get an education won the first Profile in Courage Award on Wednesday. Carl A. Elliott, a 76-year-old Southern Democrat, was awarded the first John F. Kennedy Profile in Courage Award, instituted by the Kennedy Library Foundation in Boston. During Elliott's 16 years in Congress in the 1950s and 1960s, he pushed for civil rights and was instrumental in enacting the far-reaching National Defense Education Act. Called a ``living profile in courage,'' Elliott ``faced intense public scorn and suffered personal abuse and eventual political defeat while achieving victories for the good of a nation he loved,'' said Paul G. Kirk Jr., chairman of the Kennedy Library Foundation. Elliott was defeated in 1964 by pro-segregation forces spearheaded by Gov. George Wallace and two years later lost a bid for governor to Lureen Wallace, the wife of Wallace, who was prevented by law from succeeding himself. That defeat left him in heavy debt, he said. ``I spent much more than every penny I had. I've been wrestling with those debts ever since and still am,'' Elliott said. But he'll get some help from the award. Next Tuesday he'll receive a trophy crafted by Tiffany & Co. in the shape of a ship's beacon, as well as a $25,000 stipend. Elliott, once a hulking figure, is now a frail diabetic, confined to a wheelchair and legally blind, Kirk said. Bill Barnard, chairman of the history department at the University of Alabama, said Elliott is the embodiment of the old adage about a prophet not being honored in his own country. ``That is what happened to Carl Elliott. You only hope you live long enough to be recognized for your accomplishments,'' Barnard said. The Profile in Courage Award was created by the Kennedy Library Foundation in 1989 to honor President John F. Kennedy and encourage people to value courage in elected officials. Elliott, now a retired attorney, delighted in the long-overdue recognition as reporter after reporter telephoned his modest home in downtown Jasper, Ala. ``I understand there were 5,000 nominations. It makes me feel good to be chosen,'' he said. ``I feel this will help the cause of education.'' ``Here's a role model who was consistent with what President Kennedy himself believed,'' Kirk said. ``Here's a fellow who knew what the price would be politically and paid it.'' In 1948 Elliott was elected to House of Representatives, two years after Kennedy was first elected to the House. But his commitment to education began when, as the son of tenant farmers, he believed then-University of Alabama President George Denny when he said anyone willing to work could make his way through the university. Elliott took Denny at his word and arrived on campus with $2.38. Denny soon found the impoverished student sleeping in a deserted building and gave him a batch of odd jobs. That experience prompted Elliott to spend 10 years trying to pass a bill that became the National Defense Education Act of 1958, the first billion-dollar education bill ever passed by Congress and the foundation for today's student loans and grants. He continued to fight for federal education aid, despite fears of many Southerners that it would open the doors of colleges to more blacks. ``There was a lot of talk of that, but we wrote that bill to take care of all Americans who were bright and wanted to go to college,'' he said. He admits to some bitterness about having his political career cut short, but he said, ``I'm not blaming anybody about any of it. I fought the good fight, and I'm proud of it.'' Of the more than 5,000 nominations for the award, four others were selected as finalists. They are: Oklahoma Gov. Henry Bellmon, a former U.S. Senator; Unita Blackwell, the mayor of Mayersville, Miss., and the first black mayor in the state; LeRoy Collins, former governor of Florida; and Morris K. Udall, a member of the House of Representatives since 1961.

DOC.HEAD: Government Upgrades Hyundai, Minivan Investigations
DOC.TEXT: Federal engineers are stepping up an investigation of reported steering wheel vibrations in Hyundai Excels manufactured between 1987 and 1989, the government said Wednesday. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said it had received 294 complaints of extreme vibrations when the cars reach highway speeds. The problem has been blamed for two accidents and two injuries, agency spokesman Tim Hurd said. An estimated 707,000 of the cars are on the road. The agency upgraded its investigation from a preliminary evaluation, involving mostly paperwork, to an engineering analysis in which the parts being questioned are inspected. The process could lead to a recall. Also upgraded to engineering analysis status were preliminary evaluations of 1987-88 General Motors Astro and Safari minivans and 1989-90 Chrysler Cherokee Wagoneers. There have been 300 complaints of power steering loss in the Astro and Safari after breakage of the power steering pump bracket. An estimated 362,000 of the minivans are on the road. One accident has been linked to the problem. The agency has received 16 complaints about the Wagoneer's anti-lock brakes, including wheel lockup to brake failure, Hurd said. The problem has been blamed for one accident and an injury. An estimated 17,000 of the vehicles are on the road. Preliminary evaluations were opened last month on: _Six complaints of engine fires in the 1985 Buick Skyhawk. An estimated 82,000 are on the road. _Two complaints of front brake discs becoming detached on Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable, 1986-89 models. An estimated 1.2 million are on the road. _One complaint of a broken rear axle assembly on the 1987 Ford Aerostar, of which 166,000 are on the road. _Two complaints of hood latch failure on the 1990 Mercury Cougar. _A Winnebago service bulletin reporting windshield wiper arm lockup on the company's 1990 M series. An estimated 244 of the recreational vehicles are on the road. _Six complaints of wheel bearing failure on the 1983-85 Winnebago LeSharo, of which 20,000 are on the road. The agency discontinued several preliminary evaluations after finding no defect trend or evidence of an unreasonable safety risk. Among them were probes of structural weld failures in the 1989 GM GEO Tracker, weld failures in the 1989 Suzuki Sidekick, and speed control problems in the 1984-89 GMC Suburban.

DOC.HEAD: Prince Charles Says He Speaks German Better After a Drink
DOC.TEXT: Prince Charles said Wednesday that he speaks German better after a drink. The 41-year-old son of Queen Elizabeth II and heir to the British throne told a group of businessmen: ``I am the kind of Englishman, I think, who finds conversing in a foreign language is made much easier with the assistance of a small alcoholic beverage. ``Maybe that is why I succeeded in failing my O-level German _ alcohol was restricted at school,'' he joked. O-levels are Britain's school-leaving examinations that are taken by students when they are about 16. On a more serious note, the prince said Britain urgently needs to make up lost ground by learning foreign languages if it is to maintain its competitive edge in the world. In a separate interview published Wednesday in The Scotsman, Prince Charles said he was sometimes demoralized by the ``vitriolic personal abuse'' he has attracted with his six-year campaign for better architecture. ``I try not to, but occasionally I get demoralized or dispirited by it,'' the prince said. But Prince Charles said he would intensify his campaign. ``I would not have gone on with my activities on the architectural design and development front unless I felt there was support from the public or that I had struck a chord,'' he said. The prince last year produced a book on his personal view of architecture, ``A Vision of Britain,'' and made a television documentary on the subject. His attacks on modern architecture have prompted protests from some architects. The prince dislikes office blocks towering over St. Paul's Cathedral in London, wayside gas stations, factories, department stores and high-rise apartments on open plains. He tends to favor classic-style buildings with porticoes and columns, and turn-of-the-century homes.

DOC.HEAD: Experts' Advice: Follow The Money To Catch Spies
DOC.TEXT: A committee of experts urged Congress on Wednesday to let investigators monitor the personal finances of government and defense workers who know top secrets because most modern spies work for money.
