After nine months of study on behalf of Sens. David Boren, D-Okla., and William Cohen, R-Maine, chairman and vice chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, the panel proposed 13 new laws. Many of the proposals are aimed at the 700,000 government and contract workers who have access to top secret information. To get those jobs, they would be required to allow investigators access to their bank and commercial credit records anytime up to five years after they leave the secret work. They would be required to report any foreign travel or contacts by citizens of foreign countries. Employees who work with codes and code machines would be subject to random polygraph tests. Questions would be limited to whether they spied or sold secrets and not ask _ in Sen. Boren's words _ ``how many cocktails they drank or X-rated movies they saw.'' The experts also recommended making it a crime to possess spy tools, like burst transmitters and secret writing devices, with intent to commit espionage. ``We hope this legislation would raise the risk that individuals would run by engaging in espionage, first, that they would be caught and, second, that they would end up paying a penalty, serving time in jail,'' said retired Navy Adm. Bobby Ray Inman, former CIA deputy director. Inman and other panel members told a hearing of the Senate Intelligence Committee that the nine-member panel had looked for patterns in the spy cases of recent years. In the 1960s there was ``an overwhelmingly shift from recruitment'' of spies through ideology to ``volunteer'' spies, usually seeking money, he said. He presented an analysis of 19 well-known cases in the last 20 years. Money was a motive in 14. Sen. Boren said the experts had pointed out ``a blind spot'' in U.S. defenses. Once workers obtain security clearances, ``we know less about them financially than if they're applying for an auto loan,'' Boren said. The experts and the senators emphasized that the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe and its internal difficulties in the Soviet Union had not lessened the spy threat. ``More and more foreign government will be out to steal our national economic secrets,'' Sen. Boren predicted. Warren Christopher, a Los Angeles lawyer who served as No. 2 official in the Justice and State departments, said: ``Looking west from the Pacific Rim, the world does not seem so much changed. It seems more dangerous, particularly in terms of economic espionage.'' But under questioning from Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., Columbia University law professor Harold Edgar acknowledged that ``the proposals do not specifically treat economic espionage'' aimed at private corporate secrets unless they also are government defense secrets. In addition, the panel proposed: _Two more criminal violations: selling any document labelled top secret and removing top secret documents from government custody. The government would no longer have to disclose what was in the secret documents. _Giving the FBI the right to obtain credit records in secret with a letter assuring the credit bureau that the subject was suspected of spying, and allowing the FBI to obtain secretly the names of unlisted telephone owners who call suspects in a spy case. These two are being proposed already by the Bush administration but have been rejected by Congress before. The American Civil Liberties Union has opposed both, arguing that the FBI has not shown a need and that the government could collect data on people making innocent calls. _Barring spies from profiting from books about their crimes. _Denying government retirement pay to U.S. workers convicted in foreign courts of disclosing U.S. secrets. _Establishing a $1 million reward for turning in a spy. _Requiring the FBI to obtain a warrant from the secret Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court before burglarizing a suspected spy. Such warrants are required to plant listening device; the burglaries, so-called ``black bag jobs,'' are done under inherent presidential powers. The Carter administration persuaded the court to issue three warrants for burglaries, but the Reagan administration convinced the judges that they did not have the power to issue burglary warrants. _Allowing the National Security Agency, the nation's code agency, to provide after-care and counseling to troubled employees, because several spies began work after they quit. The panel was informally chaired by venture capitalist Eli Jacobs, Baltimore Orioles baseball team owner and government defense adviser. Other members are: former CIA Director Richard Helms; former Carter White House counsel Lloyd Cutler; former Reagan White House counsel Arthur B. Culvahouse Jr.; former ambassador to the Organization of American States Sol Linowitz and former ambassador and State Department official Seymour Weiss.

DOC.HEAD: Israelis Celebrate in Jerusalem; Army Extends Curfew for Arabs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with one killed in Jordan, Palestinian dies of wounds, Israel opposes stationing of U.N. troops in occupied lands. EDITS to TRIM. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos TLV1,2,JRL1; LaserColor TLV102
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of flag-waving Israelis celebrated the 1967 capture of Arab east Jerusalem, and the government launched a counteroffensive at critics who link its hard-line policies to the killings of seven Arabs. In neighboring Jordan, a Palestinian rioter was shot to death and four other people, including two policemen, were seriously wounded during a six-hour clash at the Hitteen refugee camp near the capital of Amman, police reported. Hundreds of Jordanian police fired live ammunition and tear gas at the massed demonstrators in an effort to prevent looting and rioing but police said two branches of the Jordan Housing Bank on the outskirts of the refugee camp were gutted by rioters. Police said the dead rioter ``was killed by a bullet of a type not used by the police,'' implying he was shot accidentally by other demonstrators. That raised the casualty toll in Jordan to four dead and 29 wounded in three days of violent Palestinian demonstrations over the murder of seven Palestinian laborers on Sunday by a Israeli civilian described by police as deranged. In east Jerusalem's Old City, angry Moslem worshipers hurled stones at Jewish extremists when the Jews tried to pray near the Al Aqsa Mosque on the Temple Mount, the site where tradition holds King Solomon and later King Herod built their temples. No one was injured. The army extended curfews on most of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip for a fourth day to quell violent protests of the Sunday massacre. About 1.5 million Palestinians were confined to their homes. In Gaza's Bani Suheila village, 8-year-old Mustafa Awad El Fajem was shot and killed when an unidentified gunman opened fire from a passing vehicle, an army spokeswoman said. She was unsure whether a military vehicle was involved. Israel radio said the passing vehicle had yellow Israeli license plates but gave no further details. Seven Palestinians were reported wounded by army gunfire in clashes. Since Sunday's massacre 13 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers trying to put down protests and more than 800 have been reported shot, beaten or suffered from tear-gas inhalation. El Fajem's death brought to 708 the number of Palestinians killed by Israelis in the 29-month-old Palestinian uprising. At least 216 other Palestinians have been slain by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel. Forty-three Israelis have also died. The European Community, echoing U.S. government statements, accused Israel of ``excessive force to put down the demonstrations'' and said the lack of peace efforts had fostered the upsurge in violence. Israeli-U.S. ties have suffered the past two months over the stalled Middle East peace process and the settlement policies of hard-line Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said the United States believes ``that absence of a peace process contributes to violence in the Middle East.'' Foreign Minister Moshe Arens, a close Shamir ally in the right-wing Likud bloc, acknowledged that Israel was on the defensive. ``There is no doubt we are having a difficult period in the international arena. We have to prepare for a confrontation in this area,'' he said. Foreign Ministry spokesman Yossi Amihud said Israel was especially concerned with embassy reports indicating that within foreign governments ``there is an attempt to make a connection between the murder of seven people and the peace process.'' Arens told Israel radio: ``We're dealing with a man who went berserk, killing people indiscriminately. We've seen these kinds of scenes in other places, including the United States.'' Israeli authorities say the man charged in Sunday's seven killings in a Tel Aviv suburb, 21-year-old Ami Popper, was deranged and also upset by an unhappy love affair. A judge ordered a psychiatric evaluation for him. In Jerusalem, thousands of flag-waving Israelis marched through the city to mark Jerusalem Day, the 23rd anniversary of the capture of the Gaza Strip, the West Bank and Arab east Jerusalem from Egypt and Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war. Israel annexed east Jerusalem in 1967, but the United States and other Western nations maintain the final status of the city should be determined in peace talks. Palestinians want east Jerusalem to be the capital of their would-be state. In a related development, a spokesman for Yasser Arafat said the PLO leader, scheduled to address the U.N. Security Council in Geneva on Friday, will seek U.N. intervention to protect Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Shamir's adviser Avi Pazner said Israel sees the idea of stationing U.N. observers in the occupied territories as a violation of its sovereignity and would ask the United States to veto such a proposal. In Lebanon, almost 10,000 people marched to a local U.N. office to protest the killing of the Palestinian laborers and to demand swift action from the United Nations and other international organizations.

DOC.HEAD: Spring Showers and Cold Snap Chill Much of the Nation
DOC.TEXT: Spring showers fell on much of the nation Wednesday and record cold temperatures chilled spots in the South and East. A severe thunderstorm watch was posted over eastern and northeast Wyoming, southeast Montana, western South Dakota and the northern Nebraska panhandle. A large high pressure system, reaching from the Great Lakes to the Ohio Valley, brought chilly temperatures from the Northeast into the eastern third of the nation. Overnight temperatures were unseasonably cool and record lows were recorded Wednesday in Greer, S.C., with a reading of 46 degrees, in Harrisburg, Pa., with 42, and in Meridian, Miss., with 50. The low temperature for the nation Wednesday morning was 30 degrees at Gunnison, Colo. A snow advisory was posted Wednesday over the higher elevations of the Mount Shasta-Siskiyou area and the northern Sierra Nevada of California. Snow advisories were posted Thursday morning across the Oregon Cascades. At noon, rain and occasional thundershowers were scattered over New England, the Midwest and Great Lakes region, the Gulf Coast of Texas, and from Montana through the Pacific Northwest. Noon temperatures ranged in the 40s and 50s over New England and the Pacific Northwest; the 70s over the upper Missouri Valley; the 80s across much of Florida; the 80s and 90s over the western half of the southern Plains; and to the 80s and 90s across the southwest deserts. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 39 degrees at Tahoe Valley, Calif., to 100 degrees at Gila Bend, Ariz.

DOC.HEAD: Canada's Mulroney Still Hopes for Conference on Endangered Accord
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said Wednesday some hope remains that differences among Canada's 10 provincial premiers over the Meech Lake accord can be sufficiently narrowed to hold a conference. Mulroney is working against a June 23 deadline. The accord, which would recognize the French-speaking province of Quebec as a distinct society and give all provinces expanded powers, will expire then unless ratified by the holdout provinces of New Brunswick, Newfoundland and Manitoba. By law, all 10 provinces must ratify the accord, which was designed to win Quebec's support for the 1982 Constitution. Sen. Lowell Murray, Mulroney's personal Meech Lake emissary, told the prime minister too much divides the premiers to hold an immediate meeting. But Mulroney, who has slept little the last few days as he searched for a way to save Meech Lake, told the House of Commons that Murray may have a way out of the impasse. Mulroney told opposition leader Herb Gray suggestions that have been advanced ``might facilitate the bringing together of the parties so that we could narrow the terrain. That process might indeed lead to a fruitful first ministers' conference'' _ meaning a conference of the federal prime minister and the 10 provincial premiers. A special committee led by Quebec Tory Jean Charest made 23 recommendations last week aimed at coming up with a Meech-saving compromise. On Monday, Lucien Bouchard, Mulroney's environment minister and his senior Quebec minister, resigned from the Tory caucus and the Cabinet. Quebec rank-and-file member of parliament Gilbert Chartrant quit the Conservative party Tuesday. Both viewed the committee report as a sellout of their province. Treasury Board President Robert de Cotret was named acting environment minister Wednesday. Bouchard, a longtime friend of Mulroney, campaigned for sovereignty-association for Quebec in 1980 before joining the Tories. He said the government now was trying to amend Meech Lake _ breaking a promise it made to Quebec, which contains 6.7 million of Canada's 25 million residents. Bouchard's defection further dampened hopes of Meech Lake's surviving. Opposition to Meech Lake has fanned separation fears in Quebec and renewed talk of sovereignty-association, in which the province would be politically distinct but maintain economic ties with the rest of the country. Murray admitted time was running out and called Meech Lake the ultimate symbol of compromise and openness by Quebec after its humiliation when the 1982 Constitution was signed without Quebec's participation. Murray called on Mulroney and Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa to accept no changes to the accord, and to let those who are trying to scuttle Meech Lake suffer the consequences. The government of Premier Clyde Wells in Newfoundland rescinded approval of Meech Lake last month. Wells argues the accord entrenches regional disparities, blocks Senate reform and gives Quebec special powers. New Brunswick and Manitoba have never approved the accord.

DOC.HEAD: Affandi, Indonesian Painter, Dead at 83
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS three grafs for final graf `Survivors include...' to ADD quotes from Affandi; no pickup. One name cq for Affandi and Suharto.
DOC.TEXT: Affandi, an expressionist painter whose works were exhibited worldwide, died Wednesday after a long illness. He was 83. He died in the home he designed on the banks of the Gajah Wong River, 400 miles southeast of Jakarta on Indonesia's main island of Java. He had been in a coma for several months. The artist, considered Indonesia's foremost expressionist painter, was born in the west Java town of Cirebon and began professional work in 1938. ``Ibu (Mother)'' was a masterpiece of his early realistic works before he turned to expressionism. ``Self Portrait'' is another famous work among the 4,000 paintings he created. In 1948, he traveled to India and later became a guest lecturer at the East-West Center in Hawaii. His works were exhibited in London, Paris, Rome, Rio de Janeiro and the Hague. In 1956, he exhibited his works in the United States under the Asia Foundation grant. President Suharto gave him Indonesia's highest award for artistic achievements. ``Fire to Live'' was a 1982 Swedish documentary on the life of Affandi, who always proclaimed himself a ``sukasrana'' _ a character in a traditional Javanese puppet story who has supernatural powers. Affandi once said, ``If I don't paint, I feel ashamed.'' He had vowed to continue painting despite old age, but he was eventually forced to take up a self-styled type of drawing with his fingers after pouring paint onto the canvas. Survivors include four children and several grandchildren. There was no immediate word on funeral arrangements.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Leaders in Baghdad Agree to Summit Agenda
DOC.TEXT: Arab foreign ministers agreed Wednesday to a five-point agenda for an upcoming conference of their kings and heads of state that will concentrate on Soviet Jewish immigration to Israel. Syria has announced it will boycott the Monday summit, which is being hosted by its main Arab rival, Iraq. The agenda, made available to The Associated Press by a conference source, also listed perceived threats against Iraq and Libya and the lack of a peace treaty between Iran and Iraq. The Palestine Liberation Organization scored a political victory when its working paper was adopted with only minor changes as the recommended draft resolution on the Middle East crisis. Egypt had suggested a working paper in line with a controversial U.S. memorandum to the summit that called on Arabs to support direct negotiations between Israel and Palestinians and made no formal reference to a role for the PLO. The adpoted draft resolution reiterates support for the PLO's peace overtures and calls for convening an international peace conference. The U.S. memorandum had suggested dropping the international conference from the summit resolutions. The paper reiterates that Jerusalem is the capital of an envisaged Palestinian state and calls for economic and political sanctions by the Arabs against any country that officially regards Jerusalem as the capital of the Jewish state. Most nations, including the United States, do not regard Jerusalem as the capital of Israel. It also called for sanctions against any country or institution that facilitates the immigration of Soviet Jews to Israel. The paper urged governments to open their borders to Soviet Jews so the emigrants do not have to move to Israel. It also called on the United Nations to secure international supervision of the occupied territories to guard against the settlement of Soviet Jews in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. The draft resolutions will only become binding if it is endorsed by Arab leaders at the summit. Resolutions drafted at foreign ministerial meetings are usually approved with few changes. The emergency meeting was called by Arafat to discuss Soviet Jewish immigration to Israel. The U.S. memorandum was delivered this weekend to Arab League Secretary-General Chedli Klibi, who submitted a text in Arabic to the foreign ministers on Tuesday. The memorandum said Washington remains opposed to the establishment of Jewish settlements in the Israeli-occupied territories but supported the immigration of Soviet Jews as ``a perfectly legitimate human right.'' It urged the Arabs not to ``try and block the right of Jews to emigrate or Israel's right to absorb them within its own territories.''

DOC.HEAD: Marx Lewis Dead at 93
DOC.TEXT: Marx Lewis, veteran labor organizer, has died at age 93. Accuracy in Media, a watchdog group on whose board he served, said Lewis died Tuesday of cardiac arrest. Lewis earned a law degree from the American University in 1924 but never practiced, chosing to become an organizer for the Cap and Millinery Workers Union. A socialist in his youth, he held several labor positions and helped organize the Liberal Party of New York. He served in the administration of Republican New York City Mayor Fiorello LaGuardia in the 1930s and 1940s and later became a Republican. He is survived by two sons, four sisters, five grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Burned Boy ID'd Suspect Hours After Attack
DOC.TEXT: A 12-year-old boy set afire by a neighborhood bully picked his accused assailant's picture from among photographs brought to his bedside just hours later, an investigator testified Wednesday. Detective Charles Higgins said that on the night of March 7 he took six photographs, one of them of the suspect, to the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center where David Opont had been admitted in critical condition with severe burns over much of his body. ``He studied it awhile,'' Higgins said of the photo array, ``and then in a clear voice he stated No. 2 is one who put fire on me.'' David's accused assailant, a brawny 13-year-old dressed in loose-fitting gray shirt and slacks, sat silently through the hourlong pretrial hearing in Brooklyn Family Court. The boy's name is being withheld because of his age. Meanwhile, David, who had been given only a 50-50 chance of surviving the attack, has been making a remarkable recovery and could possibly leave the hospital within the next week, a hospital spokeswoman said. David may be called on to testify against the teen charged with setting him on fire in an abandoned Brooklyn building. He was walking to school on the day before his 12th birthday when a neighborhood bully forced him into a vacant building, tied him to a railing inside, and set him on fire. David, who allegedly was robbed by the boy a day earlier, suffered burns over 55 percent of his body.

DOC.HEAD: Arpino to Remain With Joffrey Ballet
DOC.TEXT: The Joffrey Ballet's artistic director, Gerald Arpino, has reversed his decision to resign, the company announced Wednesday. Arpino, who resigned May 1 and withdrew his works and those of the company's founder from the Joffrey's repetoire, has been meeting with a committee from the ballet's board of directors since then, according to a statement issued by the company. He resigned after the board voted to set up an operating committee that would run the company in place of both Arpino and the 55-member board. Ten board members resigned in protest over what one member called a takeover by businessmen ignorant of artistic matters. Arpino, whose resignation was never accepted by the board, continued as artistic director of the company's ballet school. Arpino earlier had given permission for his ballets to return to the company's repertory this Friday, two days before the end of a four-week season in Los Angeles. The co-chairmen of the 55-member board, David Murdock in Los Angeles and Anthony Bliss in New York, and the company's executive director, Penelope Curry, all resigned during the month. Wednesday's statement from the company said that Arpino and the committee had reached an agreement ``which resolves all outstanding issues between Mr. Arpino and the company. ... Under this agreement, which will be presented for the full board's consideration at a meeting this Thursday, Mr. Arpino will license his ballets and those of the late Robert Joffrey to the company.'' The Joffrey was founded by Arpino and Robert Joffrey in 1956. Arpino became artistic director following Joffrey's death in 1988. Arpino has been a dancer and choreographer with the modern ballet company since its early days. However, critics and dance buffs alike have often called his works pedestrian instead of inspired, and without structure, purpose or artistry. With the exception of such works as ``Sea Shadow'' (1962) and ``Viva Vivaldi'' (1965), Arpino is considered a second-rate choreographer who merely moves dancers around a stage.

DOC.HEAD: Peace Games Try To Change Mind Set Of Youth
DOC.TEXT: Most kids would rather play video games than fight ivory poachers, but some University of Connecticut educators worked to change that Wednesday. The First International Peace Games Festival brought students from 94 high schools and middle schools around the state, Massachusetts and Canada to participate in a celebration of peace and play peace games designed by the students. ``We have to change the mind frame of children,'' said Francelia Butler, a UConn English professor and organizer of the event. ``We have to make them look at tragedy and say `What can I do to resolve this?''' Butler, 77, said she is tired of ``singing songs and holding candles'' and other such demonstrations against world conflict. She believes a more practical approach is changing the attitude of tomorrow's peace makers. ``Glasnost has changed a lot of people's mind and peace is possible,'' she said. The student-designed games had themes ranging from abortion to environmental causes. One, called ``Tusk Mania,'' addressed the plight of the endangered African elephant. The game board, designed by sixth graders, was in the shape of Africa and the object was to get the elephant-shaped game pieces safely to a sanctuary to avoid ivory poachers. In another game, entitled ``Peace With Nature,'' players were penalized for bringing styrofoam cups to a picnic or for using aerosol spray cans. But, if they donated money to save the rain forest, they were awarded an extra turn. Butler said her students at UConn have been designing board games for her classes for three years as a requirement of the course. Some of those students went around the state to show the younger children how to design a peace game. A successful peace game should feature conflict resolution, where ``peace wins and war is averted,'' she said. Her students turned in 11 games last semester on the Berlin Wall, including one where for each correct trivia question answered, another brick would be taken off the wall.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Candidate: United States Lax in Drug War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead; SUBS two grafs for 8th `Officials blame' to UPDATE with three more policemen killed; pickup graf 9 pvs, `Despite U.S...'
DOC.TEXT: Colombia's presidential frontrunner said Wednesday the United States must work harder at stopping the narcotics trade and more vigorously prosecute drug suspects like Washington Mayor Marion Barry. Cesar Gaviria, the only of four candidates in Sunday's election to take a hard-line stand on Colombia's drug traffickers, complained that Colombians are dying in the drug war while other nations take only limited action. In a statement released Wednesday, Gaviria said the United States and other industrial countries must take more responsibility. He said other countries ``are not showing a serious commitment to end this scourge'' of drug traffickers. He also called for increased economic aid to this violent-prone South American country. ``The Colombian public does not understand why we should assume the costs of the battle against drug trafficking and simultaneously put up with discrimination against our export products,'' said Gaviria. He said exports likes coffee and flowers should receive preferential treatment. The drug trade has been a major issue in the election. Gaviria, of the governing Liberal Party, has rejected negotiations with drug traffickers. He has said he will continue extraditing U.S. drug suspects. The other three candidates have all allowed the possibility of some agreement with the traffickers to end the terror. Three more policemen were assassinated Wednesday in Medellin, home to the world's most powerful cocaine cartel. Officials blame drug traffickers for murdering 29 policemen there this month. Officials blame cocaine traffickers for killing more than 250 Colombians since August, when President Virgilio Barco launched a U.S.-backed drug crackdown. Among the victims are three presidential candidates, including the Liberal Party's previous presidential candidate, Luis Carlos Galan. Despite U.S. aid, Gaviria said Wednesday, ``For us, it is discouraging that Washington Mayor Marion Barry, caught using drugs, continues to be free and seeking re-election.'' Barry has been indicted on cocaine possession, conspiracy and perjury charges, but his case has not yet come to trial. Barry hasn't said if he will run again, but he has been making political appearances. In another development Wednesday, the army said Colombia's leftist guerrillas were stepping up attacks in advance of this week's elections. Military spokesman Col. Eduardo Arevalo told The Associated Press that the National Liberation Army on Tuesday kidnapped two mayors, two mayors-elect, and three city councilmen in the northwestern state of Antioquia. In addition, the rebels attacked a military checkpoint in northern Colombia Tuesday night, killing at least two soldiers, Arevalo said in the telephone interview. The Bogota daily newspaper El Tiempo, citing military sources, said the National Liberation Army and another insurgent group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, are planning to sabotage presidential elections. Also Wednesday, the National Liberation Army bombed the country's main oil pipeline near Samore, about 200 miles northeast of Bogota, according to the state oil company Ecopetrol. It said the bombing will temporarily prevent delivery of 230,000 barrels of crude oil daily.

DOC.HEAD: Romanian Prime Minister Wants Election Non-Violence Pact
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Andrei Lukanov on Wednesday criticized the opposition for refusing to sign a non-violence pact before June 10 elections. His foes said the pact ignores campaign problems they encountered. One called it a propaganda ploy. Lukanov was a major figure in the former Communist Party, now called the Socialist Party. He said relations with the opposition to date had been ``civilized,'' referring in particular to the 16-party Union of Democratic Forces, or UDF. But he alleged that a ``tendency'' existed in the opposition to campaign using unethical means, and said if this increases, his party may find itself unable to cooperate with the opposition after the elections. The document was drafted at the initiative of President Petar Mladenov and was to have beeen signed at a televised ceremony last Monday by all parties contesting the elections. But UDF chairman Zhelyu Zhelev and others refused to sign. They complained that the language of the agreement papers over the obstruction, intimidation and even physical violence suffered by the opposition during the campaign. Among accusations brought by Zhelev and the other UDF leaders were falsification of electoral lists, violation of accords signed during negotiations with the former Communists, and a virtual ban on opposition campaigning in army barracks. UDF officials said their representatives were barred from joining electoral commissions in many constituencies and that many instances had occurred of physical attacks on opposition candidates. Among other organizations that refused to sign Mladenov's pact were the Political Opposition Bloc, a grouping of 14 right-of-center and conservative parties, and the Alternative Socialist Party, which broke away from the then Communist Party after a party congress early this year. The Alternative Socialist Party is the fourth biggest party in Bulgaria after the governing Socialists, the UDF, and the Agrarian Party, once a docile ally of the Communists before longtime strongman Todor Zhivkov was ousted last November. Alternative Socialist chairman Nikolai Vasilev told a news conference Mladenov's propoosal was a propaganda move that ``may hoodwink the public at home and abroad.'' He termed the text of the agreement ``nonsense,'' since all its clauses are already in the constitution. Vasilev said he could conceive of close cooperation with one of the UDF parties after the elections, though not with the Socialist Party. ``The ASP can easily imagine a broad social democratic bloc which is led by Petar Dertliev,'' leader of the Social Democratic Party, Vasilev said. He said if Dertliev ran for the presidency, the Alternative Socialists would support him.

DOC.HEAD: Police Investigate Allegedly Staged TV Pit-Bull Fight
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT that series of reports began April 29 sted 30.
DOC.TEXT: Police and NBC are investigating allegations that a television station staged a fight between two pit bull terriers for a report on illegal dog fights. KCNC-TV insists it received a videotape of the fight in the mail. The allegations arose from a four-part series on illegal dog fights compiled by KCNC reporter Wendy Bergen and two video camera operators. In Colorado, staging a dog fight or attending one is a felony punishable by up to four years in prison and a maximum $1,000 fine. One of the series of reports _ broadcast April 29 through May 2 during a ratings ``sweep'' period _ featured the fight between two unmuzzled dogs that police say occurred on a grassy area near the South Platte River in Sheridan, a Denver suburb. After the report, sources telephoned some competing Denver TV stations and a newspaper with claims the fight was staged for KCNC and that the station paid for it. Their reports identified the sources only as current or former KCNC employees. KCNC general manager Roger Ogden on Wednesday denied the claims, saying the station received unsolicited tape of the fight anonymously in the mail. Investigations were launched by the Sheridan and Lakewood police departments and the district attorney's offices in Arapahoe and Jefferson counties. Sheridan is in Arapahoe County, and Lakewood, the hometown of a man who allegedly owns one of the fighting pit bulls, is in Jefferson County. ``We are close to concluding our investigation,'' Lakewood police spokesman John Hunt said. ``We expect, within the next few days perhaps, to have some sort of statement.'' Ogden said an internal investigation is underway at the NBC-affiliated station, and the network also is looking into the matter, said NBC spokesman Richard Cutting in New York. The station has released edited tapes of the four-part series to police. Police say they identified the owner of one of the pit bulls involved, but declined to identify him. The tapes showed people at the dog fight, but their faces were distorted to protect their identities, said Robin Duxbury, executive director of the Rocky Mountain Humane Society. The organization has called for advertisers to boycott the station until it releases the unedited versions of the tapes. KCNC news director Marv Rockford declined to say whether the station would release the tapes. The organization sent letters to businesses this week, asking them to boycott KCNC, but it was too early to measure the effort's success, she said. Ms. Bergen has declined to be interviewed. Ratings sweeps periods take place four times a year and are crucial to local stations because they help determine local advertising rates. The controversy heightened local debate over the pressure-cooker effect of the sweeps on news operations. ``The staging of news is unethical, period,'' David Bartlett, president of the Radio and Television News Directors Association, said from Washington. He declined to speak specifically about the Denver case until the investigations are completed.

DOC.HEAD: Three Bombs Explode in Upscale Athens District
DOC.TEXT: Three powerful bombs exploded in a fashionable district of Athens before dawn Thursday, and police said one person was slightly injured. A police spokesman said three cars with Greek license plates were destroyed by the bombs but it was not immediately known whether the explosives were placed in the vehicles or under them. One bystander was suffered minor injuries from flying glass, the officer said. The blasts occurred near the American School of Classical Studies and the British School of Archaeology in the Kolonaki district. No organization claimed responsibility for the bombs, the officer said.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Brings Home Mortar Shell
DOC.TEXT: Tom Shackleford served with an Army tank battalion so he knew what his stepson had when the 11-year-old walked in the door. ``I was watching TV,'' Tom Shackleford said Tuesday. ``He and his mama came into the house and he plopped it in my lap. I said, `Oh hell.''' It was a live mortar shell. The youngster and another Charleston boy found two mortar shells while spending the weekend at a lake on Fort Chaffee, where the National Guard trains. Each boy brought a shell home on their bicycles. Shackleford put the shell on feed sacks in the house for the night and then drove it in his van to a cafe and called authorities. U.S. Army explosive experts picked up the first shell at the other boy's home and then defused Shackleford's. ``They want to play war, but they don't understand,'' Shackleford said of the two boys.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Say Liz Has Improved Significantly, May Leave Hospital in 3-4 Weeks
DOC.TEXT: Elizabeth Taylor was significantly improved in her seventh week of hospitalization for a near-fatal bout of pneumonia, and her doctor said Wednesday the actress may go home early next month. Dr. Michael Roth's prognosis shaved a couple of weeks off the length of her anticipated hospital stay announced earlier this month. Doctors said previously that Miss Taylor would remain at St. John's Hospital and Health Center until late June. ``Her response to anti-fungal medicine has been very positive,'' Roth said. ``She is resting comfortably and her spirits are good. Miss Taylor, 58, was first hospitalized at Daniel Freeman Marina Hospital on April 9 with what was described as a sinus infection. But her condition worsened and she was transferred to St. John's in serious condition with viral pneumonia. She was placed on a respirator and intravenous medication and doctors said she was near death on April 22. Miss Taylor rallied, however, and was moved from the intensive care unit to a fourth floor hospital suite early this month.

DOC.HEAD: New Billboards Welcome Soviet President in Russian
LaserPhoto MP1
DOC.TEXT: Billboards featuring Mikhail Gorbachev as a vodka pitchman began coming down Wednesday. In their place was a message toasting the Soviet president's health _ in Russian. Johnson Brothers Wholesale Liquor Co. decided on Monday to remove the billboards showing Gorbachev holding a bottle of Minnesota-made Karkov vodka. The liquor distributor said it wanted to show respect for the Soviet president, scheduled to visit the Twin Cities on June 3. The old billboards carried the caption, ``The Party's Over,'' a reference to the Communist Party's problems. The new displays carry a message in Russian above the words, in English, ``Karkov, the Spirit of Minnesota.'' There is no picture of Gorbachev on the new white-and-black billboards. Some Minnesotans felt the old billboards, which went up before Gorbachev's visit was announced, would offend the Soviet president.

DOC.HEAD: Yemenis Celebrate New Unification
DOC.TEXT: SAN`A, Yemen (AP) _ Thousands of people in the capital of the day-old Republic of Yemen poured into the streets on Wednesday to celebrate with traditional dances and chants the merger of North Yemen and South Yemen. Radio and television broadcast nationalist songs and congratulatory messages from other nations around-the-clock. In San`a, people celebrated by dancing with daggers, as is the tradition here, and chanting, ``One Yemeni nation, one Yemeni army.'' Women ululated as a sign of joy. In the south, celebrations were limited to official ceremonies, including night parades at the city stadium, and there were no major street celebrations. Saudi Arabia's King Fahd, Jordan's King Hussein and Iraq's President Saddam Hussein were among the first to telephone their congratulations Tuesday to the new president, Gen. Ali Abdullah Saleh. Saleh served as president of North Yemen the past 12 years. Newspapers around the Persian Gulf said the creation of the united Republic of Yemen ``added strength to the Arab world.'' Yemen is one of the poorest Arab nations, but it has newly discovered oil reserves estimated unofficially at 2 billion barrels. Saleh declared the union of the pro-Western North Yemen with the Soviet-allied South Yemen at noon Tuesday. South Yemen became the Arab world's only avowedly Marxist state after it gained independence from Britain in 1971. But it began to reform as democratic changes swept through the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. Scores of Cuban and East German military experts are said to have left Aden, the capital of South Yemen in recent months. The merger bid has been outwardly promoted by oil-rich nations on the Arabian Peninsula such as Saudi Arabia, which is eager to snuff out Soviet influence. Aden has been designated as the commercial center of the new state and North Yemen's capital of San`a has been declared the new capital. Truckloads of cheering soldiers chanting ``unity is strength'' could be seen from time to time en route to Taiz, which is halfway between San`a and Aden. The mountain resort is almost 150 miles from either major city and has been selected as headquarters for the armed forces of the united republic.

DOC.HEAD: Skipper Acquitted of Criminal Liabilty in Destroyer's Collision
DOC.TEXT: The former skipper of the USS Kinkaid was acquitted of criminal liability Wednesday in the collision of the destroyer with a merchant ship off the Malay Peninsula, an accident that killed one crewman. A military judge said the prosecution failed to prove charges of negligence and dereliction of duty during Cmdr. John Cochrane's court-martial, which lasted eight days. Cochrane, who was relieved of his command about a week after the accident, smiled and embraced his attorneys, then his wife, Suzanne, upon hearing the judge's verdict. ``I'm not bitter towards the Navy. I love the United States Navy,'' he said afterwards. ``In the end I was exonerated, and it proves the military justice system works.'' The destroyer collided with a Panamanian-registered merchant vessel in the Strait of Malacca, 240 miles northwest of Singapore, on Nov. 12. The accident killed one crewman and injured five others. Lt. Tom Courtney, one of Cochrane's attorneys, said the case should never have come to court-martial because the Navy had assigned accountability to Cochrane for the accident by stripping him of his command. The judge, Capt. Richard Reed, agreed, noting in his decision that accountability traditionally assigned a Navy skipper for the safe navigation of his ship and well-being of his crew differs from criminal liability. ``The standards applied are significantly different,'' said Reed, adding that criminal sanctions demand proof beyond a reasonable doubt. Prosecutor Lt. Cmdr. Leroy Dickens left the courtroom immediately after the verdict without comment. But Cmdr. Danny Barrett, the chief Navy prosecutor in San Diego, said the verdict changes very little. The defense attorney, Cmdr. Bayne Smith, said during his closing argument earlier Wednesday that Cochrane should not be held criminally liable for the failings of subordinates. ``A commanding officer cannot do everything hands on. Ultimately, he must rely on his men to do their jobs and obey his orders,'' Smith said. Dickens said in his closing argument that Cochrane's weak management style and failure to follow established procedures led to the accident in the heavily traveled Strait of Malacca. Cochrane was charged with failing to obey Navy instructions, dereliction of duty and hazarding his vessel. He faced up to two years confinement, loss of future pay, including his pension, and dismissal from the Navy. The case arose from the collision of the San Diego-based Kinkaid with the Panamanian-registered Kota Petani at 430-foot freighter. The collision occurred in the dark, while the Kinkaid was on the wrong side of the strait under an established traffic scheme. The accident killed Lt. Sean Michael McPhee, 24, a navigator on the ship, and injured five others. The Kinkaid was en route from the Indian Ocean for a port call in Singapore.

DOC.HEAD: West Germany Rejects Rescue of East German Firms
DOC.TEXT: The government Wednesday rejected a bailout of weak East German companies amid new signs that unification may bring negative side effects to West Germans. Also Wednesday, the president of the East German parliament said political unification could be complete by the end of the year. The two Germanys last week signed a treaty on joining their economies. That merger is to take place July 2. However, West Germany's opposition Social Democrats charge that the treaty should go further in protecting East German factories and jobs and giving East German goods a fair chance of competing with West German products. Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government has refused to change the accord, known as the ``state treaty,'' but indicated a willingness to negotiate new provisions. ``I am always ready for compromise, if compromise means reasonable cooperation. But if it means renegotiating the state treaty, my answer is a clear `no,''' Kohl said Wednesday. He said he would meet with Social Democratic leader Hans-Jochen Vogel next week. However, the government said it would not pump huge sums of money into failing East German businesses. Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann said the opposition demands would cost the West German government ``an additional burden of way over 100 billion marks,'' the equivalent of $60 billion. He said measures will be taken to help East German businesses survive the sudden immersion into capitalism, but he acknowledged that some would collapse. ``It doesn't make sense to preserve uncompetitive operations against market forces,'' said Haussmann. ``My course is: adaptation yes, but artificial preservation, no.'' However, the Social Democrats renewed their charge that too many East German factories and jobs will become extinct after July 2. ``East Germany must not be turned into an extended supermarket for West German goods,'' said West Berlin Mayor Walter Momper, a Social Democrat. At the same time, the Social Democrats softened their stand, saying they won't try to delay the economic merger. Also Wednesday, a major utility company said West German electrical capacity could be pushed to the limit if East Germans become dependent on it. ``There could be huge problems if there is an especially harsh winter,'' said Klaus Knizia, head of the United Electrical Works of North Rhine-Westphalia state. East Germany, which uses air-fouling brown coal for heating, is expected to switch to cleaner methods during the unification process. West Germans also fear tax hikes and inflation as a result of their aid to East Germans during unification. In Bonn on a visit, Parliament President Sabine Bergmann-Pohl of East Germany said she ``could imagine'' the East German states declaring themselves part of West Germany by the end of the year. Kohl, who is pushing for quick unification, has suggested joint German elections in December.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Appoints Envoys To Poland, Bangladesh, Congo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS graf with mortgage corp. nominations
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will name Thomas Simons Jr. as ambassador to Poland, succeeding John R. Davis Jr., the White House announced Wednesday. Bush also will name William B. Milam ambassador to Bangladesh and James Daniel Phillips as ambassador to the Congo. Simons, a visiting scholar and adjunct professor of history at Brown University in Providence, R.I., previously served in the State Department as deputy assistance secretary of state for European and Canadian affairs and director for Soviet affairs, and in various Foreign Service capacities in Bucharest, Moscow and Warsaw. Phillips is ambassador to Burundi and previously served in the Foreign Service in Morocco, Luxembourg, Gambia, Zaire, and Paris, as well as in various State Department posts. Milam, deputy assistant secretary for international finance and development at the State Department, has held Foreign Service postings in Cameroon, London, Liberia, and French West Indies, and served in several State Department capacities. Bush also announced he would name as members of the board of directors of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation: George Argyros of California, the chief executive and president of Arnel Development Co. in Costa Mesa; former Ohio Rep. Thomas Ludlow Ashley, a close friend of Bush's and now president of the Associaton of Bank Holding Companies in Washington and investment management consultant Woodward Kingman of Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Gun Maker Lambasts Senate On Weapon Restrictions
DOC.TEXT: The president of Colt's Manufacturing Co. assailed a Senate vote Wednesday to outlaw some assault weapons as a ``sad and dishonest effort'' to make voters think lawmakers are fighting crime. A spokesman for Intratec in Miami, which makes one of the guns on the proposed weapons hit list, was more optimistic. ``We've had proposals in the past and we really don't know what the final outcome will be,'' said Mike Solo, national sales and marketing director of Intratec. ``This of course doesn't look good but it doesn't tell us where our future is.'' The restrictions, which await final Senate action, would bar the import of five foreign-made assault weapons and outlaw U.S. manufacture of four others. The 52-48 vote came as a sharp defeat for the National Rifle Association, which had lobbied to kill the curbs in the wide-ranging bill. Law enforcement groups had called on the Senate to support the restrictions. The Bush administration opposes the restrictions. Colt has said it no longer makes the AR-15, once the best-selling semiautomatic rifle in the nation and one of the weapons named in the omnibus crime bill.The bill also outlaws production of the CAR-15, made by Colt. ``It is a sad and dishonest effort to make the public think the politicians are actually doing something about crime,'' said Richard F. Gamble, president of Colt's Manufacturing. ``In fact, rifles of any description are almost never used in crimes and semiautomatic so-called `assault rifles' have been used in less than three-hundredths of 1 percent of all crimes where a gun was involved,'' Gamble said. He refused to comment Wednesday on what effect, if any, the ban would have on Colt's Manufacturing. Colt Firearms, a division of Colt Industries, stopped production of the AR-15 in 1989 shortly after Bush banned the importation of similar weapons. Colt's new management has begun producing a weapon it calls the Sporter which gun-control advocates contend is nearly identical to the AR-15. The company maintains it is a different weapon, noting it cannot be fitted with a bayonet and its magazine capacity is only five rounds. The Sporter is sufficiently different from the AR-15 to be unaffected by the bill, which listed specific models of weapons, said Bob Maynes, press secretary to Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., a supporter of the ban. Intratec's Solo said the public would suffer most from the restrictions. The Intratec Tec-9 was one of the guns targeted for restrictions. ``It's just a shame the average Joe Citizen, whether it be a plinker or a target shooter, gets muddied from the bad guys,'' Solo said. The other domestic guns on the restricted list are the Street Sweeper-Striker 12 and the MAC 10 and MAC 11.

DOC.HEAD: Court Sentences Rapist to 142 Years in Prison
DOC.TEXT: A provincial court on Wednesday sentenced a 29-year-old man convicted of a series of rapes to 142 years in prison, one of the stiffest sex-crime penalties in recent Spanish history, sources said. But Francisco Javier Amedo, a former coalminer, can only serve a maximum 30 years according to the Spanish constitution, which places a maximum limit on imprisonment. The sentence came as feminist groups have stepped up protests against sex crimes and rulings by conservative judges who have imposed light sentences on rapists. There are no trials by jury in Spain. A three-judge court in this northern city found Amedo, married with a young daughter, guilty of seven counts of rape and five counts of sexual molestation. The trial gained national attention because of protests outside the Oviedo courthouse by feminist groups demanding stiff sentences for the rapist who terrorized women in the city from 1985 to 1988. Police arrested Amedo in January 1989 after he was identified by one of the victims. Amedo was described by the local press as ``the station rapist'' because all the attacks occurred near train and bus stations. He received prison terms of 17 years and four months on each rape count and four years and two months for each of five counts of sexual molestation. During his trial Amedo denied any involvement in the attacks. Nine victims testified against him saying they had been raped or molested at knife point after accepting rides in his car. Women's groups praised the stiff sentence, saying it served as a strong deterrent to sexual attacks.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Says Study Needed Before Antibody Therapy Approved For AIDS Babies
DOC.TEXT: More research is needed before injections of immunoglobulin blood cells are used generally to treat babies with AIDS, a National Institutes of Health committee said Wednesday. The committee made the recommendation after studying the uses of an treatment called intravenous immunoglobulin therapy, or IVIG, which is becoming widely used for a variety of illnesses related to the immune system. Dr. Peter E. Lipsky, the committee chairman and a professor at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center, said that although IVIG has been reported in one limited study as useful in treating newborns with AIDS, there have been no clinical trials to prove its value. ``The treatment is unpleasant,'' said Lipsky. ``If it doesn't afford much benefit, it doesn't make sense to subject them to this expensive treatment.'' Clinical trials are now underway, the committee said, to determine if the IVIG therapy can help babies born with AIDS to develop natural defenses against disease. The panel was organized to establish a medical consensus for the uses of IVIG. The immunoglobulin therapy has been approved to treat some types of immune deficiency diseases, but experimental uses have developed what Lipsky called ``anecdotal evidence'' that IVIG may be useful in treating other illnesses. Immunoglobulin is the antibody component of human blood. Antibodies are disease-fighting proteins made by the body's immune system. Antibodies will attack any bacteria, virus, tissue, cell or substance that that appear foreign to the host body. Doctors have used human antibody shots for years to protect patients from a variety of infections or to boost a patient's immune system. But the shots are very painful and, as a result, were used only when no other therapy was available. In the 1980s, however, pharmaceutical companies developed a way to process immunoglobulin so that it can be injected into veins. This is far less painful and enables doctors to use massive amounts. Lipsky said the new treatment had such a dramatic effect on patients with immune problems that many doctors began using IVIG to treat other conditions. ``The enthusiasm has caused there to be lots of therapeutic adventurism,'' said Lipsky. He said the NIH committee was established to determine which of the new treatments actually work. The committee recommended that IVIG continue to be used for patients whose immune systems do not create natural antibodies, a condition called primary immunodeficiency. IVIG is also appropriate, the committee said, for reducing infection among patients who have received bone marrow transplants or who have chronic lymphatic leukemia. The committee said IVIG also has been shown effective among children who develop Kawasaki syndrome, an inflammatory disease that often causes heart disease. Lipsky said that though there have been limited examples of IVIG preventing infection among premature babies and relieving symptoms of such disorders as arthritis or brain seizures, the committee could not recommend IVIG for those uses until further study is done. Seven companies now produce IVIG, but Lipsky said the therapy continues to be very expensive. IVIG treatment for some patients with chronic immune system problems may cost up to $5,000 monthly, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Poll: Half Favor Higher Taxes to Reduce Deficit
DOC.TEXT: About half of the American voters questioned for a poll released Wednesday said the federal government should increase taxes to reduce the nation's budget deficit. The survey of 1,000 registered voters conducted for NBC News and The Wall Street Journal found 51 percent favoring higher taxes and 42 opposed. A similar survey last month found only 39 percent in favor of raising taxes, NBC said. If taxes do go up, 36 percent said they would blame the administration of former President Ronald Reagan and 30 percent would blame Democrats in Congress. Only 16 percent said they would lay the blame on President Bush's administration. The survey was conducted May 18-22 and had a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Soldier Defects in Suriname, Army Seals Road to Rebels
DOC.TEXT: The army sealed a road to a rebel base on Wednesday after a soldier defected to the insurgents with an unspecified amount of weapons, the military said. The army identified the defector only as ``Sgt. Woodley'' and claimed the rebels bribed him with drugs or gold. But a man identifying himself as ``Woodley'' told state radio he had gone over to the rebel forces voluntarily because the army is ``frustrating the peace process.'' The Jungle Commando rebels has been waging an on-again-off-again guerrilla war on behalf of the country's Bush Negro minority for nearly four years. They are believed to number 200 to 400 men. The army sealed off a road to a Jungle Commando guerrilla camp near the mining town of Moengo in eastern Suriname after the defection. The army said it took the action ``due to the increasingly insecure situation in the eastern part of Suriname.'' Suriname is a former Dutch colony on the northern shoulder of South America. It has 400,000 residents.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney: U.S. Fixed Nuclear Shell `Problem;' Denies Risk
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 22nd `In the...' to UPDATE with comment from Sen. Nunn; pickup 23rd pvs `The artillery...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BRU3; with LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on Wednesday acknowledged a safety problem with U.S. nuclear artillery shells in Europe but said it was fixed and there never was a risk of accidental nuclear explosions. In 1988, he said, officials found that the W-79 howitzer shells did not meet minimum safety standards. ``The necessary steps were taken to assure (it) does meet our very high safety standards today,'' Cheney said. The Washington Post reported Wednesday that the United States was repairing artillery shells and examining the design of two kinds of missiles because of the risk of an accidental nuclear explosion. Responding to the story, Cheney told reporters: ``It is important here not to over-dramatize the nature of the problem. I will simply say that ... there was no danger, but that the shells in question did not meet the very high standards that we have. I don't believe there was any cause for concern.'' He declined to go into details of what was done to correct the problems, saying such matters are classified. He spoke after a two-day NATO defense ministers' meeting. The bulk of U.S. nuclear shells are in West Germany, with the remainder stockpiled in the Netherlands and Italy. Cheney said the West German government was told ``we had identified the problem and that we had solved the problem.'' Speaking at a separate news conference in Brussels, West Germany's defense minister, Gerhard Stoltenberg, confirmed this but said his government was not told what was wrong with the shells. He said this was normal. In the past, he said, U.S. officials have informed Bonn of ``modifications'' to U.S. nuclear arms on German soil without detailing the modifications. He said U.S. officials have said there was ``at no point in time any danger'' to either personnel or the environment, Stoltenberg said. In the Netherlands, where some U.S. nuclear weapons are based, a Dutch Defense Ministry spokesman said: ``We are always informed when the Americans are planning maintenance'' on nuclear weapons there. The spokesman, Martijn Verbrugge, would not say when, or if, Dutch officials were told about problems with the nuclear shells. The Washington Post said U.S. troops in Europe were warned not to move the shells until they were fixed. The problem with the W-79 shell was one of three found recently by Energy Department experts, it said. A special committee will review the W-88 warhead on the new seaborne D-5 missile, the Post said. And it said special flight restrictions have been instituted pending review of the W-69 warhead on the short-range SRAM-A missile carried by some bomber aircraft. The two warheads use the same volatile fuel that experts feared could explode in certain accidents and set off the conventional explosives that trigger the nuclear ones. Those conventional explosives surround a mass of plutonium and compress it from all sides to the point where the nuclear chain reaction begins, causing a nuclear explosion in a split second. John C. Tuck, an acting assistant secretary at the Department of Energy, told a congressional subcommittee Wednesday that his agency ``is satisfied'' that the W-79 howitzer warhead is safe. He said the W-88, a Trident missile warhead, ``is a safe warhead'' as well. However, he said the W-69 may be removed from alert-status aircraft and stored until actually needed. Stanford University physicist Sidney D. Drell, who has been named to a subcommittee panel with two other outside physicists to study the safety of U.S. nuclear weapons, said Wednesday, ``I don't think there is any question of coverup or negligence.'' ``They just wanted to appoint three of us with some experience to give our best technical judgment about what's being done and how it's being done and whether it's appropriate.'' In the telephone interview from his New York office, he said he expected the panel to start work this summer. He said he was uncertain how long its studies would take. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said he believed a nuclear war would more likely result from an accident or safety problem than from a deliberate attack. He said the United States should enter into an accord with the Soviet Union for a ``thorough and fail-safe review'' of nuclear safety. The artillery shell problem was discovered by special computer studies in 1988, the Post said. It said these raised the possibility that a bullet striking the conventional explosive could set off part of it, dispersing the highly toxic plutonium, though not necessarily causing a chain reaction. But if the bullet hit while the shells were in the artillery piece, the barrel of the weapon might reflect neutrons back into the plutonium to cause a nuclear explosion, according to experts questioned by the Post. The W-88 was feared to be vulnerable to an accidental nuclear explosion, but the W-69 threat was dispersal of plutonium, the paper said. An unidentified senior military official was quoted as saying, ``For a while, we were worried that these things might go off if they fell off the back of a truck and landed in a certain way.'' Special teams early in 1989 installed ``safing mechanisms,'' and the shells are being modified, the Post said.

DOC.HEAD: Mexican Police Seize Tons of Marijuana, Cocaine in Tunnel Town
DOC.TEXT: Federal police seized more than a ton of cocaine and 14 tons of marijuana Wednesday after a shootout in the town where a tunnel used to smuggle drugs across the Arizona border was discovered last week, authorities said. A communique from the Attorney General's Office said the drugs belonged to the man identified as the owner of a house at one end of the tunnel in Agua Prieta, Sonora. Two people began firing when they saw the federal anti-narcotics agents and then fled in a vehicle, the statement said. It was not immediately reported if anyone was injured. Roads in Sonora state were closed and U.S. authorities were notified to be on the watch for the two fugitives. The marijuana and 2,330 pounds of cocaine were found in a warehouse in Agua Prieta, across from Douglas, Ariz., which was supposed to contain disposable diapers. ``It has been determined that the drug confiscated belongs to Rafael Camarena Macias, owner of the house where ... Federal Judicial Anti-narcotics Police found a tunnel about 200 yards long,'' the statement said. It said the warehouse was equipped with a hydraulic system for raising and lowering a platform where the drugs were found. U.S. and Mexican authorities using jackhammers and blowtorches broke into the tunnel last week and found about 25 pounds of marijuana, officials in both countries said. The officials said then that the tunnel leads from the Agua Prieta house north to a Douglas Building Supply Co. warehouse, also belonging to Camarena. The tunnel was built eight months ago and is one block from the Customs enforcement building and four blocks from the international port of entry. Equipped with storage areas for up to five tons of drugs, it was five feet high, four feet wide and lighted. U.S. customs agents estimated it was used to smuggle at least a ton of cocaine into the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Honus Wagner Card Raises Collectors' Doubts
DOC.TEXT: Baseball card experts raised doubts Wednesday about the authenticity of a Honus Wagner baseball card that turned up in this central Maine town. An authentic card in good condition featuring the Hall of Fame shortstop from the early 1900s could be worth $10,000 to more than $100,000, according to card shop dealers. Arlo Quint, 12, said he unearthed the Wagner card and three others while digging for worms in his back yard Monday. The cards were in an old tooth powder can, Quint said. The Wagner card surfaced only about a month after a boy in Stockton Springs, about 30 miles away, found a what was said to be Honus Wagner card under similar circumstances. The similarity of the discoveries almost immediately sparked doubts about Quint's find. Bob Thing, an area man who has been collecting cards for 40 years, inspected Quint's card Wednesday. He said the paper on which the Wagner card is printed appears to be thinner than it would be on an original, and the ink colors appeared wrong. He also noted that the lower portion of the card, where reproductions printed in later years would have been marked as a reprint, was missing. Baseball card authority Lew Lipset in New York, who hadn't seen the card, said Honus Wagner cards are so rare that a find would be extremely unlikely. He said it is believed that all of the original Honus Wagner cards remaining, with perhaps one exception, were issued by Sweet Caporal cigarettes. However, Quint's card is marked as a Piedmont cigarette issue.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Revolutionary Leader Granted Political Asylum
DOC.TEXT: A Chinese student who was one of the leaders of last year's student protest in Tiananmen Square has been granted political asylum in the United States. ``I am not giving up my country, but I have to do this,'' said Yin Ping Zhang, 20, wiping away tears at a news conference Wednesday. ``I love my country. I love my motherland. But they won't allow me to stay there. I am a woman who cannot return. I can't go back,'' she said. Zhang fled to the United States in August. Sen. Tim Wirth, D-Colo., intervened when he found out Zhang's tourist visa was expiring and she might be forced to return to China. She learned this week that her request for asylum had been granted. ``Yin Ping Zhang is a genuine hero,'' Wirth said. ``Living in a free country, it is difficult to comprehend the courage and bravery that people such as Yin Ping exemplify. Yin Ping put her life on the line because she wanted to be free, and because she wanted her people to be free. ``This week, she received her freedom. It's sad that Yin Ping had to leave home to be free. It is wonderful, though, that she could come to the United States and be free.'' Zhang was a student at Beijing Foreign Studies University when she met her American sponsor, Rosemarie Montoya, an English teacher. When the revolution erupted in shooting and executions in June 1989, Montoya encouraged Zhang to flee. Zhang tried to get a passport, and was picked up for questioning by police three times. Zhang decided to flee, got a passport that was mistakenly issued by an inexperienced clerk and managed to get on a plane to the United States on Aug. 14 before police returned to pick her up, Wirth said. Zhang said one of her friends was shot in the leg during the massacre, and she feared for her life. Zhang said she asked another friend, a soldier in the Chinese army, why he was shooting students. ``He said, `We have to, because if we don't shoot them, my leader will shoot me. They tell me I can shoot anybody I want, and nobody will punish me,''' she said. Zhang also said life has not been easy during her brief time in the United States. Her sponsor wanted to take her to San Francisco to be near Chinese friends, but their car broke down and they ran out of money in Colorado Springs, and had to seek temporary housing. ``We don't even have the money to find food, and Rosie can't find a job,'' she said. ``I want to help her do something. I want to support myself.'' Zhang said she wants to study to become a doctor, to return the help she has received from the United States. But she also said it is hard to be happy after the events of the past two years. ``I lost my country, my education, my family,'' she said. ``Sometimes I feel very sad.''

DOC.HEAD: Colditz Castle Escapee Maj. Patrick Reid Dead at 79
DOC.TEXT: Maj. Patrick Reid, the British World War II officer who escaped from Colditz Castle, a supposedly impregnable Nazi prison camp, has died, an official said Thursday. He was 79. Kenneth Lockwood, secretary of the Colditz Association, said Reid died Tuesday at Bristol's Frenchay Hospital after a short illness. Reid was taken to the supposedly impregnable 17th century Colditz Castle in 1940 after six attempts to escape from other prisons. In 1942, Reid and Lt. Cmdr. Billy Stephens, disguised as French workmen, used a smuggled saw to cut through window bars and sneaked out of the prison through a sewer that led into the castle's moat. They eventually escaped by train to Switzerland. Lockwood said Reid was constantly trying to discover new ways to break out during his two-year imprisonment at Colditz Castle, which overlooks the Mulde River near Leipzig. ``He was a very, very good escaper. He was full of ideas, escape was always uppermost in his mind,'' Lockwood said. ``He was always willing, before he got away himself, to help anybody else with their escape.'' Reid's book, ``The Colditz Story,'' was published in 1953 and was made into a film and a British television series. Reid set up a building company after the war and lectured on his wartime experiences. Recently, he worked as a planning consultant to East Germany's tourism bureau on the modification of Colditz into a museum. He was made a Member of the British Empire in 1940 and awarded the Military Cross in 1943 for gallant and distinguished services. Reid is survived by his wife, Nicandra, and by three sons and two daughters from a previous marriage to Jane Cabot.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Planes from World War II Found, Paper Says
DOC.TEXT: The remains of three U.S. warplanes believed to have crashed during World War II were found at a remote Indonesian island, a newspaper reported Wednesday. The daily Pos Kota said the wreckage was found at Biak Island in the easternmost province of Irian Jaya, about 2,100 miles northeast of Jakarta. It quoted a local leader, Dorus Rumbiak, as saying the three planes were found separately _ two in forests and the other about 20 feet under the sea. The paper did not say if any human remains were discovered, and it did not provide details on the type of planes.

DOC.HEAD: City University To Sell its Tobacco Stocks
DOC.TEXT: City University of New York voted to sell its stock in cigarette companies, a move recently completed by Harvard University. The moves come at a time tobacco companies are under increasing public pressure over the health risks their products pose. Critics have focused on advertising they maintain is intended to persuade the young and uneducated to take up smoking, and on efforts to boost tobacco exports. The City University of New York policy was adopted Monday at a regular board meeting. ``The policy is that the university will divest itself of its stocks in companies that manufacture cigarettes,'' said Rita Rodin, a spokeswoman for CUNY on Wednesday. ``They will do it in a way that will not adversely affect the university's portfolio.'' Harvard officials decided to sell the stocks last September and completed the sales in March, according to Harvard President Derek Bok. He revealed the sale May 18 in a letter to three Harvard School of Public Health students, who had been demanding the university sell its investments in companies manufacturing cigarettes. ``In reaching its decision, the corporation was motivated by a desire not to be associated as a shareholder with companies engaged in significant sales of products that create a substantial and unjustified risk of harm to other human beings,'' Bok wrote. Dr. Allan Blum, a Houston physician and chairman of Doctors Ought To Care, a national anti-smoking group that pushes for divestment of tobacco stocks, called Harvard's decision a ``breakthrough morally and financially.'' Sara Ridgway, vice president of public affairs for the Lorillard Tobacco Co., said the decision may deprive Harvard of profitable stock investments.

DOC.HEAD: Resignations Leave Kosovo Government Without Ethnic Albanians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS one graf for 10th `Also on...' to CORRECT spelling of paper to Delo; pickup graf 11 `The government...'
DOC.TEXT: The last four ethnic Albanians in the government of Serbian's restive province of Kosovo resigned on Wednesday, Tanjug reported. Ethnic Albanians comprise 90 percent of the population there. The government now consists of four Serbs, a Montenegrin and a Moslem. Moslems are considered a separate nationality in Yugoslavia. The official Yugoslav news agency announced the resignations on the second day of a stormy Kosovo parliament session called to discuss the resignations of Prime Minister Jusuf Zeinulahu and six other ethnic Albanians, submitted a month ago. The provincial parliament also was supposed to debate what the Belgrade daily Politika called ``the catastrophic situation in economy, education, health service and internal affairs'' in the province. The ethnic Albanians resigned to protest the Serbian Communist leadership's increasing control over Kosovo, where 60 ethnic Albanians have died in anti-Serbian riots since February 1989. The ethnic Albanians seek restoration of the broader autonomy they enjoyed under a 1974 constitution that was amended in March 1989. Serbia said the changes were needed to protect the Slav minority in Kosovo from alleged harassment by ethnic Albanians. The Serbian parliament on Wednesday adopted unspecified new powers to amend measures passed by Kosovo's administration in a further extension of Serbian control. Serbia's actions in Kosovo have drawn international allegations of human rights violations. Serbia is the only one of Yugoslavia's six republics not to have legalized opposition parties. Its Communist leaders have failed to schedule any talks with the burgeoning Albanian opposition movements in Kosovo. Also on Wednesday, the new center-right coalition government of the Slovenian republic announced plans to shut down Yugoslavia's first and only nuclear power plant at Krsko by 1995, according to the Slovenian daily Delo. The government took power from communists this spring after Yugoslavia's first free elections in 50 years. The station has been plagued by malfunctions. Slovenian environmentalists have campaigned for the plant to be closed and neighboring Austria has repeatedly expressed concern about the plant's safety. The 632-megawatt Krsko plant was a joint Slovenian-Croatian project and the Slovenian decision requires consent from Croatia. Ecologists claim the station does not meet safety standards. It was commissioned in 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Fiji Expels Indian Diplomats
DOC.TEXT: Fiji on Wednesday ordered India to close its embassy in Suva and told the Indian charge d'affaires to leave within 24 hours. The announcement by Fiji's ministry of foreign affairs also ordered all Indian Embassy staff to leave within two weeks. In New Delhi, India's government said it would not comment on the move. A government statement said the embassy was ordered closed because the Indian government was conducting an ``unwarranted and unacceptable international campaign against Fiji and was similarly blocking Fiji's re-admission into the Commonwealth.'' Earlier this month, the Indian government said it would conduct an international campaign against Fiji to protest what it called ``political discrimination'' against Indians born in Fiji. Relations between India and Fiji have been strained since 1987 when the first of two racially inspired coups by the predominately ethnic Fijian army ousted the Indian-dominated coalition government that had been elected only weeks earlier. Fiji was expelled from the Commonwealth as a result of the coup and India has said it will oppose Fiji's re-entry as long as the country discriminates against its Indian population. Indians make up nearly one-half of the 720,000 people on the South Pacific island. In October, Fiji expelled India's ambassador, Thettalil Sreenivassan, claiming he had interfered in local affairs. Sreenivassan had made public comments after ethnic Fijian Methodists burned four Indian places of worship in the city of Lautoka. Fiji refused to permit India to replace Sreenivassen and the Indian Embassy has been headed by charge d'affaires Vidya Bhusan Soni. Fiji's interim government has said a constitution that would give ethnic Fijians a guaranteed majority in a new bicameral parliament would be the best way to restore parliamentary rule.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Backs Away from Ammunition Capacity
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS ``banning'' to ``limiting'' in first graf; CORRECTS ``deadlines'' to ``deadliness'' in last graf and CORRECTS ``bursts'' to ``many rounds without reloading'' in last graf; INSERTS graf 5: ``Another White,'' with official saying White House will try to get provision back
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Crime Bill, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration for now has backed away from its insistence on limiting the ammunition capacity of semiautomatic assault weapons, the White House acknowledged Wednesday. President Bush, as part of his anti-crime package, last year proposed a ban for private citizens on gun magazines of more than 15 rounds. But now he supports legislation by Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., that doesn't include that ban, said White House spokeswoman Alixe Glen. ``It's better to support a bill that gives us nine-tenths of our goal rather than go without any reforms,'' she said. Glen said Bush still supports restricting magazine capacity. Another White House official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the White House would try to get the provision into the House version of the crime legislation when the Senate bill reaches the House. Bush opposes the Senate Democratic-backed anti-crime package. The wide-ranging bill would, among other things, restore capital punishment for 30 federal crimes including presidential assassination and overhaul the way courts review the constitutionality of criminal trials. Bush suffered a defeat when senators voted 52-48 Wednesday to retain a ban on the manufacture of four types of semiautomatic weapons. They also upheld a ban on imports, which Bush has already put into effect. There is no similar bill on the House calendar.
