While banning imported semiautomatics, Bush has refused to act against the manufacture and sale of similar domestic models, contending some are used for sport. Bush has threatened to veto the Democratic-backed crime bill, which is a vastly revamped version of the package he sent to Capitol Hill last year. Thurmond's package incorporates many of the proposals Bush made, but not his ban on ammunition capacity. Bush proposed a prohibition on the importation, sale or manufacture of gun magazines of more than 15 rounds as a way of curtailing use of military-style guns whose deadliness is enhanced by the ability to fire many bullets before reloading.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer Says Imelda Marcos Associates Helped Hide Properties
DOC.TEXT: A Panamanian lawyer testified Wednesday his firm was asked by associates of Imelda Marcos to fabricate documents showing that companies they secretly controlled were owned instead by financier Adnan Khashoggi. The attorney, Jaime Arias, said he refused because the request ``did not correctly reflect the situation.'' But in the end, he said, his firm agreed to handle a document that was notarized with a phony date. Arias testified as the government sought to show how Bienvenido Tantoco and his wife, Gliceria, intimates of the former Philippine first lady, tried to keep the companies from falling into the hands of President Corazon Aquino's government after it took power in Manila in 1986. Mrs. Marcos, 60, is accused of helping her late husband, former President Ferdinand Marcos, embezzle more than $220 million from their country's treasury to secretly buy four New York properties and artwork. The prosecution alleges that Khashoggi agreed to falsely claim ownership of all the properties as a favor to the Marcoses. Tantoco, a one-time Philippine ambassador to the Vatican, and his wife also were named as co-conspirators in the 1988 indictment, but are fugitives. Mrs. Tantoco was owner of Manila's leading department store and widely regarded as Mrs. Marcos' closest friend. Under stern cross examination by Khashoggi attorney James Linn, Arias acknowledged that he originally was indicted as well, but that the government dropped the charges of mail fraud and obstruction of justice in exchange for his cooperation. In reply to defense questions, he said that to his knowledge neither Khashoggi nor Mrs. Marcos had any direct role in the discussions to falsify the documents. The government says the offshore companies, located in the Netherlands Antilles and the British Virgin Islands, were part of a network of shell companies set up by the Marcoses to conceal their ownership of the four New York properties and other financial dealings. Arias said his law firm assumed power of attorney for the New York properties in 1985, replacing a New York firm with whom the Tantocos were feuding. Shortly after the Marcos government fell in February 1986, he said, he met with the Tantoncos in Rome to discuss a new crisis _ an Aquino government move to seize all Marcos holdings including the New York properties. ``They were worried about the impact of New York legal proceedings on their Philippines business and assets. If the companies were known to be theirs, it could have a negative impact under (the Philippines) monetary and tax laws,'' Arias said. Arias said Mrs. Tantoco came up with the name of Khashoggi, a friend of the Marcoses, ``as someone who might be able to help'' if he would allow himself to be identified as the ``beneficial owner'' of the properties. The lawyer said an agreement to this effect was reached in May 1986 after meetings between the Tantocos and Karl Bock Peterson, an aide to Khashoggi, in Panama City. The Saudi financier was not present, he said, but some documents brought by Peterson bore the initials ``A.K.'' along with some proposed changes in dates that would make it appear that Khashoggi had ``organized and managed'' the companies from 1981 on. James Linn, Khashoggi's attorney, did not object to the documents being introduced as evidence by the prosecution, but asked U.S. District Court Judge John F. Keenan to instruct jurors that they were only ``drafts'' and ``not documents executed by Mr. Khashoggi.''

DOC.HEAD: Hungary's New Leader Firm on Leaving Soviet Alliance
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Jozsef Antall was sworn in Wednesday as chief of Hungary's first democratically elected government in 43 years and said again he intends to pull the country out of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. He also defended the ``Program of National Rebirth'' he presented to Parliament the day before, which calls for halting inflation; creating a broad social safety net of welfare services; and changing over education and health services, while transforming Hungary's socialist economy into a market economy. Critics complained in debate prior to Antall's winning a vote of confidence that he was vague about how to carry out the changes and how to pay for them. Viktor Orban, leader of the League of Young Democrats' parliamentary faction, called Antall's program ``a loosely collected wish list.'' Katalin Bossanyi, a Socialist Party lawmaker, said she consulted experts and ``in their view, the program would require an additional $3.2 billion in the budget.'' Antall retorted, ``It is easy to give advice, but the responsibility of governing rests upon our shoulders.'' But he promised the opposition parties their criticism will be heeded when it comes to spelling out details. Antall promised the deputies ``this program, which we view as a guideline, will be replaced by a detailed program within three months, by which time we shall have had a chance to assess the concrete situation.'' The 58-year-old politician-historian said Hungarian officials will soon start negotiations on leaving the seven-nation Warsaw Pact military alliance since ``the agreement cannot be unilaterally abandoned.'' ``Hungary wants to leave the Warsaw Pact because the pact is not suitable for guaranteeing anything to Hungary,'' Antall said. Other Pact members are the Soviet Union, Poland, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Bulgaria and Romania. Antall stressed that withdrawal would come in the context of new security arrangements for all of Europe. He said he hoped Hungary could join the European Community in the next decade. The Communist Party, which long ruled Hungary, reshaped itself in advance of the elections in March and April, but was overwhelmingly defeated. Antall's Hungarian Democratic Forum has 165 seats in the 386-seat Parliament, and its coalition partners the Independent Smallholders' and the Christian Democrats 44 and 21 seats respectively. The new prime minister told Parliament his government intends to ``dismantle the system of repression ... (and) inaugurate the system of liberty.'' His new government faces serious economic problems. The annual inflation rate is in double digits, unemployment is rising and Hungary has a $20 billion foreign debt, the highest per capita in Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Solar-Powered Cars Hum Off On First Leg Of Road Rally
DOC.TEXT: Under dark and cloudy skies, 15 solar-powered racers hummed off the Statehouse lawn Wednesday on the first leg of a Vermont-to-Massachusetts road rally. Sounding more like golf carts than race cars, the solar electric vehicles whooshed away after Gov. Madeleine Kunin waved a green flag to begin the second annual American Tour de Sol. The race winds its way through Vermont and New Hampshire before ending Sunday at Tufts University in Medford, Mass. The 234-mile race is organized by the Northeast Solar Energy Association. Despite another day of dark, cloudy skies, the racers said there was enough daylight to recharge their batteries. ``It's been sucking up some energy,'' Gregory Halverson, a junior at Conval High School in Peterborough, N.H., said of his car's solar panels. ``As long as there's some light, we're getting some energy.'' ``This is happening because of people's concerns about the environment, air pollution in cities, and the limitation of fossil fuels,'' said Nancy Hazard, the group's associate director. ``It's really positive and encouraging to see people excited and interested about the technology.'' The cars in the race are either fully or partially powered by sunlight. The bodies are lined with photovoltaic cells, or solar panels, which capture sunlight, convert it to electricity and then store it in a bank of ordinary car batteries. These batteries can also be charged by plugging them into electrical outlets or other solar panels. Solar electric cars are environmentally safer than gasoline-burning cars because they do not give off any exhaust pollution, Hazard said. The burning of fossil fuels is blamed for creating one-third of the greenhouse gases. Entrants in the race came from California, Florida, Massachusetts, Michigan, New Hampshire, Tennessee and Vermont. After stopping over in Fairlee on Wednesday night, the racers will travel another 39 miles to Canaan, N.H., Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: India Rejects Pakistani Call for Plebescite in Kashmir
DOC.TEXT: A senior Indian official Wednesday rejected a Pakistani call for a plebiscite in Indian-controlled Kashir on the future of the region wracked by secessionist violence. ``As fas as Kashmir is concerned, I still maintain it is an insurgency, and we can deal with it,'' said George Fernandes, India's minister for Pakistani affairs. Fernandes, in Cairo for a meeting of the Socialist International, spoke to reporters at a news conference. His remarks came four days after Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan, also visiting Cairo on a regional tour, said her country would support Kashmir's independence ``no matter what the consequences.'' She said her government backed a plebiscite among Kashmiris and talks to end the Moslem separatist movement. The revolt in Indian Kashmir, in the far north on the Pakistani border, has left 400 people dead since January. On Monday, Indian forces killed 58 separatists during a funeral for a slain Moslem leader of Kashmir. Fernandes repeated previous Indian charges that Pakistan trains and arms the Moslem militants. Pakistan has denied the charge and accused India of a bloody crackdown in the region. Kashmir is Hindu Indian's only mainly Moslem region. Pakistan is predominantly Moslem. India and Pakistan fought wars over the area in 1949 and 1965. Though he insisted Wednesday that the issue is an internal Indian matter, Fernandes also said, ``We do not want to see another war; we will go to any length to see that the issue is resolved.''

DOC.HEAD: Trinity River Cresting At Liberty, Receding Elsewhere
LaserPhoto HT8
DOC.TEXT: Floods from torrential rains three weeks ago 200 miles to the north pushed the Trinity River toward a crest Wednesday in Liberty, the last sizeable Texas city before the Gulf of Mexico. Federal Emergency Management Agency officials began distributing relief funds to flood victims in the Livingston area, 50 miles north of Liberty. ``Everything I've got is under water. I can't even find my house,'' said Joe Tomlinson, 35, of Goodrich, just south of Livingston. He was applying for federal aid. An estimated 10,000 Texans have been forced from their homes by flooding, Laureen Chernow of the Texas Division of Emergency Management said. Forty-one Texas counties are eligible for disaster assistance. Elsewhere, flood waters started to recede in southern Indiana, and Louisiana officials said flooding there wasn't as bad as expected, causing about $10 million damage to farms. In Arkansas, tourism officials assured travelers that holiday weekend visits to state parks shouldn't be cancelled for fear of flood damage. They stressed that the weekend's flash flooding, while serious in some places, was localized. In Texas, federal and state officials in Livingston and Liberty briefed local agencies about programs available to people displaced by the floods. The Trinity River was expected to crest in Liberty at 30 feet, six feet above flood level and one foot higher than a record set in 1942, the Trinity River Authority said. Liberty is about 16 miles from the Trinity Bay which feeds into Galveston Bay and eventually the Gulf of Mexico. ``I think we're getting the worst of it now,'' said Jim Mitchum, Liberty County Emergency Management coordinator. Water from rain-swollen Lake Livingston has been funneling at record levels through a 208-square mile area downstream, but the amount of water released from the lake's dam dropped for a third straight day Wednesday. Liberty city employees and volunteers continued a two-week-old effort to shore up a mile-long levee protecting high-priced lakefront homes. ``But as soon as we get one low spot fixed, the waters seem to come over someplace else,'' Liberty City Secretary Beth Staton said. In Livingston, officials said it is too early to determine the extent of flood damage. ``One problem here is that the water is still up and we can't get in to inspect,'' said Graham Nance of FEMA. About $1 million in federal money already has been distributed. Nance said flood victims should be able to get federal checks within four to six days. The agency had received 3,800 applications for help, he said. In southern Indiana, the east fork of the White River continued to spill over its banks from Petersburg to the Indiana-Illinois state line, the National Weather Service said. At the Indiana Route 57 bridge, the river was more than 1{ miles wide. The Wabash River along Interstate 64 stretched from Graysville, Ill., to near Griffin, Ind. _ nearly 3 miles wide. Water covered much of western Gibson County, the weather service said. More than 10,000 people in Pike and Gibson counties remained without drinking water, which was lost Saturday when the White River tore through a section of levee and burst the town's main water line. In central Louisiana, Farm Bureau president Ronnie Anderson said that more than 100,000 acres of cropland have been flooded and more are expected to go under. ``There's no doubt that this can be considered a disaster and we're going to ask Congress, as well as Secretary of Agriculture Clayton Yeutter, to declare it so,'' Anderson said. But Arkansas tourism officials sought to downplay reports about flood damage. ``I think a lot of people are taking it that the whole state is under water,'' said Richard Davies, interim state Parks and Tourism Department chief, Flash flooding occurred Saturday night in Hot Springs _ one of the state's top tourist areas _ but the water was gone 24 hours later. Much of the flooding earlier along the Arkansas and Red rivers involved farmland. Joe Rice, state tourism director, said employees in Little Rock have fielded about 200 calls a day from tour operators and potential tourists. People want to know if they should cancel their holiday weekend plans at state and national parks because of flooding, Davies said. ``I've never seen it like this,'' he said. ``We're trying to get the word out that flooding is localized. That's not to say that some places weren't hit hard, they were; but others are completely unaffected.''

The House voiced strong disagreement with current U.S. policy toward El Salvador in a largely symbolic vote to slap sharp restrictions on military aid to the Central American country. But moments after Tuesday's 250-163 vote on that issue, the lawmakers reversed course and voted to kill the bill to which the aid curbs had been attached. Despite the murkiness of the situation, it was apparent that a solid majority in the chamber believes continued human rights violations by the Salvadoran military dictate an end to what some have called a ``blank check'' policy. ``The American people and the American Congress have been played for fools'' by the military and by extremists on both the left and right in El Salvador, said Rep. Joe Moakley, D-Mass., a sponsor of the aid restrictions. ``This must end and it must end now.''

President Mikhail S. Gorbachev moved closer to dialogue with the Baltic republics by meeting with two of their leaders, but reportedly did not budge from his hard line against independence. Lithuania, meanwhile, said that beginning today private motorists will no longer be able to buy gasoline. The republic has been struggling with a Kremlin-imposed economic blockade since it declared independence March 11. In Stockholm, Sweden, leaders of the three Baltic states appealed Tuesday to the United States and Europe for diplomatic recognition and economic help for their republics. Gorbachev, who met last week with Lithuania's prime minister, met at the Kremlin for 20 minutes with presidents Anatoly Gorbunov of Latvia and Arnold Ruutel of Estonia, the Estonian News Service reported.

Standardized tests should be prohibited at all elementary schools and severely curtailed at colleges and on the job, a commission said today. The National Commission on Testing and Public Policy released a highly critical study of standardized, multiple-choice tests and called for a restructuring of educational and employment testing so that the talents of all Americans are promoted. ``We recognize that in the past some tests have been a positive force for numerous individuals and institutions,'' the report said. ``However, the growing over-reliance on testing over the past several decades deprives the nation of much of the talent it needs and sometimes conflicts with the nation's ideals of fairness and equal opportunity,'' it said.

The countryside offers no escape from the social and economic pressures that lead kids to do poorly in school, a study suggests. A study that surveyed school officials in 312 rural, urban and suburban districts last year cast doubt on the popular image of rural children leading wholesome, trouble-free lives compared with youngsters in crowded communities. The study asked officials to estimate the percentage of their students who fit into one or more of a dozen risk categories, including involvement in crime, sexual activity, drug or alcohol abuse, depression, child abuse, poverty or parents who are substance abusers. Rural children fared worse than non-rural children in 34 out of 39 statistical comparisons, according to the survey by the National Rural Development Institute based at Western Washington University.

Rocky Graziano, whose rise from ``world's champion punk'' on the streets of the Lower East Side to world middleweight boxing champion was chronicled in the movie ``Somebody Up There Likes Me,'' has died. Graziano, who put his dese's and dose's to work after his boxing career as a TV pitchman for products from yogurt and foot powder to dog food and auto mufflers, died of cardiopulmonary failure Tuesday at New York Hospital. Hospital spokeswoman Diana Goldin gave his age as 71, but other sources listed him as young as 68. He was hospitalized April 8 after a stroke. He had a heart attack in February.

After nearly a century in which most residents paid a few dollars a year, the only U.S. city on land leased from an Indian reservation has agreed to a fourteenfold increase in rent to the Seneca Indians. The agreement, reached Monday nine months before a 99-year lease expires, also calls for a $60 million payment from the federal and state governments to compensate for what both sides said were unfairly low rents under the old pact. But city officials and residents Tuesday worried about how the community would raise its annual payments to the Indians from $57,000 to at least $800,000. ``If the economy of Salamanca is really impacted by this lease, it can't survive as a city,'' said Patrick Callaghan, chief city negotiator. ``The package we worked out is about the best package we can get from the Senecas. whether we can get through this, I don't know.''

DOC.HEAD: Books and Authors: Put the Blame on Exxon
DOC.TEXT: The Exxon oil-shale debacle eight years ago this month was the biggest and most expensive boom and bust in the history of the West, and Exxon has to shoulder most of the blame for it, according to a new book, ``Boomtown Blues.'' Battered by criticism over the past year for its Alaska oil spill, Exxon inflicted human misery at least as damaging as the oil spill during the western Colorado oil-shale bust of May 1982, says author Andrew Gulliford, who also wrote ``America's Country Schools'' in 1984. In ``Boomtown Blues,'' Gulliford, who lived in Silt, Colo., from 1976-83, chronicles 100 years of western Colorado's oil shale booms and the people who tried to make money from it. His book's history of booms and busts culminates in ``Black Sunday'' _ May 2, 1982, the day Exxon shut down its Colony oil shale project near here. Les Rogers, Exxon's chief spokesman at the company's Houston headquarters, said the company will not comment on the book. Exxon was hardly the only player in the boom that swept the rural Western Slope in the late 1970s and early '80s, but the actions of the world's largest oil company both exacerbated the boom and triggered the bust, according to Gulliford. After Black Sunday, 2,200 people immediately were thrown out of work, and by the time related industries packed up, more than 10,000 people in sparsely populated western Colorado had lost their jobs. So many people had to leave that local humor called the exodus ``the Parachute U-Haul Races.'' That was a misnomer, in a way, because for two years it was literally impossible to rent a moving van anywhere in western Colorado. Eight years later, the area has yet to recover fully. ``Though the recent oil shale boom poured millions of dollars into the Western Slope of Colorado, on the human side of the equation, the net result was only economic instability and personal chaos,'' Gulliford writes. ``The Colony shutdown was not just an isolated incident of an industrial project gone sour, but the largest, most expensive, and fastest mining boom and bust in the history of the West,'' his book says. ``Boomtown Blues'' reads more like sociology than history, with plenty of interviews with the people who lived through the boom and who have survived the bust. Not everyone survived. Gulliford includes the tragic story of a Grand Junction banker who shot himself in the economic rubble Exxon left behind. The residents of Garfield, Mesa, Rio Blanco and Moffat counties are still suffering from the aftereffects of the bust. Bankruptcies are still being filed by professionals and others who struggled to recover from BlacK Sunday but failed. Gulliford attributes many of the divorces in the area to the boom and bust. Foreclosures were common, and families were split up when younger people had to leave Colorado to find work. Mothers became ``weekday widows'' when their husbands were forced to commute to jobs several hundred miles away. The social fabric of small-town western Colorado towns was torn, he writes, both by the fast development of the boom that brought developers to the area, and by the shock of the bust. Gulliford, who is the director of the Museum at Western New Mexico University in Silver City, attributes the out-of-control development mentality to Exxon's now-infamous white paper. Issued in 1980, Exxon predicted shale oil production of 8 million barrels per day by the year 2010, with production reaching 1 million barrels a day by 1990. To cope with the resulting growth, it was estimated the area would need 700 new schools, 3,000 teachers and 700 new police officers and firefighters with 140 vehicles. An estimated 75,000 new housing units would be required to handle the influx of 1.5 million people into the Colorado River Valley between Glenwood Springs and Grand Junction. Those predictions threw Colorado, historically ready to jump on any development, into a growth frenzy. While the oil companies _ mostly at the insistence of then-Gov. Richard Lamm _ pumped millions of dollars into schools, sewer plants, roads and apartments, Gulliford argues that their promises of never-ending prosperity only contributed to the inevitable bust. ``The trauma of the bust was in direct proportion to Exxon's grandiose expectations,'' Gulliford writes. ``Because people believed in oil shale and Exxon, the bust created deep feelings of anxiety and doubt, coupled with realistic fears of financial failures.'' The historian concludes that companies need to be held accountable for agreements they make before the building starts. ``Corporate responsibility must be spelled out to the letter; it cannot be assumed. Grandiose promises and projections mean nothing in the face of declining prices,'' he wrote. Exxon executives have contended it is unfair to blame the oil company alone for the economic disaster. An executive in charge of heading Exxon's slim western Colorado operation during the latter part of the '80s has argued that it is time to look to the future and not dwell on the past. Gulliford's answer? ``The issues of investment, disinvestment and corporate ethics are significant, but so, too, are the houses that sat vacant in Rifle and Grand Junction, the 1,600 foreclosures in 1985 alone, the high local unemployment rates, loss of self-esteem, spouse abuse, child abuse and bust-related suicide. ``Far too little energy has been spent looking backward.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PM Tues May 29

DOC.HEAD: Time Will Determine Artistic Value
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Persecution and public condemnation didn't stop Bai Hua from writing, and now that he faces unofficial ostracism, he's still committed to his work. Bai, one of China's best-known writers, has little hope that his plays will be published or performed in the current political atmosphere inspired by a cCommunist opposition against ``bourgeois'' art and literature. But the 60-year-old writer said it is too late for him to cease his work. ``Writing is my occupation. I should write. Only time can decide whether a work is good or bad,'' he said in an interview at the Shanghai Writers' Association. The great classics of Chinese literature ``were not written after receiving instructions,'' he told a reporter. ``They were original ideas.'' Bai said he will not write differently because of the current politics. ``It is meaningless for me to write rubbish,'' he said. Nonetheless, he and other artists are holding off on the presentation of their works to avoid trouble, a year after the military suppression of China's pro-democracy movement. An unofficial campaign against artists is part of a general return to ideological orthodoxy following the student-led popular movement, which pressed for liberalization in China. Communist Party chiefs have criticized the artists, saying they have become tainted by ``bourgeois liberalization,'' or Western ideas. The leaders also revived a 1942 Mao Tse-tung speech in which he said art and literature must be a ``component part of the whole revolutionary machine.'' At a recent forum, representatives of the official Chinese Writers' Association criticized advocates of ``pure literature'' for divorcing themselves from the masses and socialist modernization. They called for Marxism and Mao Tse-tung thought to be given the leading role in all works of art, and condemned symbolism and other literary techniques as incomprehensible to ordinary Chinese. Bai, a People's Liberation Army playwright until 1985, is a veteran of such campaigns. He was branded a ``rightist'' and persecuted during Mao's 1957 crackdown on outspoken intellectuals. Again silenced during the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution, he was not rehabilitated until the late 1970s. Bai was singled out again in 1981 when the official press, reportedly on orders of senior leader Deng Xiaoping, condemned his play ``Bitter Love'' as a blasphemy against the Communist Party. The play depicts a patriotic painter who is persecuted during the Cultural Revolution and, in a death scene on a snow-covered field, utters the words, ``I love the motherland, but does the motherland love me?'' Bai was accused of being ``antagonistic to the party and the people'' and forced to write a self-criticism. Today, he says the attacks were misguided because the protagonist was speaking only of the Chinese nation under the Cultural Revolution. ``I think the motherland is eternal,'' he said. He was also among the numerous writers censured in a 1983 campaign against ``spiritual pollution.'' Bai spent five months in the United States in 1988 and 1989, lecturing at 20 universities. He returned last May to join the pro-democracy rallies in Shanghai and to sign a petition calling on the students and the government to refrain from violence. Later he was called to account for his actions. ``I told them the truth and said I thought the petition was correct,'' said Bai, who has not been persecuted and can travel freely within China. He remains vice chairman of the Shanghai Writers' Assocation. Most writers who supported the democracy movement have received similar treatment, despite some instances of harsher treatment. Writer Wang Ruowang, 72, has been labeled a ``reactionary and social parasite'' and is under police investigation. He was one of three intellectuals expelled from the Communist Party after student protests in 1986-87. Bai said he has had to turn down invitations to visit West Germany, South Korea and Japan because of the current atmosphere. A play set for performance by the Beijing People's Opera Troupe last June is indefinitely on hold. His play, ``Can't Get Out of the Deep Mountains,'' is a story of peasants in the snare of physical and spiritual isolation, but Bai said the theme includes the reality of all Chinese. He expressed sympathy for editors who are forced to reject such controversial works to protect their organizations, or who can't act without approval from senior party leaders. ``Art in China is not the same as in other countries,'' he said. In other countries writers would love to have state leaders comment on their works. In China, they have no other choice. Bai said the current situation was like crossing a river where ``we are afraid of deep holes even when walking slowly.'' We may laugh at our fears when we reach the other side, he said, but ``most frightening would be to turn back.'' Bai Hua is not about to turn back, but like others he is moving with caution. ``Last year I could have taken you home for lunch,'' he said to this interviewer. ``But not this year.''

DOC.HEAD: Pozner Promised Himself He'd Never Lie _ But Now Admits He Did
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Vladimir Pozner, the Soviet journalist who for years was an apologist for the Kremlin on American television, is making an apology of his own. With his perfect English and knowledge of all things American, from Joe DiMaggio's batting average to brands of breakfast cereal, Pozner was the first Soviet commentator able to put the Kremlin's spin on events without turning Americans off. He is proud of his efforts during the 1980s to counter what he calls ``enemy images'' of angry, boorish, downtrodden and dangerous Russians _ of Khrushchev banging his shoe and Brezhnev slurring his speech, crowds queuing for food and tanks crossing Red Square. Although he insists he should not be considered an ``official'' Soviet spokesman, he is pleased to be known throughout America as an embodiment of the Soviet Union. In short, he believes he's done a lot of good. So why should he feel bad? Because, he admits in his new autobiography, ``Parting With Illusions,'' he said many things he didn't believe _ and didn't have the courage to say some things he believed strongly. In commentaries broadcast around the world by Moscow radio and appearances on American television shows such as ABC's ``Nightline,'' he excused the Warsaw Pact invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968, endorsed the internal exile of Andrei Sakharov in 1980, idealized the accomplishments of the Soviet economy and sang phony paeans to justice in a communist society. ``Why did I do this? Some things I did not see, and others I did not want to see,'' he said in an interview in New York. ``... It was very painful to come to the realization that I was trying to defend things that really weren't defendable.'' To many Americans, Pozner's confession that he was not completely honest with his listeners, or with himself, will come as little surprise. He never has lacked critics or doubters here. The timing of his admission _ in a period when the Kremlin is encouraging self-criticism and historical revision _ also invites skepticism. A decade ago, such a confession could have landed him in jail and would have been courageous. But now that resentment against orthodox communists is running high in the East bloc, his admission of past ideological impurity appears useful, even necessary, to his career. Pozner, confident and sharp-witted at age 56, knows that for these reasons, his apology might not meet rapid acceptance in either the Soviet Union or the United States. Yet he is undaunted. He has trumpeted the confession in his autobiography, published this spring by The Atlantic Monthly Press. The book recounts Pozner's childhood in New York City, where he learned to love the Brooklyn Dodgers, Pete Seeger and Mark Twain. His mother was French, his father a Russian emigre who earned a handsome salary in the American film industry but remained a devoted communist and never gave up his Soviet citizenship. Despite a classic American boyhood _ paper route, baseball games, summer camp _ Pozner says he never felt fully American. Other kids at Stuyvesant High School thought of him as Russian. For a while, he thought of himself as French. When his father lost his job because of his communist sympathies in the late 1940s, the teen-age Pozner and his family headed for the Soviet Union. They went first to war-ravaged Berlin, where his father grew impatient with a Soviet diplomat who found one excuse after another to delay the family's permission to go to Moscow. Only much later, Pozner says, did he and his family realize that the diplomat had been trying to protect them from Josef Stalin, who feared the influence of Russians with experience in the West. ``Had we arrived in the Soviet Union any earlier than we did, there is little doubt that we would all have ended up in one of the Gulag camps,'' he writes. As it happened, Stalin died not long after the family arrived in Moscow in 1952, and they were spared. Vladimir studied at Moscow University and managed to apprentice himself to Samuel Marshak, perhaps Russia's greatest translator of English literature. Later, he broke into journalism and became a commentator for Moscow radio. Today, he works for the state television network, hosting two talk shows. At the very start of his career, Pozner says, he made a promise to himself that he would not lie. ``I made that promise in all honesty, but I cannot honestly say I kept it,'' he says in the book. ``It was not that I deliberately misinformed my audience. Rather, I censored my statements, I deleted passages that could be threatening to me, I rarely spoke my mind fully. ``More than once I questioned what was really influencing my decisions _ fear for myself and my family's well-being, the desire not to furnish the `enemy' with ammunition, a false sense of patriotism, or a real lack of courage? Probably, a bit of each.'' The book, written in a conversational tone, mixes political arguments with personal recollections, sometimes switching abruptly from one to the other as it charts Pozner's two marriages, his rise through the ranks of Soviet journalists, a bout of depression and heavy drinking in 1977, and his success in the We stopped allowing vending and camping because facilities and halls with which we had been doing business with for years said, `We love you, but we can't do business with you anymore.''' Said Duffy: ``It was one of the few ways left in America to grow up. ``You'd have your adventures. In the old days it was the West. Now there is no West.''

DOC.HEAD: Oldest College Class Poll Shows Anger, Humor, Long Memories
DOC.TEXT: Their classmate was a slain Democratic president, but today they are mostly Republicans. They fought for the Western democracies, but more than a third now think Western culture is marking time and only slightly fewer think it is declining. In what Harvard officials say is the oldest college class poll in the country, the men who graduated from Harvard College in 1940 have answered a questionnaire about their lives and the world three times over the past 50 years. The latest results, compiled by classmate Donald M.D. Thurber and mailed to the class last month, contain a few surprises. Although John F. Kennedy Jr. graduated with them, members of Harvard's class of 1940 harbor an abiding mistrust of national government, dubbed by one alumnus ``National Theater and Public Relations.'' Their median income is more than three-quarters of a million dollars, but the class has its share of radicals, one of whom professes to ``get redder as I age.'' More than anything, reading the survey results is like taking a ride in a time machine. Step into the world of the class of 1940 _ as represented by the answers members gave _ and you hardly would know that decades had passed since they graduated, years of wars at home and abroad, of the Beatles, Watergate, AIDS. Who is their favorite musician? George Gershwin. The most popular sports player? Joe DiMaggio. Beloved entertainer? Fred Astaire. Particularly telling is the man voted the most admired figure overall: former British Prime Minister Winston Churchill. ``An Englishman? A man whose career peaked about 50 years ago? A man with no Harvard connections? These questions could easily be asked by a man who is 40 years old,'' said Thurber, 72, a retired public relations executive from Grosse Pointe, Mich. But, in fact, the choice does not surprise him, he said. Almost on the exact day the class of 1940 graduated, Thurber pointed out, France fell to the Germans. The British left their military equipment for the enemy at the beaches of Dunkirk as the Allied soldiers fled for their lives. The world seemed on the brink of vast change. ``It was just a very traumatic thing that the free world hung by such a thread at that time. Many of us thought that we were graduating into a Nazi world,'' Thurber said. ``That we did not do so is due more to the efforts of Winston Churchill than any other single person.'' It is because the class spent years gripped by World War II that they list nuclear war as their greatest fear, Thurber said. ``We fought a war to prevent all wars and now we're going to be blown up and our grandchildren are going to be blown up,'' explained Augustus Soule, the class secretary. The results of the latest poll vary slightly from its predecessors, which posed mostly the same questions. More think Harvard is a worse place to go today than when they attended, and more favor a conservative approach to society. A dramatic change, however, was recorded over the three polls in class opinions about Western culture. In 1940, a third of the class thought it was advancing and in 1965, that number jumped to 49 percent. Today, however, only 30 percent think so. The class, which once included more than 1,000 men, now numbers 688, 495 of whom completed the latest questionnaire in time to have their answers tabulated. Medicine led the list of occupations, with 68 alumni, with education ranking second with 62 and law third with 54. Most of the respondents, however, said they were retired or semiretired. Almost 90 percent said that on the whole, their lives have been very happy or fairly happy. ``Fairly happy. We won World War II,'' one wrote. Sixty-three percent said they were happier than their parents, who were part of the generation hit by the Great Depression. ``I can remember the Depression very, very well,'' said Soule, 72. ``A lot of our parents lost their jobs, some committed suicide or literally had to go out and beg on the streets.'' Skepticism about government and society runs deep in the class of 1940. Asked to choose among a number of positive characteristics to describe the country's current leadership, 59 percent marked ``none of the above.'' Wrote one alumnus: ``Strong and dependable ... you can depend on it to do strongly the wrong thing.'' ``Executive department waffles on issues. Congress is completely self-oriented. Judiciary swamped in endless frivolous litigation,'' one disillusioned graduate penciled in. ``Ethics and integrity _ forget it,'' another wrote. The class came up with a wealth of suggestions for improvements, some earnest, some plaintive, others humorous _ at times, inadvertently. ``Clean out the entire Congress and replace the incumbents with their challengers,'' wrote one. ``Get rid of television,'' said another. ``Eliminate polling,'' one alumnus wrote in. ``The middle seat on an airplane,'' answered another. ``Get people to think!,'' one graduate pleaded. ``I have no panacea,'' answered a classmate. One, in all seriousness, offered a blueprint for change that was a near parody of the so-called Harvard liberal. He advised ``not allowing anyone to own over $1 million.'' Soule disapproved. ``There's always a few kooks in every class,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Mon PMs, May 28

DOC.TEXT: American and Soviet churches plan joint prayers for the success of the summit talks of President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev starting next week. The prayer vigil in Washington is scheduled to continue through the conference May 30-June 4. The Rev. James Hamilton, general secretary of the National Council of Churches, told its governing board meeting that a participating delegation of Soviet Christians will be led by Russian Orthodox Archbishop Kirill. Also, a delegation of Americans is going to Moscow to participate in simultaneous prayer services there. ``Our prayers will give expression to the hopes and longings of the American and Soviet peoples for the coming of peace and the prospects for increased mutual understanding,'' Hamilton said.

Panama's Episcopal Bishop James H. Ottley criticized the U.S. invasion of the country and disputed the official civilian death toll of about 700, saying it is closer to 1,000. ``The United States is now morally obligated to provide compensation for loss of life, for injuries and for the destruction of property,'' he said.

Directors of the world mission arm of the United Church of Christ have decided to combine it with its counterpart in the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ). The merger, expected to be accomplished by 1993, would result in the two denominations sharing personnel and programs that they sponsor in partnership with churches overseas, including medical, educational, agricultural and disaster-relief work. The action by the United Church Board for World Ministries had been approved earlier by the Disciples' Division of Overseas Ministries.

A multilingual Roman Catholic priest says about 90 percent of the male oriented usages in the Bible would be eliminated if translations adhered to the meaning in the original manuscripts. The Rev. Joseph Arackal, whose doctoral studies were on original biblical texts, told the archdiocesan weekly, Catholic Bulletin, that the basic problem was that English lacked a common gender form. Although the Hebrew word translated as ``man'' often simply meant ``human being,'' Arackal said, ``English couldn't duplicate that, so translators just went with `man'. When you compare it with the original, most places where `man' is used now can be changed to `human being'.''

Sen. Jesse Helms, North Carolina Republican, has been presented with the Southern Baptist Public Affairs Committee's Religious Liberty award. He was praised for favoring religion in schools and for fighting abortion and pornography.

Australian biologist Charles Birch, co-winner of the 1990 Templeton Prize for Progress in Religion, said a ``deeper understanding of both science and religion are criticial ingredients'' in solving world problems. Birch, who shared the $600,000 prize with Baba Amte, founder of leper communities in India, told the award ceremony May 8 at Buckingham Palace: ``The growing points of the Christian religion today are along the frontiers of modern science.''

The president of the Southern Baptist Foreign Mission Board says conflict in the denomination has cut its resources and ``hindered the fulfilling of our biblical mandate.'' In an open letter to the 15 million members of the nation's largest Protestant denomination, the Rev. R. Keith Parks said: ``We were once known as a people of evangelism and mission. Now, even internationally, we are headlined as a people of controversy. Our witness of love and hope is less effective.'' Referring to the 11-year battle in which Bible fundamentalists have gained control of the denomination, he said: ``The effort to control has excluded many major supporters of cooperative missions. ... More and more churches and individuals are noting the controversy as a reason for withholding support.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Fri PMs May 25.

For Release PMs Thurs May 24 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Even Bush Can't Keep the Busy Summit Schedule Straight
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: It used to be lonelier at the top. The summit is so heavily booked for meetings these days that even President Bush has had trouble keeping the schedule straight. There are four summit meetings, one domestic, three international, on the Bush agenda for the next six weeks. Sometimes they blur a bit. But if this is London, it must be NATO. Houston means it's economic. Washington has the budget summit, which will drag for weeks. And the big one: Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, whose four-day summit conference begins in a week. In advance of the Gorbachev summit, Bush has met individually with the leaders of western allies. Conferring with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany at the White House last week, Bush was reminded that the Gorbachev meetings end June 3. ``We go off to NATO the next day, don't we?'' the president said. ``Nein, nein, nein,'' corrected Kohl, who also will be at the NATO summit in London one month later, on July 5 and 6. That's to be followed by the seven-nation allied economic summit in Houston, opening a three-day stand on July 8. Theories of summit diplomacy have changed since the Cold War days when every step, statement and gesture was supposed to be carefully planned, lest a misreading make trouble. That may have happened at the 1961 summit between President John F. Kennedy and Nikita S. Khrushchev; miscalculations in Moscow the next year led to the Cuban missile crisis. But the structured, scripted summit conference was yielding to something less structured and more informal long before the Berlin Wall came down. That also carried risks. When Ronald Reagan met Gorbachev in Reykjavik, Iceland, in 1986, for what was to have been a warmup for an arms control summit, they wound up talking about the elimination of all nuclear weapons, then parted at odds over the U.S. strategic space defense program. That's the kind of thing that makes diplomats wary of unstructured meetings between their bosses. Bush and Gorbachev held one at Malta, in the Mediterranean, last December. Bush proposed it as an informal, feet-up session at which they could get acquainted and make sure no messages were missed amid the changes sweeping eastern Europe. But he took along a detailed agenda of arms control items he wanted negotiated in preparation for the real summit, now coming up. ``Summits take on a definition, an expectation of grand design and grand agreements,'' Bush said before the Malta meeting. This time there are agreements ready to meet that expectation, one to ban most chemical weapons, two treaties strengthening limits on nuclear tests. The biggest deal, cutting strategic nuclear weapons, isn't finished, although an administration official said Bush and Gorbachev should be able to announce ``substantive agreement on major START issues.'' A strategic arms reduction treaty will take more negotiation; final terms could be signed at another summit meeting in Moscow late in the year. Nor has there been the pace and progress Bush sought in negotiations for the reduction of conventional Soviet and U.S. forces in Europe. Bush said he still hopes an agreement to cut troops and conventional weapons can be signed before the end of the year. That would be a 35-nation agreement, and some summit. Overall, Bush said Tuesday, preparatory talks on arms accords went well, ``clearing the way for what I hope will be the highly successful meeting with Mr. Gorbachev.'' Successful outcomes are more elusive for the summit meetings Bush has been calling to deal with problems at home. His education summit with the governors, and the drug summit in Colombia produced promises and plans for action, but real results will be a long time coming. The current budget summit can succeed only with a clear and workable agreement to cut the federal deficit. When world leaders meet at the summit, they usually part with mutual congratulations on the success of their talks. The perception of success equals success. And the scoring system assures the outcome.

DOC.TEXT: Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Pay Cable Movies Up the Ante
DOC.TEXT: It used to be that there were three distinctions between made-for-cable television movies and those produced for CBS, NBC and ABC: naked bodies, hard-core curse words and no commercials. Cable movies still have bare breasts, a whole lot of profanity and no bathroom breaks. But times have changed for pay cable films, and now they have more _ namely, big stars, bigger distribution, sophisticated scripts and critical acclaim. In the seven years since Home Box Office pioneered the field by making ``The Terry Fox Story,'' movie legends including Elizabeth Taylor, Bette Davis and Jimmy Stewart have starred in made-for-cable films. Newer stars such as Ellen Barkin, Andy Garcia, Rebecca DeMornay, Ben Kingsley and Powers Boothe also have debuted on the small, cable screen. But as the industry has grown, so, too, has controversy over who gets a piece of the increasingly lucrative pie. At recent hearings before the Federal Communications Commission over whether to re-regulate the cable industry, independent producers screamed that cable networks operate ``closed shops'' that practice ``programming apartheid.'' Marcy Carsey, whose Carsey-Werner Co. produces such mega-hits as ``Roseanne'' and ``The Cosby Show,'' said she can't get in the door of cable networks such as Showtime. The message, she testified during a Los Angeles FCC hearing held in February, is loud and clear: ``Do it their way, creatively and financially, or don't come at all.'' What Carsey and others were referring to is so-called ``vertical integration,'' a fancy term that simply put means cable networks and their big corporate owners can control virtually every aspect of moviemaking, from production to distribution to overseas rights to syndication. And what Carsey and other Hollywood independents want is for the FCC to implement the Financial Interest & Syndication Rules of 1970 _ which prohibit broadcast networks from owning financial interests in their programs _ in the cable industry. FCC commissioners did not seem overly sympathetic. ``I've heard some strange arguments in my time,'' commissioner Andrew Barrett said at the hearing. ``It sounds like you folks want to have your cake and eat it too, and you want us to protect your cake.'' Cable network officials feel likewise. And, they say, the assertions of producers such as Carsey are simply not true. ``We do not produce our films in-house,'' said Showtime's senior vice president of original programs, Steve Hewitt. ``We've used independent producers for a lot of our films.'' And while ``back-end'' deals (Hollywood jargon for splitting up who gets the proceeds from distribution and syndication rights) are not as profitable in cable movies, Hewitt said Showtime wouldn't use independent producers just to cheat them on the back end. HBO leads the pack in cable movies, having produced 47 of them. It also is the only cable network to have won an Emmy, for best screenplay in the critically acclaimed ``Murderers Among Us: The Simon Wiesenthal Story.'' Over the years, HBO has tackled social issues and charismatic leaders, from ``Mandela'' in 1987, starring Danny Glover as then-imprisoned anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela, to ``Sakharov'' in 1984, starring Jason Robards as the dissident Russian physicist and Nobel Peace Prize winner. ``Our goal s to get the best movie possible,'' said Robert Cooper, senior vice president of HBO pictures. ``And we'll buy from anyone to do that.'' HBO just spent $7 million to make ``By Dawn's Early Light,'' a doomsday thriller that debuted last week. It was the most money the network had ever spent on a movie. On average, cable networks such as Showtime, USA Network and Ted Turner's TNT spend between $3 million and $5 million. The revenues from such productions are generated by subscriber fees, home video sales, domestic syndication and foreign theatrical distribution. Showtime's Hewitt said his network is happy just to break even on cable movies. HBO's Cooper said his company sometimes ends up writing off a big chunk of what it costs to make a movie. Don't let them fool you, however. According to estimates by the media research firm of Paul Kagan Associates, Inc., a well-received cable film can bring $2 million to $4 million in foreign revenue alone. And in an era of intense competition between broadcast networks, cable networks, independent television stations, theatrical movies and home video rentals, made-for-cable television movies are in an enviable position. They attract big stars, they're made on relatively small budgets, some have garnered rave reviews, and _ in the language that speaks best to the cable networks' corporate owners _ they can bring in big bucks.

Elsewhere in television ... I'LL TAKE `MORE MONEY' FOR $100, ALEX: If you're a ``Jeopardy!'' fan, get ready for a new installment of the hit game show. ``Super Jeopardy!'' will air Saturday nights on ABC in June, followed by ``Monopoly'' _ both from Merv Griffin Enterprises. ``Monopoly,'' modeled after the board game, will be hosted by Mike Reilly, a former ``Jeopardy!'' contestant.

DOC.HEAD: The Medical Business, A Remarkable Marketplace
DOC.TEXT: If restaurants priced services the way hospitals do, customers would be charged for each use of the salt shaker, each pat of butter, each glass of water. Still, there would be a difference: at least the customer could read the restaurant's bill. That description is from a report on health care by the National Center for Policy Analysis, a Dallas-based think tank with a strong inclination toward free-market solutions to economic problems. John Goodman, its president, says health care is dominated by insurers, government and employers, leaving individuals little control over the prices they pay or the quality of care they receive. His hope, he says, is ``to restore the patient as the principal buyer of health care and unleash an army of millions of informed shoppers into the medical marketplace.'' While that prospect seems distant, the report suggests that a beginning could be made by requiring any hospital that receives Medicare money to quote preadmission prices to all patients. At the moment, it says, nobody understands a hospital bill, nor do many patients or even their insurers read them thoroughly or with understanding. At discharge, the report states, the patient is probably no better informed than on entering. The reason: literally hundreds of line items prices. Why, after just a few days ``a typical bill can stretch 30 feet in length.'' The potential is much longer. A single hospital, the report states, can have as many as 12,000 different line-item prices. Comparison shoppers in the Chicago area, it says, would have to contend with 600,000 prices. It isn't so much the length of the bill that's sickening, the report suggests, as it is the likelihood that ``about 90 percent of the items listed on a hospital bill are in principle unreadable.'' As a result, it continues, patients often cannot even recognize the service rendered, and even when they can recognize the service they cannot form a judgment about whether the charge is reasonable. ``For example, a $30 charge for a Tylenol capsule is common but clearly outrageous, as is a $45 charge for an admissions kit, similar to the free kits airlines give patients on international flights,'' says the report. What is a reasonable price for an X-ray, a blood count or a urinalysis? The center answers: They can be many times the cost at one hospital compared with another within walking distance. Here are some examples of total charges for outpatient services reported to the state by Chicago hospitals in 1988: Mammogram, from $13 to $127; CT scan, from $59 to $635 (however, the center failed to specify the types of scans); tonsillectomy, from $125 to $3,365; cataract removal, from $125 to $4,279. If patients knew about these differences, says Goodman, they might be able to significantly reduce their medical bills. How do such variances occur? One reason, the report states, is that line-item prices have little to do with supply and demand, as do prices in most businesses. They are artifacts of the reimbursement system; they aren't real, it says. Because they are reimbursed by insurers on the basis of costs, hospitals have an ``incentive to artificially raise or lower prices in order to manipulate their reimbursement from third-party payers.'' Reading this report, you might conclude, is enough to make a person sick. Well, at least mildly so, but nothing like the shock of being confronted by 600,000 hospital prices or receiving a hospital-style bill in a restaurant. But sick enough, certainly, to avoid going to the hospital.

DOC.TEXT: The president of the Southern Baptist Foreign Mission Board says conflict in the denomination has cut its resources and ``hindered the fulfilling of our biblical mandate.'' In an open letter to the 15 million members of the nation's largest Protestant denomination, the Rev. R. Keith Parks said: ``We were once known as a people of evangelism and mission. Now, even internationally, we are headlined as a people of controversy. Our witness of love and hope is less effective.'' Referring to the 11-year battle in which Bible fundamentalists have gained control of the denomination, he said: ``The effort to control has excluded many major supporters of cooperative missions. ... More and more churches and individuals are noting the controversy as a reason for withholding support.''

Australian biologist Charles Birch, co-winner of the 1990 Templeton Prize for Progress in Religion, said a ``deeper understanding of both science and religion are criticial ingredients'' in solving world problems. Birch, who shared the $600,000 prize with Baba Amte, founder of leper communities in India, said at the award ceremony at Buckingham Palace, ``The growing points of the Christian religion today are along the frontiers of modern science.''

Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., has been presented with the Southern Baptist Public Affairs Committee's Religious Liberty award. He was praised for favoring religion in schools and for fighting abortion and pornography.

A multilingual Roman Catholic priest says about 90 percent of the male oriented usages in the Bible would be eliminated if translations adhered to the meaning in the original manuscripts. The Rev. Joseph Arackal, whose doctoral studies were on original biblical texts, told the archdiocesan weekly, Catholic Bulletin, that the basic problem was that English lacked a common gender form. Although the Hebrew word translated as ``man'' often simply meant ``human being,'' Arackal said, ``English couldn't duplicate that, so translators just went with `man.' When you compare it with the original, most places where `man' is used now can be changed to `human being.'''

Directors of the world mission arm of the United Church of Christ have decided to combine it with its counterpart in the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ). The merger, expected to be accomplished by 1993, would result in the two denominations sharing personnel and programs that they sponsor in partnership with churches overseas, including medical, educational, agricultural and disaster-relief work. The action by the United Church Board for World Ministries had been approved earlier by the Disciples' Division of Overseas Ministries.

Panama's Episcopal Bishop James H. Ottley criticized the U.S. invasion of the country and disputed the official civilian death toll of about 700, saying it is closer to 1,000. ``The United States is now morally obligated to provide compensation for loss of life, for injuries and for the destruction of property,'' he said.

American and Soviet churches plan joint prayers for the success of the summit talks of President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. The prayer vigil in Washington is scheduled to continue through the conference May 30-June 4. The Rev. James Hamilton, general secretary of the National Council of Churches, said at its governing board meeting that a participating delegation of Soviet Christians would be led by Russian Orthodox Archbishop Kirill. Also, a delegation of Americans plans to go to Moscow to participate in simultaneous prayer services there. ``Our prayers will give expression to the hopes and longings of the American and Soviet peoples for the coming of peace and the prospects for increased mutual understanding,'' Hamilton said.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Crusader Sees Lesson for U.S. in Soviet Prisons
DOC.NOTE: With Laserphoto
DOC.TEXT: Charles W. ``Chuck'' Colson probably has been in as many prisons as anyone, including serving a term in one. His latest incursion _ into the lockups of the Soviet Union _ turned up an approach he considers lacking in this country. They have ``better organized work programs,'' said the veteran traveler of the behind-bars circuit and fervent advocate of bracing up prisoners, body and soul. ``It's an area where we can learn something from the Russians,'' he said in an interview. ``One of the troubles with American prisons is that we don't give inmates meaningful work. That can drive a person crazy.'' Colson is head of Prison Fellowship, a group based in Reston, Va., that has grown into a worldwide organization to bolster religious faith among prisoners and seek reforms in the system. Talking about the work programs in the two countries' prisons, he said, ``The Russians are doing a better job of it.'' That was his conclusion after a rare visit inside five Soviet prisons with a U.S. Department of Justice delegation at the invitation of the Soviet Bureau of Internal Affairs. ``All of them had work programs, including for juveniles,'' he said. ``It was especially good in a women's prison. Everbody had a job. There was plenty of work to do. They got two-thirds of the going wage for their work. ``They were paid bonuses if they produced more. They were charged for room and board. Morale was excellent. I told them they were more capitalistic than on the outside. They didn't understand that. ``It's one of the best industry work programs I've seen anywhere in Europe or the United States.'' Colson, who became a staunch Christian after serving seven months in prison as a Watergate conspiracy offender, started his prison organization in 1976. He has since visited prisons in 28 countries, including about 300 in the United States. He said most of the Soviet prisons he visited, one the remote Perm 35 where several notable political prisoners once were held, remained repressive, restricting mail and family visits, but all had work programs. Developing such productive programs would improve American prisons, he said. It's a reform also advocated by retired Chief Justice Warren Burger, but opposed by labor and businesses as unfairly competitive. Since human beings are ``made in the image of God, purposeful and creative'' work gives a person ``a sense of purpose in life,'' Colson said. ``Take away that sense of purpose and you kill him. ``To deprive him of work is to deprive him of human dignity. That's one of the worst things we do in American prisons.'' Colson's Prison Fellowship conducts Bible-training seminars in about 600 U.S. prisons, with courses given 50,000 inmates last year, served by 33,000 volunteers. Also last year, 50 work-release programs were conducted in each of which several prisoners were furloughed for community renovation projects. ``The movement is spreading very rapidly,'' Colson said, noting the group has chartered programs in 39 countries and some work in 20 others. He also expects it to be functioning soon in the Soviet Union at the invitation of Interior Minister Vadim Bakatin, who Colson said told him crime was up sharply and religion needed. ``They welcome it,'' he said. ``The Russians thoroughly realize they need religious values to give order to society.'' Colson said a training program was planned for the Soviet Union in June, with Russian Orthodox, Baptist and other denominations invited to participate. Colson, 58, a Baptist, added: ``Ironically, the Russians for pragmatic reasons want religion and we're trying to eliminate it. It's crazy. It's one of the great ironies of history.'' For example, he noted the U.S. Supreme Court has banned display of the Ten Commandments at public schools, but said a committee of the Soviet Academy of Sciences is studying how to integrate the commandments into education. ``They're now treating them as the greatest moral code ever,'' Colson said. But ``Americans, wallowing in self-indulgent materialism, are working to expurgate religion from every area of life.'' He attributed the unexpected overturning of communism across Eastern Europe to an overflowing of pent-up spiritual energies, citing its church-based origins in Poland, East Germany and Romania and similar processes elsewhere. However, he contended, the U.S. government and news media had largely ignored the religious impetus, as they did prior to similar upheavals in Iran and the Philippines. U.S. embassies typically ``don't understand it,'' he said. ``They don't know what's going on. The spiritual is hard to discern and they're just not with it. They don't look beneath the surface. Intelligence satellites can't see into human hearts. ``When we take our political measurments, we count the nuclear situation and gross national product, but mark religion as a throwaway.'' Partly, he said, it's a result of ``religious illiteracy'' among journalists and other analysts. ``But there's also a bigotry that won't take religion very seriously,'' he said. ``There's a denial of religion by our cultural elite as irrelevant and simple-minded. So we don't see it when it's there.''

DOC.HEAD: A Year After Tiananmen, Chinese Students in U.S. Less Politically Active
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 21st graf, ``The broadcast ... southern China,'' to CORRECT spelling of Chongqing and that it is a city, not a province; PICKS UP 22nd graf, ``The government ... pro-democracy movement.''
DOC.TEXT: A year after the massacre that left their friends dead and bloodied on Tiananmen Square, the fervoas faded and many Chinese students in the United States have put away their protest signs and reopened their br of last June hooks. Chinese students here still push for democratic reforms, but many are split over what road the movement should take. And some former activists even suggest their counterparts in China pushed the government too far and are partly responsible for the infamous crackdown. Xu Chenggang, 38, a graduate student in economics at Harvard University, watched the televised images of the tanks rolling into the Gates of Heavenly Peace, as the square is called in Chinese. He saw his friends maimed and killed. Like many others, he was roused to action. ``In that time, in my mind, the most important thing was to stop the killings, so I got very active and emotional,'' Xu said. ``For two months, I went to ralli not be true,'' Li said. ``In certain places, people don't have food anymore. That information could trigger pro-democracy movement.'' A pro-democracy newspaper set up by Chinese journalists and students in Los Angeles has a circulation of 30,000 and is published every 10 days. It is distributed in China and several Western nations. ``We get into China three ways _ fax, mail and smuggling,'' said editor-in-chief Ben Tang. ``We are in at least 20 major cities there.'' Many students, however, continue to be frightened to speak up, both because they want to return home someday and because they fear reprisals against loved ones in China, Pei said. The students' fears were heightened recently by reports from a Chinese bureaucrat who defected to the United States. He said the Communist Party planned to send officials to U.S. college campuses to court sympathetic students and intimidate the Chinese activists. ``They saw what happened in China. They know politics is a risky business,'' Pei said. ``We lost quite a large number of people, especially after the new revelations.'' Pei said students no longer believe change will take China by storm as it has Eastern Europe, so their concerns are less urgent than last spring and their goals have become long-term. Key issues now are economic sanctions against China and whether the country will continue to enjoy favorable trading status with the United States, he said. Here, there is disagreement. Some students said they support strong economic sanctions against China for the crackdown. Xu, however, said sanctions would hurt fledgling entrepreneurs and joint business ventures with the West. ``Joint ventures are really good things,'' Xu said. ``Removing those things would remove the seeds of the revolution.'' Pei said student emotions ``have cooled a little bit since last June. Some people say tough sanctions, others say less. People differ on how the movement should proceed.'' The students do agree that the long march toward democracy in China began in earnest last June 4. ``Before last spring, democracy as a goal was illegitimate,'' Pei said. ``Now it's been branded by blood into the national consciousness.'' The gains made, they also note sadly, came at a high price both for the students who stood in the square that night and those who stood with them from afar. ``I'm one of the so-called extreme counterrevolutionaries,'' said Pei, whose parents, sisters and brother are back home in Shanghai. ``It would be suicidal to go back.''
