DOC.HEAD: It Is a New World, and the Superpowers Don't Run It
DOC.TEXT: The superpowers suddenly don't seem so super anymore. Or so threatening. So the notion of George Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev sitting down at a superpower summit, as they will in four days, seems vaguely out of date. They can still destroy the world, but they can't control it. Even the idea of chipping away at nuclear stockpiles _ each side has about 25,000 nuclear weapons _ lacks the urgency it had only a few years ago. They're not about to go to war. The less the threat of war, the less the need for superpower protectors and the more the rest of the world can go its own way. ``Summits are good things, the more the better,'' says Sam Lambroza, professor of Soviet studies at St. Mary's College in St. Mary's City, Md. ``Everyone benefits; no one walks away the loser. ... But it is not Roosevelt, Churchill and Stalin, dividing the world.'' Moreover, in the 1{ years since Bush took office, the Soviet Union has lost its empire, its constituent republics are rebelling, and its economy, the CIA says, is ``near crisis.'' ``We don't need to rub the Soviets' face in the fact that they are not that relevant any more in most respects,'' says Helmut Sonnenfeldt, a veteran Soviet expert and former Henry Kissinger sidekick. ``They are a receding power, and you can argue whether or not we are an ascending power.'' ``The Soviet Union is a superpower in the sense that it is a huge land mass, although it is a restless and messed-up land mass,'' says Sonnenfeldt, a hardliner in U.S.-Soviet relations. ``It remains a superpower because it has a formidable military capacity, even though there's some question even about the morale of its troops.'' Adds Lambroza: ``We're not talking to them about Cuba or Africa or the Middle East because in some ways the Soviet Union has stopped being players.'' In 1986, the world gasped when Gorbachev and Ronald Reagan, in the frosty city of Reykjavik, Iceland, came, it seemed, within a handshake of agreeing to cut their strategic stockpiles by half. Now the world would nod approval if Gorbachev and Bush did that, then go about its business. But the notion that the leaders of the United States and the Soviet Union could settle the world's problems no longer resembles reality, if it ever did, experts say. ``What we're talking about is power that can't be measured in Jane's Fighting Ships anymore,'' says James H. Billington, head of the Library of Congress and a scholar of Soviet affairs. Bipolar summitry doesn't fit in the multipolar world now taking shape, Billington says. He notes the drive toward a united Western Europe, the rise of the Japanese economic giant and, down the road, the potential clout of China, India, Brazil and the belt of Islamic nations. ``We are heading for a very interesting, polycentric world,'' Billington says. Former Sen. Charles McC. Mathias, a Maryland Republican and close observer of international affairs, agrees. The superpowers, he says, are not talking about the problems in which they could make a real difference. ``Just imagine if they got on the agenda I would like to see _ population problems, the environment, drugs _ problems proven beyond the scope of even the most powerful nation to control,'' says Mathias. ``If the Soviet Union and the United States would join on that agenda, it would vitalize the world.'' It has been a long time since world leaders could impose their wills in the manner of the Congress of Vienna of 1814 and 1815, where the crowned heads of Europe redrew the continent's boundaries under the tutelage of Prince Klemens Wenzel Nepomuk Lothar von Metternich of Austria, the master diplomat who dominated the continent for a third of a century. The leaders of the United States and the Soviet Union have met 16 times since World War II, once a year since 1985. But the world is no longer sharply divided into two antagonistic armed camps and a nonaligned Third World that sometimes managed to turn the competition to its own advantage. In those days, the superpowers fought proxy wars, in Korea or Angola or Vietnam or Afghanistan or Nicaragua. The proxy wars have ended; so has the superpowers' unchallenged ability to call the shots in friendly countries. The United States opened negotiations with the Philippines this month by saying that if Filipinos want this country to give up its bases there it will leave ``with our pride fully intact.'' Festus Brotherson Jr., a former senior foreign policy official in the South American country of Guyana and now a political scientist at Baldwin-Wallace College in Berea, Ohio, says: ``Traditionally when a superpower speaks, the whole world listens. But now when Gorbachev speaks, there is a perception that he lacks the will and wherewithal to execute his policies.'' Brotherson, a specialist in Third World politics, adds, ``The troubling aspect at the summit for people like myself is that whenever there is a cozy relationship between the United States and the U.S.S.R., there is always trouble in the Third World. ``The Third World movement can no longer play one against the other. ... Once there's no East-West conflict, the West ignores the Third World's claims.'' Another observer, Stanford University historian Gordon Craig, an expert on Germany, refers to the United States and the Soviet Union as ``the two former superpowers.'' ``There has been a very perceptible weakening of their power,'' he says. ``The Russians are incapable of doing _ or even threatening _ what they once could and the United States has not been acting like a superpower. ``Their inability to control what is happening in Europe is shown by the German unification process, which has gone on with tumultuous speed without any brakes by any powers, let along the superpowers.'' Just as Czechs, Hungarians, Poles and Romanians shoved the communists out of power, ordinary Germans on German streets brought down the German Democratic Republic, the Berlin Wall and the idea that two Germanys must exist separately, Craig says. He says ordinary people compelled Moscow and Washington to negotiate an orderly German reunification even as it was becoming a fait accompli.
DOC.NOTE: MORE
$adv27
For Release Sunday, May 27, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: WASHN: fait accompli.
DOC.TEXT: Simon Serfaty, executive director of the Johns Hopkins Foreign Policy Institute, raises a cautionary note. ``The devaluation of superpower influence in shaping events does not mean it has acquired zero value,'' he says. ``We remain relevant to unification in Western Europe and the Soviets to the process of liberalization in Eastern Europe. The negotiations over Germany show that. What has been devalued can be revalued.'' He says that if Gorbachev were to be overthrown, there could be a ``renewed assertiveness of Soviet power,'' which even now ``remains far from insignificant.'' Meantime, Serfaty asserts, the United States remains ``relevant to what happens in the Middle East, southern Africa and Western Europe _ if we have the will.'' Serfaty makes another point: Raw military might has not lost its relevance. Soviet influence ``totally disappeared'' in central Europe extraordinarily fast, but only after Gorbachev made it clear to his communist allies that ``Soviet military power was no longer available,'' Serfaty says. Political scientist Bruce Jentleson of the Brookings Institution says both superpowers have had trouble turning allies into puppets. He says the United States was unable to call the shots in South Vietnam or Israel and the Soviets could not make things happen in the Arab states or Afghanistan. For all that, ``the fact remains that this summit is at least the single most important meeting in the world,'' Jentleson says. He cites the possibility of reaching historic arms-destruction agreements as well as the need to ``maintain the relationship'' in the face of tensions newly arising from Gorbachev's move to squelch the secessionist movements in the Baltics. And he points to Bush's decision against imposing economic sanctions on the Soviets because of their crackdown in Lithuania as a demonstration of the limits of American power. ``Every ally said they wouldn't go along'' with sanctions, he says. ``The largely non-violent uprising in Eastern Europe and guerrilla warfare in the Third World have undermined the importance of military force to impose dominance,'' says political scientist Stephen Zunes of Whitman College in Walla Walla, Wash. ``Meanwhile the rise of Japan and the European Community have demonstrated that military might is not the only the way to go. ``So I would argue that the upcoming summit may not, in fact, be between the leaders of two superpowers but between (the) leaders of two countries desperately trying to justify their standing.'' ``I just think that summits are less important than they used to be,'' adds Zunes, a student of Third World politics. ``The issues that need to be addressed are beyond the control of the superpowers.'' Even Bush feels obliged to argue that all is not settled in the world, that American power still matters. ``President Gorbachev has made profound progress in his country, reforms so fundamental that the clock cannot be turned back,'' Bush said in a commencement speech at Oklahoma State University in Stillwater a few weeks ago. ``Yet neither can we turn the clock ahead to know for sure what kind of country the Soviet Union will be in years to come.'' Still, the world has moved so far from armed-to-the-teeth confrontation between communism and democracy that Manfred Woerner, the secretary general of NATO, raises no eyebrows when he says, as he did May 7, ``We are looking towards the Soviet Union as a partner in security.''

DOC.HEAD: The Russians Are Coming, But Without the Hoopla
DOC.TEXT: International camera crews couldn't get enough of the Soviet chic featured at a punk Georgetown boutique when Mikhail Gorbachev came to town in 1987. This time, there'll be no Cyrillic logos or Lenin T-shirts at Commander Salamander. Weapons watchdogs will not give daily press breakfasts and demonstrators will be relatively sparse. It's the second time around for Gorbachev and the capital is not exactly reeling with the thrill _ even four days before the president of the Soviet Union sits down with president of the United States. ``First-time events are more exciting than reruns,'' said Tom Cochran, a nuclear physicist who helped found Summit Watch to analyze and explain the landmark arms-reduction treaty signed by Gorbachev and President Reagan during Gorbachev's first visit. The group of nuclear arms experts put on $80,000 worth of briefings and breakfasts at a hotel across Lafayette Park from the White House. This year they're giving out their phone number. ``We deliberated about whether or not there would be a foundation out there to give us money this time,'' said Stan Norris, another founder. ``It's hard to sell it when the perception is that the Cold War is over and there's not a specific focus'' such as the treaty signing. It's the second time around and the protests won't be as passionate. In 1987 a crowd of 200,000, including several presidential contenders, turned out to make a poignant plea for freer emigration of Soviet Jews. This year the Baltic states want out, but a pro-independence rally is expected to draw no more than 10,000 people. Organizers acknowledge Gorbachev's role in the stunning events of Eastern Europe and say they hope their confidence in him can be restored. It's the second time around and the glitz is gone. Wendy Red, co-owner of Commander Salamander, ordered piles of merchandise keyed to a Soviet theme for the last summit. But the funky shop recently discontinued a line of jeans and shirts that had Cyrillic logos and came in Soviet cans. ``We thought it was going to be phenomenal, but it didn't sell. Probably two years ago I would have had people banging down the door to get it,'' Red said. ``It's not as trendy since we're all friends now.'' Still, a summit is a summit, and Gorbachev will not be ignored. Soviet and American flags will hang side by side across the city; souvenir pins, T-shirts and key rings will appear as always; bars will rename their drinks and at least one restaurant _ the Hard Rock Cafe _ will feature Soviet musicians and dishes like pirogi and potato soup. Gorbachev himself will be treated to a ceremonial welcome, a state dinner and a day at Camp David. But he may create more excitement once he leaves town. At Stanford University in Palo Alto, Calif., where the Soviet leader has scheduled a two-hour stop, Vice President Bob Freelen said the visit and a possible speech are ``the highlight since Queen Elizabeth came'' seven years ago. ``We've gotten lots of inquiries for volunteering to be on the invitation list,'' he said dryly. In Minnesota, officials said their phones have not stopped ringing since Gorbachev arranged to spend six hours in Minneapolis. Eight limousine companies have offered to provide his transportation. People want to give him a wolfhound, a lamb, a giant sheet cake decorated with the Soviet flag. They want to show him tame black bears, a preserved log cabin, a father's World War II memento. He's been invited to Rotary meetings, high school graduations and town picnics; to have coffee, visit an art gallery, stay at a cabin on the St. Croix River. ``The only thing that this compares to is when the Minnesota Twins won the World Series in 1987,'' said Eileen Biernat, an aide to Gov. Rudy Perpich. ``People were just going wild then and they are just wild over this.'' The hubbub has not reached that level in Washington, at least not yet. Typical was the reaction of George Washington University President Stephen Trachtenberg. His school's basketball court will be turned into a press center for thousands of journalists. ``This is kind of an exclamation point, but it is representative of a regular excitement that we are accustomed to,'' Trachtenberg said. The university is glad to help out, but doesn't need the visibility, he said. Washingtonians were not quite so blase when Gorbachev turned up in 1987. Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., was among the stalwart few who refused to succumb to the Gorbymania engulfing the city. He had been invited to the state dinner honoring Gorbachev but ate that night instead with some contractors in New England. He was running for president and, as his spokesman said, ``Mikhail doesn't vote in the New Hampshire primary.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, May 27, and thereafter

DOC.HEAD: SEASON OF ANXIETY
Publishers Face a Time of Trauma
With BC-AP Arts: Polish Publisher, b0770
DOC.TEXT: Ann Getty, wife of one of the world's richest men, had a problem: She loved to read all day, but she also believed in the Protestant work ethic. ``I come from nice Puritan stock, and I grew up believing that you have to work all day,'' she explained. Lord Weidenfeld, one of Britain's most distinguished publishers, also had a problem: He had been wanting to break into American publishing for 20 years. But where would he get the money? It seemed Getty and Weidenfeld had solved their problems in 1985 when they teamed up to buy Grove Press and start Weidenfeld & Nicholson New York, a medium-size, independent publisher of quality books. But five years later Grove-Weidenfeld was put up for auction, like some paperback rights routinely are. As losses approached $15 million, Getty's financial advisers reportedly told the voracious reader her job was prohibitively expensive. The story of Grove-Weidenfeld is merely one trauma in what Random House executive Peter Osnos has described as ``a season of anxiety in publishing.'' The source of the anxiety is money _ big, corporate, international money, and its transformation of what had been a small industry run and staffed by people who cared as much about literary quality as profit. Almost every famous name in publishing now has a famous business name behind it: Simon & Schuster (owed by Paramount Communications), Harper & Row (Rupert Murdoch's News Corp.), MacMillan Co. (Robert Maxwell Publications), Little Brown (Time-Warner Inc.), William Morrow & Co. (Hearst Corp.). Indeed, ``Corporate Takeover of the Word'' was the title of a recent writers conference at New York University. ``I'm struck by the level of concern, that 120 people would spend a sunny Saturday indoors talking about the publishing industry,'' says Alec Dubro, president of the National Writers Union. ``If an author is very concerned about the handling of a book, about its content, he or she is being driven away from the major publishers,'' he adds. ``The majors are perceived as being far more homogenized and commercialized than they once were.'' The complaint, which is difficult to document, runs like this: Corporations want books that earn quick profits, create little controversy and accord deferential treatment to any person, product or cause that it or its subsidiaries hold dear. However limited their grasp of literature, corporate managers can usually read a balance sheet, and it is to this _ not ideology or censorship _ that much of the season's anxiety can be traced. Simon & Schuster posted pre-tax losses of $140 million, and the chairman of Doubleday was forced out because of financial problems there. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich borrowed $3 billion to fend off a takeover bid, raising questions if the company can meet its interest payments, let alone invest in its future. The predictable corporate response to such conditions: Smaller advances for authors; layoffs for employees; and, since only two books in 10 make money, fewer new titles for the public. According to preliminary figures compiled by Publishers Weekly, new title output declined by about 4 percent last year. So far, the most notable casualty of the money crunch has been Pantheon Books, a Random House subsidiary long known for its intellectually challenging books on a variety of subjects. In February, Andre Schiffrin resigned as Pantheon's managing director rather than accept orders from Random House (itself a subsidiary of the Newhouse family's Advance Publications) to publish fewer books. At this, several authors defected, six senior editors resigned and several hundred members of the literary community demonstrated on the street outside Random House's offices. Whatever the merits of its books, Pantheon had lost $3 million last year on sales of $20 million. The demonstrators said Random House should absorb Pantheon's losses, but industry sources say Random House made little or no profit in 1989. Advance's S.I. Newhouse insisted Pantheon pay its own way, saying, ``I do not like charity cases.'' Publishing's crisis has its roots in the 1950s, when the heart of the retail book market moved from a relatively few, large city bookstores to many more smaller ones in suburban shopping centers. By the late '70s, bookstore chains, such as Waldenbooks and B. Dalton Bookseller, were adding hundreds of new stores a year, and they featured hardcover best sellers at discounted prices. Readers who once waited for best sellers to come out in paperback could now snap up the new Tom Clancy or Danielle Steele for only a few dollars more than they would pay for the paperback a year later. The hardcover best seller became the industry's cash cow, but it also changed the relationship between some best-selling authors and their publishers. What had been a sort of marriage, for better or worse, evolved into a temporary alliance based on the highest bid. And as long as new stores kept opening, no bid seemed too high. Shopping mall construction and bookstore openings slowed over the last five years, but literary agents continued to demand ever-larger advances and guarantees. Jason Epstein, a top editor at Random House, cites Stephen King's sales figures to illustrate the consequences. In 1985, King's ``Skeletn Crew'' sold 720,000 copies; two years later, as chain store volume was peaking, sales of his ``Tommyknockers'' doubled to 1.4 million copies. Last year, however, only 1.6 million copies of King's new novel, ``The Dark Half,'' were shipped to retailers, and many of those were returned. With fewer stores opening, there is no way sales of ``The Dark Half'' can exceed those of King's previous novels at anything like the rate at which sales of ``Tommyknockers'' exceeded those of ``Skeleton Crew.'' Yet for ``The Dark Half'' and King's next three novels, King's publisher is said to have guaranteed between $35 million and $40 million _ ``sums that presuppose a continually expanding market,'' Epstein says. Even in this inflationary atmosphere, Grove-Weidenfeld was conspicuous, as one observer put it, for ``noisily slapping money down on the table.'' One of its editors was quoted as saying, ``They have given me a very big budget to acquire very big books.'' Very big sales, however, proved more elusive. Shana Alexander was paid $500,000 for a book on the Pizza Connection heroin trial, but booksellers sold only 26,000 of a 100,000-copy printing and sent the rest back. On Feb. 27, the same day Schiffrin resigned at Pantheon, Grove-Weidenfeld was put up for sale. Potential bidders were reported to include the usual corporate subsidiaries, including MacMillan, Harper & Row, Simon & Schuster and Random House. But two months later Getty said the firm would not be sold because of ``the strong feeling among authors, agents and booksellers that we should not be swallowed by a publishing conglomerate.'' In fact, according to industry sources, the conglomerates decided Grove was indigestible. The publishing house once described as ``famous for low sales and high advances'' had failed to elicit a decent bid.

DOC.HEAD: SEASON OF ANXIETY
A Polish Publisher Learns the American Way
With BC-AP Arts: Publishing Woes, b0769
DOC.TEXT: The Polish publisher had struggled for 12 years in the underground to provide books to an audience hungry for the truth. Now all those clandestine times were behind him, and he was touring the West to seek the help of friends in transforming his press into a commercial venture. But Grzegorz Boguta's first taste of the Western publishing trade was a bit sour. Arriving on a New York visit, he learned that his friend, Andre Schiffren, had been forced to resign as director of prestigious Pantheon. The publisher's corporate parent, Random House Inc., found that Schiffren hadn't been paying enough attention to the bottom line. This lesson about the duress that money can exert on artistic endeavors was a ``good one for us to learn,'' Boguta said, somewhat ruefully, in a recent interview. ``It showed us we have to mix books we think are important with books that will sell.'' Boguta's NOWA (independent publishing house) press published more than 500 titles between 1977 and March, when he closed it. Most were tiny editions distributed free among friends. Among the authors he published were Nobelists Alexander Solzhenitsyn and Andrei Sakharov, Jean Paul Satre and Philip Roth. But one advantage to underground publishing, Boguta said, is that as long as it remains free of the security police's clutches, it is totally independent. As he attempts to restart NOWA as a commercial publisher, Boguta is coming to grips with a new variety of problems. No one in Poland has the money to invest in a publishing house, and Boguta is leery about relying on the Polish state or foreign investors. Furthermore, Poland's brusque experiment with free-market capitalism has sent prices skyrocketing. ``People don't have enough money to buy food, let alone books,'' he said. ``Coming into a free market economy is hurting publishers even more than it's hurting other people,'' said Roland Algrant, director of the International Freedom to Publish Committee of the Association of American Publishers. The group provided money to clandestine publishers of manuscripts in the Soviet Union in the old days and continues to help them. But their needs have increased dramatically, Algrant said. ``When they did everything with carbon copies, $100 was a lot of money,'' he said. ``Now a $2,000 grant is practically nothing. They need paper, they need equipment. All of a sudden they have a market and want to make 10,000 copies instead of 10.'' Americans are helping. Writers such as William Styron and Kurt Vonnegut have donated the rights to their novels to publishers in the newly democratic countries of Central Europe. The U.S. Information Service is providing grants for equipment. Schiffrin, who as Pantheon's director led a group called Friends of NOWA, had signed an agreement that provided the Polish publisher $25,000 for rights to the English translations of future NOWA books. But out of solidarity with Schiffrin, Boguta hasn't approached the publisher's new directors to ask about the status of that loan. The Pantheon brouhaha is part of a wave of mergers, shakeups and financial troubles at quality American publishers in recent years. Amid the general nervousness, some editors questioned whether these houses were capable of showing greater interest in Eastern European writers. ``You have a whole attitude in the publishing industry these days that you don't publish unless you can make profits,'' said Algrant. ``The editors are all dying to get new Eastern European writers, but the financial managers say, `Where's all this going to lead?''' Said one editor who has worked with Czech writers: ``I think it's sadly ironic that just when the Eastern European writers have an opportunity to publish without smuggling their manuscripts out, the climate in the United States is a little harder-nosed as far as the bottom line goes.'' Some believe the apparent end of Communist rule will diminish interest in a literature whose piquancy partly resided in its dissident character. Wendy Luers, who befriended many of Czechoslovakia's leading intellectuals when she and her husband, then-Ambassador William Luers, were in Prague in 1983-86, recalled telling a Czech novelist: ``If you want to be judged on your merits, not as a dissident, you have to hit the hard old business of getting your manuscripts rejected.'' Luers, as president of Charter 77 Foundation-New York, has been involved in a variety of programs to support Czech culture and bring Czech and American writers together. She is organizing a Prague visit for top literary agents, Lynn Nesbitt and Mort Janklow. ``We hope that if we can get American publishers interested in Eastern European writers we'll get the Latin American literary phenomenon _ creating a genre that people will be interested in reading,'' she said. Knopf is publishing two of Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel's books this year, as well as two books by novelist Ivan Klima. But the lasting appeal of many important dissident writers, both in translation and their home countries, remains to be seen. Some suggest that many members of the underground will stay there, although it will be a legal underground. ``Nobody knows yet whether the `alternative culture' that existed can continue to exist in a free society,'' said Czech writer Iva Pekarkova. ``There were some writers who were read simply because they were illegal. Now they may have to face the fact that nobody wants to read them anymore. Not all of them are great writers.'' Pekarkova, who has lived in New York for four years, took part in a panel of young Czech and American writers at New York University in March. When some of the American participants complained about publishers' timidity, the Czech panelists nodded sympathetically, Pekarkova said. But they didn't really understand the problems because the translator was unable to convey what the Americans meant by ``censorship.'' ``I personally have had problems trying to publish my book in English,'' said Pekarkova, who has been driving cabs for a living. ``But you can't call it censorship. If the American public does not want to read a book and therefore a publisher doesn't want to buy it, that's not the fault of the government. ``Czech writers haven't had to worry about money, but ... how can you worry about money when you can't get published at all, for political reasons?'' Yet some in Eastern Europe are beginning to have to confront such dilemmas as their economies shift to market emphasis. Boguta watched uneasily, for example, when Rupert Murdoch and West Germany's Axel Springer newspaper group bought into two independent Hungarian newspapers last year. ``We could sell our stock to foreigners, but what about our independence?'' Boguta said. Instead, he is attempting to set up a consortium of publishers in Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia who could negotiate as a group with foreign investors without fear of losing editorial control.

DOC.HEAD: Jerry Seinfeld Says Backup Characters Took Over His Show
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Jerry Seinfeld thought his new NBC show would be a showcase for his stand-up comedy, but the background story and characters of ``Seinfeld'' took it over. ``Our original concept was that my stand-up act would be the main thing and the story would be filler,'' he said. ``It's turned out to be just the opposite. We have some good actors, and the relationships really clicked. We said, `Hey, let's do more of this!' ``We thought we were going in one direction, but ended up going in another. which was totally against my will. The characters at first were just props. Now, they're the show.'' ``Seinfeld'' is running for four episodes behind ``Cheers'' on Thursday nights, through June 21. Jason Alexander, a Tony winner for ``Jerome Robbins' Broadway'' who appears in the box office hit ``Pretty Woman,'' plays Seinfeld's best friend. Julia Louis-Dreyfus is his former girlfriend, and Michael Richards is his next-door neighbor. ``I'm really intrigued by the idea of fitting in tiny pieces of stand-up into the story,'' Seinfeld said. ``I write the stand-up to go with the story. We tape that separately on a comedy club set. I do a whole routine and we edit it down.'' Seinfeld calls himself a comic without a hook or a shtick. ``I just do observations about life,'' he said. ``I'll take an idea, like a sock trying to escape from a dryer. Then I'll turn it into a whole prison escape thing. I don't use things from my personal life. It's not that funny.'' Seinfeld is a popular comic who makes at least 300 appearances a year at nightclubs, concert halls, casinos, conventions, comedy clubs and colleges. He was voted the ``Funniest Male Stand-Up Comic'' in the 1988 American Comedy Awards show. He appears at the Improv in Los Angeles, Catch a Rising Star in New York and the Sands in Atlantic City. In Las Vegas, he and Cher split the bill at the Mirage. He also makes frequent guest appearances on ``The Tonight Show'' and ``Late Night With David Letterman.'' Seinfeld said he has no plans to spend a lot of time on television. In fact, he still sees television mainly as a means to promote his stand-up appearances. ``To me, the big thing is to get people to come and see you,'' he said. ``That's an accomplishment. Watching a comedian on TV is no big thing. I wouldn't want to go from show to show like Bob Newhart. This is going to be it for me as a sitcom actor. ``I love meeting people and traveling. That's what stand-up comics are supposed to do. I don't have a personal life, but I don't seem to require one. I think personal lives are overrated. I do a lot of one-nighters. But I get back to my home in New York regularly. I have as much free time as anyone.'' Seinfeld, who grew up in Brooklyn, said he decided at age 8 to become a comedian. ``I didn't really do any comedy until I was out of college, but I was always fascinated by it,'' he said. ``I liked Bill Cosby a lot when I was young. He was great. He's still great. I liked Alan King, George Carlin, Lenny Bruce, Robert Klein. I was always fooling around like kids do. I just couldn't stop doing it. It was fun to laugh and make other people laugh. ``I started out on amateur nights at the comedy clubs. I was nervous at first, then I really got into it. I knew I was going to make it from my first moment onstage.'' Seinfeld writes all of his own material because it gives his act a point of view. He said most of the episodes for ``Seinfeld'' were written with another comedian, Larry David. A few years ago, he appeared on ``Benson'' three times as the governor's joke writer. ``The idea was that the jokes would be so bad they would be funny,'' he said. ``But bad jokes aren't funny. They're just bad. That was my only previous acting experience. I had no idea what I was doing. That's how I'm most comfortable.''
