DOC.HEAD: Processed Rice Foods Find a Niche in Japanese Market
DOC.TEXT: Japan officially bans rice imports but there's a loophole that allows shipments of processed rice products. A major share comes from Japanese-financed companies in the United States. The niche market ``has shown promising growth for U.S. exporters,'' says James V. Parker, U.S. minister-counselor for agricultural affairs in Tokyo. Manufacturers are prevented by Japan's food-control law from importing cheaper foreign rice, so they have turned to importing processed rice items, which are not covered by the ban. Japan has stubbornly resisted attempts by the United States and other rice exporting nations to relax its import restrictions. Parker, writing in the June issue of AgExporter magazine, said the United States ranks second behind Thailand as a supplier of the processed rice products, which include rice flour preparations, rice crackers, rice mixed with meat or seafood, and rice wine. Most of the processed rice products are imported by smaller trading houses with ties to Japanese food processors and retailers. ``The big jump in rice product imports from the United States, at the expense of Thailand, can be traced to Japanese investment in the United States,'' Parker said. ``In the past year, Japanese firms have invested in four food processing plants in California.'' Besides ensuring that the products suit the palates of Japanese consumers, the companies are familiar with government import red tape and Japan's distribution systems. However, Parker said Japanese customs officials carefully analyze the rice mixtures to see that they conform to standards. And there are tariffs on the processed items. The niche market is relatively small, but it apparently is attractive to Japanese investors who are using it to circumvent Tokyo's official policy against rice imports. It also is attracting other suppliers. Besides Thailand and the United States, competition is developing from Taiwan, China, Australia, New Zealand, South Korea, Indonesia and others, Parker said. Although the niche market for U.S. rice products is a help, it still skirts the broader issue of Japan's flat-out refusal to open its import door to foreign rice. The rice issue came to one of its periodic heads in the last few weeks after Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter predicted April 9 that Japan would abolish its rice import bank by the end of this year, when the ``Uruguay Round'' of trade talks is scheduled to end. In a televised satellite interview with European reporters, Yeutter said Tokyo could not stand for world trade liberalization without looking at its own policies. ``And my judgment is that the political leadership of Japan will come to that same conclusion between now and December, and, therefore, Japan will open its rice market,'' Yeutter said. But Yeutter conceded there will be a great debate among Japanese leaders as to how far the rice door will open. ``No one is suggesting that Japan must open its rice market totally,'' he said. ``That's unrealistic.'' Earlier this month, Japan's minister of agriculture, forestry and fisheries, Tomio Yamamoto, told reporters in Tokyo that Yeutter had been interfering in Japan's internal affairs. Yamamoto, asked about remarks by U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills also touching on rice policy, replied that his country ``is not patient enough to endure further meddling by U.S. government officials in Japan's rice policy.'' Yeutter, after reading press reports about Yamamoto's remarks, fired off an angry letter to the Japanese official, with copies delivered last week to news organizations. Yeutter was U.S. trade representative in the Reagan administration before taking over as secretary of agriculture for President Bush. ``After working so hard over the past three years to manage this issue in a non-confrontational way, I am personally offended and deeply distressed to read that I am, nonetheless, accused of interfering in Japan's internal policy,'' he wrote Yamamoto. Yeutter said Japan ``agreed conceptually'' to negotiate on its agricultural import restrictions when Yamamoto's government concurred in the formation of the Uruguay Round of talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Meanwhile, Yeutter and other American critics say Japanese consumers are paying two to three times the world price for domestic rice because of their government's import policy.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, May 27

DOC.TEXT: Ivan F. Boesky calmly admitted he paid for inside information with briefcases full of cash as Wall Street's most celebrated felon gave his first public testimony since his 1986 plea bargain. Testifying Tuesday against former friend John A. Mulheren Jr. on securities fraud charges, Boesky recounted the crimes he committed with other players in Wall Street's insider trading scandal _ such as Dennis Levine, formerly with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., and investment banker Martin Siegel.

The federal fund that insures deposits at the nation's 13,200 banks lost money for the second consecutive year as a result of a continued hefty number of bank failures, the government said. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. on Tuesday reported a loss of $851 million in 1989, when 207 banks failed or required government assistance to stay open. The 1989 loss was down from a $4.24 billion in 1988 when a post-Depression record of 221 banks failed.

Citicorp's credit rating was lowered by another major debt-rating service, which based its decision on concerns about the quality of real estate and takeover loans at the nation's largest banking company. Moody's Investors Service Inc. said Tuesday it downgraded a total of $37.4 billion in debt of Citicorp, some of its subsidiaries and debt that it guarantees. The announcement came nearly one month after rival Standard & Poor's Corp. took similar action.

President Carlos Salinas de Gortari accepted legislative recommendations for a free trade agreement with the United States, but economists and advisers said it isn't likely to happen any time soon. ``The recommendations will be the framework in which ... my administration will carry on Mexico's trade negotiations,'' Salinas told 55 senators at the presidential residence Tuesday.

President Bush's son Neil voted as a board member of a Colorado thrift to approve $106 million in loans to a business associate who defaulted on the entire amount, a federal regulator said. Stephen Hershkowitz, deputy director of enforcement for the Office of Thrift Supervision, revealed the amount of the loss Tuesday after a House Banking Committee member pressed him to testify on Neil Bush's role in the collapse of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver. Bush, 34, was to testify Wednesday before the panel examining the $1 billion collapse of the thrift in December 1988. He was a director of Silverado from 1985 to August 1988, resigning two weeks after his father received the Republican presidential nomination.

The National Transportation Safety Board recommended that children now flying free in parents' arms be required to sit in separate safety seats on airliners. ``All objects must be secured during takeoff and landing, including coffee pots and luggage,'' board chairman James Kolstad said Tuesday. ``And yet infants, our precious children, are not.'' The proposal does not deal with who will provide the seats or whether children will pay fares.

A dispute over how fast Japan will liberalize interest rates on deposits could make banking the next area of trade tensions in coming months, a senior U.S. official said. After two days of talks with Japanese officials on financial reforms, U.S. Undersecretary of the Treasury David C. Mulford said Tuesday that Japan's refusal to finish deregulating interest rates within one year was beginning to ``look more and more like a trade problem.'' Vice Minister of Finance Makoto Utsumi said Japanese officials agreed on the need to completely liberalize interest rates, but disagreed on timing.

One of the nation's leading medical publishers, J.B. Lippincott Co., is being sold by News Corp. Ltd.'s book publishing affiliate to a Dutch publisher for more than $250 million. News Corp.'s Harper Collins affiliate said Monday it reached a definitive agreement to sell the Philadelphia-based Lippincott in an effort to reduce its $800 million debt and to focus on educational, religious and general books. The buyer is Wolters Kluwer NV, a publisher of professional, scientific and educational materials that is based in Amsterdam.

A former editor for The Wall Street Journal sued the financial daily Tuesday for $12.64 million, claiming he was fired and his reputation smeared by a false charge of plagiarism. Jonathan Kandell, the Journal's assistant foreign editor prior to his dismissal May 2, also demanded the return of original notes and other documents that he contended the paper's editors had kept, knowing they would support his position. A spokesman for Dow Jones & Co. Inc., owners of the Journal, said the company believes the suit is without merit.

Fresh declines in interest rates and a late buying surge helped the stock market extend its spring rally on Tuesday. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 7.55 points to 2,852.23, its fifth record high in seven sessions. Bond prices were strengthened by foreign buying and a news report that suggested the yawning federal deficit might not be so intractable. The dollar gained ground, particularly against the West German mark. Cocoa futures prices seesawed to 14-month highs amid mounting fears of supply disruptions from the Ivory Coast, the world's largest producer. Precious metal futures rose; copper advanced; grains and soybeans were mostly lower; energy futures were mixed; and livestock and meat were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: High-Tech Additions Alter the Office Desk
LaserPhoto GS1 of May 22
DOC.TEXT: If your image of the office desk is a flat, rectangular surface with drawers on the side, then get ready for the ``work station of the future.'' Officials at Steelcase Inc., the world's largest office furniture manufacturer, unveiled prototypes Tuesday of six futuristic stations designed by art college students. Among the prerequisites for each design: a place for a fax machine, videocassette recorder, personal computer and telephone. One model featured a mini marble conference table that folds up like an ironing board into a shelving tower with space for a VCR, fax machine and computer. Protruding from the sides of the tower are large fans, used as office dividers. When everything is folded up, it becomes a free-standing unit on wheels. Another model has a small work space with a computer but is linked to a larger station with what appears to be a low, round coffee table in the center. Images from the computer terminal are projected onto a flat monitor on the table, which is surrounded by three lighting columns. ``The worker reaction? Some would probably be attracted to them, and then some would wonder, `how did it land?''' said Paul Cornell, manager of behavioral and environmental research at Steelcase. Nineteen students at the Art Center College of Design in Pasadena, Calif., worked for three months on the Steelcase-sponsored project, called Smart Box, which is on display at Steelcase's Corporate Development Center through May 24. Another requirement for the work station is that it allow three people to work there at the same time to meet the trend toward group problem-solving _ but that it be flexible enough for the worker who wants privacy. ``As a result, you have components that can be moved, reconfigured to meet the situation,'' said Terry West, industrial design director for Steelcase. Some of the designs were relatively simple. One had two trapezoidal glass tops surrounded by posts, between which a tarpaulin is stretched to create a ``kids' clubhouse'' atmosphere, West said. The designs emphasized natural materials, lighter colors and warmer lighting to replace the ``hard plastics and flashy chrome'' of the 1970s, Cornell said. Through the program, Steelcase hopes to stimulate curriculum toward office furniture design at the art school, West said. However, he said some components of the work stations may be coming soon to an office near you. ``We are `blue-skying' with this project, but there is an anchor to real life,'' West said. ``It may not be that far into the future.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Has Business On His Mind
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev will try to forge some strategic business alliances to help revitalize his country's slumping economy during a post-summit visit to the West Coast June 3-4. The Soviet leader might squeeze in a quick ride on a cable car or a peek at the Golden Gate Bridge, but his mind will be on business during his trip to Stanford University and San Francisco, his hosts say. ``Gorbachev is really interested in business opportunities with West Coast business leaders,'' said Carol Piasente, director of communications for the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce. The chamber plans a luncheon for Gorbachev with leaders of 150 area businesses and local politicians. ``He wants to hear from the business leaders, learn about their ideas and concerns, and tell them what he is interested in. I expect there will be some sort of question and answer exchange,'' Ms. Piasente said. Gorbachev's advance party from Moscow, which spent Monday and Tuesday working out details of the visit with Bay area officials, said he is most interested in meeting executives in the areas of finance, agriculture, food processing and computers. Gorbachev is expected to arrive with his wife, Raisa, the night of June 3 after a six-hour stop in Minnesota following summit talks with President Bush in Washington. Tentative plans confirmed by officials Tuesday include a breakfast meeting June 4 with former President Reagan and former Secretary of State George P. Shultz. That will be followed by a visit to Stanford University, where Gorbachev will make a speech and meet scholars from the Hoover Institution and the School of Business. Hoover director John Raisian said Gorbachev will not be in the area long enough for ``substantive dialogue,'' but his visit could set in motion a relationship between Hoover and Soviet economists. Rep. Tom Campbell, R-Calif., said Gorbachev may be less interested in discussing economic theory than in meeting with business school professors about programs to teach Soviets how to start and run businesses. Gorbachev's visit coincides with a previously planned ``Soviet Silicon Summit'' in Santa Clara June 4-14, which will bring together leading Soviet and U.S. high-technology business leader to build trade relations. Even if Gorbachev doesn't go to that conference, his mere presence and his interest in economic development is charging up excitement among Silicon Valley executives. But not everyone is planning a warm welcome for Gorbachev. The Armenian community plans demonstrations to protest military rule and alleged human rights violations in Nagorno-Karabagh, an autonomous province in Soviet Azerbaijan. Estonians, Latvians and Lithuanians also are preparing protests to demand the independence of the Baltic states. ``We want (Gorbachev) to see what he's doing is really wrong, especially the (economic) blockade'' of Lithuania, said Joe Sidas, of the new Baltic Alliance, an umbrella group for various organizations of the nearly 5,000 Estonians, Latvians and Lithuanians in the Bay area. The Soviet Jews Bay Area Council, angry about ``virulent anti-Semitism'' in the Soviet Union, considered protests but decided not to because it wanted to acknowledge Soviet progress on Jewish issues, said spokesman Marshall Platt. Instead, the council plans to collect petitions outside the Soviet consulate and ask the consulate to submit them to him.

DOC.HEAD: Convention Ends Early, Bargaining Priorities Set
DOC.TEXT: United Auto Workers leaders promised to seek cost-of-living adjustments for pensioners in this summer's contract talks despite turning back a local initiative to require such inflation protection. The issue of COLA for retirees attracted the most attention of any proposal at a two-day special bargaining convention that ended Tuesday, one day ahead of schedule. Resolutions passed by the convention will serve as a road map for bargaining committees when they sit down with the Big Three automakers in the first two weeks of July. Asked after the convention closed if he would seek cost-of-living protection in pensions, UAW President Owen Bieber said, ``Oh, sure. We'll have the whole six miles out there.'' Earlier Tuesday, delegates killed an effort that would have required bargainers to seek COLA protection for the union's 446,000 retirees. In refusing to consider a resolution from a Flint, Mich., local, delegates backed Bieber's plea to keep negotiating committees unfettered. Bieber repeatedly told delegates that a resolution before the convention that did not specifically refer to COLA protection did not bar negotiators from seeking pension adjustments keyed to inflation. ``I do not believe that there is one single person in this convention hall, and certainly your president, who reads that language to preclude our attempting to get COLA,'' Bieber said. Indexing pensions could be extremely costly for General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp., the companies and the union have said. The union estimates such a provision could cost more than $1 billion a year for the Big Three. The UAW isn't required to bargain for retirees. But in the past, the union has negotiated lump-sum payments for retirees to counter inflation. Bieber cited five major goals of this year's bargaining _ better job security, higher wages, pension improvements, better health care and more responsive management. Contracts with the Big Three automakers expire at midnight Sept. 14. It's the first time in 11 years that each of the contracts expire at the same time. Some of Bieber's political allies broke ranks to argue for cost-of-living protection for retires. ``We must help these brother and sister retirees who have lost the battle against inflation,'' said Jerry Melillo, president of Local 1250 in Cleveland and a member of the UAW's Ford bargaining committee. Among other business, delegates also approved a proposal to merge three of the union's 15 regions into two. Some delegates opposed the move saying it would water down their clout. But the union, like the automakers it bargains with, is shrinking. During the past 15 years, UAW membership has dropped by about a third to about 1 million members. The three-region merger, which would affect members in Ohio, West Virginia and western Pennsylvania, would occur only when one of the regional directors leaves office. There are about 113,000 members in the three regions.

DOC.HEAD: Pinnacle West Rejects Fourth Offer from Utility Company
DOC.TEXT: Directors of debt-ridden Pinnacle West Capital Corp., citing success in early stages of a retrenchment plan, have rejected a $1.82 billion cash takeover offer from PacifiCorp. Tuesday's rejection of the latest offer from the Northwest utility was expected to heat up today's annual meeting of Pinnacle West. The Arizona utility holding company suspended common stock dividends in October and has told stockholders not to expect a return for several years. PacifiCorp, in turn, threatened to take its offer directly to Pinnacle West shareholders. Pinnacle West Chairman Richard Snell said the board also rejected as too low a $500 million offer by the Salt River Project utility to buy part of Arizona Public Service Co.'s service territory in the Phoenix area. APS is Pinnacle West's flagship subsidiary and has been its only profitable company for two years. PacifiCorp, based in Portland, Ore., last week made its fourth offer since last fall in an attempt to acquire APS through Pinnacle West. Company executives said they would not make another pitch to Pinnacle West directors. Verl Topham, PacifiCorp's executive vice president, said Tuesday his company was ready to take its offer to Pinnacle West shareholders. ``We have yet to hear any positive statement from Pinnacle West management concerning the future,'' Topham said in a prepared statement. ``Continued rejection of a better alternative for shareholders and customers is unacceptable,'' he added. ``We think it is appropriate for shareholders and customers to seek responsible action from Pinnacle West management.'' Pinnacle West's annual meeting was expected to be raucous even before the takeover rejection. After incurring a $676 million loss from its former MeraBank subsidiary, Pinnacle West reported a $551.4 million net loss in 1989. Snell said PacifiCorp's $21-a-share offer _ $8.25 higher than the company's stock price at the time _ was financially inadequate and did not ``reflect the value of this company.'' ``More importantly, this is not the time for us to sell this company,'' Snell said. He said it would take two to three years to win regulatory approval for a takeover. Shareholders would not receive their money until approval was won, Snell said, and by then ``Pinnacle West's business strategies will have significantly increased both equity and the intrinsic value of the company.'' He said Pinnacle West has resolved its problems with MeraBank, which lost more than $400 million before the federal government took it over Jan. 31. The prospect of better operations at the Palo Verde Nuclear Generating Station also bode well for the company, he said. Malfunctions have kept most of the $9.3 billion, three-reactor power complex out of operation since March 1989. ``I am convinced, based in part on discussions with the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, that we are very close to getting the plant up and running,'' Snell said. He said Units 1 and 2 were expected to be in operation before the end of June. Unit 3 has been producing power since last month at the generating site 50 miles west of here. Snell said PacifiCorp would be in for a long fight if it pursued a takeover by a shareholder proxy fight. PacifiCorp, which owns Pacific Power & Light and Utah Power & Light, has begun an advertising campaign here to solicit support from shareholders and APS ratepayers. The company is running full-page advertisements in newspapers along with radio ads and direct mail pieces.

DOC.HEAD: Service Ousts Food as Top Restaurant Concern
DOC.TEXT: Restaurants will be judged in the 1990s not by what they serve but how they serve it, experts said. With more two-income families, people value time more and are unwilling to put up with second-rate service, insiders in the $200 billion-a-year industry said Tuesday at the National Restaurant Association trade show. ``People expect top-notch service even in fast-food restaurants,'' Dru Scott, a San Francisco psychologist who advises organizations on customer satisfaction, told about 100 restaurateurs in an address. To survive, restaurants must use psychological tricks to keep the customer satisfied, she said. ``Think more of customer delight, not just satisfaction,'' she said. That means using only positive behavior in negative situations. If a restaurant runs out of a certain item, the server should not say, ``We don't have that,'' but instead should offer something on the menu that is similar as an alternative, Ms. Scott advised. If there's a long wait, give those in line menus to keep them interested. And if a customer complains, assure them that their comfort is your top priority, she advised. Seek customer feedback to learn how to please them, and encourage employees to serve better by developing ``games'' such as keeping track of which server tallies the biggest checks for the day, Ms. Scott said. John Iannotti, manager of Nick's Fishmarket in Chicago, said his restaurant has discovered the recipe for keeping the customer happy. ``Service is definitely our main priority,'' said Iannotti, one of thousands of restaurateurs who gathered at the five-day show. ``We want people to walk out of the restaurant commenting first on the service, and second on the food,'' he said. ``You really can't do that much with food'' to improve on another quality restaurant's menu, Iannotti said. Service is the variable that can determine if a customer returns, he said. Service showed up as a top concern among consumers queried for this year's Yankelovich survey, an annual study of 2,500 consumers nationwide conducted for consumer-oriented industries by the Connecticut-based consulting firm, said Bonnie Schwartz, director of restaurant marketing for American Express. ``We're moving into a much more financially conservative decade, with intense competition for discretionary dollars, which of course forces services to become more attentive,'' she said. American Express unveiled a program it calls the ``American Express Salute to Restaurant Service'' in which the company will give cardmembers certificates to award to restaurant staffers who give the best service. The staffer who gets the most certificates will receive $10,000 in travelers' checks. The customer who gives out the most certificates will win a culinary tour to France, Ms. Schwartz said in an announcement timed to coincide with the restaurant show. The nationwide contest runs from June through September.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Raises S&L Bailout Estimate
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Senate Banking Committee meets 10 a.m. EDT; lead planned. Also moved on the general news wire.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration says the savings and loan industry bailout will cost $61 billion next year, almost eight times more than an earlier estimate, documents show. Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady planned to provide detailed projections of the costs today before the Senate Banking Committee. Brady and fellow administration officials unveiled some of the figures Tuesday during the third round of budget negotiations with congressional leaders. According to papers distributed at the closed-door session, an administration ``guesstimate'' is that the S&L rescue will cost $116 billion over the next five years. At that three-hour meeting in the Capitol, Democrats and Republicans moved toward a consensus that about $500 billion in tax increases and spending cuts would be needed to balance the budget over the next five years. But they remained divided over precisely how much savings would be needed. Participants in the talks emphasized that the administration estimates of the S&L bailout costs could change dramatically. Variables include how the economy performs, how many additional thrifts fail and how successful the government is in selling S&L assets it takes over. It's ``a real hit and miss number,'' said House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. In the 1991 budget he proposed in January, President Bush estimated that the S&L rescue would cost the government about $8 billion next year. Fiscal 1991 begins Oct. 1. The thrift industry has been wracked by regional economic downturns and fraudulent managers in recent years, forcing the government to make good on its pledge to protect depositors' savings. The General Accounting Office, Congress' investigative arm, has calculated that it could ultimately cost the government $500 billion to deal with continuing S&L failures. Last year alone, the 2,878 surviving thrifts reported $19.2 billion in total losses, the Office of Thrift Management has said. Hundreds more of them are expected to eventually fail. The administration documents distributed Tuesday also showed that the White House has increased its estimate of the size of the deficit over the next several years. In January, Bush projected that an improving economy would push the budget into balance by 1995. But the papers show that the administration now says the budget still will be $32 billion in the red that year. Nonetheless, the administration estimates are much more optimistic than those embraced by the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office. According to CBO, the 1995 deficit will be $119 billion unless action is taken. Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., emerged from Tuesday's bargaining session to say that Democrats want a five-year package saving at least $500 billion. Sen. Pete Domenici, R-N.M., ranking GOP member of the budget panel, said Republicans preferred a plan in the $450 billion to $500 billion range. ``It seems to me we're beginning to see some daylight that that might be doable,'' Domenici said. The two sides do not expect to begin exchanging specific offers on how to slash the deficit for weeks. They meet again Thursday to continue studying technical issues. In recent days, White House budget chief Richard Darman has conceded that next year's deficit will be about $138 billion. Bush said in January that the shortfall would be $100 billion. The Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law sets a 1991 budget gap target of $64 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls, Stock Advances
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell sharply against the Japanese yen today, while the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index advanced. The dollar closed at 151.35 yen, down 1.05 yen from Tuesday's 152.40-yen finish. It opened at 151.65 yen and ranged between 150.60 yen and 152.00 yen. The dollar now has fallen 1.90 yen in the last two days. Dealers said market players were buying the yen against the West German mark for technical adjustments. ``Trading was very rough, speculative and directionless,'' said Mitsuhiko Kinugasa, a dealer with Daiwa Bank. ``Dollar-selling for profit-taking also prompted the yen's strength today,'' he added. But the dollar did not fall below the 150-yen level, where Japanese life insurance companies were buying back the U.S. currency, he said. Some $14.4 billion changed hands in spot trading. On the stock market, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average gained 238.21 points, or 0.75 percent, closing at 32,176.51. The index rose quickly in early trading as the yen's gains encouraged market players, traders said. Masahiro Umemori, a stock analyst with Nomura Securities Co., said many investors bought spot issues to take profits from price gaps between the spot and the futures markets. Buying slowed in the afternoon amid uncertainties over such developments as the currency union between East and West Germany, he said. ``Market players were generally optimistic, expecting that a slowdown in the U.S. economy would bring U.S. interest rates lower, which also would result in lower interest rates here,'' he added. Trading was moderate, with first section volume estimated at 630 million shares, up from Tuesday's 500 million. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond inched down to 87.40 points from Tuesday's close at 87.45. The yield rose to 7.085 percent from 7.075 the previous day.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Clean Air
DOC.TEXT: Here are the widely discussed alternatives to conventional gasoline for power motor vehicles, their benefits and tradeoffs.

Gasoline modified to contain more oxygen so it burns more completely, thereby reducing emissions of smog-causing hydrocarbons, carbon monoxide and toxic chemicals. Contains lower concentrations of aromatics, chemicals that boost octane but also cause toxic releases. Advantages: Existing distribution system, requires no modification in vehicle, has no loss of driving range. Drawbacks: Slightly more expensive. Not available in all grades of gasoline. Does not meet all toxic and smog emission control requirements in clean air legislation.

An alcohol fuel from natural gas. May also be made from coal, but environmental benefits then are significantly reduced. Advantages: Reduces emissions of air toxics such as benzene. Substantially lower emissions of smog-causing hydrocarbons. High octane rating. Easily blends with gasoline. Adaptable to current retail distribution system. Disadvantages: Highly toxic and emits formaldehyde, a carcinogen. Costs more than gasoline and provides less energy per gallon. Highly corrosive and will require modifications in vehicles. Difficult starting in cold weather. Burns without flame when at 100 percent. Lower energy content and lower driving range per tank.

An alcohol fuel made from corn. Advantages: Reduced emissions of smog-causing hydrocarbons, benzene and carbon dioxide. High octane rating. Available through renewal agriculture source. Blends well with gasoline. Disadvantages: Limited availability. Significantly more expensive than gasoline. Has lower energy content and lower driving range per tank. Corrosive to engine and fuel system. Difficult starting in cold weather.

Fuel already in use among a substantial number of fleets, including school buses and delivery trucks. Advantages: Abundantly available from U.S. sources with general distribution system already in place. Lower cost than gasoline. Substantial reduction in emissions of smog-causing hydrocarbons and toxic chemicals. Disadvantages: Requires vehicle modifications. Is bulky because it requires pressure tank, normally in trunk. Substantial reduction in driving range. Limited number of retail refueling stations.

Also known as liquefied petroleum gas. Advantages: High octane. Significant reductions in hydrocarbon, carbon monoxide and nitrogen oxide emissions. Cheaper than gasoline. Disadvantages: Requires pressurized tank and extensive modifications to vehicles. Driving range limited. Tanks prohibited in some tunnels. Available through limited number of fueling stations.

Automakers are pursuing development of electric cars and some prototypes are being tested. Advantages: Considered the most environmentally benign alternative to gasoline. Disadvantages: Technology for widespread application not anticipated for decade or more. Initial application expected to be limited for specific purposes such as short-range commuting.

DOC.HEAD: Debate On Disabilities Act Now Turns To AIDS Exemption
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs lead to CORRECT ``suffers'' to ``sufferers''.
DOC.TEXT: House and Senate negotiators must decide whether the Americans with Disabilities Act can limit the employment rights of AIDS sufferers and still be regarded as landmark civil rights legislation. The House voted 403-20 Tuesday to pass the disabilities act. The act guarantees the millions of disabled Americans equal access to jobs, businesses and services, transportation and telephone service. Three Democrats and 17 Republicans voted against the bill. Except for an amendment letting employers remove workers with ``contagious diseases'' from food-handling chores, the House bill closely resembles the Senate bill that passed last September on a 76-8 vote. The bill, which has White House support, has been hailed as the most significant piece of civil rights legislation since the 1964 act that opened doors to blacks and other minorities. ``We have just assured that 43 million Americans who suffer from a disability but who have great abilities, if accommodated, will be included in our American society,'' said Rep. Steny H. Hoyer, D-Md., lead House sponsor. ``This is landmark legislation which extends civil rights protections to those with disabilities,'' said Steve Bartlett, RTexas, who managed the Republican debate on the bill. ``It is legislation that is 20 years overdue.'' Both agreed that a bill would likely be ready for Bush's signature before the July 4 break. But Bartlett and Hoyer disagreed on whether the final version will include the food-service workers amendment, which was sought by the restaurant industry. ``When the facts are known ... the Senate may not feel it is necessary,'' said Hoyer, who attributed the amendment's passage to misunderstanding of the protections already offered in the bill. ``My view is that the Chapman amendment needs to survive'' the House-Senate negotiations, said Bartlett. ``Either the Senate can include it or the House can revote it. ... I think everybody understood it really well.'' Bartlett was referring to the 199-187 vote Thursday on an amendment by Rep. Jim Chapman, D-Texas. The amendment would let employers reassign a worker with an infectious or contagious disease so that worker wouldn't handle food. Both sides agreed that the amendment was intended to address irrational public fears about AIDS. ``This Congress should not license discrimination of any kind,'' Rep. John Miller, R-Wash., said last week. He said the same argument about public perception was used to justify discrimination against blacks. Dr. Louis Sullivan, the secretary of Health and Human Services, said the amendment is unnecessary because AIDS is not spread through casual contact and the bill already restricts people with dangerous infections. White House spokeswoman Alixe Glen said Tuesday the administration did not take a position on the amendment and that President Bush will sign the bill with or without it. Among key provisions of the bill: _A ban on job discrimination would be phased in over two to four years. Companies with fewer than 15 employers would be exempt. _Hotels, restaurants, shopping malls, drug stores, and business and professional offices, along with any other ``public accommodations,'' would have to be accessible to disabled people. _Transportation, public and private, would have to be accessible. Timetables for implementation vary according to system. _Speech- and hearing-impaired people would have access to telephone service by means of relay services. These services would have to be provided by phone companies within three years. Voting against the bill were: Reps. Bill Archer, R-Texas; Richard Armey, R-Texas; Joe Barton, R-Texas; Herb Bateman, R-Va.; Dan Burton, R-Ind.; Jim Cooper, D-Tenn.; Philip Crane, R-Ill.; William Dannemeyer, R-Calif.; Tom DeLay, R-Texas; Mel Hancock, R-Mo.; Wally Herger, R-Calif.; Jim Lightfoot, R-Iowa; Ron Marlenee, R-Mont.; Howard Nielson, R-Utah; Jim Olin, D-Va.; Ron Packard, R-Calif.; Norman Shumway, R-Calif.; Bud Shuster, R-Pa.; Charles Stenholm, D-Texas; Bob Stump, R-Ariz. Not voting were: Reps. Bill Alexander, D-Ark.; Larry Craig, R-Idaho; Ronnie Flippo, D-Ala.; Thomas Foley, D-Wash. (by tradition the speaker does not vote); Harold Ford, D-Tenn.; John Paul Hammerschmidt, R-Ark.; Donald Lukens, R-Ohio; Bill Nelson, D-Fla.; William Thomas, R-Calif.; Wes Watkins, D-Okla.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Soviet Union to Hold Referendum on Economic Reforms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 16 grafs at end to UPDATE with new quotes, more detail on proposals, plans to seek no-confidence vote, fears of hoarding and panic.
DOC.TEXT: The government plans to call its first national referendum to seek public approval of an economic reform plan that could throw tens of millions of people out of work, Soviet officials said today. First Deputy Premier Yuri Maslyukov told a news conference that the government believes it must have a clear indication of public support before instituting a program that will switch the country to a market economy. The plan is expected to double food prices and lead to massive closures of inefficient factories. No date was set for the referendum. ``If the public refuses to consent to the price rises, then perhaps we will have to resort to round-table discussions,'' Maslyukov said in response to a question. There have been calls in the Soviet Union by reformist groups for such discussions with the government and the Communist Party to accelerate political and economic reforms. The new plan sets target price increases for various sectors of the economy, including an 82 percent rise in energy prices, an average 43 percent rise in retail prices and a doubling in the price of food, which is now heavily subsidized. Deputy Premier Leonid Abalkin told the news conference the potential number of jobs that could be lost might be in the tens of millions, even under the slow, less-drastic response the government is recommending. Maslyukov said if the Soviet Union had chosen Polish-style ``shock-therapy'' reforms that instituted the economic changes in only two years, unemployment could rise as high as 40 million. ``We are unable to offer normal living conditions to such a number if they lose their jobs. It would the lead the country to the edge of an economic crash,'' Maslyukov said. The long-awaited plan was approved by Gorbachev's advisory Presidential Council on Tuesday and was to be presented to parliament on Thursday. Nikolai Petrakov, Gorbachev's top economics aide, made it clear in a speech to a Soviet-American trade group that he is unhappy with the proposal, which will increase retail prices on Jan. 1. Asked if announcing the price increases seven months before they take effect would cause consumers to buy everything now, and cause businesses to hold back their products until the price rise, Petrakov agreed. He said bluntly: ``This will create a panic, an economic panic.'' Vladislav Malkevich, chairman of the Soviet Chamber of Commerce, interrupted. ``That's happening now,'' he said. Petrakov nodded and continued: ``We'll have to see what the parliament has to say about the steps taken by the government.'' ``I think we should not lose these seven months,'' he added. A bloc of progressive legislators with similar discontent over the reform is planning to call for a vote of no-confidence in the government of Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov when he presents the reform package Thursday in a speech to be broadcast live on Soviet radio and television. The progressives lost a no-confidence vote in December when Ryzkhov proposed three more years of central planning before installing any market reforms. The Soviet economy's precipitous decline since December prompted Gorbachev and Ryzhkov to abandon that economic plan and accelerate transformation to a market economy. In the first three months of 1990, wages spiraled up 13.4 percent while production declined. Official, industrial output dropped 1.2 percent, but some estimates are as high as 5 percent. Petrakov said the most crucial battles had been won because the government finally agreed on the need to convert to a market economy. ``Many ideological barriers have been removed, barriers which prevented economic reform for a long time,'' Petrakov said, referring to the Communist Party's recent decisions to permit such ``capitalist'' notions as private ownership of factories. But the Presidential Council chose a slow five-year transformation, rather than the ``shock therapy'' working in Poland, for fear the shaky Soviet government could not withstand public anger over sudden jumps in prices, plant closures and unemployment. Workers are to receive 40-ruble raises, with smaller sums for non-working spouses and children. Enterprises then are to recalculate their books based on the new prices, and the government will discover how many will need subsidies to continue operating. Petrakov said 220,000 state-owned enterprises, or 70 percent of the total, will be converted to stock-based companies within the next several months, as a first step toward the government gradually selling the shares to individuals, companies and banks. According to Maslyukov, 60 percent of prices will remain controlled. These include prices for raw materials, energy and products made by the monopoly firms dominating the economy.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Official Says USSR Wants to at Least Double Soybean, Oilseed Imports
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union wants to eliminate wheat imports and intends to more than double purchases of soybeans while cutting back on corn, a top Soviet agriculture official says. But Ivan Skiba did not give a timetable for what would be a drastic shift in grain trade and he also said the Soviet Union would stick to its grain purchase agreements. One such accord, slated to be signed at the June summit between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev, would increase minimum Soviet grain purchases from the United States by more than 11 percent over each of the next five years. Skiba, who is chief of the agrarian department of the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party, discussed grain imports Tuesday in response to reporters' questions at a symposium at Iowa State University. He also said ``there may be grounds'' behind reports the Soviet Union has made late payments to suppliers but said he believed the problem was temporary. ``We do pay our bills. We don't borrow from Peter to pay Paul,'' Skiba said through an interpreter. He said that to meet new requirements for increased protein in animal feed, purchases of soybeans and other oilseeds on world markets would have to rise to 8 million to 10 million metric tons a year from the current 3 million to 4 million. Skiba said the shift in grain procurement policy would mean smaller purchases of corn, the leading feed for livestock. He also said the Soviet Union ``wants to do away with buying wheat.'' ``Theoretically we can satisfy our domestic demand'' for wheat, he said. Skiba's comments came in response to questions on recent record Soviet grain purchases from the United States and reports of criticism within the Communist Party that such spending is using up limited USSR reserves of hard currency. Hard currency has become scarce in the Soviet Union because of falling world prices for oil and natural gas, two commodities the Soviets have relied on to help finance their foreign purchases. In the 12 months ended June 30, 1989, the USSR bought 15.5 million metric tons of wheat from all world sources and 18.6 million tons of corn, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture. The U.S. share was 4.6 million tons of wheat and 16.8 million tons of corn. The U.S. grain purchases were a record. Skiba said some of that could be attributed to weather problems that reduced wheat production in the Soviet Union. Under a previously announced grain agreement to be signed with the United States, annual minimum American grain shipments to the Soviets would rise to 10 million metric tons from 9 million. A metric ton is approximately 2,205 pounds. Under the agreement, the USSR will be committed to buying at least 4 million tons each year of wheat and feed grains. In any one year, the Soviets may substitute up to 750,000 tons of one commodity for the other. The agreement for the first time includes sorghum and barley as well as corn under the definition of feed grains. The additional purchases under the agreement could be made up of wheat, feed grains, soybeans or soybean meal. The accord also will allow the Soviets to buy up to 14 million tons of grain annually without further discussion with Washington. The pact it replaces had an automatic limit of 12 million tons. But Skiba said that as the Soviet Union moves to introduce private farms and improve farm productivity it needs to prod farmers by reducing imports. He said relying on imports has caused the Soviets to become ``couch potatoes'' when it comes to productivity.

DOC.NOTE: $adv24
For Release PMs Thurs May 24
DOC.HEAD: Financial Planning: A Question of Cost
DOC.TEXT: What's a fair price to pay for financial advice? That always-thorny question can be especially tough to answer when you engage the services of a financial planner _ a sort of ``family doctor'' specializing in the health and well-being of your personal finances. Much effort has been expended over the past decade or so to create a set of standards against which members of this growing occupation can be measured. Still, would-be customers of financial planners can find themselves faced with a wide array of choices. One subspecies charges a flat fee, in the manner of a physician providing a medical checkup or a given surgical procedure. Another may work for an hourly rate, much like a lawyer or accountant. Still another makes its living on commissions for products sold, the way many stockbrokers and life insurance representatives do. Still others, like Bob Hewitt, a Monterey, Calif., planner and chairman of the 17,000-member International Association for Financial Planning, use a combination of those systems. Each type has its advocates, depending to a great extent on the kind of service the customer wants. The public at large shows no strong preference for any given method, according to the results of a new survey conducted for the IAFP by the Gallup Organization. Among the 1,058 households taking part in the April survey, the IAFP reports, 51 percent saw benefits to be gained from the services of a financial adviser. Within that 51 percent, respondents cast a split vote among the types of planners. For instance, they leaned toward commission and commission-and-fee planners over the flat-fee variety by 49 percent to 43 percent on the question of which was likely to make available the ``best investment.'' But flat-fee planners outpolled the commission and commission-and-fee groups as the ones likely to provide the most objective advice. That prompts the conclusion that ``the method of compensation, as long as it's fully disclosed, is not that important to them,'' Hewitt said in an interview. In most cases, a planner working on commission may be the logical first choice if you are operating on a relatively small scale or seeking ways to pursue a single goal, such as planning for a child's college education. By contrast, a flat-fee planner could be the likely candidate to consult for someone who was seeking to resolve broad debt problems or find a way to manage a windfall, such as an inheritance or proceeds from a winning lottery ticket. Even in cases where the customer has no preference, a strong case can be made for inquiring how much and through what arrangement a planner gets paid. Among the IAFP survey respondents who saw merit in getting professional investment advice, 95 percent either agreed or ``strongly agreed'' that all clients should get written notice in advance of how an adviser is paid. The idea behind that seems sensible, first of all, simply to help gauge whether any planner is worth his or her price. What's more, a knowledge of the compensation setup puts you in a better position to consider the source of the advice you are getting.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Thurs May 24

DOC.HEAD: Coca-Cola Buys Ads as Can Promotion Hits Snag
DOC.TEXT: The Coca-Cola Co., responding to complaints about its ``MagiCan'' promotion, ran full-page advertisements in several major newspapers today warning consumers not to drink the contents of the prize-filled cans. The Atlanta-based soft drink maker said ``a very small number'' of the cans are defective. The special cans, distributed in what is billed as Coke's largest promotion ever, contain a mechanism that is supposed to pop out various prizes rather than Coca-Cola Classic when the tab is opened. Coke officials say some consumers have complained that the mechanism has detached, preventing the prize from ejecting. Also, chlorinated water in the can, to make the unopened can feel like a regular container, has leaked out. The water is not meant for drinking. Coca-Cola spokesman Carlton Curtis said he did not know how many newspapers were running the ``Take A Good Look'' ad, though it was seen in The Atlanta Journal-Constitution, the Gwinnett (Ga.) Daily News and The New York Times. The newspaper ad includes a toll-free number for consumers to call Coke if they obtain a defective can. Randy Donaldson, a spokesman for Coca-Cola, said that as of Friday the company had received only 15 complaints since the promotion began May 7. He stressed that while the water in the prize cans tastes bad, it is harmless.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Dampened by Trade Data
DOC.TEXT: Prices weakened on London's Stock Exchange Wednesday, hit by disappointing British trade figures after rising on heavy institutional buying. Selling followed the news that Britain's merchandise trade deficit totaled 1.78 billion pounds, or $3.02 billion, in April, narrowing from 2.09 billion pounds in March but wider than the expected 1.5 billion-pound deficit. But dealers said stocks still looked well supported despite what one trader called ``a rather disappointing set of trade figures.'' At midday, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-stock index was down 9.4 points or 0.4 percent, at 2,301.9 points. Volume was 335.8 million shares, compared with 365.5 million shares at the same time Tuesday.

Stock prices turned downward today as traders cashed in some of the gains from the market's recent rise to record highs. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 10.67 to 2,841.56 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Losers outpaced gainers by about 7 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 511 up, 714 down and 552 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 59.86 million shares at midmorning. The Commerce Department reported this morning that new factory orders for durable goods fell 4.1 percent in April, providing a fresh sign of weakness in the economy. But unlike other recent signs of sluggish growth, this one did not prompt an immedinterest rates. Instead, prices of long-term government bonds dropped about $2.50 for each $1,000 in face value, increasing their yields to the 8.62 percent-8.66 percent range. Brokers said bond tradersate decline in i seemed wary about chances for a further drop in rates over the near term. That in turn seemed to encourage the impulse among stock investors to take profits after the Dow's rise Monday and Tuesday to new closing peaks. Losers among the blue chips included Exxon, down \ at 47|; Philip Morris, down \ at 44}; Deere & Co., down 1{ at 74], and International Business Machines, down \ at 117{. The idea behind that seems sensible, first of all, simply to help gauge whether any planner is worth his or her price. What's more, a knowledge of the compensation setup puts you in a better position to consider the source of the advice you are getting.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Thurs May 24

DOC.HEAD: New Milk Subsidies and Seafood Inspection in Farm Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs grafs 4-6, Under the House, to CORRECT details of price support plan. Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A revision of government support for dairy farmers and new regulations for the seafood industry are being included in the 1990 farm bill. The House Agriculture Committee completed work Tuesday on the key portions of its dairy section of the bill that will set government policy on agriculture for the next five years. Earlier in the day, the Senate Agriculture Committee approved legislation that makes seafood inspection part of the farm bill for the first time. Under the House committee's dairy plan, the government price per hundred pounds of milk would never go below $10.10. Under current law, dairy support prices have no minimum and could drop as low as about $8.60 per hundred pounds. With the new plan, the government price support would rise by at least 25 cents if surpluses fall below 3.5 billion pounds. If dairy surpluses grow in the subsequent year to between 5.01 billion and 7 billion pounds, the government could drop the price by 25 to 50 cents, but it could never drop it below a total $10.10 per hundredweight. If more than 7 billion pounds of surpluses result in any one year of the five-year farm bilan Sen. James McClure won his party's primary. Democrats picked a Boise businessman to oppose him. With all precincts reporting, Rep. Larry Craig had 66,249 votes, or 59 percent, to 45,689 votes, or 41 percent, for Attorney General Jim Jones in the GOP Senate primary. Craig, 44, campaigned on his conservative record over 10 years in the House, underscored by his drive to pass a constitutional amendment for a balanced federal budget. In the Democratic Senate race, businessman Ron Twilegar had 30,197 votes, or 64 percent, to 16,658 votes, or 36 percent, for political newcomer David Steed. Andrus was governor from 1971 to 1977, then served as President Carter's interior secretary for four years. He regained the governorship in 1986. A longtime opponent of abortion, Andrus angered anti-abortion forces when he vetoed what would have been the nation's most restrictive state abortion law a half-hour after the Republican-dominated Legislature adjourned on March 30. The legislation called for outlawing abortion except in cases of rape reported within seven days, incest if the victim is under 18, severe fetal deformity or a threat to the life or physical health of the woman. Fairchild, 37, said during the campaign that he would have signed the legislation ``in a baby's heartbeat.'' Abortion-rights advocates targeted lawmakers who backed the bill. The Right to Life Committee took aim at legislators who backed legalized abortion. The effort created 20 primary races on Tuesday's legislative ballot that pitted candidates with opposing abortion stands, but only nine involved incumbents.

DOC.HEAD: American Ponders Bid For Pan Am
DOC.TEXT: American Airlines is considering a bid to buy the Pan Am Shuttle, which carries passengers in the densely traveled Boston-New York-Washington corridor, sources say. Fort Worth-based American is conducting an internal study to determine whether the airline should try to buy the shuttle, and if so, how much it should offer, The Dallas Morning News reported Wednesday. ``They're taking a good, hard look at it,'' an unnamed source told the newspaper. ``They're seriously interested.'' Since the Pan Am board of directors announced last week that it wanted to sell the shuttle, the names of most of the major U.S. airlines have surfaced as potential buyers. ``It's not surprising that American would be looking at it,'' said analyst Helane Becker of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ``All the major airlines have to. It really offers a unique opportunity.'' Pan Am has hired Kidder Peabody & Co. to handle sale of the shuttle. Confidential financial information was being sent out this week to potential bidders, and business so far has been brisk. ``There has been significant serious interest in the project,'' Kidder senior vice president S. Lane Genatowski said Tuesday. Although he would not identify the interested parties, Genatowski said they include private individuals and publicly held corporations, including airlines. American officials would only say the company always considers buying airline assets that come on the market.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Mixed; Weather Provides Strength
DOC.TEXT: Forecasts for more wet weather lent modest strength to wheat futures and to new-crop corn and soybean futures in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade. Rain was expected to return to the Midwest today after a two-day dryout, posing a threat of further planting delays for the corn and soybean crops. Isolated thunderstorms also were forecast for the winter wheat regions of the Central and Southern Plains, where flooding in some areas already has lowered yield expectations. Analysts said buying sentiment in the wheat market was tempered by perceptions the United States will produce a large crop of soft red winter wheat despite excess moisture, and by predictions for beneficial spotty showers in the Northern Plains, where spring wheat is grown. In early trading, wheat futures were \ cent to 5 cents higher with the contract for delivery in July at $3.35 a bushel; corn futures were { cent lower to 1{ cents higher with July at $2.74\ a bushel; oats were { cent lower to } cent higher with July at $1.51 a bushel; soybeans were { cent lower to \ cent higher with July at $6.08{ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were sharply lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Some hog and pork belly contracts fell their respective daily limits in line with lower cash markets. Live cattle futures were .10 cent 1.02 cents lower with June at 73.50 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .02 cent to 1.07 cents lower with May at 85.50 cents a pound; live hogs were .28 cent to the limit 1.5 cents lower with June at 65.50 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.42 cents to the limit 2 cents lower with May at 67.65 cents a pound. Livestock futures retreated on Tuesday while pork bellies advanced.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Third Largest Cookie Company Sold to Taiwan Firm
DOC.TEXT: The nation's third largest cookie company has been sold to a huge Taiwanese company for $335 million, the chief executive officer of Wyndham Food Inc. announced. Ian Wilson, a San Francisco financier and Wyndham CEO, said Tuesday that about half the price will be paid in cash and the remainder represents assumption of debt, including $10 million in junk bonds. The deal with President Enterprises Corp., Taiwan's largest integrated food company, should close in June following the approval of Wyndham shareholders and federal regulators, Wilson said. Wyndham, founded in 1985, includes eight regional cookie companies in the South and Southeast including the nation's largest baker of Girl Scout Cookies. It sells mostly low-priced cookies under the brand names Murray, Jack's, Jackson's, Greg's, Barbara Dee and Plantation. Wyndham paid just over $200 million for the cookie companies, whose revenues topped $300 million last year. Wilson and his investors _ wealthy families and a few institutional investors _ have about $35 million worth of equity in the company. Founded in 1967, President Enterprises is a publicly held company with more than $1 billion in revenues, producing instant noodles, edible oils, dairy products and fruit juices. It is also the exclusive distributor in Taiwan of Welch's juices and Budweiser beer, and is the Taiwan franchise of Pepsi, 7-Eleven stores and Kentucky Fried Chicken. President wants to expand in the United States, and selected Wyndham as its first U.S. acquisition because ``they can get a good look at this country without competing head-to-head with a major food company like Keebler or Nabisco,'' Wilson explained. Wilson, chairman and chief executive of Wyndham, will stay with the company as a consultant for one year under the deal. But at the same time he'll be working with another food-products company he has assembled _ Windmill Corp., which is even larger than Wyndham after several acquisitions. Windmill, a holding company for specialty consumer goods, has about $350 million in revenues. Since March 1988, Windmill has spent $225 million buying Roush Bakery Products, Country Hearth, Martha White Foods, Frozen Specialties, Flour Pot cookies, and Pet Specialties.

Stock prices lapsed into a steady decline today as traders cashed in some of the gains from the market's recent rise to record highs. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 15.42 to 2,836.81 by noontime on Wall Street. Losers outpaced gainers by more than 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 527 up, 809 down and 532 unchanged. The Commerce Department reported this morning that new factory orders for durable goods fell 4.1 percent in April, providing a fresh sign of weakness in the economy. But unlike other recent signs of sluggish growth, this one did not prompt an immediate decline in interest rates. Instead, prices of long-term government bonds dropped about $2.50 for each $1,000 in face value, increasing their yields to the 8.62 percent-8.66 percent range. Brokers said bond traders seemed wary about chances for a further drop in rates over the near term. That in turn seemed to encourage the impulse among stock investors to take profits after the Dow's rise Monday and Tuesday to new closing peaks. Losers among the blue chips included Exxon, down { at 47]; Westinghouse Electric, down 1{ at 34{; Deere & Co., down 2[ at 73}, and International Business Machines, down \ at 117{. Precious-metals issues tumbled as the price of gold fell. ASA Ltd. lost 2 to 49{; Homestake Mining 1[ to 18|, and Newmont Gold 1| to 43]. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped .70 to 194.88. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was off 1.61 at 358.24. Volume on the Big Board came to 83.65 million shares at noontime, against 115.07 million at the same point Tuesday.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tops with 7 grafs to UPDATE with House beginning consideration of amendments, picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Automobiles cause ...;' subs 12th graf pvs, `Extend the...' to conform; deletes last 4 grafs to shorten. Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The House began considering a string of amendments to sweeping clean air legislation today including proposals requiring cleaner gasoline in smog-clogged cities and assistance to workers who lose jobs to tougher pollution controls. House Speaker Tom Foley, D-Wash., said he expected a final vote on the bill possibly as early as late Wednesday, but more likely by Thursday. Floor fights were anticipated on several issues including one calling for a $250 million, five-year job-loss assistance plan. The Bush administration has opposed the jobs assistance proposal as well as a proposal to require automakers to build 1 million cars that run on fuels other than gasoline. The automakers have waged an intense lobbying campaign against the car production proposal. White House Chief of Staff John Sununu told Republican members shortly before floor debate began that the White House had ``strong opposition'' to both the car production and unemployment assistance program and that both could threaten the legislation. The jobs amendment, sponsored by Rep. Robert Wise, D-W.Va., would apply to all workers. An attempt to require a much broader and more expensive unemployment assistance provision in the Senate failed by a close vote in April. Sununu stopped short of suggesting that President Bush might veto legislation containing either provision but said the White House wanted a bill without ``unnecessary amendments,'' said Rep. Sherwood Boehlert, R-N.Y., who was at the meeting. House negotiators have reached a compromise agreement on amendments that would require cleaner fuels to be sold in the most smog-polluted cities and also on requiring tougher controls on air pollution from offshore oil platforms. Both provisions are expected to be approved on the floor. Automobiles cause nearly half of the smog-producing pollutants that plague the nation's major cities. They also are the source of dangerous toxic emissions including a number of cancer-causing pollutants. Tougher air pollution controls included in the clean air legislation now before the House, and approved by the Senate earlier this year, call for sharp reductions in emissions from cars and trucks. Automakers will have to install new emission controls to meet the new standards, and oil companies will have to produce cleaner fuels. But some congressmen say neither bill goes far enough, at least in the nine cities where the smog problem is the worst and where motorists buy 22 percent of the nation's gasoline. Among the amendments cleared for consideration by House rulemakers late Tuesday were proposals requiring: _Production of 1 million cars a year by 1997 that burn fuels other than gasoline. The cars would be sold in nine cities with the worst pollution. Auto industry lobbyists, who oppose the proposal, argue the amendment calls for such stiff emission cuts that the cars could be run on only pure methanol or compressed natural gas. Supporters argue truly alternative fuel vehicles are needed to rid urban areas of smog. _The sale of cleaner gasoline blends that have specific oxygen content in nine cities with the worst smog and 44 other cities that fail to meet carbon monoxide standards. The requirements likely will be met only by selling a gasoline-ethanol blend of fuel. Despite a $1 million advertising and lobbying campaign against the measure by the oil industry in recent weeks, the measure is expected to be approved by the House. A similar proposal is in the Senate bill. Among the other amendments that were cleared for floor consideration were proposals that would: Extend the warranty requirements on pollution control equipment on cars; direct a phaseout of ozone-damaging chemicals such as chlorofluorocarbons; and require visibility controls for many national parks and wilderness areas. In addition to controls on auto emissions, the clean air bill requires industry to curtail smog-causing emissions; calls on electric utilities to cut 10 million tons of sulfur dioxide emissions that cause acid rain; and will require tough new controls on toxic industrial releases.

DOC.HEAD: Remington Shaver Owner Has Tougher Break Turning Football Team Around
Laserphoto
DOC.TEXT: Victor Kiam once got so excited watching a football play he knocked himself unconscious and speared his hand on a tennis trophy. He probably won't be doing that again. The New England Patriots' owner and successful entrepreneur, known for trying to buy businesses he likes, says he's still enthusiastic about his favorite spectator sport and the team he acquired two years ago. But after last year's dismal season, he's containing his expectations. ``I'm not counting one single chicken until it's in the broiler,'' said Kiam, 63, whose hapless Patriots were 5-11 and missed the playoffs for the third straight time last year, his first full year as owner. ``I'm just as enthusiastic about winning, but I think I have tempered my anticipation,'' Kiam said in an interview. ``I'm saying, `OK, it looks good, let's see what happens now.''' Kiam is perhaps best known as that gravelly voiced guy in the bathrobe who's appeared on television screens pitching the shaver made by his Remington Products Inc. As he reminds TV viewers and others who meet him, he loved the shaver so much he bought the company. Well, he likes football so much he bought the Patriots in 1988 from team founder Billy Sullivan, which Kiam at the time called ``the ultimate football fanatic's dream.'' His purchase was especially notable because other big-time takeover entrepreneurs like Marvin Davis and Donald Trump had unsuccessfully attempted to buy the Patriots earlier. Kiam was skinny growing up and concentrated on tennis, which eventually earned him a national ranking. He couldn't play football himself, but came to love its strategy and unpredictability. He admits he knocked himself cold once in his living room when running along with a play on Monday Night Football. Unfortunately for Kiam and Patriots fans, the team isn't nearly as successful as its owner. The Patriots finished fourth in their division and hurt for a quarterback. Important teammates suffered untimely injuries. ``Last year we had three of our key players out for the last exhibition game. You go home exceedingly depressed _ absolutely destroyed _ and say, `How do we recover?' That was so damaging. It's a tough one to come back from,'' he said. Kiam acknowledged owning a football team is different than owning Remington or The Friendship Collection, his wife Ellen's jewelry company. There's a lot more media attention and more focus on short-term results, similar to the pressure faced by companies answerable to stockholders. Kiam hated that when he was president and chairman of Benrus Watch Corp. ``I didn't like the fact that we were constantly saying, `If we do this now, what's it going to do to our earnings in this quarter?' You can't have two masters. You can only have one master, and that's the business,'' said Kiam, who left that company 12 years ago to buy Remington from Sperry-Rand. Nor does he relish the fact that the bounce of a ball can change the outcome of a football game. ``In business you can catch these miscues. It takes a real letdown in the organization, or a screwup, when your product gets affected. But the nature of athletics is they don't have the systems built into the structure and at any moment something can go wrong, and that is something you cannot control,'' he said. Nonetheless, Kiam said he's mesmerized by the same uncertainties. He even likes the shape of the ball because it's prone to unusual bounces. ``The reason I got into this is to be part of a football adventure,'' Kiam said. ``I don't think I'll ever give up the ghost, now that I'm into it.'' The Patriots will improve, if Kiam gets his way. After suffering large losses last year the franchise has already strengthened financially, partly because of a $9 million increase in the Patriots' share of the NFL's network TV contract. Kiam said the business could come close to breaking even. He also expressed confidence that he could make the team more successful on the field, with the same kind of perseverance he used to revitalize Remington, which at the time he bought it was a comatose business that Sperry-Rand was eager to unload. In what became one of the first successful debt-financed takeovers, now commonly called leveraged buyouts, Kiam borrowed the money to buy Remington, repaying the debt partly by trimming his acquisition's fat. He started by cutting 79 executive positions, eliminating perks like country club memberships, and consolidating operations at the company's headquarters in Bridgeport, Conn. He also cut the price of the shaver, streamlined its packaging and improved quality control, eventually increasing sales from $43 million in 1979 to an anticipated $350 million this year. ``I look at the Patriots like a business _ how are we going to do five, 10 years down the pike?'' Kiam said. ``When you get married, you don't say, `Well, I'm going to have a nice honeymoon,' and then move on to happy hunting grounds.'' Kiam's satisfaction at turning Remington around is so big he's written two books about his business triumphs and lessons learned along the way: ``Going for It,'' and ``Live to Win.'' He spent his first five years working on its shaver, but has since branched into a wide range of household goods, from an instrument that sucks up bugs to a device that keeps nose hairs out of sight. ``This thing, I think, is going to be a zinger,'' he said at his desk, holding up the latest gizmo, a hand-held tanning wand, which he demonstrated on his arm. ``This is a revolutionary new product. It certainly fills a need.'' He's also keeping busy selling belts, men's ties, travel accessories, precision instruments and a monthly magazine for day care centers. ``Live to Win,'' published last year, describes his fateful, self-inflicted knockout while watching the Monday night game. ``As soon as I recovered my wits all I wanted to know _ gore and all _ was, `Did they win?' ... We zealots are a breed of diehards.''
