DOC.HEAD: Tokyo Land Prices Scary, But Unlikely to Fall
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Japan's land prices are so inflated that many experts fear a sudden drop could devastate domestic financial markets and send shock waves throughout the global economy. Nonetheless, few believe such a calamity is likely. Although pressure for land reform in Japan has grown dramatically over the past year, any changes are expected to be slow and cautious. Japan has only 4 percent of the United States' land area but its real estate assets are worth four times the value of U.S. real estate _ $14.9 trillion, Economic Planning Agency figures show. A doubling in nationwide land values since 1984 has put home ownership out of reach for most Japanese and driven up business costs in city centers. This has led to calls for reform of what critics call a byzantine system of taxes and regulation that would make more land available and stop the spiral. High land prices also have become a trade issue. U.S. officials complain that high rents make doing business here prohibitively expensive for foreign companies, subverting Japan's claim that it is leveling the playing field for competitors from abroad. But analysts say the cost of significantly cutting land prices would far outweigh the benefits. Promises made by Tokyo during trade talks to increase the land supply through tax and other reforms, theoretically reducing land prices, are likely to happen over a long period of time, they say. The overheated real estate market has underpinned phenomenal growth in Japan's stock markets and overseas investment. The sense of wealth evoked by ballooning property values has fueled unprecedented consumer spending, contributing to four years of uninterrupted economic expansion. A Bank of Japan report issued May 9 said the government should find ways to cool overheated land prices gradually but avoid sudden measures that could hurt the economy. ``Experiences abroad suggest that it is important to forestall any turbulence which might arise from a sudden change in land prices, in order to maintain a safe and sound financial system,'' the central bank said. Economists here agree that a sudden drop in prices would have a disastrous impact on the stock market, on banks and other lenders. The integration of Japan's economy with the rest of the world ensures that such a shock also would hit foreign financial markets. ``The financial markets here are founded on trust in rising land prices,'' said Susumu Kato, head of economic research at Goldman Sachs (Japan). ``Lots of borrowing for stock trading at home and overseas is based on land collateral.'' A fall in land values would generate bad debts throughout the system and cripple major banks and securities houses, Kato said. Major financial institutions would face a cash crunch as the value of collateral evaporated. Many would pull out of foreign markets. That possibility could do particular damage in the United States, where Japanese investment has become an increasingly influential force, especially in the market for U.S. Treasury bonds used to finance the large federal deficit. A drop in Japanese demand for U.S. Treasury bonds could force the United States to raise interest rates dramatically to attract other buyers of its debt. Some economists say that would set off a chain reaction of events that could lead to a recession. Most overseas investment is based on borrowing against real estate at home. ``They don't have that kind of cash just lying around,'' said Ronald B. Talmage, assistant director in Tokyo of the British investment bank N.M. Rothschild and Sons. The risk of exposure if real estate prices here fall has worsened recently. Commercial finance and leasing firms, for example, have ignored Finance Ministry warnings and increased their lending based on real estate, said David Pike, manager of research at UBS Phillips and Drew International. After real estate-related loans grew 14.1 percent last year to an aggregate total of $310 billion, the ministry told banks not to let such lending grow faster than overall lending. Barring more drastic government action, there is little likelihood of a downward spiral in land prices because demand for land remains strong, Pike said. Land prices climbed only 2 percent in Tokyo last year, down from 23.8 percent in 1987 and 65.3 percent in 1988. But nationwide, prices jumped 17 percent last year as inflation spread to Tokyo's distant suburbs and other major cities. ``There's demand for residential construction and a shift in preference toward larger homes,'' Pike said. ``Growth in economic activity, new roads and railways, all these use land.'' Demand continues to rise on these islands crowded with 123 million people, but supply remains limited. The Construction Ministry estimates that tax laws and zoning regulations are preventing the conversion of 148,200 acres of farmland and underutilized sites in the Tokyo metropolitan area alone to commercial and residential use. Government plans to revise tax laws to encourage development of such land are unlikely to bring about a sudden change, the analysts say. ``If they puncture the land price balloon, it would shock the market, but they're not going to do that,'' Pike said. The Bank of Japan report called for reforms to curb property speculation and encourage more efficient land use. Financial institutions should also be monitored, it said. ``In our view, the report showed that the Bank of Japan was serious about the land price problem,'' said Kermit L. Schoenholtz, senior economist at Salomon Brothers (Asia) Ltd. He said the report, which attributed some of the land price inflation to easy credit, indicated that the central bank would keep interest rates high to help curb excessive lending to land speculators. The bank's discount rate, the loan fee to banks that strongly affects other interest rates, remained at 2.5 percent for nine years until last May. Since then, the bank has raised it four times to curb inflation and help support its weakening currency. It is now 5.25 percent. ``It's easy to make doomsday statements, but I don't think the problem should be exaggerated. The gap (between land prices and other prices) has been growing for 20 years. I don't see any of that changing overnight,'' Schoenholtz said.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Sunday May 27

DOC.BYLINE: Pepsi Cola Returns to India After 28 Years ^By JOHN POMFRET
DOC.TEXT: Pepsi-Cola went on sale in India for the first time in 28 years Wednesday following a bitter five-year battle to sell the U.S. soft drink in the tightly controlled Indian market. Pepsi, Seven-Up and Mirinda, an orange soda, hit the market in Jaipur, capital of the western state of Rajasthan, said Christopher Sinclair, president of Pepsi-Cola International. In the coming weeks, the drinks will be sold throughout the country, he said. As part of an agreement with the Indian government to ``Indianize'' the soft drinks, they will carry the prefix Lehar, meaning ``wave'' in Hindi. To sweeten the pot, Sinclair also promised the company would invest $1 billion over 10 years in bottlers, distributors and other small businesses in India. He also released a copy of a letter written to U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills in which he urged the U.S. government not to take action against India for alleged unfair trading practices. The compromises are expected to pay off, say analysts, who believe Pepsi is poised to dominate the market. India's $350 million-a-year soft-drink industry is controlled by three domestic soda kings, but industry analysts say there is room for growth. Indians consume an average of only three bottles of soft drinks a year, compared to 13 in neighboring Pakistan, 38 in Thailand and 550 in the United States. Indians view Western products as superior to their own. And their domestic soft-drink market currently faces turmoil because the government recently banned an additive, brominated vegetable oil, used by all three producers. Pepsi's position is also enhanced by the absence of its principal foe, Coca-Cola. In March, the Indian government turned down a Coke proposal to build a $3 million plant. ``The agreement,'' Sinclair said, ``shows that India can be a vital part in the system of world commerce and that it can accomplish it on its own terms and not on terms dictated by the West.'' But many view the Pepsi announcement as the last good news for foreign investment here, at least in the near term. With the fall of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi in November, India appears to have ended its brief economic liberalization and is again closing its markets to foreigners. Prime Minister V.P. Singh recently said India is interested only in foreign investment in high technology. Last year, foreign investment totaled only $200 million and this year isn't expected to be much better. Pepsi's experiences here testify to the difficulties of investing in India, analysts say. Pepsi has been accused of paying bribes, unfair business practices and even possible links to terrorists. Its investment proposal faced more than 20 parliamentary debates and 15 committee reviews. In a last-minute move, the government forced Pepsi to change the name of the soft drink from Pepsi Era to Lehar Pepsi because Era wasn't considered sufficiently ``Indian.'' The action cost Pepsi $150,000 in bottle fees. Indian newspapers hypothesized without proof that Pepsi might want to destabilize the Indian government because its operations are based in Punjab state, the site of a bloody separatist movement led by members of the Sikh religion. ``Our project here has been an unprecedented experience on all fronts,'' said Ken Ross, spokesman for Pepsi-Cola International. ``It's been very tough sledding all the way.'' The Pepsi project began in India in 1985 when Pepsi-Cola International submitted a proposal to the Indian government, which immediately rejected it. Pepsi then joined with a state-run company, Agro-Industries Corp., and the privately owned Tata Group. In February 1990, the first products _ potato chips under the Hostess brand name and cheese-flavored Cheetos snacks _ hit the market. The project, based in the northern state of Punjab, includes agricultural research, crop diversification, processed fruits and vegetables along with soft-drink concentrate and snack foods. Pepsi's share in the $15 million project is 39.9 percent due to an Indian law which restricts the holding of foreign partners in a joint venture to 40 percent. According to the government's terms, soft-drink production will be restricted to 25 percent of the project's turnover and exports of food items will have to be five times the value of imports. Indians were cut off from U.S. soft drinks in 1977 when Coca-Cola was forced to leave because it would not agree to the 40 percent ownership rule. Pepsi left India in 1962 because of slow sales.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Plunges While Dollar Ends Slightly Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites thruout to move up drop in gold prices, UPDATE with closing dollar figures. An AMs version planned by 5:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: Gold prices plunged Wednesday in hectic European trading following a confusing morning fixing session and amid reports of heavy selling by Mideast investors. The dollar, meanwhile, ended slightly lower against other major currencies. Gold lost $11 in London to settle at $375 a troy ounce, and $11.35 in Zurich to close at $364 an ounce. Earlier, in Hong, gold had risen $3.66 to $377.24 an ounce. By midday on the New York Commodity Exchange, gold was trading at around $364 an ounce. Gold began to tumble after the five leading London dealers had trouble matching demand and supply during a record 2{-hour morning London fixing session, traders said. The fixing was finally set at $363.25 a troy ounce. The fixing is an average price calculated twice a day by the five dealers from what they hear on the market and it is a guideline for other traders and investors. ``Nobody had a chance to get out of positions,'' during the fixing, said a Zurich dealer. ``And no business was possible.'' ``This decline wasn't predictable,'' another Zurich dealer said. Dealers said news of big Middle East sell orders, plus follow-through selling, escalated gold's sharp decline. The downturn also was attributed to a market perception that gold, having approached $378 an ounce, had to fall back, they said. ``The upside began to look vulnerable to some people,'' said a Zurich trader. The dollar's slight drop against other major currencies in Europe was attributed largely to speculation that West Germany might raise its interest rates. That would push up the value of the mark at the dollar's expense. A member of the Bundesbank's central council, Wilhelm Noelling, said in a newspaper interview that he couldn't exclude another rate hike. He said price and tax increases were likely as a result of the planned reunification of the two German states. Foreign exchange dealers said activity was moderate but diminishing with the approach of Thursday's Ascension Day holiday in continental Europe. Many traders planned to take Friday off as well to get an extra-long weekend, and Monday is a public holiday in Britain. In London, the British pound rose to $1.6975 from $1.6915 late Tuesday. It traded at around $1.69275 in New York. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday: 1.6682 West German marks, down from 1.6685; 1.4065 Swiss francs, down from 1.4175; 5.6125 French francs, down from 5.6175; 1.8740 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8760; 1,223.00 Italian lire, down from 1,225.25; and 1.1855 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1907. Selected dollar rates in New York at midday: 1.6745 West German marks, 1.41725 Swiss francs, 1,229.75 Italian lire, and 1.18525 Canadian dollars. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 1.05 yen to a closing 151.35 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 150.90 yen, and by midday in New York at 151.265. Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid price of $5.24 a troy ounce from $5.19 bid Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Summer Air Fare War Erupts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf and INSERTS one graf after the 6th graf with USAir plans.
DOC.TEXT: The nation's major airlines, seeking bigger market shares during the summer travel season, are battling one another with fare discounts on domestic flights. American Airlines joined the fight today, saying it would match cuts announced Tuesday by Trans World Airlines. USAir said it would match the discounts on a case-by-case basis. United Airlines opened the fray on Monday by running newspaper advertisements that contained coupons for $35 off round-trip tickets of $175 or more. The coupons are good on flights through Dec. 14 but excluding Nov. 16-30. The offer requires a Saturday night stayover and tickets must be bought seven days in advance of departure and no later than Aug. 31. TWA responded to United's move by cutting its domestic round-trip fares by as much as 30 percent for travel Tuesday through Thursday. TWA also is requiring a Saturday stopover and a seven-day advance purchase, and tickets must be purchased by June 7. The discount is in effect for flights through Dec. 13. For example, the lowest coast-to-coast fares would fall to $298 from $428.50. USAir said today it would honor the United coupons and would selectively match the TWA discounts. Spokesman David Shipley said USAir fares were already lower in some markets and would not be discounted in those areas. Northwest Airlines said it would also honor the United coupons, and was studying TWA's discount program and decide later whether to match it. Spokesmen for Continental Airlines, Eastern Airlines and Delta Air Lines said today their carriers were also studying the fare changes and had not yet decided what action, if any, they would take. The fare war comes during the airlines' big vacation season, and the discounts, in particular the TWA program, are aimed at vacationers. Passengers are likely to gleefully greet the lower fares, but the battle for bigger shares of the domestic travel market could take a toll on airline company profits.

DOC.HEAD: Dun & Bradstreet Puts Donnelly Marketing Up For Sale
DOC.TEXT: The Dun & Bradstreet Corp. said Wednesday it plans to sell most of the Donnelly Marketing division, which provides an array of services to help marketers of packaged goods and consumer services reach customers. The assets for sale include Carol Wright Sales, which markets merchandise to consumers by direct mail and distributes cents-off coupons through a cooperative mailing program. Its Donnelly Direct program, also included in the sale, is a major provider of consumer mailing lists. The huge business information marketer said the proposed sale is part of a previously disclosed strategy of focusing on key markets for its information services. Dun & Bradstreet said the assets for sale generated revenue of about $225 million in 1989 and were profitable. It said the absence of operating income resulting from the sale will be offset by investing and redeploying the cash proceeds. The company, which earned $586.4 million, or $3.14 a share, on revenue of $4.32 billion last year, has said it expects earnings to fall to the $2.80 a share range this year. The expected decline stems partly from lower sales and higher costs within its U.S. credit services business, stung last year by complaints from some customers who said they had been overcharged. The company said it has taken corrective action in recent months. J. Kendrick Noble Jr., who follows the company for PaineWebber, said he estimates the assets for sale could bring a price exceeding $200 million. The company said the assets for sale exclude Donnelly Marketing Information Services, the unit that provides products to help customers define and execute their marketing strategies. In addition, the company said it expects to make leaseback arrangements with the new owner that will give it continued access to the Donnelly Marketing consumer database, which has information on about 84 million U.S. households. Charles W. Moritz, chairman and chief executive of Dun & Bradstreet, said in announcing the sale plans that ``the long-term interest of D&B's shareowners are best served by focusing our investments and resources on the information-intensive businesses of our consumer-marketing information group.'' That group includes Nielsen Media Research, which compiles television audience ratings, and Nielsen Marketing Research, which helps companies track the movement of products through the stores and gauge the effectiveness of their advertising and promotion programs. Earlier this year, Dun & Bradstreet announced it would sell five other operations, Datastream International, Interactive Data, Neodata Services, Zytron and Petroleum Information, which had combined revenue of about $355 million last year. Datastream International is a London-based provider of investment information and portfolio accounting services to clients in Europe and Asia, while Interactive Data in Lexington, Mass., provides similar services to the U.S. investment community. Neodata of Boulder, Colo., handles subscriptions for more than 270 publications; Petroleum Information of Littleton, Colo., supplies drilling and production information to the oil and gas industries and Zytron of Menlo Park, Calif., puts information on microfilm for big computer users. No announcements have been made on the status of those sales.

DOC.HEAD: Sign Unprecedented Deal With Soviets
DOC.TEXT: France's state-owned Elf Aquitaine signed an oil exploration and production accord Wednesday with the Soviet Union, which the company's president called the first such Kremlin deal involving a Western oil concern. The ageement signed in Moscow gives Elf access to more than 13,500 square miles of Soviet territory north of the Caspian Sea near the Volga river, Loik Le Floch-Prigent told a news conference. He said it was the first full-scale exploration and production deal that the Soviet Union has signed with a foreign oil company. The Soviet government up to now has restricted such relationships to technical assistance on the part of the foreign concern. The Elf president declined to say whether this meant the French oil company and the Soviet government would be joint partners in the venture, or whether Elf had been awarded an exclusive area in which it could exploit oil and gas reserves. Le Floch-Prigent said details of the agreement, including the method of marketing the oil and gas produced, remain to be worked out. He said the Soviets will provide manpower, transport and communications support, while Elf will furnish and manage the technology used in the process in the same fashion that it runs operations in other foreign countries. Le Floch-Prigent said he expected the agreement to lead to a long-term collaboration, lasting 20 to 30 years, and that it could lead to cooperation with the Soviet Union in other areas, including refining, chemicals and cosmetics production. He provided no details on the financing of the exploration and production project.

DOC.HEAD: Can Get Once-Forbidden High-Tech Products After July 2
DOC.TEXT: Western nations have agreed to lift most Cold War-era restrictions on high-tech deliveries to East Germany, officials said Wednesday. East Germany promised the goods won't fall into the wrong hands. More than 380,000 Soviet troops are stationed in East Germany, and Washington has made clear it is not ready to lift the ban on many high-tech goods to Moscow. East German and West German officials announced that after their two countries become a single economic entity on July 2, East Germany will have access to a lot of high-tech products long barred from the former Communist-run nation. West German Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann said that as of that date, all goods ``with the exception of a small category of highly sensitive technology'' can be shipped to East Germany without export license or coordination with other members of the COCOM group. The decision was made ``in close cooperation with our partners in COCOM,'' Haussmann said in a statement. For the first time, East Germany will be able to legally obtain Western-made telecommunications equipment, machine tools and other goods, officials said. COCOM stands for the 17-nation Coordinating Commitee on Multilateral Export Controls, which has worked together since the Cold War days to try to keep the Warsaw Pact from obtaining products that could be used for military purposes. The United States has previously said it has no objection to easing restrictions for East European countries undertaking democratic political reforms. Washington has indicated it wants to keep more stringent rules for the Soviet Union itself. Haussmann said ``an important goal has been achieved'' with the decision. ``Namely, making available to the GDR (East Germany) those modern investment goods and technologies that it needs so that its companies can compete with advanced industrial lands,'' he said. A spokesman for the East German government, Matthias Gehler, said East Germany will strictly control access to the new products and technology and assure ``that there is no misuse.'' The West German Economics Ministry said among the items that will still be banned for delivery to East Germany are submarine technology and super computers. The United States and other COCOM nations have given their informal approval to the change, the Economics Ministry said. Formal approval is expected at a May 29 COCOM meeting in Paris.

DOC.HEAD: Former IBM Chairman Describes Complex Ties To His Father
With AM-Watson Interview
LaserPhoto NY30
DOC.TEXT: Many sons of famous corporate tycoons who take over the family business do so with trepidation. Thomas J. Watson Jr., son of longtime IBM Chairman Thomas J. Watson, was no different. ``I'd heard so many stories about sons of prominent men failing in business, and I could imagine their devastation at finding themselves unable to fill their fathers' shoes. I worried I'd end up the same way,'' Watson writes in his autobiography, ``Father, Son & Co.,'' which goes on sale Thursday. Needless to say, Watson did not fail. Watson's father had transformed International Business Machines Corp. from an obscure tabulating machine company to a worldwide powerhouse before he turned over control to his son in 1956. He died a few months later at age 82. Watson Jr. furthered IBM's growth, leading it into the age of computers _ an area his father originally shied away from. The book, co-authored with a Fortune magazine editor, Peter Petre, provides a rare firsthand account of the coming of age of a CEO and his company. Central to the story is the tense relationship between Watson and his larger-than-life father. ``In public he would praise me lavisly ...,'' the 76-year-old Watson writes. ``But in private father and I had terrible fights that led us again and again to the brink of estrangement.'' Watson left IBM in 1971 after suffering a heart attack at age 56. He later served as U.S. ambassador to the Soviet Union and remains IBM's chairman emeritus. He said in a telephone interview that writing the book has allowed him to relive his life and to clarify his relationship with his father. ``It's a love story. It is a story of a son who was terribly, terribly fond of his father. But the son didn't know how to express it,'' Watson said in the interview. ``He was the greatest man I ever knew.'' Among the book's insights into Watson Sr.: _He ran IBM along the lines now associated with Japanese companies. Employees sang company songs and recited company slogans. Watson's favorite motto, ``THINK,'' was emblazoned on posters and company newspapers, along with Watson's picture. But Watson's son worried that his father was creating a personality cult. _Watson Sr. believed that you got the best out of employees by treating them with respect. ``IBM offered the best benefits money could buy,'' his son writes, including education and company country clubs. However, he was tough with IBM's managers, often badgering them with obscure questions about IBM's operations. In the book, Watson Jr. describes himself as an aimless, spoiled youth who partied his way through Brown University while barely keeping his grades high enough to keep from being expelled. Watson decided to join IBM after college, despite having little idea what he wanted to do with his life. He went through IBM's sales training program, where he first became painfully aware of how hard it was to be the boss's son. On his first sales call, a corporate executive gave him a lecture on the difficulty of following his father's footsteps. He told of one such young man who became a drunk from too much high living and was fired by his father. ``I was tempted to abandon my IBM career on the spot,'' Watson writes. But he perservered, and rose to become IBM's top salesman after a lucrative account was added to his sales territory to make him look good. The achievement won him headlines in the company newspaper. ``I felt demeaned,'' Watson writes. ``Everyone knew that I was the old man's son, and that otherwise I never could have sold so much in such a short time.'' Watson escaped the pressures of IBM and his father for several years by flying for the Air Force during World War II. But at the war's end, he decided to return to his father's company. Watson rose quickly, and was named president in 1952. But he never escaped the heavy hand of his father as IBM entered a period of explosive growth. ``I don't think my father realized how far he was pushing me,'' Watson writes. ``There were times when I wondered if I was going to have a nervous breakdown.'' In 1956, Watson was preparing to sail in a yacht race when he was called back to New York. His father was in the hospital, and soon died. Watson ran the company on his own for five years. But in 1961, he relinquished the job of president to prepare for an eventual successor. He kept the job of chief executive and also became chairman. That period led to what Watson Jr. calls the biggest mistake of his life. Watson believed that his younger brother, Dick, who was in charge of IBM's international operations, would be his natural successor as chief executive. But instead of preparing Dick for the job outright, he set him up in a competition with other executives. Dick Watson ran into trouble during the launch of a computer line that was crucial to IBM's future. The project was severely behind schedule. Watson decided his brother just couldn't handle the job and gave it to another executive. That put Dick Watson out of the running for president. ``I felt nothing but shame and frustration at the way I'd treated him,'' Watson writes. Watson says he never regrets leaving IBM before retirement age. Having a heart attack made him realize how much he had been pushing himself. ``I've never missed IBM as IBM,'' he said in the interview. ``I've just missed things to do sometimes.'' Watson, who has six daughters and a son, also doesn't regret the fact that none of them is involved with the company today. He said he didn't want them to feel the pressure he felt from his father. ``I don't think I ever thought of them working at IBM,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Say First Quarter Profits Rise 39 Pct on Extraordinary Gain
DOC.TEXT: BAT Industries PLC reported a 39 percent gain in first-quarter earnings Wednesday, largely because of a one-time gain resulting from an antitakeover strategy that helped repulse a hostile takeover bid. On a pretax basis, the British conglomerate said earnings sank 27 percent because of winter storm-related claims at BAT's Eagle Star insurance unit. BAT said earnings for the three months ended March 31 totaled $445 million, vs. $320 million in the same period a year earlier when there were no extraordinary items. It said pretax earnings totaled $393 million, down from $541 million. Sales rose 6.5 percent to $8.7 billion from $8.1 billion. Sales gains by the group's tobacco and other interests offset a slight overall decline in financial services, the company said. Chairman Patrick Sheehy said the first quarter ``will not be representative of the year as a whole. I expect the group to be able to make solid progress in what is very much a transitional year.'' BAT is completing the disposal of several large U.S. retail stores, including Saks Fifth Avenue and Marshall Field's, and the spinoff of its huge paper and pulp manufacturer, Wiggins Teape Appleton. These were among various measures taken to fend off a hostile takeover from financier Sir James Goldsmith's Hoylake Investments group, which bid $22.7 billion for the company last year. The Anglo-French financier and his fellow investors dropped the offer in April because of regulatory frustrations. BAT said its reshaping plan yielded a $243 million extraordinary gain in the quarter, the result of the sale of its 69 percent interest in V.G. Instruments PLC. The figures were converted at the current exchange rate of $1.70 to the pound.

DOC.HEAD: Award Shareholders $13 Million
DOC.TEXT: A judge has approved a $13 million settlement for shareholders of SmithKline Beckman Corp. who sued the company last year after it announced a merger with the Beecham Group PLC. The $13 million will be paid to shareholders of SmithKline who held shares between April 10, 1989, when the merger was first announced, and July 26, 1989, when the deal was consummated and SmithKline Beecham was formed. The approval by Common Pleas Court Judge I. Raymond Kremer on Tuesday will benefit about 25,000 shareholders. Dianne M. Nast, one of several attorneys representing shareholders in the case, said distribution of the proceeds would begin in 30 days if no appeals are filed. The $13 million will be prorated based on the number of shares held by each member of the class. Nearly two dozen attorneys representing the shareholders will share a separate $1.9 million as reimbursement for their services in the case, Nast said. Beginning on April 12, 1989, nine lawsuits were filed against SmithKline Beckman, its officers and directors and Beecham Group. The cases were later consolidated. The suits alleged that SmithKline ``has engaged in conduct which has been detrimental to its shareholders.'' Among the allegations in the suits were accusations that the individual defendants had failed in their duty to seek potential buyers for SmithKline at a higher price than that offered by Beecham.

DOC.HEAD: Settle Lawsuit Over Jet Engine Design
DOC.TEXT: General Electric on Wednesday announced a settlement of its $1.15 billion breach-of-contract suit against Daimler-Benz, the West German technology giant working with both GE and its fiercest U.S. rival in designing jet engines. GE's lawsuit claimed that Daimler's new alliance with Pratt & Whitney, a division of United Technologies Corp., breached an agreement it already had with GE to develop high-thrust engines for jumbo jets. Under the settlement, currently pending in U.S. District Court in New York, Motoren und Turbinen Union, the aerospace division of Daimler-Benz, will be free to continue its cooperation with Pratt & Whitney on the high-thrust PW4000 engine, GE said in a press release. In return, Daimler-Benz and MTU agreed to drop out of GE's parallel venture _ the development of the GE90 engine, GE said. Daimler-Benz also agreed to return to GE any trade secrets it has gained so far from its cooperation in the GE90 program and to keep confidential all other proprietary information it has gained from cooperating with GE. Daimler-Benz also agreed to renegotiate its contract with GE under which the companies cooperate in designing smaller engines to power most large commercial aircraft such as the Boeing 747 and the McDonnell Douglas MD-11. GE said the renegotiation of that contract will provide it with ``significant'' additional revenues from the sales of engines and parts. GE spokesman George Jamison would not estimate the value of the renegotiation. David Franus, an aerospace industry analyst for Forecast International in Newtown, Conn., said the renegotiation could be worth as much as $500 million to GE over the next 15 years. That arrangement gives GE a partner in what is now the most lucrative slice of the jet engine industry. Most large commercial aircraft are powered by engines that range in power from 50,000 pounds of thrust to 75,000. But the industry's giants are scrambling to develop larger, high-thrust engines to power the bigger, wider commercial aircraft of the future, and the settlement leaves GE without a partner in that venture. ``It still comes with that slap in the face _ that for engines over 75,000 pounds of thrust, GE has lost a longtime partner,'' Franus said. ``GE is going to have to scramble to find other partners.'' Another industry analyst, Paul Turk of Virginia-based Avmark, said GE faces only minimal risk of losing trade secrets to Pratt & Whitney. ``That's a short-term concern,'' he said. ``These things change twice a week.'' He said most of the inside information from GE that would be of value to Pratt & Whitney would be financial rather than technological, and would probably not differ significantly from Pratt & Whitney's own information. UTC spokesman Dan Harrison said the Hartford-based company would have no comment on the lawsuit, in which it was not a party. He added that UTC and Daimler-Benz are still working out the details of their alliance. When GE first filed the lawsuit, Harrison said neither UTC nor Pratt & Whitney ``needs, wants or would accept confidential GE information.''

DOC.HEAD: Claims Defunct Shipyard Hid Financial Troubles
DOC.TEXT: Operators of a Finnish shipyard concealed financial troubles before collapsing in bankrupcty with millions of dollars worth of unfinished work, a major cruise line alleged Wednesday. Carnival Cruise Lines Inc. is seeking $700 million from two Finland-based companies that owned Wartsila Marine Industries Inc., which filed for bankrupcty last November before completing a three-ship contract for Carnival. The suit, filed in U.S. District Court in Miami, claims Miami-based Carnival suffered $400 million in additional construction costs and lost passenger bookings. The suit also seeks $300 million in punitive damages from Oy Wartsila Ab and Valmet Oy Ab. In 1987, Carnival signed a $600 million contract with Wartsila for three 2,600-passenger ships. But the bankruptcy halted all work at the Helsinki yard, which was taken over by several shipowners, the Union Bank of Finland and the Finnish government. The new yard, renamed Masa-Yards, completed work on the Fantasy, which began service March 2. The Ecstasy is under construction at Masa-Yards and scheduled for delivery in April 1991. Carnival, which has an 11 percent stake in Masa, is looking at several European shipyards for the Sensation, the third vessel from the Wartsila contract, said company spokesman Tim Gallagher. The suit alleges the two companies misrepresented the financial condition of the Wartsila yard in order to get the Carnival contract. Among the allegations is that Warstila principals transferred overvalued assets and hid losses from some shipbuilding contracts. Carnival attorney Lewis Clayton said Wednesday he did not know whether the defendants had hired attorneys in the United States. Officials at the two companies could not immediately be reached in Finland for comment. Carnival recently signed a $700 million contract with Fincantierri Shipyards of Trieste, Italy, for three vessels for its Holland America Line subsidiary. Carnival, which presently operates 15 ships worldwide, blamed ship-refurbishing projects for a 46 percent decline in first-quarter profits this year. Income for the quarter fell to $25.2 million, or 19 cents a share, compared with $46.3 million, or 34 cents a share, for the same period last year. During the period, two ships were tied up for maintenance and improvements. Revenues for the quarter ended Feb. 28 rose to $259.4 million from $231.8 million, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Close Mixed In Dull Trading
DOC.TEXT: Wheat futures prices closed mostly lower while corn and soybeans advanced modestly in quiet trading Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Traders were cautious amid the uncertainty over future sales of U.S. grain to China and the Soviet Union. The Bush administration is expected to announce soon whether it will renew China's favorable trade status. Analysts say economic woes in the Soviet Union could force Moscow to reduce grain imports. The two nations are among the largest foreign buyers of U.S. agricultural products. Pessimism about export sales was offset in the corn and soybean markets, though, by reports of more rain in the Midwest. Heavy precipitation during the past two weeks has slowed the pace of corn and soybean planting and further delays could affect crop yields, especially for corn. DOC.HEAD: Watson Says Today's IBM Managers Have Tougher Time Than He Did
With AM-IBM-Watson
DOC.TEXT: Running Big Blue is an even tougher job today, concedes former Chairman Thomas J. Watson Jr. Watson details the challenges of his 15 years at the helm of International Business Machines Corp. in his newly released autobiography, ``Father, Son & Co.'' In an interview with The Associated Press, he said the demands of the job have grown considerably for current IBM chief John F. Akers. ``I had real trouble managing $7 billion (in annual revenue), and he's managing $70 billion,'' Watson said. Another fundamental change: The company has shifted its focus from rentals to sales, Watson said. In 1956, when Watson took over from his father, Thomas J. Watson, nearly all of IBM's machines were rented. By selling one-year rental and maintenance contracts, instead of the machines themselves, IBM was guaranteed a steady annual revenue stream, Watson said. ``With rental, you didn't have to sell anything. As long as you kept them (customers) satisfied, then you got the same rental this year as next year,'' he said. ``It makes for a much steadier financial base.'' But that comforting arrangement was challenged by an antitrust suit filed by the federal government in 1952. Settling the suit required IBM to start selling some of its machines, recalled Watson, who retired from IBM in 1971. Watson says the computer industry has changed dramatically since his departure. One of the most profound changes is the miniaturization of electronic components that culminated in the development of microprocessors, or computers on a silicon chip, which weren't commercially available until several years after Watson left IBM. ``It was thrilling for me to see us move into electronics, but I had never any idea that somebody could give me something an eighth of an inch square and maybe an inch long and say that could store a 400-page book,'' he said, describing a device he was shown on a recent visit to an IBM facility. Watson says he has full confidence in IBM's current management despite the company's lower profits of recent years and increasing competition from upstart competitors. But he says he's glad he left the business when he did. ``Perhaps the industry was the best at the time to be in,'' he said of his tenure. ``Ten years earlier, it wouldn't have been an industry, and 20 years later it would have been terribly difficult, as it is today.''
