DOC.HEAD: UAW's Short And Mostly Sweet Convention Sends Good Signal To Automakers
DOC.TEXT: A short, and mostly sweet, United Auto Workers bargaining-strategy convention is sending a good signal to the nation's Big Three automakers, analysts said Wednesday. But that doesn't mean the summer bargaining will be a cakewalk. Delegates to the two-day meeting approved 120 pages of resolutions laying an agenda for the union's three bargaining committees. Talks between the union and General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. open in July. The contracts expire Sept. 14. Officials of each of the Big Three automakers declined to comment Wednesday on specific UAW bargaining positions. UAW President Owen Bieber outlined five priorities for the union's negotiators: job security, wage improvements, maintaining health-care benefits, pension improvements and making management more accountable to workers. ``They seem pretty rational, they are not asking for the moon,'' said auto analyst Charles Brady of Oppenheimer & Co. in New York. ``I think they have finally come to grips with the reality of the situation _ the degree of competition that exists in the automotive world and particularly in the United States.'' During the 1980s, the role of the Big Three on the world's automotive stage changed drastically, mostly because competition from Japan-based automakers eroded their dominance. As the companies' roles changed, so did the UAW's. Membership in the nation's largest industrial union dropped from a peak of about 1.5 million in the mid-1970s to about 1 million today. The UAW's leadership in the U.S. labor movement, particularly in setting model contracts for other heavy industries, has eroded. Consequently, the general priorities of the UAW have changed from wages and benefits to job security. ``Clearly, there is one key issue, and that's job security,'' said auto analyst Joseph Phillippi of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in New York. Job security's emergence as the No. 1 bargaining issue was no surprise at the convention Monday and Tuesday. ``Fact number one is that we have a more urgent need for job security and a more legitimate claim to job and income security for our members ... than at any previous time in our history,'' Bieber said Monday. Current contracts with the UAW permit plant closings only when products made at the factory suffer a sales slump. GM and Chrysler have used that clause to justify closing eight assembly plants and laying off 17,000 employees during the past three years. ``We must compel them (automakers) to retain all current workers unless their ability to survive is severely at risk as a result of conditions beyond their control,'' Bieber said in a speech to the convention. Just what causes such a financial hardship may be a bone of contention in itself, said Brady, the Oppenheimer analyst. ``Keeping a plant operating when it's not productive is a financial hardship,'' he said. ``I think the more enlightened members of the union have said the only real way to job security is to get the consumer to demand our product.'' UAW bargainers also are going to have to pay attention to the 446,000 retirees carried on pension rolls. Most of the debate at the UAW convention centered on providing cost-of-living adjustments, or COLAs, for retirees. The proposal puts Bieber and the UAW leadership in a tough spot. Members are demanding it, but Bieber knows, as automakers have said, that COLAs for retirees are extremely expensive. Some estimates put the cost at more than $1 billion a year for the Big Three. If such a proposal were adopted, other contractual benefits would be cut, some have contended. Bieber told delegates he didn't want bargaining committees handcuffed by proposing a cost-of-living adjustment as the only inflation hedge for retirees. Auto analyst Scott Merlis of Morgan Stanley & Co. said he was optimistic about the upcoming contract talks. ``What struck me about the demands is that never before have we had so much potential for easy agreement when it comes to pension,'' he said. ``I think management will give some kind of inflation protection, some kind of lump-sum payment.'' He said the atmosphere at the convention modified his thought of a month or so ago that a UAW strike was more likely this year than in recent years. ``The leadership ultimately has to be responsive to the rank and file,'' Merlis said. ``And with the lack of dissidents, the odds of a meaningful strike become much less likely.''

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Sharply Lower
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil prices tumbled in frenzied trading Wednesday as dealers worried that continued overproduction from OPEC members would result in a worldwide oil glut. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the July contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, slipped 78 cents to settle at $18.14 a 42-gallon barrel, after falling as low as $17.95 at one point Wednesday. Other contract months also fell sharply. The June WTI contract, which expired Tuesday, had declined 58 cents in that session. Peter Beutel, an energy analyst at Elders Futures Inc., said signs of a possible oil glut already are emerging, making oil traders nervous. He noted that northwestern Europe is being flooded with crude from Iran, and that the Trans-Panama pipeline has run out of storage space for crude. In addition, a report released late Tuesday by the American Petroleum Institute said crude oil stocks had reached a larger-than-expected 4.4-million barrel buildup at the end of last week. Beutel said last week's stock levels were the highest in about eight years. Traders weren't optimistic about reducing the current oversupply of oil. Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries earlier this month agreed to production cuts, but the cartel's output has not fallen enough to move oil prices higher. Among refined petroleum prices traded Wednesday on the New York Merc, the June contract for wholesale heating oil fell 1.19 cents to 50.21 cents a gallon, after losing 0.04 cent Tuesday. June unleaded gasoline settled at 62.51 cents a gallon, down 0.53 cent. The contract had fallen 0.31 cent Tuesday. In natural gas trading, the July contract fell to $1.602 per 1,000 cubic feet from $1.613 Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Highest Closes in Dow Jones Industrials Average
With AM-Wall Street
Two-Year Yields Down
DOC.TEXT: Yields on two-year Treasury notes fell in Wednesday's auction to the lowest level since February. The average yield was 8.52 percent, down from 8.90 percent at the last auction on April 25. It was the lowest rate since two-year notes averaged 8.50 percent on Feb. 21. The notes will carry a coupon interest rate of 8.5 percent, with each $10,000 in face value selling for $9,996.40. A total of $10.88 billion in notes was sold out of bids totaling $37.57 billion.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices inched ahead on the strength of some late buying Wednesday, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average to its third straight record closing high. Dow Jones's average of 30 blue chips rose 4.03 to 2,856.26, extending its gain over the last three sessions to 36.35 points. Advancing issues and declines were about evenly balanced in the overall tally on the New York Stock Exchange, with 753 up, 739 down and 517 unchanged. The Commerce Department reported Wednesday morning that new factory orders for durable goods fell 4.1 percent in April, providing a fresh sign of weakness in the economy. As the day passed, the news helped to foster a moderate decline in interest rates. Prices of long-term government bonds rose almost $5 for each $1,000 in face value, reducing their yields to the 8.57 percent-8.60 percent range. Still, brokers said bond traders seemed wary about chances for any extensive further drop in rates over the near term. That in turn seemed to encourage the impulse among stock investors to cash in a few of the market's recent gains. Precious-metals issues tumbled as the price of gold fell $11.50 an ounce to $364.60 on the Commodity Exchange in New York amid talk of gold sales by major investors in the Middle East. ASA Ltd. lost 2] to 49[; Homestake Mining 1{ to 18\; Placer Dome 1 to 16[; American Barrick Resources 1 to 18{, and Newmont Gold 1{ to 43{. Energy issues also were mostly lower as oil prices sagged. Exxon dropped { to 47]; Amoco { to 53\; Chevron | to 69]; Schlumberger } to 57, and Halliburton ] to 48}. Gainers among the blue chips included International Business Machines, up 1 at 118}; Coca-Cola, up 1] at 44~; Philip Morris, up [ at 45[; General Motors, up [ at 49, and McDonald's, up { at 34[. Donaldson Co. rose 2} to 30. Late Tuesday the company posted higher quarterly profits and raised its dividend. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 172.33 million shares, down from 203.35 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 205.58 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $6.47 billion, or 0.19 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained .27 to 195.85. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 1.12 to 419.32, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up .86 at 359.29. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market climbed 2.98 to 456.87. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 359.65, down .20.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Futures Tumble On Second Big Mideast Sale This Year
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices tumbled to seven-month lows Wednesday on New York's Commodity Exchange amid frantic selling prompted by a cash sale of an estimated 10 to 30 tons of the metal by Middle Eastern interests. The plunge of more than $11 an ounce shook the confidence of investors who had begun returning to the gold market aftr being burned by a similar but even steeper drop two months ago. On other commodity markets, crude oil futures fell sharply; pork futures plummeted; and grain and soybean futures were mixed. Gold futures settled $11.80 to $13.10 lower in New York, with the contract for delivery in June at $364.60 a troy ounce, the lowest settlement of a near-month contract since Oct. 13. Silver futures ended 5.3 cents to 5.7 cents lower on the Commodity Exchange with May at $5.23 a troy ounce; platinum futures settled $6.30 to $6.70 lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange with July at $498.20 a troy ounce. The large Middle Eastern sell order, which some analysts believe originated in Jidda, Saudi Arabia, coincided with the opening of the London gold market and triggered so much sympathetic selling that dealers were unable to agree on a morning price fix until nearly 2{ hours after trading began. Like the March 26 event _ which involved a sale of an estimated 94 to 125 tons _ the Middle Eastern order seemed designed to shock the market, possibly to abort a fledgling rally. Gold prices rose about $5 an ounce last week and gained more than $2 Tuesday. ``I'm not so sure it was done because they needed to sell but because they needed to drive the market,'' said John Jonat, a gold trader with Deak International Inc., a large currency and precious metal dealer. But other analysts said the sale may have been prompted by a need for cash to buy arms. Investment interest in gold has been notably slack since the March 26 collapse. But the market's recent strength appeared to again be attracting the public sector. ``Yesterday, they began to get some faith again but that shifted today _ very quickly,'' said Bette Raptopoulos, a metals analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Crude oil prices crumbled in frenzied trading on the New York Merc amid concern that continued OPEC overproduction could lead to a worldwide oil glut. Analyst Peter Beutel of Elders Futures Inc. said northwestern Europe is being flooded with crude from Iran, and the Trans-Panama pipeline has run out of storage space for crude. In addition, a report released late Tuesday by the American Petroleum Institute said crude oil stocks rose last week by a larger-than-expected 4.4 million barrels. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 11 cents to 78 cents lower with July at $18.14 a barrel; heating oil was .67 cent to 1.19 cents lower with June at 50.21 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .45 cent to .65 cent lower with June at 62.51 cents a gallon. Livestock and meat futures ended mostly lower on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Selling was centered in the hog and pork-belly pits, where some contracts plunged their permitted daily limits in line with weakness in the cash markets. Pork bellies were further pressured by the exchange's weekly report Tuesday on out-of-town stocks. The report showed an unexpected increase of 630,000 pounds of bellies in commercial freezers outside of Chicago. Live cattle futures settled .25 cent to .80 cent lower with June at 73.72 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .70 cent lower to .08 cent higher with May at 85.60 cents a pound; live hogs were .40 cent to the limit 1.5 cents lower with June at 65.70 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .85 cent to the limit 2 cents lower with July at 67.15 cents a pound. The May contract expired at 67.40 cents, off 2 cents. Wheat futures prices closed mostly lower while corn and soybeans advanced modestly on the Chicago Board of Trade amid uncertainty over future sales of U.S. grain to China and the Soviet Union. Wheat futures settled 1\ cents lower to { cent higher with July at $3.33} a bushel; corn futures were 1{ cents to 2\ cents higher with July at $2.76\ a bushel; oats were { cent to 1 cent higher with July at $1.51{ a bushel; soybeans were \ cent lower to 1\ cents higher with July at $6.08\ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Wonder Who's Willing To Loan Money To Greyhound
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound Lines Inc. is rolling, but with mounting financial problems and an unresolved strike, bankruptcy court could be the bus company's next stop. With its nearly 3-month-old drivers' strike eating up cash reserves, the company is struggling to pay bills and is about 60 days behind in most payments. It needs an immediate infusion of cash to buy back junk bonds from investors at a deep discount and reduce expenses. ``The question is: who steps up to the plate,'' said one analyst, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``Banks are very cautious. I don't think the union problems will go away. I don't think the bondholders are going to roll over and play dead.'' P. Anthony Lannie, Greyhound's executive vice president, answered Wednesday: ``There're lots of very wealthy investors that are interested in investing in small companies that they can earn a good return on. A number of those are very sophisticated about unions and the risks inherent in our particular situation.'' Lannie said the company is meeting with various investors to line up financing for the bond buyback announced Monday. Greyhound said it would purchase up to 85 percent of the face value of $225 million worth of high-yield debt at steep discounts. One of the conditions of the offer, however, was obtaining financing, plus additional working capital. Lannie said Greyhound figures it needs to borrow between $125 million and $150 million to swing the deal, although he points out that the company is committed to repurchasing only 51 percent of the bonds. Without the refinancing, the company likely will be forced to seek protection from creditors in bankruptcy court because of losses from a bus drivers' walkout that began March 2. Chairman Fred G. Currey estimates the strike will end up costing Greyhound between $75 million and $100 million. Greyhound lost $56 million in the first quarter and last week missed a $9.75 million interest payment on its most senior debt. Combined with its failure to make about $5 million in lease payments at the end of April, the company has opened the door for creditors to begin the process of forcing it into bankruptcy. Such a move could come as early as June 14, although the company says its bondholders have not indicated they will demand payment. Lannie said he believes about 70 percent of the bonds are held by investors who purchased them in secondary markets, meaning that the company's offer of 54 cents or 27.5 cents on the dollar represents a fair profit on their investments. Some analysts question whether so many of the bonds have been sold by their original investors, who are unlikely to be happy with the prices offered. Greyhound's chances are further clouded by a finding this month by an official with the National Labor Relations Board, who said the company engaged in an unfair labor practice by implementing a contract on the day the union walked out. The finding, plus the union's offer Tuesday to return to work, sets the stage for a legal battle that could end with the company being forced to rehire union drivers and pay $10 million a month in back wages. Greyhound has been operating at reduced levels since the strike, using newly hired drivers plus crossovers. Earlier this month, Currey said the strike had become irrelevant because Greyhound had enough drivers to operate. On Tuesday, Greyhound said it had reached its highest level of ridership since the strike began, as it carried 91,666 passengers, or 80 percent of the same day last year. The company is nearing the end of a two-week, half-price fare promotion that it credits for the surge in ridership. Whatever financing Greyhound ends up with will almost certainly come from a private placement with an investor demanding a lucrative return for the risk, Lannie said. ``They're going to want somewhere between 25 and 30 percent return,'' he said, ``and how they get it will be a matter for their creativity.'' He did not rule out giving up equity in the company as an enticement for new money, and most analysts expect an investor to demand equity in the company. Some suggest Currey will not be able to retain his position as chairman. ``The type of ideal would be someone who's willing to make a loan at an aggressive interest rate, but also with a big equity kicker,'' said Leigh Walzer at R.D. Smith & Co. in New York. ``No one's going to do this as a straight coupon investment.'' Greyhound already has been turned down by one equity holder _ Greyhound Dial Corp. of Phoenix, its original owner. The bus company was created three years ago when an investor group led by Currey paid Greyhound Corp. _ as it was then called _ $270 million for its bus operations. Lannie said the bus company had made a ``direct request'' to Greyhound Dial, but was turned down.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Plunges While Dollar Ends Mixed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-7, `Market watchers ... and traders' to CLARIFY that Saudi government believed to have sold gold; picks up 8th graf, `Bernard Savaiko...
DOC.TEXT: Gold prices plunged worldwide Wednesday, reaching a seven-month low in domestic trading, as reports of heavy Mideast selling brought chaos to the morning fixing session in London and triggered a sympathetic selloff in the United States. The dollar, meanwhile, ended mixed against major foreign currencies after falling slightly overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold tumbled $11.50 to settle at $364.10 a troy ounce, after losing about $11 an ounce in Europe. Gold had been as low as $360 an ounce on the exchange before rebounding somewhat. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $363.95 an ounce, down $10.55 from late Tuesday. The last time gold was near the $364 level was in October, according to William O'Neill, research director at Elders Futures Inc. Market watchers said gold's nose dive was triggered by one huge sell order from Saudi Arabia. They said the Saudis are believed to have sold between 10 tons and 30 tons of gold, and some speculated that the proceeds may be earmarked for arms purchases from Britian. The Saudis also are believed to have been responsible for a similar sharp drop in gold prices two months ago, according to analysts and traders. Bernard Savaiko, a senior metals analyst for PaineWebber Inc., said gold had been overbought in recent weeks, though, and traders were preparing for a ``correction'' of sorts. ``Because of the lack of buyers, the large sell order had a profound impact on gold prices,'' Savaiko said. The Saudi sale resulted in an order imbalance in Europe and ultimately brought chaos to the morning London fixing session. The five leading London dealers that set the fixing spent a near-record 2{ hours trying to set a price after having trouble matching demand and supply. The fixing was finally set at $363.25 a troy ounce. The fixing, often used as a guideline for traders, is an average price calculated twice a day based on market demand. ``Nobody had a chance to get out of positions,'' during the fixing, said a Zurich dealer. ``And no business was possible.'' Dealers said market sentiment was that gold eventually had to fall back after approaching the $378-an-ounce level. But as one dealer in Zurich explained, ``This decline wasn't predictable.'' Trading was more subdued in foreign exchange. Activity was diminishing with the approach of Thursday's Ascension Day holiday in continental Europe and Monday's Memorial Day Holiday in the United States. Monday also is a public holiday in Britain. Traders said technical factors were largely responsible for the dollar's movement Wednesday. In the spotlight again was the Canadian dollar, which has been under pressure in recent days. Canada's Progressive Conservative government was thrown into turmoil after a senior cabinet minister resigned amid growing doubts about the future of a constitutional reform package. The Canadian dollar did regain some strength Wednesday in Europe and New York. In Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the dollar fell 1.05 yen to a closing 151.35 yen. It traded at 150.90 yen in London, and at 151.45 yen in New York, up from 151.25 yen Tuesday. The dollar was weaker against the British pound compared to Tuesday. Sterling rose to $1.6975 from $1.6915 in London, and to $1.6940 from $1.6930 in New York. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.6760 West German marks, up from 1.67315; 1.4175 Swiss francs, down from 1.41765; 5.6400 French francs, up from 5.6300; 1,229.00 Italian lire, up from 1,228.00; and 1.18415 Canadian dollars, down from 1.18735. Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Tuesday, included: 1.6682 West German marks, down from 1.6685; 1.4065 Swiss francs, down from 1.4175; 5.6125 French francs, down from 5.6175; 1.8740 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8760; 1,223.00 Italian lire, down from 1,225.25; and 1.1855 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1907. Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion settled at $5.230 a troy ounce, down 5.3 cents from late Tuesday. Silver rose in London to $5.24 an ounce from $5.19.

DOC.HEAD: Boesky Eludes Cameras
With AM-Mulheren Trial
DOC.TEXT: When word leaked out that Ivan F. Boesky would be taking the witness stand in Manhattan's federal court, news photographers and television crews staked out the steps for a shot of the infamous stock speculator. But so far, no one has been able to get a picture because Boesky did not make an appearance outside the courthouse in two days of testimony. Although court security officials would not discuss Boesky, it was believed that he was granted the unusual right to enter and exit through an underground garage. Boesky, who began his testimony Monday, is a government witness against former friend John A. Mulheren Jr., who is being tried on securities fraud charges.

DOC.HEAD: Baker: Human Rights ``Not the Only Factor'' in China Decision
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf pvs, `Supporters of ...,' to RESTORE dropped word `cite'; SUBS penultimate graf, `The House ...,' to UPDATE with hearing rescheduled. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III, laying groundwork for the expected renewal of trade benefits to China, said Wednesday that human rights ``should not be the only factor'' in such a decision. ``The real issue is who gets hurt or who gets hit if you decide you're not going to extend it,'' Baker told a White House news conference. He said ending China's most-favored-nation status, as many in Congress are suggesting, would harm ``significant and substantial'' U.S. economic interests. Administration and congressional sources said Bush would formally announce his decision to extend the trade benefits to Beijing for one year on Thursday. Even before the announcement, the move has provoked angry outcries from congressional critics who consider Bush too accomodating toward the current regime in Beijing. Although he stopped short of actually announcing Bush's decision, Baker rattled off a list of reasons to justify extension of the preferential trade status. ``You should consider the effect of this upon the reformers in the Chinese government, people that want to take China toward more openness and toward more democratization. You ought to consider, I would think, the effect on some very significant and substantial economic interests that the United States has, the effect on Hong Kong,'' Baker said. Most-favored-nation status gives China the same trade benefits, including lowest-possible tariffs, that the United States extends to its major trading partners. Supporters of extending the most-favored-nation status frequently cite China's connection to Hong Kong. The free-market enclave on the coast of South China, now under British control, serves as a middleman between much of the trade between the United States and China. Some $8.5 billion in Hong Kong's exports to the United States each year are actually products made in China _ and would be subject to sharply higher tariffs if the trade benefits are withdrawn. At the same time, Baker cited a ``disappointing lack of progress'' on human rights since the June 4, 1989, Tiananmen Square crackdown. However, he said the administration welcomed China's ``release recently of 211 detainees, the lifting of martial law in Tibet'' and what he called ``a general indication of willingness to take steps such as that.'' But, Baker said, ``you ought not to draw that type of linkage. The real issue is who gets hurt or who gets hit if you decide that you're not going to extend it _ and what are the consquences of terminating it.'' ``That's the way you ought to look at this _ not so much what has been done in the one year period since Tiananamen. Although that's one of the factors, it should not be the only factor.'' The House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Asia postponed a hearing that had been planned for Wednesday to explore China's trade status with Richard Solomon, an assistant secretary of State. The hearing was rescheduled for Thursday afternoon. The office of subcommittee Chairman Steven Solarz, D-N.Y., said the administration asked for the postponement because they weren't ready to testify on the issue.

DOC.HEAD: Westwood One Gets Radio Rights to 1992 Summer Olympics in Spain
DOC.TEXT: English-language radio broadcast rights to the 1992 Summer Olympics in Barcelona, Spain, have been awarded to the NBC Radio Networks, a division of Westwood One Inc., it was announced Wednesday. Westwood One was awarded the rights by the NBC television network, which has exclusive English-language broadcast rights to the games and will televise them. Westwood One, the nation's second-largest radio network owner after Capital Cities-ABC Inc., paid $50 million for NBC's radio networks in 1987. NBC TV, a division of General Electric Co., also had the broadcast rights to the 1988 Summer Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, and worked closely with Westwood One, which handled radio broadcasts of those games. Terms of the latest agreement with NBC TV were not announced. The deal involved both money and joint promotions and marketing, said William J. Battison, Westwood One's president and chief financial officer. He said NBC had put the rights up for bid to other radio networks, but Westwood One had the inside track, ``largely because of the job we did in 1988.'' Westwood One's other divisions, the Westwood One Radio Networks, the Mutual Broadcasting System, The Source and Talknet, will help promote the broadcasts.

DOC.HEAD: Defective Toasters to be Replaced
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs `Toastmaster Inc. ...' with 1 graf to CORRECT word to toasting, sted tasting. Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 9,000 four-slice toasters will be replaced because a defective switch poses a fire hazard or could burn or severely shock users, the manufacturer said Wednesday. Toastmaster Inc. of Columbia, Mo., told the Consumer Product Safety Commission it will replace 8,857 of its model D126T toasters because the defective switch allows the electric heating elements to continue operating after the toasting cycle has been completed. ``There have been no reports of injuries or fires ... as a result of switch failure,'' the commission said in a written statement. The chrome-based toasters were manufactured and sold nationwide between April and June 1989. The Toastmaster name appears on a black and silver nameplate in the lower right-hand corner of each toaster. Consumers should also check the crumb tray at the bottom of the toaster for a five-letter and digit date code enumerated from EL101 to EL158. The CPSC said no other Toastmaster products were involved in the recall. Consumers may call the company at 1-800-527-3069 for instructions on returning the toasters.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Exchanges Moving Toward Electronic Trading Pact
DOC.TEXT: The Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange said Wednesday they have reached a tentative agreement to share an electronic trading system. The announcement by the world's two biggest commodity exchanges came one day after the Merc announced Japanese government approval of its proposed Globex electronic trading system. Japanese participation is perceived as the linchpin of Globex, which would allow traders to buy and sell certain financial futures even when the exchange itself is closed. Globex is a joint venture of the Merc and London-based Reuters Holdings PLC, which is supplying the computer terminals and other technology through its worldwide market-information network. The Board of Trade has been developing a separate electronic trading system called Aurora. The exchanges didn't make clear if the tentative agreement would produce a single electronic exchange or establish links between the two systems. The exchanges began talking a year ago about the possibility of offering both trading systems on the same terminals to reduce costs for the exchanges and for traders who want access to both systems. The exchanges said committees of technical and legal representatives had been formed to hammer out a formal agreement. The system could begin operating by November, they said.

DOC.HEAD: Chairman Unshaken by Rowdy Annual Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Shareholders of Pinnacle West Capital Corp. angrily called for several top officers to resign Wednesday because of last year's $551.4 million loss and the rejection of a takeover offer from another utility holding company. Some of the more than 1,000 shareholders who packed a hotel ballroom for the annual meeting also voiced anger over the company's suspension last October of quarterly stock dividends. Two of about 20 who reached microphones after the conclusion of business remembered the promise of vice president Henry B. Sargent at last year's meeting that dividends were safe. ``We have a chief financial officer who earns $300,000 a year, keeps the books and who ... is so inept that he can't do the job properly. I ask that you fire him summarily,'' shareholder Peter Ranke told new chief executive and chairman, Richard Snell. Others called for the resignations of directors Keith Turley, who retired as CEO Feb. 5, and Carl Eller, whose expansion of Circle K Corp. drove the convenience-store chain to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection May 15. Eller resigned as Circle K's chairman and CEO eight days before the filing. Turley left the room after the meeting without commenting, but Eller told reporters he had no intention of resigning. ``I have been on the board a long time, and I have contributed as much as I can,'' he said. Snell was booed and called a liar for defending the credentials of directors. One shareholder yelled out from the audience, ``Fire Snell.'' The chairman said he could not ask directors to resign because they were elected by shareholders. Formal business was completed quickly: approval of minutes, the re-election of incumbent directors and rejection of a shareholder proposal to force board members to hold at least 2,000 shares of Pinnacle West stock. The proposal received only 14 percent approval, company officers said. Jeanne Rossi of Boonville, Calif., who offered the idea, said it would instill loyalty in a board she called ``mediocre, at best.'' Snell told reporters later that he expected most of the criticism but was surprised by the sniping at Sargent, who is respected in the utility industry, and at the salaries and retirement packages of top management. ``It's easy to look at those numbers and be affronted by them, but it is almost impossible to attract the people you need without a golden parachute, and if you don't have it, the headhunters come and take them away,'' he said. Snell defended the company's rejection Tuesday of a fourth takeover offer from PacifiCorp as inadequate. The Portland, Ore.-based utility offered $21 a share or $1.82 billion, a premium of more than 25 percent of the market price. Complaints about Tuesday's rejection reflected more on the effectiveness of a $200,000 PacifiCorp advertising campaign than the offer itself, he said. In his address to shareholders, Snell acknowledged problems from a five-year expansion that saw the company acquire uranium-mining, real-estate and banking subsidiaries, but said the company was on a ``clear path'' to recovery. He noted the company recently sold a resort and is close to finishing the sale of its unprofitable Malapai Resource Co. mining subsidiary. Pinnacle West's 1986 purchase of MeraBank, the state's largest thrift, nearly proved Pinnacle West's undoing, Snell said. MeraBank lost more than $200 million in 1988 and 1989. Federal regulators took it over in January and required Pinnacle West to infuse $465 million into the thrift before cutting ties to it. Snell also acknowledged problems with the Palo Verde Nuclear Generating Station, owned by the company's chief subsidiary, Arizona Public Service Co. The three-reactor plant operated at only 24 percent of capacity last year. Snell said he plans to operate Palo Verde efficiently, raise morale at APS, contain costs and improve relations with the Arizona Corporation Commission, which regulates APS. It may be three years before dividends are restored, Snell said. However, a stronger performance should strengthen the company's stock price, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Health Secretary to Propose Restrictions on Cigarette Vending Machines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lede and deletes 4th graf to update with Sullivan expected to propose that states ban cigarette vending machines; moves up 9th graf pvs, ``On May,'' to 6th graf, rewritten to note vending machine provision. Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Health Secretary Louis Sullivan plans to ask states to ban cigarette vending machines and take other action to limit sales to youth, government sources said Wednesday. Sullivan was to present his proposal at a Senate Finance Committee hearing Thursday, said the sources, who spoke on the condition they not be identified. ``It will be a proposal for the states to review'' and decide upon, and Sullivan will not propose new federal legislation, said one source. Another source said the secretary will propose that retailers be licensed to sell cigarettes. Forty-four states and the District of Columbia prohibit the sale of cigarettes to children, but the laws are widely unenforced. On May 16, the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee approved a $110 million program aimed at encouraging states to enforce laws against the sale of cigarettes to minors, including restrictions on vending machines. The Bush administration in February called the legislation unnecessary. A study in this week's issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association estimated annual cigarette sales to youths under age 18 at 947 million packs and revenues at $1.23 billion, about 3.3 percent of all tobacco sales. Nearly 19 percent of high school seniors smoke daily _ 11 percent of them more than a half pack per day _ according to an annual survey of high school seniors by the National Institute on Drug Abuse's annual survey of high school seniors. Surveys have also shown that the vast majority of adult smokers started in their teen years. Sullivan has made anti-smoking issues one of his top priorities at the Department of Health and Human Services. In January, he took on R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. for planning to test market a cigarette aimed primarily at blacks, saying the company was promoting ``a culture of cancer.'' The next day, Reynolds canceled its plans. Then he called on professional athletes to turn away the ``blood money'' from cigarette companies that sponsor sporting events. More recently, lawmakers were wondering if Sullivan had changed his views on smoking when his assistant secretary for health, James Mason, canceled his appearance at a congressional hearing on cigarette exports, reportedly at the direction of the White House. But Sullivan said one of his top priorities remains ``to eliminate the use of the only legal substance that when used as intended causes death.'' Cigarettes, the department says, cause about 390,000 premature deaths annually from lung cancer, heart disease and other cardiovascular disorders.

DOC.HEAD: Atlanta-Based Cellular Company Going to Hungary
DOC.TEXT: Atlanta-based Contel Cellular Inc. announced it has signed a joint venture agreement with a Hungarian company to develop a cellular telephone system in that country. The joint venture with Hungaria Telekom Kft. will be named Contel Hungaria Kft. Contel will split ownership equally with private Hungarian partners within Hungaria Telekom while taking principle managerial, technical and operational responsibilities. The new company has been granted an 15-year operating concession from the Hungarian government with a five-year renewal option, Contel said in a news release Wednesday. It will be the first national cellular system in Eastern Europe and will be designed to provide service to at least 50,000 subscribers by 1993. The system will be designed to carry voice, data, facsimile and fixed cellular applications. ``Contel Hungaria Kft. will provide telephone service to a country with a tremendous demand for telecommunications service,'' said Paul Kozlowski, president and chief executive officer of Contel Cellular. ``Our cellular system will be designed to complement Hungary's existing wireline telephone network.'' Charles Wholstetter, chairman of Contel Corp., which owns 90 percent of Contel Cellular, said, ``Our Hungarian venture typifies the global view Contel takes of the cellular industry and the major role cellular telecommunications will play around the world in the future.'' Contel Cellular already participates in a venture that provides cellular service in parts of Mexico.
Eds: The vote on final passage of the bill is under way in the House. A 2nd Ld will be expedited with result.

DOC.HEAD: Midland Bank to Establish Fund of Brazilian Debt for Equity Swaps
DOC.TEXT: Britain's Midland Bank PLC is establishing a $1.5 billion fund of Brazilian bank debt to swap for equity in state companies to be privatized by the government, officials said. Wednesday's announcement by Nicholas Reade, Midland's representative in Brazil, came during a conference on privatizations organized by the British embassy in the capital. The fund, to be sponsored by several foreign banks, would be ready by July and in operation in September, Reade said. Chase Manhattan Corp. and the Bank of Tokyo are discussing becoming sponsors of the fund, and negotiations with other banks that have loans to Brazil are continuing, he said. Midland is the country's largest British creditor with about $2 billion in loans. Brazil owes about $62 billion to commercial banks worldwide and has a total foreign debt of $114 billion. Loan commitments made by the banks to the fund will be counted at the original loans' face value, but debt-for-equity trades will be negotiated, with a discounting of the debt's value expected, he said. Most of Brazil's bank debt sells for less than half its face value on the open market. The government, which has announced a wide-ranging privatization program to cut a bloated public deficit, has considered selling off most of the almost 200 state-run enterprises. These enterprises have a combined deficit of $62 billion. Reade said the idea of creating a fund to participate in the process of privatizing Brazilian state firms came about because of the volume of capital needed, which no bank could provide alone. ``We prefer to unite our resources at the start of the process, rather than create unions afterwards,'' he said. Another reason was the success of a similar fund organized by Midland in Argentina, in which 12 large creditor banks participated, he said.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Plans To Subpoena Former Thrift Chairman
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. House Banking Subcomittee voted Wednesday to subpoena David L. Paul, ousted chairman of CenTrust Savings Bank, as part of its investigation into the failure of the huge Miami thrift. The decision followed months of effort to persuade Paul to participate in its investigation into the huge thrift's failure. In March, he declined to appear at a hearing the committee held on CenTrust. Committee chairman Henry Gonzalez, D-Texas, had indicated then he would consider subpoenaing Paul if the former banker continued to refuse to appear. Wednesday's resolution doesn't set a date for his appearance. Paul's lawyer, Sanford Bohrer, told The Miami Herald he hadn't seen the resolution and had no comment on it. Paul built CenTrust into Florida's largest savings and loan. At one point, it boasted assets of $11 billion. But he was sharply criticized for lavish salaries, extravagant spending on the thrift's landmark tower in downtown Miami, and the use of $30 million in bank funds to purchase a collection of fine art. Federal regulators took CenTrust over Feb. 2, immediately dismissing Paul. Some experts say the thrift's bailout, estimated to cost $2 billion or more, will be the nation's most expensive.

DOC.HEAD: House Approves Clean Air Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs; minor editing to trim. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The House by a wide margin approved sweeping clean air legislation late Wednesday, requiring tougher pollution controls for factories, automobiles and electric power plants. The bill, the first revamping of federal air pollution controls in 13 years, now must be reconciled with a similar Senate version approved in April before going to President Bush for his signature. The final vote was 401-21. The way was cleared for House passage after daylong closed-door negotiations led to a compromise easing a requirement for alternate-fuel cars. The agreement erased the last obstacle to the bill, which had been approved by the Energy and Commerce Committee six weeks ago. While clean air legislation over the years has been one of the most contentious issues before Congress, the broad-reaching bill moved through floor action in less than two days. Most of the thorniest issues had been resolved in committee or closed-door negotations. Like the Senate version, the bill imposes tougher air pollution controls on automobiles and industry, including curbs on acid rain precursors from electric power plants and toxic industrial chemicals. The costs of the legislation to the economic has been put at more than $21.5 billion by the Bush administration when all provisions go into effect. The vote approving the compromise on alternate-fuel cars was 405-15. Under the agreement, Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., chief backer of the bill, agreed to abandon a proposal requiring automakers to build 1 million cars annually that burn fuels other than gasoline. Instead, the production of such cars would be limited to a ``pilot program'' of up to 300,000 for the Los Angeles area, which has the nation's worst smog, by 1997. Emission controls on fleet vehicles and urban buses also would be toughened for many cities with major smog problems. ``The last remaining issue has now been resolved,'' declared Rep. Norman Lent, R-N.Y., senior Republican on the Energy and Commerce Committee, on the House floor. The House has struggled months to pass the sweeping clean air bill, which will impose tougher air pollution controls on automobiles and industry, including curbs on acid rain precursors from electric power plants and toxic industrial chemicals. The costs of the legislation to the economy has been put at more than $21.5 billion by the Bush administration. The Senate passed a bill similar to the one before the House last April. Differences between the two bills have to be worked out in a conference committee of members from the House and Senate before anything is laid before the president for signing into law. Among other differences is the absence of any ``clean car'' provision in the Senate bill. Waxman's original ``clean car'' amendment would have applied to nine cities with the worst smog problem: Los Angeles, Chicago, San Diego, Milwaukee, Houston, Baltimore, Philadelphia, New York City and Hartford, Conn. Negotiations continued most of the day to find ways to accommodate Waxman, who argued that his proposal for the mandatory production of 1 million cars was little more what President Bush had suggested a year ago. The White House has since abandoned mandatory production requirements. The auto industry had vigorously fought the measure and had on their side Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., the powerful chairman of the Energy and Commerce Committee, whose district includes Ford Motor Co. headquarters. Dingell, calling the Waxman proposal ``the most contentuous issue'' faced by the House, announced the compromise on the House floor. Earlier the House by a 274-146 vote approved a $250 million financial aid package over five years to help workers who lose their jobs because of tougher air pollution controls. The job-loss relief measure came despite strong opposition from the White House as Bush administration officials argued the measure could be many times more expensive than expected. The plan would extend unemployment compensation for an additional six months and provide retraining assistance at a cost of $50 million a year for workers displaced by tighter air pollution requirements. Unlike a proposal defeated in the Senate, it would provide relief to workers in all industries and not just coal miners, but the assistance is considerably more modest, said Rep. Bob Wise, D-W.Va., sponsor of the measure. ``I think it's a matter of simple justice,'' argued Rep. Gerry Sikorski, D-Minn. The worker assistance amendment was aimed primarily at helping an estimated 5,000 coal miners who may lose their jobs to tougher acid rain provisions in the legislation. Wise, however, emphasized that the financial aid would apply to all industries. Critics of the bill have argued that there could be widespread unemployment in some industries if plants close because of tougher standards. Lent said the measure holds the environmental bill ``hostage to labor protection.'' The Bush administration is expected to push to delete the provision when differences between the House and Senate bills are negotiated later this year. White House chief of staff John Sununu and William Reilly, head of the Environmental Protection Agency, wrote House leaders that such assistance ``would create a potentially open-ended liability'' for the government because it would be impossible to determine when a worker loses employment because of clean air legislation. Meanwhile, the House put its formal approval on a series of compromise amendments: _A provision requiring cleaner gasoline blends in cities with the worst pollution. The oil industry opposed the tougher emission standards, arguing they will require use of gasoline-ethanol blends. _A requirement for the Environmental Protection Agency to develop new regional visibility regulations within two years for many national parks and wilderness areas. _A requirement that offshore oil platforms off the California coast and elsewhere outside the Gulf of Mexico adhere to federal air pollution regulations. To please oil state congressmen, platforms in the Gulf of Mexico, where most offshore oil is drilled, were exempted. _A mandatory phaseout of chemicals such as chlorofluorcarbons, or CFCs, as well as a number of substitutes. _A requirement that automakers provided expanded warranties up to eight years and 80,000 miles on pollution control devices.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Gains, Stocks Ease
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with morning Nikkei, comments
DOC.TEXT: Share prices erased their opening gains and fell modestly on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday morning while the dollar was slightly higher against the yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average lost 56.47 points, or 0.18 percent, ending the morning session at 32,120.04. The index rose 238.21 points on Wednesday. The dollar closed the morning session at 151.55 yen, up from Wednesday's close of 151.35 yen. The dollar started trading at 151.50 yen and ranged between 150.90 yen and 151.55 yen during the morning. ``The (Nikkei) index took a downturn as market players stepped off to the sidelines after buying actively in early trading,'' said Kozo Hasunuma, a trader with Yamaichi Securities Co. Investors were reluctant to buy ahead of announcements by major companies of their performance during fiscal 1989, Hasunuma added. In currency dealings, the dollar was holding above the 151-yen line after weakening slightly earlier as investors bought the yen against the West German mark, dealers said. The price of the benchmark No.119 10-year Japanese government bond rose to 87.52 from Wednesday's close of 87.38. That dropped the yield to 7.06 percent from 7.09 percent.
